column4: "The morning tide is basically, well, WATER in the MORNING."
column5: "This is not the eventide, but the water of the morning tide."

column4: The water that flows from the meadow is the source of life for the wild antelope.
column5: The source of clean water is from the meadow (#134): it comes from that spring at the bottom of the cliff. Pay no attention to Julie Andrews lying face down in spring. The water's clean. Trust me.

column4: "Conversations can become more lively after everyone has had a few drinks. It's because ""watery tongues"" loosen lips!"
column5: I'm sure I can get her pretty lively and wet using my tongue.

column4: "To extinguish a SPARK, you need WATER."
column5: You need a few drops of water to extinguish the candle.

column4: "If you ask your teenager if what he's drinking is water (and not Vodka), he will answer ""but of course""."
column5: "キョウ But of course, this character really means ""situation/condition"". ""Elder brother gulped some water and said, 'What the hell was Heisig's mental CONDITION when he came up with this definition? Heisig must have a drinking CONDITION. But of course, if Heisig sticks to water, rather than sake (like me, water quaffing, situation assessing, sober elder brother), his SITUATION may improve.'""　[MODEL COMPOUND: 状況　(じょうきょう)　state of affairs; conditions]."

column4: A river CAN exist only if there is WATER.
column5: "I kept confusing this with stream. My Japanese friend said that to him this is for an artificial river. Looking at kanji compounds with this there are two that struck me: One is the Yellow River in China (黄河), and the other is the Milky Way (銀河). Now I either think of the Little Engine that could dragging a bunch of stuff down a river in China and polluting it (so it turned yellow) or I see the Little Engine that Could flying across the sky making the Milky Way."

column3: overnight;put up at;ride at anchor;3-day stay
column4: Please supply a guest who stays overnight with WATER and WHITE sheets.
column5: "When I go to an OVERNIGHT party, all I need is a bit of water and some of that hard white. (crack). (not really, but come on. much easier to recall than white sheets)."

column4: "This is my favorite story. Simply associate the sad moment of an OLD person, standing near the WATER of the lake and looking at the MOON reflected in the lake. The created primitives themselves are put so beautifully, that you will not forget this kanji."
column5: Water reflects the old moon in the lake.

column4: A fathom is the unit you use when making rules about water's depth.
column5: You can't fathom how deep this water is. Perhaps you should use a ruler to measure it?

column4: "Remembering soil is easy. If soil is soft, you can take a walking stick and plunge it two* feet into the ground."
column5: King Arthur pulled the magical sword Excalibur out of the hardened soil to claim his place as king.

column4: "The only things that come out of my MOUTH and onto the GROUND are spit and vomit. Everything else (words, song) floats on the air."
column5: SPIT goes from my MOUTH to the GROUND.

column4: The GROUND at the base of a CLIFF must suffer from enormous pressure.
column5: "For physics people: p = F/A (p:pressure, F:Force, A:Area). Where the force is from the immensity of the cliff. The area on the cliff is covered by soil. So the equation becomes p = F/A = cliff/soil which preserves the position of the primitives."

column4: "This refers to LAND, not the STRANGE gear superheroes wear."
column5: "Cape Cod ""odd"" is a land where odd=strange things happen."

column4: "Before the Great Wall of China, there was a dirt hedge that spanned across."
column5: The HEDGE of roses growing from the castle grounds fully spanned the castle walls.

column4: Piling SOIL upon SOIL for aeons is how SQUARE JEWELS are formed deep in the earth.
column5: How would you stop someone stealing your biggest square jewel? Bury it deep in the soil under ground. Then plant ivy to mark the spot.

column4: The king used a special seal of ivy leaves glued onto his document.
column5: "A bit of ivy glued to a letter can make a lovely SEAL when in a pinch, says Martha Stewart."

column4: Try to reverse Heisig's story in this Kanji: imagine being trapped in one of those prison towers on an ivy cladcliff like in the movies. From your prison ontop the ivy clad cliff all you can see in the distant horizon is nothing but water.
column5: "From the water, I can see the ivy-clad-cliffs on the horizon."

column4: "At the Buddhist temple the monks are seated on the ground, glued there in meditation."
column5: "To be allowed to join the Buddhist temple, imagine an aspiring monk being asked to stand still in the soil for a long time in a measurement of his resolve."

column4: "When the SUN starts to shine on the TEMPLE, it's time to get up."
column5: "In ancient Japan, TIME of ''day'' was announced at the ''buddhist temples''. They did this by ringing large iron bells. This is similar to churches who ring their bells to announce the time of day."

column4: Soil is scooped up into a ladel. The extra drop is brushed off to make it level.
column5: "To remember the extra stroke in the ladle, make a vivid image of a big drop of excess soil fr0m the ladle falling out onto the ground when you level it."

column4: "For some reason, this kanji reminds me of a person running, her arms (the two drops) raised up, because she caught on fire!"
column5: A tepee getting shot at by fire arrows.

column4: To fight fire with fire would just inflame a situation.
column5: An inflammation can often feel like FIRE upon FIRE burning.

column4: An anxiety feels like FIRE in the HEAD.
column5: "Many performers get ""Michael Jackson anxiety"" wherein they fear their head will catch on fire."

column4: "Drink water and burn twice as many calories as you eat... you'll definitely get thin. Imagine inside your body, all those calories literally being burned from above and below... THAT's what it takes to become thin."
column5: Thin girls are twice as hot when they're wet.

column4: Imagine old gas lamps which had a flame to light up the street signs.
column5: A lamp is fire you can hang from a nail.

column4: Many farms are created by first setting FIRE over the land to clear the land for the FIELDS.
column5: "When creating a farm, the prospective farmer must first set fire to the forest to clear the ground. Only then can he plow the fields. Fire before fields to make a farm."

column4: "What a disaster! First a FIRE, then on top of it came FLOODs."
column5: "Don't know about Japan, but here in Australia, flooding rivers and bushfires are the most common natural disasters."

column4: The fire underneath the cliff will eventually turn everything above to ashes.
column5: "Scene from ""The Big Lebowski"" : Walter scatters Donny's ashes, but a wind blows much of the ashes into ""The Dude"" Lebowski's face. Upset, The Dude lashes out at Walter. Walter apologizes and hugs The Dude, before suggesting ""Fuck it, man. Let's go bowling."" I bet you that The Dude wanted to cremate (fire) Walter right there and then, at the top of the cliff! (thanks Elktapestry)."

column4: The FORTUNE TELLER was burned by FLAMES on the spot because she was accused of being a witch.
column5: You have to stimulate the G-spot with your magic wand in order to get her on fire. Or you can juste use your mouth...

column4: SHINING FLAMES illuminate!
column5: "The sun was seduced to give us fire, by which we illuminate the night."

column4: "The elements of this kanji are bound up, rice field and cooking fire. When I think of bound up cooked rice, it makes me think of sushi, which in turn brings to mind fish."
column5: Bind that FISH and cook his brains! Yarhh!

column4: You need WATER and FISH for fishing.
column5: "If you are confusing this with angling like me, take fishing to mean not the act of catching a fish but the act of being a fish not living but fishing (i.e. in the water)."

column4: The ri is a Japanese way of measuring the area of the GROUND underneath a RICE FIELD.
column5: "Hint: Heisig makes here a severe disservice to everyone by using a weird keyword for this character. You'll save a lot (and I mean, a whole lot) of trouble later by giving it instead its intended meaning: House of the Parents."

column4: "If you burn the GROUND of a RICE FIELD with FIRE, eventually it will turn black."
column5: "If your parent's home catches on fire, it will turn black."

column4: Theres BLACK on the GROUND...most likely someone spilt some black ink.
column5: Anyone who has worked with laserjet ink cartridges will know the black ink looks like powdered dirt.

column4: Japanese carp are massive fish - they are measured in ri!
column5: The fish got carpal tunnel syndrome from the computer(I know it's lame but it's hard to find a good story for this).

column4: "I did such a quantity of work that when NIGHT BREAK came, I was asleep on the COMPUTER."
column5: "If you find that by nightbreak, you're still playing at your computer, chances are your World of Warcraft character has a high quantity of levels. [thanks to ssmoler] ..... To remember that nightbreak appears ABOVE computer, think of looking UP from your computer at the window to realize you've been playing until nightbreak."

column4: "I threw my Rindows computer off a cliff because it kept crashing. Now, after its last crash, it's worth less than a rin."
column5: A computer dropped off of a cliff would be worth about 1 RIN.

column4: "You can't bury computers underground, because of the dangerous heavy metals, so you hide them behind an equally large mound of soil and hope no-one notices."
column5: I used SOIL to BURY my COMPUTER.

column4: "Muslim women wearing veils (HOOD) all look the same, you can just see ONE MOUTH and very little else."
column5: Imagine monks wandering around the monastery. Covered in their hoods and chanting as if with one mouth they all look the same !

column4: All the animals in the den share the same water.
column5: """Den"" and ""cave"" also make me think of a monk's cell. Monks take vows of silence and fast. So a den is where you'd find nothing but water (to drink) and a monk."

column4: "A trunk, a trunk // The body of a monk // The body of a monk in a trunk, a trunk."
column5: "Dead flesh all looks the same when you chop off everything but the trunk. Yes, I'm appalled at how gruesome this story is too."

column4: Look over yonder ! That tiny dot is robin hood at the mouth of his secret cave !
column5: "There was an old woman named Wanda,// Who wanted to make herself blonder.// She covered her くち// With a glass hood from Gucci// And dropped some hair dye on from yonder."

column4: An especially esteemed alien has three antennae on his helmet.
column5: "Remember that scene from Star Wars, where Luke is wearing that helmet that only his mouth could see, and was swinging at that little thing buzzing around the room? That was Obi-Wan's trick to get Luke to build his self-esteem, or his confidence in the Force."

column4: CHILDren learn Kanji characters underneath a HOUSE.
column5: """Why do I have to wear this roof on my head all the time father?"" ""Shut up! It builds character!""."

column4: "A GUARD is usually ""glued"" to the house he watches."
column5: A guard provides a measure of security to those under a roof.

column4: Make the perfect impression in the beginning by removing your shoes upon entering a Japanese home.
column5: "In the beginning, Adam and Eve had a home in Eden. It was perfect."

column4: You can proclaim your opinions from the comfort of your HOUSE and have it SPAN the entire globe these days via The Internet.
column5: I heard young Muslims have to memorise the Koran and proclaim it aloud as a kind of rite of passage. Imagine the SPAN of hours spent under a ROOF practising that! It must surely be worse than trying to get through Heisigs RTK - count yourself lucky.

column4: I burn the CANDLE in my HOUSE until the WEE HOURS reviewing the kanji!!!
column5: "I agree with elktapestry. This kanji really means ""early evening"", not ""wee hours"" [Heisig really should have done his homework on this and several other characters (e.g., #145 ""but of course"" -- what the hell???). Oh well.] ""Every house lights candles in the EARLY EVENING which stay lit until the wee hours"". E.G. 宵の口（よいのくち）early evening; 今宵（こよい）this evening; tonight."

column4: "It's funny, Hesig gives no Kanji in his book that means cheap/inexpensive... well... if you were wondering what Kanji would carry that meaning, look no further. Sometimes I wonder if Hesig just thinks our little brains would be too easily confused by multiple meanings. Regardless, think of that woman relaxing. Cheapest place to do that is in one's own home rather than at some fancy resort, eh? 家で休暇を取るは安いですね。."
column5: "You can only relax, when you have woman under roof to do all chores."

column4: The WOMAN spent all DAY preparing a banquet in the HOUSE.
column5: "Under the roof, all day long, the woman prepared for the banquet (this wording helps me remember the order of this kanji's elements)."

column4: "The strange house has a sign saying ""DRAW NEAR"" in its window, instead of a 'Beware' sign. It must be a trick!"
column5: Imagine a horror movie set in a haunted mansion. The house is very strange. The characters draw near to one another for protection against the unknown.

column4: Remember Ducktales? That rich duck had that room in his house where he kept all the wealth! He had so much in that house you could even swim in it!
column5: "In ancient Japan, a RICE FIELD is a unit of wealth as it can produce enough to feed all the MOUTHs in ONE HOUSE."

column4: It takes a lot more than one clam of savings to buy a house on a street.
column5: "My SAVINGS plan - I nail my moneybags up in the rafters below my roof. I'm very secretive about it, and I wear a disguise with a big mustache (another meaning of this kanji) while I stash my loot."

column4: "If you need a story for a tree, then you need to be hit by one."
column5: Pictograph of a tree.

column4: A grove has at least two TREEs.
column5: Two tree huggers saying that protecting the environment is grovey man...　RTK2:　リン　森林　しんりん(woods and forests).

column4: "The higher you go up a mountain the less trees there are, that's so u dont mess up with their possition like i do."
column5: Another tree planted within a grove turns it into a FOREST.

column4: "Simple mnemonic : ""The Japanese Judas-tree is the tree on which Judas hang himself to the ivy"" (Judas the traitor of the Christian bible). Just picture Judas hanging himself, using ivy as a if it was a rope."
column5: "A tree covered in poison ivy will quickly betray you, thus the name JAPANESE JUDAS-TREE."

column4: "The wood from oak trees can be used to make barrels in which white wine is aged. What's more, I love white wine with an oaky flavour..."
column5: "An oak tree is white, from left to right!"

column4: wood at 90 (9 * 10) degrees.
column5: Nine out of ten picture frames are made out of wood. The rest are made of metal or plastic.

column4: "At Christmas time, on the treetops, people used to place great big candles (Now we usually place a star instead)."
column5: "If you cut off the treetops, they still resemble the trees they used to be part of. Treetops=tree resemblance."

column4: A shelf is a wooden companion to books.
column5: "I think of an Otaku, with a wooden shelf full of anime action figure statures, who are sadly his only companions."

column4: From the tree straight into the mouth is the best way to eat an APRICOT!
column5: Imagine Totoro sleeping under his tree. As he snores a giant apricot falls nicely into his open mouth and he emits a giant burp of satisfaction. I can hear that music alreay....to - to to - to - ro...

column4: "In Japan, a paulownia (きり）is known as the ""princess tree"". It was once a traditional TREE planted at the SAME time as the birth of a daughter. It would grow fast enough that, at the time of her wedding, it could be used to make a dresser as a wedding present for her."
column5: Paulownia is a Japanese tree which looks same as any other tree.

column4: Plants don't become trees straightaway.
column5: "When you plant plants, you use a piece of WOOD to make the plant grow STRAIGHT."

column4: A tree withers away as it gets old.
column5: "When flowers get old they suffer (frame 225), but old trees just WITHER away painlessly. (Picture flowers crying in pain, but a dried up tree silent and sad)."

column4: Wooden wands are the crudest. They are nothng compared to their carbon fibre equivilents.
column5: "A beginner magician starts with a crude wooden magic wand. Later he'll upgrade to magicite, of course."

column4: "If you've ever played an old 8 bit or 16 bit RPG, like Dragon Warrior or Final Fantasy or Inindou, you'll remember that every town was all bordered off by a line of trees with no space in between to get out through. Imagine that the trees were glued together so you could only exit town through the main or side gates, (so you couldn't escape the important scripted scenes.)."
column5: "Pfft. At it's core, a town is just a bunch of wood glued together. Edit - Stop starring this piece of crap story! xD."

column4: The prime minister is having inter-course behind that tree! All you can see are his eyes poking out from the righthand-side of the tree.
column5: "ソウ/ショウ/あ INTER /MUTUAL /ASPECT /PHASE /MINISTER. ""Long ago, before there were telephones, people living far from one another would climb trees to eye each other's aspects and inter-act for their mutual benefit. Those who did this best became government ministers, with the top person (perhaps the one with the longest neck (首, neck (#70)) becoming the prime minister 「首相 (しゅしょう)""."

column4: "My wooden desk is so messy, it looks like a strong wind blew my things all over it."
column5: "Whenever I'm alone at my computer desk, I'm always getting wood and breaking wind."

column4: The origin of a book is paper made out of TREEs. ONE tree can make many books.
column5: An axe cutting a tree to make books.

column4: Botanists like to identify TREEs by HOOKing tags on them.
column5: "Might be good to note that this is also the Kanji for ""Paper Money"" w/ the reading さつ (千円札＝1000 Yen paper bill)... It also takes on the meaning of Playing Card with the reading of ふだ as in 花札 (Hanafuda cards) or トランプの札 (""trump"" playing cards). For the tag meaning I like to think of wooden tags hung on hooks from trees... but for these other meanings I like to think of both paper money and playing cards as paper (tree) products with the ability to ""hook you in"" so to speak."

column4: "Years-Months-Days: It takes many years for a cliff to form or erode. A tree takes many months to grow. But days pass by regularly - so in this way, we see the movement of time such as with a CALENDAR."
column5: "This is just a picture of a wall calendar with a page for each month. The bottom half has the grid of days, the top half has a pretty picture of a forest this month. The cliff radical here is the top and left edges of the paper. You can see the paper curling up at the lower left where a breeze is trying to turn the page."

column4: I plan to RELAX on top of that TREE.
column5: "If you bring a woman to your house, generally its not a good plan to stick your wood up her bottom, she may scream in pain あん!"

column4: "Tip: goods + wood/tree : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest ""furniture"" (a common type of wooden goods). REF: parch (FRAME 215) , maneuver (#671), winding (#1369), seaweed (#2035). Story: It's been so parched recently that your furniture suddenly catches fire."
column5: The parchment says you need fire to make goods from trees.

column4: I believe a better version of that by mameha1977: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) does not yet (未) have exremities (末) of vermilion (朱).
column5: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) is not yet (末) vermilion (朱).

column4: "The tree has reached the extremity of its growth and no longer produces small, new branches at the top. Instead the existing top branch just grows longer and longer."
column5: "There are no great stories for this one yet, and I always forget it.. So, let's try something ridiculous: The man lived by himself in the wilderness, with no females within miles. So, his only way of relief was to stick his extremity into a small hole in a tree.. The poor guy. Which horizontal stroke is the extremity? The longer one or the shorter one? That, my friends, is up to your own imaginations. I'd prefer not to dwell on that point, myself. ;)."

column4: The extremity of a wave of water is the splash.
column5: A splash is WATER that has reached its EXTREMITY.

column4: My mouth has not yet swallowed the food because the flavor is so delicious that I keep chewing it.
column5: "To enjoy a food's FLAVOR, it must be in one's MOUTH but NOT YET swallowed."

column4: My younger sister is NOT YET a fully grown WOMAN.
column5: Is your younger sister a woman? Not yet! Damn!

column4: It's autumn: only one vermilion leaf on the tree has not yet fallen.
column5: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) is not yet (未)[correction wrong character before] vermilion (朱).

column4: "Which tree would you buy stocks in - the healthy one on the left, or the one with only one vermilion leaf left on the right?"
column5: "Ideally, one buys stocks when a company is young, ""green,"" and rapidly growing -- then sells them just before the last vermillion leaf falls off, and a period of dormancy or limited growth begins."

column4: The young little girl held a cute flower in her right hand.
column5: "In Hawaii, if you wear a flower over your left ear, it means you are taken. A flower over the right means you are not. The younger you are, the more likely you are to have a flower over your right ear…　　　　　　RTK2: 　ニャク　老若　ろうにゃく (young and old)　　　　　　　　　　　　　　 ジャク　若干　じゃっかん(few)."

column4: Grass grows in earlier than flowers.
column5: This grass is very long. The only flowers you can see are sunflowers – the rest are hidden by the grass.

column4: Flowers for the old man suffering in the hospital.
column5: The derivates from opium poppies such as morphine can be used to tame the suffering of the old.

column4: A tolerant person will ignore SEEing GRASS (marijuana) in the HOUSE of a friend.
column5: "To be tolerant is to see flowers (meaning ""beautiful things"") in every house, instead of looking for drawbacks."

column4: A Dr. missing his needle can only use dilute flower water for medicine.
column5: "Note This character belongs to a set of characters which share the flower/water primitive such as:: dilute (#227), fall (#299), clan (#1912), and seaweed (#2035).... (落 薄 藩 藻) It may be helpful to create a primitive keyword for this occurrence (like seaweed or watering can) which can save a lot of time distinguishing them from characters like Sino 満 and Full 満, where the water primitive is larger than the flower primitive."

column4: "On top of the leaves a flower appears, promising new generations for the old tree below."
column5: The flower generation spent far too much time up trees trying to smoke leaves.

column4: "If I find out this furniture you're selling me is made of imitation wood, I'll put you in the graveyard."
column5: "The Japanese are so enamored of everything plastic, they even put IMITATION plastic trees in their graveyards! (No, not really, but I wouldn't be surprised)."

column4: The precise locations of sailors who meet a WATERY GRAVE are vague.
column5: "The water in the graveyard has worn away the headstones, so the writing is vague."

column4: The soil under a graveyard is full of graves.
column5: A grave is a patch of soil in a graveyard.

column4: He made a livelihood out of robbing GRAVEYARDS in broad DAYlight.
column5: "The gravedigger makes his LIVELIHOOD digging in the graveyard all day For graveyard, imagine an idyllic picture: beautiful grass with the sun shining down...and a dog peeing on one of the graves. Don't confuse with occupation (#1034). Hold onto the irony of making your LIVElyhood from tending dead people."

column4: "In the moonlight of the graveyard I hear a zombie say, MMMMM..EMM...BRANEsssss."
column5: The membranes in your flesh rot when placed in the graveyard.

column4: If you plant seedlings in a FIELD eventually they will FLOWER.

column4: When your wife's LEGs get huge hairs on them it is surely a bad portent for things to come.
column5: A bad portent makes the hairs on your legs stand.

column4: The pits of a peach tree look like turtles.
column5: King Koopa consistently captures Princess Peach. Eventually he's going to run out of castles and just set her in a tree.

column4: Sauron's One fiery eye stare at Frodo and it is a sign of portent. Evil will become whomever the eye is staring upon.
column5: "You lost a staring contest with a turtle because you blinked your eye before he did. (The contest wasn't fair, because turtles have nictitating membranes, and don't need to blink so often.) Eye comes first, because stare is most associated with eyes. And compare with challenge (#658) where this same obstreperous turtle challenges you to a finger wrestling contest. (Sibyl's story with some notes that helped me)."

column4: "A large dog, dripping drool."
column5: "If we remember large (#107) as a man with his arms outstretched, the drop represents man's best friend - a dog."

column4: It was left to the turtle to make right with the dog and thus maintain the status quo..

Visualize the hotdog curling as it cooks, to remember the unusual way the flesh primitive curves in this kanji. (tweaked version of ziggr's. Thanks!)."
column5: "There are all sorts of things in hot dogs. (I use hot dog for this primitive (meat of a dog over a cooking fire). I swear I can actually see the 月 here as a hot dog, with its slight curve and grill marks.)."

column4: REEDS are the only FLOWERS that WILD DOGS like to FIRE up and smoke while they are playing poker.

column4: The cat hid in the FLOWERS of the FIELD from the WILD DOGs.

column5: "The Church Lady is traveling through Japan and notices with distaste a sacred cow relieving itself inside a Buddhist Temple. ""Well, isn't that special""."

column4: "The revelation makes the cow's mouth drop down, ""Hamburgers are made of what?!""."
column5: "When you get a revelation, you may drop to the ground with your mouth wide open."
