column4: "In Japan, you always wash with water from the shower before you enter the bathtub."
column5: You wash things with WATER to get them back to the clean state they were in BEFORE.

column4: "The two strokes at the bottom look like a J and I, which stands for ""jammed in.""."
column5: Two people jammed in under an umbrella. A woman with a dress and a man (straight). It's always me that ends up getting wet.... but the tail of the skirt is this time!

column4: One Japanese farmer I know is so small minded that he thinks the entire world is JAMMED IN the borders of his little RICE FIELD.
column5: A famous philosopher once said that his world consisted of all the things he could jam into his brain.

column4: "Some people think drinking tea is boring and quaint. That's why I spice mine up by adding a cocktail umbrella, which of course is made from a wood-en toothpick supporting a paper umbrella with flowers printed on top."
column5: "When I drink herbal tea I like to drink it under a parasol. If it's too hot I go ""ho, ho, ho !!"" (katakana ホ)."

column4: "I wouldn't mind a meeting of mouths with her, she's really fit !"
column5: He had such a big mouth that he could easily fit one whole umbrella in it.

column4: In order to build a pagoda in this small Japanese garden everything has to fit: the soil to the left and the flowers in the upper right corner.
column5: "Pictograph-o-rama. This is a corner of a Japanese garden, with a small mound of soil on the left, and a little concrete pagoda in the front with flowers behind it. (To my eye, the fit looks a lot like a little pagoda anyway. This may or may not cause confusion for you, though...)."

column4: To be king you have to be a real crafty one !
column5: The king unites heaven and earth. (imagine heaven being the top line over the soil).

column4: The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...
column5: "The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...and he hangs left! (I always screw up the direction of the ""drop"")."

column4: On treasure island is a single house - where all the jewels are stored.
column5: "Put a ""roof"" (lid) on your jewels and voila! You've got a treasure chest."

column4: The king of the Oysters produces special Vermillion pearls!
column5: King Vermillion is a little queer and likes to wear pearl necklaces.

column4: The KING ... can SEE clearly the PRESENT state of affairs in the land. (maybe he hees them in the crystal ball on the left?).
column5: "Hey, I want my money back! This crystal ball is out of order, I can see the present instead of the future!"

column4: Oh no ! A pack of dogs has bitten the king. He has turned into a rabid lunatic !
column5: "Think of King Nebuchadnezzar, who for 7 years lost his sanity and had to live like a wild animal."

column4: "Ancient Rome had Emperors instead of Kings, and they wore white robes. Thus an emperor is a king in white. (make sure you picture a roman emperor not a japanese one and you'll be ok)."
column5: The white dove descended on the king and he was promoted to emperor.

column4: The mouth of the king is displaying his bling.
column5: "What a pathetic display! The king is sprawled on his throne, head back and mouth wide open, fast asleep. We should never have let him drink so much at that banquet last night."

column4: "The fat king hogs the whole space under his umbrella. (tweaked version of radical tyro's story. ""fat"" makes a more vivid image for me.)."
column5: The king takes up the whole space under his umbrella.

column4: "The fat king under his umbrella offers useless advice to the workers. ""You'll need the whole tree to plug that gap"". Imagine a grossly fat, incompetent king under a parasol giving annoying advice to sweating workers who know what they're doing. (I always have trouble bringing up the ""whole"" primitive. This story reminds me how to build that part. )."
column5: "To plug the hole, you need to use a whole piece of wood - like a cork or something."

column4: The king of LOGIC is the computer.
column5: Computers are ruled by logic (it is the king of computers).

column4: A lord is a little drop down from King in hierarchy.
column5: "Although this kanji's meaning hasn't caused me much trouble, I've had problems remembering the direction of the drop above king, since drops at tops of kanji often seem to appear in different directions. To remember this one, I think of the placement of the drop in jewel (#256). Both of them use the king primitive and include a short drop stroke going from the top left to bottom right."

column4: Visualize an idiot trying to figure out how to extinguish a candle. He sees a glass of WATER and decides to pour it onto the CANDLESTICK to put it out. Water spills everywhere.
column5: Like water the hot wax poured down the side of the candlestick.

column4: The main pillar in a house should be made of the biggest and strongest tree - the lord of the trees.
column5: """Why has this pillar been carved in the shape of a giant penis?!"" ""You said that 'it should be made of wood', My Lord.""."

column4: The fat king taking up the whole space under the umbrella actually isn't fat - he just has two big gold bars hidden under his clothes.
column5: "Under the umbrella's shade, the king sang, "" Drop it to the left, drop it to the right, give me all the GOLD in sight!""."

column4: "Pig iron is basic/crude metal, that is, before it has been processed."
column5: "Pig-iron is crude metal (金) before (先) it is refined. If you have trouble with this character, envision a big minotaur (cow head with human legs) as a blacksmith, smelting metals and making swords for war."

column4: "This is the BOWL of an alchemist: see how he mixes metals in his bowl, as he follows the instructions from his book?"
column5: "If I was begging with a BOWL, I would want GOLD and BOOKS."

column4: "I can't believe no one has used this one yet: Copper is metal which looks almost the same as gold. Really, look it up on Wikipedia, it's yellow and it's shiny (atleast in some compounds)!"
column5: "Copper is an excellent conductor. In other words, it's a metal for which the voltage is the same everywhere. That's why it's used for wires."

column4: All the people that go to the Japanese festivals to catch fish part time are suckers. Me? I'm a pro. I bring a big-ass golden ladle. I'm a true ANGLING professional.
column5: Imagine an effeminate Roman 2000 years ago angling with a golden ladle instead of a rod because it matches his eyes and hair better and it impresses the boys. (Why a Roman? Because 'angling' is just the roman-derived way to say 'fishing' - use this to distinguish fishing from angling.).

column4: Remember the story of the needle in the haystack. Why would someone even look for a needle if it wasn't a GOLD NEEDLE?
column5: A golden needle is worth ten times more than an ordinary needle.

column4: "A piece of metal with a name on it. Well, this is basically the definition of inscription."
column5: I imagine ancient Egyptian inscriptions: Pharaohs' names written in gold.

column4: Tranquilize - using a metal syringe to get the truth.
column5: Enough gold can tranquilize the truth in anyone.

column4: "When we go out on the ROAD-WAY, we often risk our own necks (that's why I take the train! )."
column5: "Watch as a villianous fiend stretches a poor damsel's neck over a dusty road. Her ear pressed to the ground, she can hear the rumble of a carriage thundering down the roadway. Will the hero save her in time? Or will her neck be ground into the road, spilling it's precious contents into the dust?"

column4: "For guidance on the road-way, glue a GPS unit to your car."
column5: Good guidance will help you stay glued to the right path.

column4: Cross-road.
column5: "This kanji appears in the remarkable compound, 辻斬り 【つじぎり】 (n): killing a passerby in order to test a new sword. Imagine a cross by the road, at a busy crossing, marking the spot of the unfortunate passerby's death."

column4: The car went too swiftly through the crossing and was hooked by the cops.
column5: "In the Heisig version of Frogger, you can image ten giant fish hooks sweeping across the road, with our hapless hero 'froggy' forced to make a swift crossing or end up as fish bait."

column4: A cow creates a road by eating all the grass on its path.
column5: CREATION is the ROAD to REVELATION (if you're feeling artsy) :).

column4: "When you have the URGE to go to White Castle, you know it's time to hit the road."
column5: "When you start down the road of cocaine, you're sure to feel some pretty bad URGEs soon."

column4: "I used my pants to make a rope, which I then used to escape from prison; hence the naked, hairy legs running along the road!"
column5: A turtle version of frogger dodging cars to escape to the other side of the road...　　　RTK2:　トウ　逃走　とうそう(escape)...　　　　　　　MIXED GROUP:　桃236　(ﾁｮｳ): 兆235　眺237　挑658　跳1284.

column4: "Caution: this kanji doesn't mean environment; it means ""environs; boundary; border; vicinity"". To separate the environs, create the border by placing daggers on the road."
column5: "To protect the environs around their village, samurai would travel the roads with their swords."

column4: The cops don't PATROL anymore - they just flood the road.
column5: The Venice cops patrol on river roads.

column4: My car is so fast it can go through ten rice fields in ten minutes.
column5: "Rather than hobbling along with a walking stick to cross through a span, it's much better to use a car. (Imagine an old man with a walking stick creeping along a span of road, and you, in a car, whizzing right by him. It's funny 'cause it's true.) Also, it's important to include the word ""through,"" so you know the walking stick goes right THROUGH the span."

column4: When you put your car on the road you should always take along a few friends. Don't confuse with carry (#303).
column5: "This kanji also means ""linked"" or ""series"" so I've changed the kanji meaning to ""GO ALONG (WITH EACH OTHER)."" Well, a ROAD and a CAR certainly GO ALONG with each other. And the CAR will help you to GO ALONG the ROAD. This Kanji is the ""Union"" in Soviet Union and the ""United"" of United Nations (the countries that ""go along with each other"" at least some of the time)."

column4: My car got so stuck in a rut it required nine people pushing to get it out again.
column5: I got my car stuck in a rut ! I'm gonna have to call 999 !

column4: "The car is a cattle-car, used to transport animals for the butcher's meeting - a convention on new butchering techniques. Hear the screams of the animals as it pulls up in front of the convention hall, where the butchers are waiting with their knives out front."
column5: The vehicle transports animals for a meeting with the butcher.

column4: When I get horny my flesh sword sticks out in front of me.
column5: "If you stand in front of a bull's horns, you are asking for your flesh to be cut (or butchered if you prefer)."

column4: "Son, I've never told you this but each woman has a second mouth between their fiiiiiine walking legs."
column5: Each and every one of us walks and talks differently.

column4: """Ranger! I want you to go check the status of each tree."" ""Errr, Each tree sir?"" replies the ranger looking out over the vast forest. ""That's Right, I want the status of each tree! Move out!""."
column5: A man measures his own status by the size of his woody...and compares it to each one he sees.

column4: There are so many abbreviations and acronyms nowadays that no brain can remember each of them. Mnemonic: ab-brain-each-ation.
column5: A very anal farmer wants to catologue each grain of rice in his rice field. Imagine him scribbling a tiny abbreviation of his name and a number on each grain.

column4: Each person under my roof is treated as a guest.
column5: In my house I welcome each guest.

column4: Sign the guestbook page with your forehead. (Picture a guestbook full of forehead prints like thumbprints).
column5: "In New Zealand, people welcome guests by touching their foreheads together."

column4: In SUMMER you are hot from the top of your head down to your walking legs.
column5: "I personally think it was too confusing to try and use head as the primitive. (How am I supposed to remember that the animal legs are replaced with walking legs instead of human legs?) Rather, I think have the image of a hot summer and you want to keep oneself under a ceiling not out jogging around."

column4: The best way to dispose of a nasty bit of wind is to let it go and use those walking legs to dissapear. Nobody will ever know it was you.
column5: To dispose of rubbish you should walk it to the bin not throw it to the wind.

column4: They all say they have a TREE between their WALKING LEGS but most only have a TWIG.
column5: "Don't confuse with branch or bough - think of snapping twigs. A twig is always the kind of wood that snaps when the hunter's walking legs just barely touch it, making a snapping sound that alerts the prey to the hunter's presence."

column4: Water each flower or the petals will wither and fall.
column5: "[It's been suggested on the forum (http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=1079) that flower across the full width of the kanji and water on the left below it should have its own keyword; seaweed is a popular choice. See also dilute (#227), clan (#1912), seaweed (#2035). This story is for the benefit of those using that idea.] Picture a group of Japanese skydivers falling through the sky -- suddenly each one opens, instead of a parachute, an enormous sheet of nori seaweed to carry them safely down."

column4: "The king's crown was blown off by the wind. ""Oh well,"" he said, ""it's just a superfluous symbol.""."
column5: "The court jester wears a crown and is full of wind with bad jokes. He is superfluous to the King's court. This kanji is read as ""JOU"" and commonly used to create the compound for jou-dan 冗談 (jest or joke) hence court jester. Also jou-go 冗語 (redundancy) and jou-in 冗員 (useless workers) 員-employee (#56)."

column4: British army cars are at the service of the crown.
column5: Imagine a crown is the hood ornament on every army car.

column4: Rays of light emitted from Apollo's chariot = radiance. Don't put the sun into this kanji. The rays are coming from the chariot directly!
column5: Radiance is an army of rays.

column4: "Don’t confuse it with “take along” (287). In that one, there was a car so you could take along your friends once you found them on the road. In this one, there is an army chariot just to carry military supplies (sorry no room for you)."
column5: Roads carry armies (in contrast to seas carrying navies or skies carrying air forces).

column4: "Remember the SUPERFLUOUS CROWN that flew away in the WIND? Well now the king is saying ""i should have had the thing GLUED to my head from the BEGINNING""."
column5: "A crown, from the beginning of the new king's life, is glued to him. He must inherit it."

column4: Last night's date with Miss Sweden was like a dream. She even laid flowers over my eyes to crown the perfect evening.
column5: "In the movie American Beauty, Kevin Spacey liked to DREAM about his daughter's friend and have a rose petal fall onto his eye from the ceiling. He did this lying in his bed each evening. You can almost see him lying in his bed in this kanji."

column4: A whirlwind digs a hole in the ground throwing out lots of dirt until it ends up with a giant pit.
column5: Tazmanian Devil whirlwinds a pit into the soil. Note: Take care difference between pit and rut.

column4: "Two little aliens in a trenchcoat and top hat, trying to look TALL. The bottom one, in the glass helmet, is under the coat. The top one has his top hat pulled down in disguise, so all you can see is his mouth."
column5: Here we have TWO MOUTHS each wearing a different hat. The top one is wearing a TOP HAT which is know to be as a TALL hat. The bottom one is wearing a SPACE HELMET which is known as an EXPENSIVE hat. (this kanji means both).

column4: "In basketball however, tall children receive all the attention."
column5: Tall children receive all the attention. They also make great receivers in football... this kanji also means 'catch' (therefore a football receiver is a great image).

column4: Welcome to our cram school: you will receive a rounded education on our grounds.
column5: """You can receive a well-rounded education if you study at our cram school"" says the advertisement. ""Just come to our school grounds and check it out yourself!""."

column4: Imagine tall children sitting round the fire toasting marsh-mellows.
column5: "The cram school (309) tortures its students - especially the tall and fat ones who need to grow up - over a fire until they mellow. (Note that here the keyword 'mellow' only means to mature, ripen, or acquire skill; not the colloquial meaning of 'chill out')."

column4: The Pavillion on crown street is the tallest I have ever seen.
column5: The tallest Pavilion crowns the street.

column4: "Tokyo, capital of Japan: tall buildings, small people (compared to the buildings)."
column5: "The capital is where the powerful act formal wearing top hats, open their mouths, and get little done."

column4: "When you're a tourist in the capital during the heat of summer, finding a water fountain is oh, so refreshing."
column5: "The water from the capital of Japan, Tokyo, is so refreshing!"

column4: Imaging the sun rising over the capital--classic postcard scenery.
column5: "Anyone who's been to Kyoto doesn't need to think too deeply into this Kanji! Imagine a sunny day in the old capital, and there's no better scenery."

column4: "If fish were cities, the whale would surely be the capital."
column5: When the whale was first discovered it was the biggest fish people had ever seen. Stories exaggerated its size - people said it was as big as the entire capital city!

column4: The cottage is so small - it has an umbrella for the roof; soil for the floor and room for only one mouth.
column5: My vacation cottage is nothing but a hole in the ground covered by an umbrella.

column4: "If my LIDDED CROCK has the same CIRCUMFERENCE as my head, I like to use it as a HELMET."
column5: You're at a motorcycle store looking to buy a helmet. The only way to check the circumference of your head is to put increasingly larger lidded crocks on your head until one slips on just right. Now you know what size helmet to buy.

column4: Imagine a road built so well that it takes only a week to travel the circumference of the earth.
column5: "Actually the week is like a never ending road where we travel in a circle through the same seven days again and again, the circumference is always the same. circumference (#317) also means circuit or lap, so that also makes think about the rotations of the moon, sun and the earth -- all important for measuring all kinds of time periods."

column4: "What a handsome gentleman. Standing up so straight, and broad shoulders too!! He's like a modern samurai!"
column5: A gentleman has broad shoulders and doesn't soil himself.

column4: The samurai's wife gives him a (uhum) before battle for good luck.
column5: "A true samurai gentleman will always mouth, ""Good luck"" to his opponents before a match."

column4: Half of a turtle shell as a shield makes a samurai more robust.
column5: The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles are robust gentlemen aren't they?

column4: A villa is fancier (decorated with flowers) and more robust than the average.
column5: The teenage mutant samurai turtles live in a villa with flowers on the roof so that the neighbours don't get suspicious.

column4: "The samurai happened to find an extra large crown that he wore as a belt on his waist, just above his legs. I wonder if he will sell it to me?"
column5: "A ""samurai"" will never sell his ""crown"" (king), even it meant having both his ""human legs"" chopped off!"

column4: "In the school house there are kids always studying. (BTW, atomiton, this is NOT 字)."
column5: "Children in schoolhouses are there to study, nothing else!!!"

column4: "In a schoolhouse in class: 1) you see something on the blackboard, then 2) you memorize it."
column5: You'll never memorize all the kanji by seeing them in a school house. You need Heisig and RtK!

column4: "The TREES FLOURISH in the CLASSROOM, a little too much perhaps, there's no room for the students any more."
column5: Students are like young trees. They tend to flourish in the schoolhouse.

column4: Make sure you practice writing kanji with a brush every day before the sun goes down.
column5: "The calligrapher had a peculiar habit: when using her brush to write, she would stick out her tongue, just slightly."

column4: A brush laying in dirty water is a haven for bacteria.
column5: The haven for a BRUSH is in WATER.. Otherwise they get dry and withered and cant be used?!

column4: "Imagine a taskmaster giving a cow the command to ""start breeding, and start doing it now!"", except that the cow takes his advice a bit too literally and starts chasing the taskmaster to carry out this command! instead of finding another cow to breed with. Hence, you see the taskmaster running to the right, trying to stay ahead of the cow."
column5: "Hint: This is the kanji from which taskmaster is derived. Actually, this kanji has nothing to do with breed, and a lot to do with pastures and shepherds (also for cowboys, japanese and spanish don't differenciate between animals). Think of a cowboy (taskmaster) who brings his cows to the pasture."

column4: Aggression is the craft of a good dominatrix.
column5: AGGRESSION is a well-honed craft for any decent taskmaster.

column4: "If you end up in failure, you give money to the taskmaster to train you."
column5: The shell who was defeated before (defeat (#63)) is being chastised by the taskmaster for his failure to win.

column3: sheet of...;counter for flat thin objects or sheets
column4: "The taskmaster is a strict bathroom monitor who hands out only one sheet of really rough, splintery toilet paper per person. You can see the wood fibers."
column5: "This taskmaster is the bathroom nazi: he counts how many sheets of toilet paper and tissue you use, and then tells you what % of a tree you just killed."

column4: An OLD TASKMASTER is no happenstance (coincidence). The older you get the more rigid in your ways.
column5: Need to disambiguate from enemy (#443) as it's easy to mix up antique and old here. Let's think of an accidental president -- he is an old taskmaster who has managed to win the election by happenstance .

column4: The flowery phrases of the schoolmaster held the students in awe.
column5: 敬 【けい】 (n) reverence; respect. 敬語 【けいご】 (n) honorific; term of respect; (P) STORY: The TASKMASTER demands RESPECT. If you don't talk to him in HONORIFICS and FLOWERY PHRASES you will be sorry.

column4: A pictogram of someone saying a four letter word from their mouth after the censors have gotten a hold of it.
column5: This is simple a pictogram of a mouth SAYing something. The lines are soundwaves. No need to complicate it.

column4: To admonish is to enforce awe by means of words.
column5: Watch in awe as mom admonishes the rude clerk with words that you've never heard her use before.

column4: A plot is a summary of a book that can be given in ten words.
column5: Say-ten's (satan's) evil plot.

column4: The wild dog family visits their cousin in prison. They exchange words over the interphone at the visiting booth.
column5: The only thing keeping the new chihuahua inmate from being 'initiated' by the pack of wild dogs were his quick words in prison.

column4: "Revise, revise and revise until you have all the words nailed down."
column5: Remember how Martin Luther revised the words of the catholic church and nailed his 95 Theses at the door of the church in Wittenberg?

column4: "I said some bad words, and my mother chastised me by washing my mouth out with glue instead of soap!"
column5: "In Colonial New England, people who committed adultery had words glued to them. A famous example is the ""A"" worn by Hester Prynn for committing adultery (i.e., not being chaste). In this way, words glued to you are supposed to chastise you and prevent further breaches of chastity."

column4: "The best type of Japanese INSTRUCTION is full immersion, which consists of going to Japan and swimming in the stream of words that surrounds you every day."
column5: Listen carefully to the words of instruction before you try swimming in the river.

column4: "The mnemonic ""words to seduce the masses"" was just too vague and I kept forgetting it. So now instead I picture a seductive female reading aloud the imperial edict to the masses, thus ""seducing"" the masses."
column5: The emperor did not need an imperial edict; his words were more than enough to seduce Anakin to the dark side.

column4: WORDS of GOOD LUCK are PACKED into fortune cookies.
column5: "Nowadays, grafitti comes pre-packaged. The factory takes a bunch of words and aerosol cans and then makes sure the words get tightly packed inside. All you have to do is spray and everything takes care of itself!"

column4: "Tales are always spoken, not written, and because of this, words fly out of your tongue, rather than your pen."
column5: "Tales are spoken words, passed on from person to person, eventually being spoken by a thousand mouths."

column4: "Listening to the words in a recitation of Vogon poetry is worse than spending an eternity in hell. [Note: I assume those 2 reports are to warn against possible confusion with poem (#346) but how can you confuse Vogon poetry with an actual poem? Anyway, it's the next frame, so it should be easy to keep them straight... Or maybe there's a kanji for Vogon in RTK3?]."
column5: "If you study some words for a recitation, there is a good chance they will be stuck in your memory for all eternity."

column4: A poem is a temple of words.
column5: WORDS used in a TEMPLE must be very well chosen. That's why most people will speak using a poem if they are SAYING something in a TEMPLE.

column4: The simplest word to say is I.
column5: May I say a word about that?

column4: Read the WORDS used to SELL things.
column5: People will say (言) almost anything to make a sale (売); don't believe everything you read (読).

column4: "To tune an old-fashioned radio, you turn the dial the full range of the circumference, until you can clearly hear what's being said."
column5: words + circumference The most catchy tunes are words the go round and round the circuference of your head and you can't get it out of your mind.

column4: Think of an online discussion group where misunderstanding someone's words leads to flaming. An angry discussion = inflamed words.
column5: Internet discussions often involve inflammatory words. Flame war!

column4: The words of the very young are useless without CONSENT from their elders.
column5: "Delores might say, ""Yes!"", but she's way too young give any legal consent."

column4: A PETA activist speaks at a meeting of butchers to rebuke them.
column5: "I imagine Socrates gate-crashing a meeting of butchers and REBUKING them: 'You've been killing things again; you have, haven't you?' while the embarrassed butchers blush and try to hide their knives behind their backs and stand in front of hanging sides of beef."

column4: Each Indian tribe crafts their arrows in a certain style..
column5: The latest style is shirts crafted out of arrows.

column4: "In an essay test, you are judged on both your choice of words and your writing style."
column5: The Japanese oral exam was a test of my speaking style.

column4: "II (older form of writing 2). After shooting one arrow (the dash top left), I have 2 arrows left in my quiver (bottom left)."
column5: "Once you have two old arrows left in your quiver, you better start running...!"

column4: "An astronaut lands back at the launch range, kisses the earth beneath him with his mouth, then heads off to a fiesta to celebrate a safe flight."
column5: "Instead of Heisig's ""Fiesta"" I use ""Spear"". Why? A spear is just a DROP extra on an Arrow. 域, range actually means range as in limits/boundary/border sort of range(In a box it was the old meaning for Country國 (581). Ok way too much etymology here, but back to story. With your SPEAR standing in a HOLE on the FLOOR with SOIL to its left9as you dug some out), you can see the RANGE of the spear in attacking a possible enemy (re Diablo and other RPGs, spear's have range)."

column4: Burglars... those guys!!! Burglars only want money (clams) so that they can get needles (drugs) and party (fiesta)!
column5: "After the fiesta, we found out that some burglar had stolen our money, probably breaking in with a lockpick needle..."

column4: The plantation is where we get our Christmas trees. We pick them out at Thanksgiving to be sure we get a good one.
column5: "During Thanksgiving, all the trees on the plantation celebrate the harvest. It's a good time for them, too."

column4: "After eating a big Thanksgiving dinner, you have to be careful in the car ride home not to drop a load in your pants."
column5: "After 'Thanksgiving' dinner, my girlfriend gave me a BJ on the drive back home. I blew my 'load' and 'soiled' the 'car'. But it was LOADS of fun! Please report this story if this makes you feel uncomfortable :)."

column4: "The gay parade looks astonishing, as if overgrown with flowers."
column5: "When your garden gets OVERGROWN, it's like the plants are mocking you. Here, you can see the roses actually parading around the yard, wilfully choking out the other, more docile plants. Then they actually go and parade down the street!"

column4: It only takes a single stroke of a dagger for a parade to TURN INTO a bloodbath.
column5: The gay parade suddenly TURNED INTO a DAGGER throwing fight.

column4: The sand castle is just the soil (#150) that turns into a castle.
column5: """Someday this mound of dirt here will turn into our CASTLE"", the ants think to themselves when scoping out a new ant hill."

column4: Sincerity happens when what you say actually turns into something.
column5: Sincerity is turning your words into actions.

column4: The march of women - against intimidation in the workplace - is pretty intimidating in itself!
column5: "Interesting that this kanji also has the meanings of ""dignity"" and ""threaten."" I can see how a march of women in Japan would be seen as intimidating by most men."

column4: Water flows down to destroy the march of fire.
column5: "Use a water cannon to destroy a line of marching fire monsters. I keep mixing this one up with disaster (#167) and demolition (#400). Remember, you DESTROY monsters (think of the Godzilla movie ""Destroy All Monsters!""). Fires and floods are natural DISASTERs. And DEMOLITION is something you carefully do while wearing protective garments. (vaguely based on stefanot's balrog story)."

column4: "When WATER was tossed on the PROTESTORS (a march of mouths), the numbers began to DWINDLE."
column5: "When water supplies dwindled, the population became a horde of dry mouths, marching to seize the water in the neighboring kingdom."

column4: Japanese festival floats are often so tall they need wood scaffolds to be completed. (http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5909.html).
column5: You need a SCAFFOLD made of WOOD to build a FLOAT if it will be several stories high.

column4: Political hopefuls in Rome threw gold COINS from floats when they were campaigning for office.
column5: Interesting fact: The Japanese one yen coin is the only coin in the world that can float on water. http://www.hanamiweb.com/floatingyen.jpg.

column4: The water can't be too SHALLOW if you expect to float.
column5: The water isn't shallow enough to ford (#372). We'll have to cross by float!

column4: "If you find in the ground a walking stick with a magic wand, STOP! Maybe it's some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing."
column5: "If you don't remember this one from the 10,000,000 STOP signs on roads all over Japan, you're beyyond help!"

column4: "When walking your pet, you must stop a few times along the way when nature calls."
column5: "When you learn to walk, you take your steps a few at a time. Picture a clumsy but happy toddler who falls every few steps but keeps getting up to try again."

column4: The new Ford Jesus. It can do everything except WALK on WATER.
column5: "A ford is a place where one can walk through the water, a place only a few footsteps deep."

column4: I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head.
column5: "Are you familiar with the joke about the ditzy secretary who repeatedly walked back and forth forcibly over all the pages of her boss' most important letters. When confronted she just says ""Well you said they needed to be stamped before they're mailed.""."

column4: A secret agreement between a covert gov't agency and aliens states that we will not step foot on the moon again in return for alien technology.
column5: NASA and Armstrong made an agreement: They'd never tell anyone that no-one actually stepped foot on the moon.

column4: Mary Poppins floated down with her umbrella to undertake the job of stopping the children's misbehaving.
column5: The Undertaker is an evil WWE wrestler - he beat his opponent with an umbrella until he stopped moving.

column4: A CURRICULUM is a calendar that replaces days with reasons to stop having fun.
column5: "A little like a calendar, your CV records your footsteps through time."

column4: ONE-ARROW can STOP a warrior.
column5: A great warrior can stop any 0pponent with one arrow.

column4: A warrior stands guard at a bridge collecting shells as a levy for any who want to pass.
column5: """Drove my Chevy to the levy but the levy was dry. And those good old warrior boys, drinking whiskey and rye, said pay up the clams or you'll die. Pay up the clams or you'll die...""."

column4: If you do it correct on the first attempt you can stop.
column5: "The correct way of learning Japanese? First, stop everything you're doing. Then, go pick up a copy of Heisig's book and work from there."

column4: Your words must be absolutely correct if you plan to use them as evidence.
column5: """If what you say is indeed correct, we could use use your testimony as evidence""."

column4: Those involved in politics are always trying to elect the correct taskmaster.
column5: "Insane political correctness on the left, and facists taskmasters on the right- thats politics in a nutshell right there."

column4: "In The Karate Kid, the boy must prove his determination by MENDING his teacher's HOUSE in various ways."
column5: "People who decide to renovate (ooh, that's a fancy word, let's say ""mend"") their houses must be very determined DIYers. (Using DIY helps me remember this story when I see DEtermine)."

column4: "Even if you lock up your GOLD, a DETERMINED thief will get it in the end."
column5: "The best stories for this kanji tend to have a thief in them, which always makes me confuse them with the kanji for burglar (357). So, let's try this one: My girlfriend wears a metal chastity belt with a lock but I am determined to open it! I must get inside!"

column4: "Hint: This kanji is NOT soil on top of mend, as Heisig claims - that would duplicate one of the strokes. Instead, it is 10 on top of mend. So my story is: If you run 10 miles, you will need to mend your socks!"
column5: The sports ground needs MENDING after the game as the players have been RUNNING around which has caused the ground to be chopped up.

column4: "A successful marathon runner needs to be able to transcend seductions, such as the possibility of rest, shelter from the rain, or a cold beer."
column5: "To transcend oneself is to reach a higher plane of reality. A head shaven monk is telling me this. We are in a Tibetan monastery. He was once an athlete, a runner. He used to run everywhere, until one day, he saw a beautiful cheerleader along his path. She tried very hard to seduce him, but he forced himself to transcend his urges. He did reach his running goal, and he has became a lonely monk. He wishes now he had just broken down back then and...."

column4: """Don't run into trouble,"" Dumbledore tells Harry. ""Proceed with caution with your wand out.""."
column5: "While running, my magic wand tells me where to proceed."

column4: The person in charge of running the parade surpassed all our expectations (by just a extra drop...).
column5: The parade of runners are all trying to SURPASS each other - and they end up running all the way to Vietnam (note that this kanji is also used for the country of Vietnam).

column4: 'Sun' 'Mend' - It just so happens that sunshine can mend your gloomy spirits.
column5: My image here is of Fabrice (the guy who runs this website) spending all day obsessively mending the code so this page looks just so....

column4: "The ""TOPIC"" of the day's newspaper must be placed JUST SO at the top of the PAGE to attract attention."
column5: "You spend ALL DAY, mending your socks JUST SO. Then you have a look at the HEADING of the newspaper. The topic---FREE SOCKS TO BE GIVEN AWAY!!!!"

column4: Making a dike is all about arranging the soil just so....
column5: "The little Dutch boy has his finger stuck in the dike, and that's the only thing keeping his town from going under. He really really needs to go to the bathroom though, so he devises a plan to carefully add a bit of dirt - there, place individual bits in just so - there, I think it's good enough. Pull it out -----yes! Success!"

column4: "Build is easy to remember if you can remember that archtiechts have two steps in building. 1. Take a brush and brush out the blueprints. 2. Get a visual image of the blueprints all rolled up like they usually are. The second step is easy, it's just the architecht stretching out the blueprints and showing it to his clients."
column5: "A construction worker's classic morning. Stretch, brush his teeth, and then start to build."

column4: Stretching correctly prolongs life. Even the top part of 正 is stretching...
column5: "Here's a great mnemonic: ""stop, drop, and stretch (!?)."" Now let's associate it with 'prolong': if you're ever in an uncomfortable spot, like being asked tricky questions or caught in a lie, just PROLONG the situation - stop, drop, and stretch. They may be confused by your odd behaviour, but it'll buy you a few moments to think up another good lie to get out of the sticky situation!"

column4: "Nativity = born, being born. Think of birth as a painful and prolonged event. And of course, all the words and curses being yelled at the soon-to-be father for doing this to her!"
column5: "When you are being born ( nativity ), your mother's WORDS are PROLONGED. (Thiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiis huuuuuuuuuuuuuurtss a lottttttttt~!! Owwwwwww!!!)."

column4: Features like stones and groves of trees are the cornerstones of a happy zoo.
column5: "A zoo which is still under construction is already full of animals. At the moment, only the cornerstone has been set in place. To temporarily keep the animals from escaping, a closely-packed grove of small trees is planted around the stone. (Note that this zoo needs some serious mending.)."

column4: "The virgin bridegroom tries to understand the new, mysterious part of his woman's body - but with little success. It's a zoo down there! (primitives placement: the part of the body is 'down there' - the woman is 'left' unsatisfied)."
column5: "The only reason anyone talks about a bridegroom is if they're about to or have just gotten married. Of course, then you have to go on your honeymoon. So you take your woman to the zoo for a month. Pretty cool honeymoon."

column4: The only garments allowed in this club are top hat and scarf.
column5: "The garments most commonly associated with the craft of a magician are the top hat and the magic wand. (It's a stretch, but the way I remembered this kanji is through that phrase. This way you can remember it through using primitives we have already learned.)."

column4: The tailor was hard at work making sure all the pilgrims were dressed in their best garments for thanksgiving.
column5: The tailor worked hard after thanksgiving to alter garments so they'd fit people who'd eaten too much at their thanksgiving dinners.

column4: The TURTLE SAMURAI needs special GARMENTs for his ATTIRE since his body is much more ROBUST than others.
column5: "The ninja turtles tried to go eat at a fancy restaurant, but they were told to come back after their were dressed in proper attire. However, it's too difficult for them to find proper garments because they bodies are so robust! (sannomiya + drwarrior12)."

column4: The computer had carefully dressed up in clothes to look human. It was n't until I looked at the back and saw the cables and stuff that I realized what it was.
column5: "Can computers be gay? I'm not sure, but mine always wears a top hat and scarf, and for some reason its back door port is always open..."

column4: "If you stand too close to a DEMOLITION site, the dust might sting you like NEEDLES in your EYE and get your GARMENTs all dirty."
column5: "Since that needle eye thing turns up a lot, I turned it into Darth Vader. It kinda looks like him to me, with the eye being his metal mouth piece thing. So, Darth Vader swings his cape (his garment) demolishing a nearby building, leaving nothing but a pile of dirt."

column4: One of my friends with a crazy sense of fashion loves to wear a tophat and a scarf so that you can't see his whole face but only his mouth. He thinks it's cool. I think it's pathetic.
column5: "A poor, homeless child like Oliver Twist, with a hungry open mouth, is pathetic-- in the original sense of the noun ""pathos."" The tattered tophat and scarf he wears only adds to the pathos."

column4: Keep distant from a lidded crock on the road wrapped in a scarf. It might be a bomb.
column5: "When traveling to a distant land, what better way of keeping warm on the road is there than carrying a warm lidded crock and wearing a scarf?"

column4: The MONKEY likes to play hide and seek with the PACK of WILD DOGS by hiding in the LIDDED CROCK. But he is easy to see because the SCARF he always wears is at the base of the LIDDED CROCK.
column5: "To catch a monkey, chase him with wild dogs into a lidded crock, then tie it with a scarf."

column4: """This is the first time we've been out of the Shire, Mr. Frodo!"" Says Sam, covering himself with his cloak and clutching his dagger."
column5: "On his FIRST TIME, he cloaked his dagger with a Trojan."

column4: A matador holding his red linen by his side.
column5: "The first rule of the Hitch-Hiker's Guide to the Universe is ""DON'T PANIC!"" The second rule, of course, is to always have a towel by your side. Personally, I prefer the linen sort."

column4: "When stranded at sea, we needed a Sail. The best we had was a TOWEL, which was MEDICORE, only catching a DROP of WIND."
column5: A towel makes a mediocre sail.

column4: "In the west, the rich use $100 bills to light their cigars... In Japan, after showering, when the wealthy don't have any clean towels, they simply grab a hanging scroll off the wall and use it to dry off!"
column5: The towels of the wealthy: hanging scrolls.

column4: "If you wear a towel as a cap, you are at risk of being seized and searched in U.S. airports."
column5: Originally the first cap was a turban which was a towel wrapped around the head to keep the sun out of the eyes.

column4: "There is a graveyard outside my house that scares me, so I put a huge towel over the window to serve as a curtain so I can get a good nights sleep."
column5: "When you're dead in the graveyard, ""it's curtains for you.""."

column4: A canopy is a towel to block the suns rays.
column5: "From the Hitch-Hiker's Guide to the Universe: A towel is useful, among other things, as a canopy to keep out the sun's rays from your face while napping."

column4: Brocade is the art of sewing gold on a white towel.
column5: "Never heard of this word before encountering it here. So it turns out that the fanciest brocade in the world is actually a towel used by a Turkish monarch. It's embroidered with gold and cocaine. Yes, cocaine - what you thought it'd be something else? That is some true art right there. I think a great many people would want to own this towel."

column4: "My recurring nightmare: Walking through the market, and suddenly realizing that I'm wearing only a top hat...and a towel."
column5: At the MARKET you find lots of nice TOP HATS and TOWELS.

column4: "Unlike the younger sister (妹), who is not yet old enough to date... the elder sister is on the market!"
column5: She's old enough to be allowed to go to the market.

column4: LUNGS are a PART of the BODY that can be found at any meat MARKET or black MARKET.
column5: "The PART OF THE BODY most important if you work at a MARKET is your LUNGS so that you can shout out at the top of your voice ""IRASSHAIMASEEE"" to attract customers."

column4: "First, note that the top half of the kanji consists of one and mountain. Of course, the ""number 1"" mountain in Japan is Mt. Fuji. The bottom half, under Mt. Fuji, consists of crown and towel. Now for the story. Archaeologists digging under Mt. Fuji (Japan's #1 mountain) in an ancient royal tomb (they know it's royal because of the crown) discover what looks like a towel, but after they clean it up, they see it is actually a splendid royal sash for the king's kimono."
column5: "Beautiful ""Miss Housewife Japan"" is on posters everywhere, cooking right before Mt. Fuji (the number one mountain) while wearing nothing but her crown, and an apron tied with a sash. (hodgepodge of mspertus, zwarte_kat, et al, with a jot of hadaka apron to focus the image.)."

column4: "History of the first karate blackbelts: In those days, it was often difficult to find fresh, clean water, so samurai usually had to wash their sashes in stagnant puddles. The longer one had been studying martial arts, the older the sash on one's karate uniform and, therefore, the darker the color. So why weren't their karate uniforms black too? Never seen a ninja????"
column5: A moat is a stagnate ring of water like an obi (sash) of water tied around the castle.

column4: "A TREE with a BELT wrapped around the middle. If you tighten the BELT, hundreds of tiny SABERS pop out of the tree in all directions, looking like THORNS."
column5: The BELT TREE has THORNS like SABERS.

column4: The system for making leather belts involves slicing up a cow with a sword.
column5: "Why all the gore and violence? How about a samurai cow? He doesn't have to be a violent samurai, either. He only wears the sword because he's part of the bushi SYSTEM. Actually, he studies ikebana, shodo, and zen. Imagine him sitting cross-legged in a Zen temple (a very Special Zen temple). The master asks him if a dog has buddha nature and, shifting the swords in his belt, he calmly replies, ""Moo!""."

column4: Made in china - a system of exploitation . making garments for nothing.
column5: A SYSTEMATICALLY made GARMENT will no doubt have MADE IN on the label.

column4: The REVOLVING wheels of the car (with REVOLVER blaring on the stereo) kicked up RISING CLOUDS of dust.
column5: "Just a note to remember the cloud primative: The name of Goku's pet cloud that he used to help him rise (fly) in the Dragonball anime series (and also the scientific name for a certain type of cloud) is Nimbus [ http://www.rpgclassics.com/shrines/gba/dbztlog/screen2.jpg ]. The katakana-ization of this is {ニム}バス, so the rising cloud primative is just an abbreviation of that name written from top to bottom in the old Japanese style."

column4: "Imagine an old Kung-fu movie: ""Try my rising cloud flower technique!!!"" smash pow crack!! ."
column5: One technique to smoke weed is to vaporize it and inhale those rising clouds to create a stronger effect.

column4: From the ceiling hangs a towel dripping four drops like RAIN.
column5: "Towel hung out on a line to ....oops, it's rain."

column4: Every rising cloud is a potential rain cloud. (Thanks astridtops).
column5: Every cloud is a potential rain cloud.

column4: Cloudy weather is when a cloud blocks the sun (up above).
column5: "In cloudy weather, the sun is still there even if obscured by the clouds...　RTK2:　ドン　曇天　どんてん(cloudy skies)."

column4: "If it's raining and you're standing in the middle of a rice field, you're sure to soon become acquainted with the thunder up close and personal."
column5: "Thunder is a sure sign of rain coming. When you hear the thunder, you've got time to get out of the field before it starts raining."

column4: "FROST is kind of an inter-weather, phenomenon, something between rain, snow and freezing temp’s."
column5: "The freezing RAIN formed FROST on the TREE right before your EYES. If you want, frost-y then think Frost Tree to get to the mnemonic. SECOND STORY: FROSTY the snowman? It's RAIN that FROSTS that can then INTER-act with the kids, till he melts of course."

column4: "Don't slip off your legs in winter, strap two skis to your feet."
column5: In winter my walking legs feel like blocks of ice.

column4: "If you think of the sky as a ceiling above our heads, here you have the heavens as the largest ceiling you could ever imagine. As Heisig pointed out, nothing comes above the ceiling primitive thus the order of primitives is taken care of."
column5: "The ceiling that all large dogs aspire to go to is known as heaven. After all, All Dogs Go to Heaven."

column4: "The nicest bridge is not in Hollywood or Los Angeles, but in San Francisco."
column5: "A small 5 year old child has lost her mother in a tragic death. Her family tells her, ""Don't worry, your mom is an angel now, in heaven, watching over you."" The small girl takes this very literally and is found one day, gathering pieces of wood. Her dad asks her, ""What are you doing with that wood?"" ""I'm trying to build a bridge to heaven to visit the angels.""."

column4: The most attractive woman in the world is obviously Angelina Jolie.
column5: "The most attractive of women are said to resemble angels. Similarly, angelic women tend to be attractive."

column4: A vase that can't stand up won't be a vase for long.
column5: "He was a stand up guy: he'd lend you the top hat he wears everyday if you asked, and he will turn everything upside down to help you find your tools."

column4: "Guys have two ways of watering when they are standing, the less common one is crying."
column5: She stood up to leave the room when her eyes started to water...

column4: "In the military, badges are given out early in the day, with everyone standing at attention."
column5: "Ash Ketchum stood up early in the morning, and said, ""Pikachu, let's go get us another badge!""."

column4: TWO twin BROTHERS are competing (VYING) for the title of who is the older BROTHER. The game is that they must balance a VASE on their head and the one who drops his looses and becomes the younger BROTHER!
column5: Two crazy brothers vying for the guiness records books of stupidity by trying to stand on their heads the longest.

column4: "The crazy sovereign stands up from his throne, wearing nothing but a crown and a towel. That's why they try to keep him locked up in the castle away from the public."
column5: "This one is so tricky for me. The key is to remember that the bottom stroke on the standing element takes those little crown ""winglets"" on the right and left. The most effective image might be of QEII (who is quite short) using her crown as a kind of stool. She's standing on her crown rummaging through a high cupboard looking for her apron. I guess the sovereign's servants have the day off."

column4: The juvenile stood on top of his computer and broke it. Noob.
column5: "The movie Zoolander is a little JUVENILE and silly, but I love it nonetheless. Just remember Owen Wilson standing on the desk, hitting the computer like a monkey. (The files are IN the computer - IN the computer...)."

column4: "In Japanese comics, the eye's of juvenilles all have enormouse pupils."
column5: WARNING: This kanji only means the pupil of the eye. It can be confusing to use a story that has pupil meaning student in it.

column4: The METAL bell rings to call the JUVENILES to class.
column5: The METAL bell rings to call the JUVENILES to COMPUTER class.

column4: I use what I think is the real etymology for this kanji which is so shocking it sticks. The STANDING member at the top is a certain part of the body that all men have and it is approaching the HOLE between TWO LEGS (the HOOD) with extra marks to show they are FLESHY - ie a womans legs. So this shows the oldest DEAL of all time - prostitution.
column5: "Slick Willy standing on the motorcycle helmet he's trying to sell you to demonstrate how rugged it is. His legs crash through the top of it and after a moment of awkward silence his mouth opens and says, ""hey, we can still make a deal.""."

column4: Legitmate wifes tend to be women who are antiques in contrast to the young bit of illigitmate fluff on the side.
column5: Your legitimate wife is like an antique bong. Its not your favorite but you still hit it sometimes...

column4: "Think of the term from televison ""suitable for all audiences"" to get the sense of the word. What program could be more suitable for the whole family than the ""antiques road(show)""."
column5: That old thing in your attic might be suitable to be shown on the Antiques Roadshow.

column4: DRIPS of WATER were collected in ANTIQUE VASES since the museum had a leaky roof.
column5: You must never let water drip onto antiques.

column4: The taskmaster became my enemy for life when he smashed the antique vase holding my wife's ashes.
column5: Indiana Jones is an enemy of taskmasters in search of antique artifacts. RTK2: 　テキ　敵地　てきち(enemy territory)...　　　　　　　　　　　Pure Group:　嫡440　適441　滴442 　摘657.

column4: "To remember the primitive meaning, picture someone sitting on the ground performing Seppuku...with a spoon. http://tinyurl.com/co48k."
column5: "Not only is stroke order important, but also be sure to note the direction of a stroke. In both 'spoon' and 'seven', the first stroke is the horizontal one - but here it is written right to left in a downward flick, while in 'seven' it is a strong line from left to right."

column4: Warning: The left part is NOT the primitive turtle! The stroke order is different. Sometimes it will look exactly the same but not always depending on the font / style used to draw this character. Be sure to study the difference!
column5: "In the north, the weather is so cold that people are often seen sitting back to back to preserve warmth."

column4: "While japanese people are generally small, people in the northern contryes have taller stature because of all the flesh they eat!"
column5: "Up in the Great White North, we eat a lot of meat - thus giving us great STATURE. Mmmm.... baby seals."

column4: A gay couple about to turn around to compare which role is better...
column5: Compare the two spoons... the one on the left is funny-looking.

column4: Grandparent spends all DAY COMPARING photos of their DESCENDANTS.
column5: "Japanese people have compared themselves as being descendants of the sun. (Amaterasu, the sun godesss). Sun, comparing = descendants."

column4: "If you compare colors, you will find that white is produced from the mix of all the others."
column5: "Sometimes, Dr. Heisig's keyword choices are really quite bizarre. This doesn't mean all, it means everyone!! Picture two ku klux klansmen comparing whose skin is whiter...finally, they agree that everyone there is white."

column4: "People have to mix their fluids (have sex), in order to create descendants."
column5: Give plants the right mix of water and sun. Then compare the results...　RTK2:　コン　混乱　こんらん(disorder).

column4: You awaken from your siesta because you feel extremely thirsty so you go looking for some water.
column5: "The muchacho taking his SIESTA cries out that he is THIRSTY. So you pull out a bottle of WATER and pretend you're going to give it to him...but then you dump it all on the ground before his eyes. HAHA, sucked in muchacho!!"

column4: The talk was so boring the audience took a siesta.
column5: The man talking during his siesta (in his sleep) is saying strange things and drawing an audience.

column4: Why is my package late? Imagine a UPS driver dressed in BROWN garments taking a siesta. What can BROWN do for you?
column5: Mexicans use a cloak (pancho) for their siestas. Their color is usually brown.

column4: "If you have a siesta with your mouthopen, you will wake up with a hoarse voice."
column5: "After taking a siesta, you find that your mouth is hoarse (after all you ARE thirsty remember)."

column4: Use a spoon to eat a DELICIOUS hot fudge sundae. Duh..
column5: It's sooo delicious I could spoon it in all day.

column4: "Every chef will tell you, fat is what make the meat taste delicious."
column5: "Fat is the most delicious part of the flesh. (Note this refers to physical fat, not the concept of obesity obese (#494))."

column4: "I am 'the one' , says the samurai with the crown around his waist and a spoon up his a***."
column5: The samurai who has been crowned number one is so good he uses a spoon to fight with rather than a sword.

column4: Freud believed every man wants to lie down with his mother.
column5: Who does every person want to lie down with? Yo' MAMA!

column4: Every master(or taskmaster) must have some degree of cleverness.
column5: Cleverness is something every taskmaster must have. Every taskmaster has cleverness.

column4: "Plums actually grow on every single tree. What, you didn't know that? They do. Orange trees, apple trees, cantaloupe trees. Plums are simply mutant fruits that have been installed in the root software of every single tree. I hear that some plum-loving scientists are working on a way to hack every tree's genetic code so that every tree will bear nothing _but_ plums."
column5: "EVERY Japanese person asks you if you like UMEBOSHI. No I say, I prefer to eat my PLUMS fresh from the TREE."

column4: Every drop of water will eventually return to the sea.
column5: "As depicted in the classic SF film Fantastic Voyage, every drop of water is a sea, if you look close enough. Imagine peering through a microscope at a vast sea teeming with microbial life (and perhaps a minaturized submarine). Note: Take care not to confuse with ocean (#549)."

column4: "Lying down, Captain Hook is begging to be spared from the ticking crocodile."
column5: Men beg lying down. Women beg as hookers.

column4: "During a drought, everything begs for even a mist for relief."
column5: Beggar has to drink mist because there is no water in the drought. I get this one confused with thirst 451 but try to remember that there is no water element beacuse it is a drought.

column4: The only body part that doubles over.
column5: "Imagine getting punched in the abdomen, a fairly tender part of flesh, and instead of doubling forward, you double back. That would be pretty painful."

column4: "My girlfiend saw someone wearing the exact same (duplicate) outfit at a party, so she doubled back to change!"
column5: "In Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Hermione uses a device called a ""time-turner"" to double back in time, but this creates duplicates. The smart thing to do would be to combine Hermione's time-turner with Harry's invisibility cloak. That way, one could double back in time without creating any visible duplicates."

column4: "To me, this kanji looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who lacks a head."
column5: When your body lacks oxygen you yawn.

column4: "This is clearly a BLOWJOB, we can see the MOUTH and the LACK OF condom. (I am sorry for the image, but it sticks forever in your mind)."
column5: I keep confusing this with suck (#689). Consider someone blowing bubbles using their chewing gum because they're lacking attention in class.

column4: "Japanese cooking sometimes lacks fire, e.g., sashimi."
column5: "This character shows the difference between a cook and a chef: a chef prepares food with passion and love; a cook only stands there with a pan over a fire, with no passion and just yawning."

column4: "Can-Can-ers lack the ability to sing a song, so they just dance."
column5: "Can-can dancers are supposed to be big-bosomed girls who dance. Yet these so called can-can dancers are flat-chested and singing a song, so audience of men is yawning in boredom."

column4: "Cars are rough steel things, lacking softness."
column5: "If your car has really soft seats, you may start yawning and eventually fall asleep at the wheel (imagine that this seat is a huge soft beanbag that nearly swallows the driver, and it will be easier to remember)."

column4: "Is this store lacking ice? Let's try the next one, then."
column5: "A rapper called ""Ice"" went for auditions but was told he lacked talent. Next..."

column4: "To prevent animals from eating the beautiful flowers in your garden, the best thing to do is to plant briar bushes immediately next to them."
column5: "The briar patch may look unremarkable now before it blooms, but there will be flowers next, and it will be beautiful."

column4: Assets are the next best thing to money.
column5: "The first SHELLS you get you obviously spend, but the NEXT SHELLS are your ASSETS, you should bury them in a low safe place (placement!)."

column4: "The next woman always has a better figure! Thinking like that, you'll end up alone in an old folks home longing for the good old days!"
column5: "Whenever I am next to a woman, I can't help but take notice of her figure."

column4: "Having a word with the next mouth over, like a neighbor, is usually a good way to consult with somebody for cheap. Because, you know, actual consultants charge huge sums."
column5: """Consulting with"" is having words with the next mouth."

column4: Compensation is money you give to someone to shut them up (i.e. muzzle their mouth).
column5: Compensation is a kind of euphemism for hush money here. Money that muzzles.

column4: "To cultivate the land is to tame it, control it. In short, you muzzle it's unruly, chaotic nature."

column4: Mirror should suggest vanity. Imagine a spoiled girl who gets her parents to buy her a Golden mirror so she can stand in front of it all day vainly admiring her lovely human legs.

column4: "In the dense cities of Japan even a small garden is a luxury. In this house, the owner has put mirrors on the boundary of his land so it feels much bigger."
column5: "This is an old trick to keep out migrants. You put a bunch of dirty mirrors on the boundary of your land and theirs. When they approach the boundary, what they see in the mirror is their own land and someone that looks like themselves, only dirtier, so they figure your country isn't any better than their own and they head back home."

column4: The top hat hanging on a hook belonged to the now deceased Charlie Chaplin.

column4: "After Godzilla laid waste to the city, the survivors put some flowers on the bodies of the deceased and floated their bodies down the stream."

column4: "You're dead meat, buddy, my ambition is to be king."

column4: "She used a perfume so strong, that you can track her by following the direction of the smell of flowers."

GOT IT YET? PRESENTS = SHELLS + INCREASE."

column4: Feng Shui states that the ridgepole of a house should be made of wood and face east.

Assuming that 99% of you guys use the age old story of a 'sun rising through a tree tells you were the east is', back in those days when people used ridgepoles they wanted to align their houses in such a way that they face the rising sun, so they wake up with a bright day, and wake up early with the sun seeping through in a perpendicular manner( as the ridge pole faces the sun in the morning)."

column4: "Eastern Siberia is often frozen by ice. According to wikipedia, Yakutia (in Eastern Siberia) holds the record as the coldest town on Earth. Check it out yourself...it made it stick for me!"

column4: "There are a bunch of HORSE CHESTNUT TREES on top of this CLIFF above the beach. Chestnuts keep rolling off the cliff and falling on people's heads. So far TEN THOUSAND people have been killed by falling chestnuts, and the Japanese government still ain't did shit about it."
column5: "There is a horse chestnut tree that has grown by a cliff for so long, it has deposited 10,000 horse chesnuts that lie at the bottom. Don't worry over this one too much, you'll spend so much time trying to figure out the right story for it, you probably won't forget it."

It dropped a steaming brown load right on my face. It changed my outlook completely. Birds are the second most vile creatures on earth."

column4: Matrimony is the state in which the woman has got you pent in like a dog so that you cannot go after other bitches.
column5: "When the woman gets angry, she treats her man like a pent in dog (i.e., puts him in the doghouse). It's a perfect metaphor for the state of matrimony."

column4: "A nice picnic pent up in the park, with your crock pot and scarf (picnic blanket)."
column5: There was a homeless man living in a box at the park so I gave him a lidded crock filled with hot curry tied with a scarf...　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　エン　庭園　ていえん(Japanese garden)…　　　　　　　　　　Pure Group:　遠402　猿403.

column4: Write mouth two -times.
column5: "Pretty much a pictograph, see book. Keyword meanings : to turn round, counter for number of times, counter for rounds. Some simple compounds using previously learned kanji : 次回 (next time), 毎回 (every time/each round), 回る (to wander around)."

column4: A man on the podium announce the rules for the contest: You must fill a top hat with dirt as many times as you can by nightbreak.
column5: "Abraham Lincoln used a simple mound of soil for a podium, when he wore his top hat and gave the speech he had practiced many times until nightbreak. But it was so magnificent that no one noticed."

column4: Try to remember all those stores from Zelda that were inside caves and had fortune-teller like vendors.
column5: The fortuneteller has a store in a cave.

column4: "I think of the Batcave. It's a big cave that Batman uses as a warehouse to store his car, the Batmobile, and all his cool big-boy toys."
column5: Have you ever worked in a warehouse? It's like a giant metal cave. Watch out for that forklift!

column4: "When the courthouse caved in, trials had to be held in the courtyard."
column5: "Back in caveman days, courts were held in caves. When too many people showed up to watch, they spilled out into the courtyard (the yard outside the cave court ) . 庭 (にわ): garden, yard, compound 庭園 (ていえん): garden, park 校庭 (こうてい): schoolyard."

column4: "Some bureaucrats at a government office decided that the tunnels of caves need to get street signs, which are then nailed to the walls of the cave."
column5: "In some of the scarier countries, when someone is invited to visit a ""government office"", it's actually a dungeon where they're dragged into a cave and nailed to the wall."

column4: The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a tree and in a cave. So these can be considered as beds.
column5: (based on mspertus:) The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a tree and in a cave. So to be on the safe side it is best to put a tree in a cave and use it as a bed.

column4: "(Image: while Batman is out, Robin is smokin' a huge doob in a secret corner of the Batcave where he nurtures his hemp grove)."
column5: "Where is the best place to hid your grove of hemp trees? In a cave, you dope!"

column4: If you grind the hemp you are bound to get stoned quicker.
column5: You must GRIND the HEMP collected in the grove by your cave on solid STONE to make the best ropes.

column4: "The four chambers in the heart. In the West, we point to our head when asked about the mind. In the East, they point to the heart. So then, the radical for ""state of mind""…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　シン　安心　あんしん(peace of mind)."
column5: Heart needs three drops of blood to work.

column4: You only truly forget her when she has perished in your heart.
column5: To forget means that something perishes from your heart.

column4: "A ninja must be able to endure the pain of clinging to a ceiling, motionless, for hours at a time, waiting for just the right moment to drop down and thrust the blade of his sword into the hearts of his enemies. By the way, this character is used in the compound 忍者 (ninja) which is why I choose to use ninja as its primitive meaning."
column5: Someone with a razor blade stuck in their heart has to endure the pain wherever they go and can tell no one about it.

column4: "You are given a speech about some serious mistakes of yours, and you have to endure the whole thing, because all you can do is acknowledge."
column5: "I never read the ""acknowledgements"" section of books or theses, because they are mostly just boring words that i must endure reading, before i can get to the interesting part. :)."

column4: "Remember the tale of Cleopatra? She was MOURNING the loss of her Marc Antony, so she placed the asp SNAKE to her HEART."
column5: "You are mourning the death of a relative, and it feels as if a snake had bitten into your heart. -- ""mourning feels like snake-bitten heart""."

column4: A samurai's intentions always come from the heart.
column5: Gentleman always have hearts full of good intentions.
column10: こ;こ;ろ;ざ;-;す;、;こ;こ;ろ;ざ;し

column4: A will is an important document that contains your final word on how you intend to distribute your assets.
column5: This is quite simple: a document is a set of words describing your intentions.

column4: Their true loyalty exists in the middle of their hearts.
column5: Your loyalty is to what's in your heart.

column4: "Naka naka , ""who's there?"" shish kebab .... ""shish kebab who?""."
column5: This is a pictograph if ever I saw one. Two chunks of meat on a skewer.

column4: A person who is afflicted with the vampire disease can only be killed with a sheesh-kebab through the heart.
column5: "If you are afflicted with severe heartburn, eating a spicy shish kebab will feel only slightly less painful than having it jammed straight into your heart."

column4: Think with your brain NOT your heart.
column5: To think is to use your brain over your heart.

column4: "Grace here is a favor freely bestowed, like a good deed. So to remember this kanji, go to the local shelter, find a big dog pent up in a small cage and adopt him. That will cause a warm feeling in your heart!"
column5: "This kanji tells us that wherever heart is the cause, grace is the consequence. Think of “grace” as a graceful act: something benevolent that comes from the heart."

column4: "[bravo, scottamus!] To apply for the job as a (replacement) Batman, you have to make it to the heart of the cave past all the traps he set up to test you. There, you see a table with the application form on it. Now that you think about it, the ad in the paper did say ""Those who don't make it to the heart of the cave need not apply.""."
column5: "In the videogame Zelda, Link enters a CAVE to visit a fairy that will APPLY magic to fill his HEART containers."

column4: "When you get a good IDEA you get excited and you can hear the SOUND of your HEART, it's pounding so hard."
column5: "Picture someone who's just had a great idea, but in place of a blinking light bulb over their head, you see a heart thumping with great noise. Imagine the greater the idea, the louder the sound of the beating heart."

column4: The concept of love is basically two hearts inter-acting as one.
column5: ''Inter-heart'' is a new therapy CONCEPT that helps macho guys share their feelings with each other.

column4: Your breath brings oxygen in through your nose which is then pumped around your body by your heart.
column5: "I think I've met my dream girl, but there's a problem. her breath is horrible! So, do I listen to my nose or my heart?"

column4: Recess to me is a school break. At recess some kiddies are comparing their latest body piercings. Tongues and noses are nothing special. The new cool is to have your heart done!
column5: "Ah recess; tongues slandering, noses being turned up, and beneath it all, young hearts being broken. Dominant in playgrounds is the noise of tongues, which helps me remember that in this kanji tongue comes first."

column4: "Too easy. Imagine the Wizard of OZ. There, the three heroes asked the Wizard for three FAVORS: the lion wanted courage of TEN men, the scarecrow wanted a BRAIN, and the tin man wanted a HEART. Ok, the lion bit is stretching but you have it memorized now, so who cares?"
column5: Do yourself a favor and take ten minutes to think about your decison...　RTK2:　エ　知恵　ちえ(wisdom)　　　ゴ　互恵　ごけい(reciprocal).

column4: "If your heart surgeon is mediocre in his craft, you have plenty of reason to fear. (""Oops, I think I left my scissors in there"")."
column5: My deep dark fear at the bottom of my heart is that I am mediocre at my craft.

column4: "She was beguiled/mislead by his charm: at the party he kissed her on the mouth, they did it on the floor and thus he stole her heart. Poor girl!"
column5: "The same cowboy from frame # 356 (elements mouth, floor and fiesta), kisses the floor with his mouth, once again, before going to the fiesta. There, he uses his good looks to beguile women (gets them to buy him drinks or such), by playing with their hearts."

column4: Emotion is a march of mouths inside your heart telling you what to feel.
column5: "Strong EMOTIONS don't stay hidden. They march right out of one's heart (below) and out one's mouth (shouted, snarled, or gently whispered - depending on exactly what kind of emotion it is!)."

column4: Melancholy makes me think of Hamlet cause he was so 'emo'. In order to play up his feelings he bares his head and holds his crown over his heart then walks (on walking legs) around the palace making everyone see how melancholy he is. What a wuss.
column5: "This is an image of the crucifixion. Jesus is on the cross. His crown of thorns has slipped down and is around his neck, right between his head and his heart. His walking legs can be seen dangling from the cross as well. How MELANCHOLY!"

column4: "The new widow sits in the house, her head in her lap (the extended stroke), her dagger in her husband."
column5: "The house's head, her husband, was murdered with a dagger. You can still see the drops of blood above the dagger. She is now a widow."

column4: "Busy (as in ""occupied"") means a state of mind where all other thoughts are perished."
column5: "^^^Make the ""state of mind"" primitive Data (from Star Trek) instead right now and save yourself the headache; 'state of mind' is too vague! (Data can stay so busy as not to sleep without dying. He's a robot)."

column4: ECSTASY alters our STATE OF MIND and makes us DEVILS.
column5: The state of mind that horny teenagers are looking for.

column4: Constancy is holding the same state of mind over a long span of time. (tweaking PepeSeco and mspertus).
column5: "Data is the epitome of constancy. As a robot, his consistency spans the entire day."

column4: "When the world's most eminent magician died, everyone's state of mind became that of lamentation. He was buried with his famous sun-flower wand in his hand."
column5: "Data laments that he could never see his eminent father, his creator, ever again. He paints a picture of his father, that looks like a sunflower in the shape of a magic wand."

column4: Enlightenment is a state of mind that goes beyond the five senses.
column5: "Data finds enlightenment when he discovers the answer to the question, ""Who am I?"". (Image: Data meditating in a sitting lotus position)."

column4: Someone in a dreadful state of mind has crawled into his bed and is hiding under the sheets (linens).
column5: "Being an android, Data is white as a sheet. Doctor Crusher always has to remind herself that this is perfectly normal. From a doctor's perspective, he really does look dreadful."

column4: (re: wazzab) The state of mind of the people of New Orleans as they examined their city's concert hall laid waste can best described as disconcerted.
column5: "Data walks in and sees Picard weeping. ""What is the matter, Captain?"" Picard looks up, and replies that his entire home planet has been laid to waste. Data, the master of tact, offers up this consolation: ""Ah. I can see how that would be DISCONCERTing"". It turns out that the flow of tears was really just because Picard had lost his chance at getting at some rare (and thus valuable) flowers on his home planet."
column10: あ;わ;-;て;る;、;あ;わ;-;た;だ;し;い

column4: """For all have sinned..."" so everyone's state of mind should be to repent."
column5: "When you repent, you heal your state of mind by going over every thing you regret doing."

column4: "Like the saying goes, Hate just begets Hate. A state of mind that just increases and increases until it explodes."
column5: Data's one true emotion is hate for Prince's music. (Image: Data hunched over hands to his ears and screaming while Picard bobs to Purple Rain).

column4: "It took him awhile, but Data finally got ACCUSTOMED to his nipple/breast piercings. They were constantly rubbing up against his shirt and his heart-shaped locket. Picture Data, shirtless, squeezing his nipples in front of Picard and saying ""Yes, at first they were a bit shelly, but I've grown quite ACCUSTOMED to them"". That last bit should do it for you."
column5: Some hardcore monks have a state of mind that has become accustomed to their self-torture through piercing themselves.

column4: "At the meeting of butchers, in their narrow state of mind, they throw lame jokes around like, 'Oh hello, it's a pleasure to meat you', and find this rather pleasing."
column5: "Image : Data attending a meeting of the butchers union. As a joke to begin his speech he says, 'Its a pleasure to MEAT you all.' (thanx to Shibo & nestOr)."

column4: "When I am in a LAZY state of mind I use my left hand to play with my meat...it feels like someone else is doing it, which is good cause I'm to lazy to get a date."
column5: "When in a lazy state of mind, the things you need to do are left for next month."

column4: Humility is the state of mind of accepting the truth about yourself - both favorable and unfavorable. (tweaked version of Raichu's).
column5: Humility is a state of mind when you consider yourself in accordance with the truth (you neither boast nor demean yourself).

column4: Remorse is the state of mind where I feel bad for what I did while I was tired and emotional!
column5: "Tip: If you are confusing this keyword, remorse, with repent (#625) and regret/resentment (#1460), then note that rEMOrse contains EMOtion."

column4: Recollection is about bringing ideas back to your mind.
column5: Data's recollection powers are unparalled. He never loses a single idea.

column4: "Pining, yearn for... etc. Presumably for lost love. An easy one here, someone standing in the graveyard, placing an old valentine card amonst all the existing tributes."
column5: "Morticia and Gomez (of the “Addams Family”) are spending their Valentine's Day at the graveyard, pining for each other's affection."

column4: "Hawaii is a little drop of heaven nestled in the waters of the Pacific, most often visited by honeymooners and valentines. It was annexed to the U.S.A. in 1959, and more recently to Japan as well-- albeit only unofficially, and through private commercial holdings."
