Being that I live near the ocean, I see tourists and vacationers coming and going constantly on the bridge. Because the bridge is so long, it forms an arc to support the structural integrity. You can see that arc here."

column4: "The calligrapher's brush is moving down a column of a script, in rhythm with his meditation."
column5: The army COLUMN walked to the RHYTHM made by the drummer using a cool BRUSH like drum stick. Picturing the brush as a drum stick is not difficult if you've seen such a thing in jazz videos.

column4: "Before going all the way to the Boss in a Final Fantasy game, you should probably double back to save at a restore point."
column5: The column of soldiers has to double back to restore the peace in the village they just left.

column4: "To gain more knowledge of what's goin on in the world I'm reading column after column of articles in the newspapers, and it takes so much time I'm glued to it till nightbreak."
column5: Imagine fat people......they avoid going outside to exercise and stay glued to their TV set until nightbreak....so of course they gain weight.

column4: The line of viking soldiers is always accompanied by a horn mending specialist.
column5: "I'm going to accompany the horny girl to her room so I can ""mend"" her."

column4: The junior employee is always RUNNING around GOING here and there for his superiors.
column5: Junior is going to run the family business one day... 　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ト　生徒　せいと(student).

column4: "A line queued up outside the Buddhist temple, waiting to see the shrine on New Year's Day."
column5: The COLUMNS of this TEMPLE are a well-know meeting spot. You can always see someone WAITING there.

column4: "In Medieval Japan, going to see your lord was often a long journey."
column5: "The fellowship of the ring is on a long journey through the depths of Khaz Modan. Imagine they walk through the hall of pillars, with only light being from their own candlesticks that. Soon they will meet much more light than they would ever want to..."

column4: America seeks to GO and CORRECT other nations. But really what they do is subjugate them...
column5: To subjugate is to have somebody stand still and stiff as a column and behave one hundred percent correctly.

column4: Scientists recently measured the diameter of Earth by drilling a deep hole and dropping a line of thread off a humongous spool until it got to the other side.
column5: "Suggestion: Replace ""spool"" with ""toilet paper/roll"". Reasons: (1) Toilet paper/roll usually comes on a spool. (2) Toilet paper is used to clean the soil off your crotch. Story: Measure the diameter of a column (maybe Nelson's Column in London?) using a roll of toilet paper. Spool also appears in stalk (#715), suspicious (#716), lightly (#717), sutra (#1360)."

column4: What's the main difference between a he and a she? The he has a column covered in a pelt... a penis. Badum-ching.
column5: "The ultimate he-man is the Neanderthal cave man. His club is as big as a pillar (column), and he wears a ragged pelt as his only clothing. To remember the column, imagine the cave man resting the club vertically like a column when not in use."

column4: Japanese kamikaze pilots (and the American from Dr. Strangelove) are so devoted to their duty that they go with their missiles.
column5: "Imagine those poor saps in charge of nuclear silos, responsible for ICBMS, those towering column missiles. When the order comes they must decide whether to obey their concience or do their duty and damn the world to atomic annihilation."

column4: Hearkening back to the kanji for LISTEN... Benevolence is a good listener who is willing to go the distance to help.
column5: "In a rare act of benevolence, the Sparten column removes the needle from the cyclops's eye, and he repays them by eating their hearts."

column4: The taskmistress in a moment of weakness allowed the man's column to penetrate her. As punishment he was made to bring up their infant.
column5: "Ha! In this frame, a bunch of taskmasters are lined up to penetrate the kids they raise/bring up! I'm thinking of some priests and choir boys."

column4: "If you see a column of kings being marched up the mountain under a taskmaster's whip... indications are, there has been a coup."
column5: All indications are that the taskmaster's son is going to be king of the mountain soon …　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　チョウ 象徴　しょうちょう(symbol)…　　　　Pure Group:　懲888.

column4: "Penal servitude is served until indications show that one has had a change of heart (learned one's lesson). Easily confused with punish (#679) and penalty (#833). Concentrate on the reasons behind the penal system (""changing people's hearts"" here), instead of the penalty itself or the punishment (revenge) aspect. It may help to note that there's no sword, but a heart :-) (Note: 懲りる = learn from one's bad experiences)."
column5: Judge: You will serve a penal sentence until indications show you have a heart.

column4: The Column of 300 spartans were in a delicate situation. They had travelled in one line (using only their legs) to the mountain pass to face the fierce Persian task master.
column5: "Telling your taskmistress (wife) why you are going mountain climbing without her is a delicate situation... ""For one thing you have such beautiful legs and I don't want to risk injuring them honey""...　　　　　　RTK2:　ビ　微笑　びしょう(smile)　""delicate laugh""."

column4: "The boulevard of boulevards, the Champs Elysées, with the Arc de Triomphe covered in ivy to give the champions a heroes' welcome."
column5: Specifically... ivy boulevard... think hollywood & vine.

column4: "To maintain the social equilibrium in a future dystopian society, the brains of citizens are bound up (hypnotized). The government is using mental wave emitting statues shaped like St. Bernard's dogs put alongside the boulevards."
column5: "I think BALANCE is an easier keyword. I was walking down a busy French boulevard when between the rushing traffic I saw the wierdest thing. BALANCING on the central crash barrier was a St. Bernard dog, BALANCING a fish on its nose. As I looked closer, I realised it was a trick; it was holding the fish's tail in its teeth, and only pretending to BALANCE it. (keeps the position of the elements!)."

column4: "The first DRAFT of catcher in the rye was actually called ""catcher in the TALL WHEAT""...good thing they changed it. I read it in 高校."
column5: Aliens often draft their plans for invasion by cutting designs among the tall wheat.

column4: "Your earnings allow you to bring home your daily bread (made of wheat, naturally)."
column5: "Hmm, EARNINGS. Think of the popular saying ""Bringing HOME the bacon"". Here, EARNINGS is the picture ""Bringing HOME the bread(WHEAT) and the bacon (PIG)."

column4: "The extent to which some people will go to create 'wheat displays', or as some call them 'crop circles', is truly amazing."
column5: "The wheat crop has come in, and the mouth of the king is gobbling it all up. Everyone is waiting to see... to what extent will the king manage to eat it this year?"

column4: "Nobody likes the tax man, so here it is only fitting that the person who comes over to take some of your wheat is depicted here as a devil. Keep in mind that in feudal societies there was no kind of money to speak of, so taxes were paid by serfs in wheat to the devils who came over to keep them poor."
column5: This is an easy one. Taxes is like the devil taking away your hard earned wheat.

column4: Immature turkeys are stuffed with wheat to make it look bigger.
column5: I can't believe I brought you to the fanciest restaurant in town and you asked for turkey on wheat...how immature is that?!

column4: The first step to harmony is having enough wheat to feed every mouth in the world. Once we are all fed it is easier to get a long in harmony.
column5: "People who live in harmony with nature live in the country. they are yokels or hillbillys. See Billy-bob sitting on the porch in their denhim dungarees a sheaf of wheat, sticking from their mouth."

column4: "Picture the WHEAT field, filled with MANY, MANY stalks of WHEAT. Notice how they SHIFT like waves in the slightest breeze. When you hear SHIFT, just picture that scene."
column5: Many people are making the shift from white to whole wheat bread.

column4: An hourglass filled with wheat counts time. A few wheat seeds drop every second.
column5: I'll be with you soon... please wheat a few seconds.

column4: "In AUTUMN, the WHEAT looks the color of FIRE, meaning it's time to harvest it."
column5: Every autumn the wheat is set on fire to clear the way for next year's crop...

column4: "In AUTUMN, the farmer's HEART is in DISTRESS as to if he has enough crops. Even better, the farmer will experience great DISTRESS in his HEART if his WHEAT catches FIRE!"
column5: "Here we have distressed (think ""gloomy"") people with ""seasonal mood disorder"" during the autumn season. Hence ""autumn heart"" is distressed (gloomy)."

column4: "Warning sign: ""Private wheat, trespassers will be elbowed""."
column5: "I already know this as watashi, or ""I"". In order to associate the keyword of private, I'll think of this one as ""Private I"", like a detective."

column4: Think of REGULARITY in terms of bowel movements. Enough WHEAT in your diet will help your DROPS with improved REGULARITY.
column5: Eating plenty of wheat will improve regularity and help you lose weight.

column4: The prize at the bottom of a cereal box is invariably a secret decoder ring.
column5: A young couple meets in secret in the wheat field because their families are enemies. They cross their hearts and swear eternal - even if secret - love. Do not confuse with secrecy (#775).

column4: "Taking appellation to mean the act of naming, we have the little baby superman reclining in the space craft that landed in a wheat field. Mr. and Mrs. Kent look down and decide to call him Clark. (I also thought of Jesus but he was born in a barn full of hay not wheat)."
column5: "WHEAT that is RECLINING and LITTLE (small) can't get the APPELLATION ""quality wheat""."

column4: "In the middle ages there where only 2 ways for peasantry to make a profit. one by being a farmer, 2 to be a mercenary and live by the way of the sword."
column5: 1. Steal a bunch of wheat from a wheat field by cutting it down with your saber. 2. ????? 3. Profit!

column4: "The Japanese pear tree is the most profitable in the world, because it produces its fruit in pairs [sorry for the awful pun]."
column5: And a profit in a pear tree...12 days of christmas.

column4: The harvest of genetically modified crops is taken onboard the Greenpeace vessel (see the flower vessel in safeguard (#700)).
column5: Wheat is harvested; the grain (flower) is put into vessels for shipping.

column4: "The pilgrims only had wheat, so they asked the Indians to do them a favor and trade them for some ears of corn."
column5: "The ""ear of a plant"" is the seed-bearing spike of a cereal plant, such as corn. In other words, it is the part which feeds us. Hence -- ""the ear (of a plant) is the favor of the wheat""."

column4: The rice plant is common in Japan because all the wheat was eaten by vultures in the olden times.
column5: "It used to be that wheat was grown in Japan. However, this was often stolen by vultures, so in olden times, the gods gave the Japanese the rice plant."

column4: "If you focus the suns though a magnifying glass on to the bottom of a stalk of wheat it will start to smoulder and burn like a stick of incense. The weird thing is that it burns from the bottom upwards, hanging in the air as if my magic. Try it and see!"
column5: When the sun burns the wheat a smell of incense remains in the air.

column4: There's a season for planting wheat and there's mating season for having children.
column5: "Look at this adorable child with a bale of wheat on his head! He's playing Autumn in his school play the ""Four Seasons"". Aww...too cute! Perhaps we should light the wheat on fire to complete his Autumn costume. (I know, twisted...but I kept forgetting what was on his head)."

column4: "Female WHEAT farmers decide to create a COMMITTEE, which they fittingly name “The WHEAT WOMEN COMMITTEE.”."
column5: "At committe meetings, Japanese bureaucrats slurp ramen noodles off of naked women."

column4: "You spend three hours putting all of your wheat sale transaction records into Microsoft Excel, when suddenly it crashes, so you put your fist through the monitor."
column5: "A soviet-era poster for the 5-year plan shouts ""Excel"" and shows a fist clenching a sheaf of wheat. Wheat/Fist."

column4: "If you excel in the Mario Kart road, your movements are saved and you can race against yourself as a transparent racer. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xe8CkcrL-k4."
column5: "If you want to excel at driving in the roadway, it's better if your windows and windshield are transparent. Picture the drivers with opaque windshields all wrecked on the side of the road."

column4: "Word and Excel somehow manage to entice people to use them, despite their plethora of bugs."
column5: Think of the smooth talker who EXCELS at using WORDS to entice women (including married women if it makes it easier to remember).

column4: There are different cereals in different parts of the world. Japan has samurai cereal. Great Britain has Crowned Wheat ... the United States and Russia have Missile cereals.
column5: "The samurai crowns wheat as the best cereal, and blows all others up with missiles (he's a cereal killer)."

column4: Can also mean bacteria.....imagine the wheat pent in your fridge growing to the point where they resemble flowers.......I actually had something similar happen to onions...they grew footlong legs after about 2 or 3 years......OR just think of that Cowboy Bebop episode with the lobster in the fridge... :-).
column5: "Actually it means germs as in microorganisms. So for example, you have to keep wheat enclosed so it isn't exposed to other plants. That way it can't catch any germs (like fungi) from them."

column4: Stroke order: I like to think of the first two strokes as “chop sticks” with which one eats the rice. The rest then is the “tree” meaning “plant” in this contexct. also: USA.
column5: "Two drops of rice in a tree, simple."

column4: Parts of parts of parts of parts of rice... is flour. (Image: geishas patting their face with RICE flour to make it white. Not wheat flour...).
column5: "In the United States, part of every meal is made from flour."

column4: "This is another way of fortune telling -- throw sticky rice against the wall, and look for the message in whatever sticks."
column5: CONDI RICE was told by the FORTUNE TELLER that she will get STICKY...

column4: "A sage is using rice to fill up a vase, but as an exercise in patience, he's doing it grain by grain."
column5: There's a contest...whoever guesses the number of grains of rice in a vase wins.

column4: "Condy Rice is actually white, but she uses special cosmetics made from dirt she found in a cave to appear black - it's better for the political situation."
column5: Modern cosmetics are just the descendants of the old RICE flour and CAVE DIRT ('cause it's darker) used in the past.

column4: "The road that the USA is heading down is, well... let's just say that they're astray..."
column5: "If you go astray, just follow the rice you dropped along the road to find your way back."

column4: "In extremely chic restaurants, you have to pay 90 bucks for a bowl of rice."
column5: "Americans think that tattoos with Chinese characters are chic, but nine out of ten times they end up with something trivial tattooed on their arm, like rice."

column4: "Imagine Japanese army provisions like obentou boxes, always containing the same quantity of rice. (thanks darg_sama, emphasizing quantity and the nuance of food ""rations"", ""food supply"": the kanji also appears in ""military provisions"" and ""army rice"")."
column5: All Japanese provisions contain a certain quantity of rice... they eat it with just about every meal!

column4: "Chrysanthemum flower consists of many tiny petals, just like many rice grains bound up together."
column5: "[+astgt] Chrysanthemum is a terrorist orginization whose sole objective is to tie up Condi Rice. One day, Condi Rice is standing outside when a group of chrysanthemum agents swoop in from the sides, bound her up with chrysanthemum rope, and dash off. They leave a lone yellow chrysanthemum flower on top of the bound Condi Rice as a sign to let her discoverers know who committed this brave and noble act."

column4: "In the core of a nuclear reactor, scientists have discovered a way to get power from rice, by penting it in under high pressure. It's very dangerous, so they've trained a st. bernard dog to run things, he's adding more drops of rice as necessary."
column5: "奥さん　（おくさん) is a common way to say ""wife"". In the innermost core of the house, the bored pent up housewife drops her chores and consumes so much rice she becomes a very large housewife."

column4: "Young taskmaster is learning numbers by watching women haul sacks of rice past him. ""One... two... four! No, wrong! Go back, go back!""."
column5: Women toil in the rice fields carrying heavy sacks of rice to be numbered and counted by the taskmaster.

column4: "The young taskmaster (see number (#929)) uses a tree as a watchtower to get a better view of his rice-carrying women. ""I can seeeee you! One! Two! Three!""."
column5: "On the top of the woodmade watchtower we look for our enemies, who will come to steal our rice and our women."

column4: "Note this character means sort in the sense of what kind, I believe a better keyword would be ""variety"" and this character does appear in some dictionaries with the primary meaning as variety, my story: I'm in a Chinese restaurant and the waiter says ""What sort of rice would you like with your dog head?""."
column5: "Condi Rice is the SORT of person that would give HEADaches to a BIG DOG.....This story has been edited because of people reporting it. I like it better without ""aches"", but whatever works for you!"

column4: "LACQUER is a type of WATERY type of liquid used to protect items made from TREES, sort of an UMBRELLA of protection. So protective, you can carry around RICE in the LACQUERED, WOODEN product."
column5: Water is falling from a tree onto the umbrella underneath which is protecting the rice underneath it. But it's completely dry since the umbrella is lacquered.

column4: "Here we have the requirements to be counted among the ranks of the noble Esq. You must posses a forested estate, herds of sheep, and granary full of grains of rice."
column5: "This is -Sama, a generic high term of respect for someone in an unusual profession. If you met a person that created a wooden sheep that was squeezing a single grain of rice out of its ass, you'd definitely call that person -sama. Because that is impressive."

column4: "Enemy: ""Any final requests?"" // MacGyver: ""Just an arrowhead and some grains of rice."" (MacGyver then throws the grains of rice at the enemy and uses the arrowhead to cut his hands free from the rope.)."
column5: Robin Hood holds his rich victim at arrowpoint and kindly requests that he hands over his grains of rice.

column4: "Someone files a request to see the family jewels and, to their surprise, you show them your balls!"
column5: The KING REQUESTS your presence at the ball ... game.

column4: "Like in the biblical sense, someone looks skyward and makes a request for salvation from this horrible taskmaster..."
column5: For salvation you have to request forgiveness from God (the ultimate taskmaster).

column4: Pandas like to eat bamboo. I'm using panda as the primitive name when it fits the story. ^__^.
column5: "Two reclining victims impaled on bamboo spheres...　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　チク　松竹梅　しょうちくばい(pine, bamboo, plum)."

column4: "When the people tried to build a tower of bamboo to reach the heavens, the gods just laughed and laughed."
column5: That Panda is in bamboo heaven! Just look at him laugh!

column4: "The bamboo vase was beautifully crafted, but the tourist didn't know what it was and wore it as a little bamboo hat."
column5: "The bamboo part is easy. Just remember that this kanji refers to those particular bamboo hats that are worn primarily by Buddhist monks, who always seem to stand outside of train stations, collecting alms."

column4: The bamboo generation smokes bamboo grass.
column5: "“One of the most attractive aspects of bamboo is that it is a renewable resource; it takes less than a year for a stalk to reach maturity, compared to the decades for most trees, whether needle or broadleaf.” -- Mnemonic : ""bamboo grass is the next bamboo generation""."

column4: "Muscle is part of the body that gives strength, and can be both supple and tense like the bamboo."
column5: Lifting BAMBOO STICKS is an old way for your BODY to put on lots of MUSCLE.

column4: The best kind of BOX is made from BAMBOO sticks that are INTER-laced to make it air tight. Just picture such a box and you've mastered this kanji.
column5: I think of a box made of inter-locking of bamboo strips.

column4: Bamboo is the best material from which to make a brush if you want it to be a writing brush.
column5: Bamboo would make an excellent writing brush as the ink could flow through the hollow center like an ink pen... 　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ヒツ　鉛筆　えんぴつ(lead pencil).

column4: "Seriously, all BAMBOO sticks look the SAME, just long CYLINDERS. Should the story be more complicated?"
column5: "Fully-grown bamboo consists of a number of cylinder-like sections, all exactly the same."

column4: "The Bamboo Buddhist Temple has bamboo buddhas, bamboo buildings, bamboo benches, bamboo beds, bamboo bowls, etc. etc. etc."
column5: """So what'd you see in Japan?"" - ""Bamboo, temples...etc.""."

column4: "Before the time of digital calculators, people used old school calculators made of bamboo (abacus). It's not as easy as a calculator, but you don't need any batteries either. All you need are your eyes and your two hands."
column5: "Tip : you may see this as an Abacus, which is used to calculate. This particular ancient chinese Abacus has eyeballs in place of beads, and its frame is made of bamboo. You'd be amazed at how fast people can calculate with this, especially if they can use both hands at once to move the ... eyeballs."

column4: "The solution to this puzzle is, like the match stick game, to make the bamboo pieces fit together."
column5: For the frustrated housewife the solution came in form of a BAMBOO stick that FITS her well.

column4: "The temples in kyoto belt bamboo around trees in a scheme to protect them from the huge number of tourists. (true story)-----------対策　　たいさく　　measure, countermeasure."
column5: (Elaboration of jameserb's story:) A clever scheme from Wile E Coyote -- he ties one of those rubber belts to some trees and uses it to launch a bamboo spear at the roadrunner...

column4: "Note : the keyword is not a verb, think of a record book. This acupuncturist who uses bamboo in place of flowers to dilute water into his patients (see frame 227), managed somehow to appear on the register of acupuncturists. Chances are, he won't stay on the register for long. My image is close to that of gorgon's story."
column5: This doctor dilutes (see 227) his patients with bamboo stalks rather than the flowers of a standard diluting acupuncturist hence he needs to be on the Bamboo Accumpunturist Diltuers (BAD) register. Pumping that much water into a body can be dangerous; see the huge bamboo stems with gallons of water sloshing in and out of the patient.

column4: "Bamboo crafting is a mediocre substitute for wood when you are building or fabricating a house. While it may look good and might attract a chick (ちく) or two, the kids'll (きず) just tear it to pieces as its not sturdy enough."
column5: A bamboo fabrication is a mediocre substitute for wood.

column4: "Behold Mister T (of ""A-Team"" fame)! I chose Mr.T because he's sure to make amusing stories. He is a very versatile character since he's both the big, tough guy and the “moralistic” person, telling kids not “to do drugs or alcohol”. He is easy to imagine, the heavy gold chains are probably the most prominent feature of the character. And last but not least you can always pepper your story with the famous line “I pity da foo!” * Fittingly, on the left side of the kanji, it looks like a “T”."
column5: "[I appreciate some people's occasional habit of using P for person in shared stories. That makes it easier to substitute Mr. T, Captain Picard, or whomever else a student is using as person.]."

column4: "Mr T's assistant is on his left. Why? Because Mr T has this bad habit of suddenly extending his right arm (what with all the boxing that he did), and his assistant got inadvertently punched in the face more than once (ouch). So now his assistant is always to his left side, much safer - ""Stay on my left, foo!""."
column5: "On your right is your ""right-hand man"" that you credit for all your success....on the left...... is your assistant who does all the grunt work and gets no credit for anything..."

column4: "However drunk Mr T is when he comes back to his place, he always get up at nightbreak. “I pity da foo who gets up after nightbreak !”, says Mr. T."
column5: "MR.T leads a busy life, however he always makes sure to be in bed by NIGHTBREAK, however much he might want to stay up watching A-Team re-runs."

column4: When Mr T shows people round his dwelling he takes a big candlestick (with a candle in it!) so that the light shows off his collection of bling bling jewellery.
column5: "Mister T dwells in a big brass candlestick, the flame of which serves as a beacon for the boats in the nearby harbour. Sometimes in the morning, Mister T has to clear the wax that has landed and solidified in front of the door."

column4: Mr T ranks first position in the stand-up competition (doing knee flexions). Just picture him doing hundreds of these while the rest of the participants are already completely exhausted after a mere hundred.
column5: Rank A person's standing.

column4: "When negotiating a hostage situation, Mr. T acted as the go-between, or person in the middle, for law enforcement and the terrorist."
column5: Go-between The person in the middle.

column4: "Mister T works out his body (body-building), using two piles of books (i.e. an exercise that can be done at home with two chairs, similar to push-ups but working mostly the shoulders, trapezius and triceps)."
column5: Mr. T works out his body then rips a book apart to test is body. His favorite to destroy is Dianetics.

column4: "Mr. T ventured out into a remote area to visit with his wise, old taskmaster who must use a walking stick to get around and originally gave Mr. T the heart to fight crime for the good of the community."
column5: "Yoda, the Jedi with the walking stick who was a hard taskmaster for Luke but who had a big heart, was permanently exiled on the remote planet Dagobah."

column4: "Note: this kanji refers to event or case. Current Affair headline: Mr. T has affair with cow. ""It's only animal 'man' enough for me""."
column5: "I'm having a hard time keep straight just which animal Mr. T is having an affair with. chamcham's story made me realize that Mr. T is not having an ""affair"", he's having an ""heifair."" Get it?"

column4: "Back in the day, a person who stands beside a samurai is usually attending to them or working for them."
column5: "[+fuaburisu] Mr T attends to Tom Cruise in the Last Samurai, who is doing hara-kiri. Imagine Tom Cruise outside in the final scene, stabbing his knife into his stomach, while Mr T looks patiently on. ""I pity da foo....no, really.""."

column4: "It's one or the other: fight Mr. T, or be thrown into the scorpion pit."
column5: Old latin saying: homo hominis scorpio (people are scorpions to other people).

column4: "Don't need a silly story for this one: prostration is when a person puts themselves in a low position like a dog, as an extreme gesture of humility."
column5: "Mr T has beaten up the chihuahua, who lies prostrated in front of him. ""Now,"" Mr T says, ""I quiero some Taco Bell!""."

column4: "Mister T transmits a message with rising clouds (smoke) signals, to a nearby American Indian tribe. The smoke signals spell : ""I p-i-t-y y-o-u f-o-o !""."
column5: "Hanging one-handed under Cloud City, the Jedi-in-training Luke, uses the force to transmit his distress to Leia."

column4: "Mr. T says, ""I ain't afraid o' no foo! I'll give anyone an elbow to the face, I don't care if it's Buddha himself!""."
column5: Buddha is a person who always seems to have his elbows bent.

column4: Mr T resting by a tree.
column5: "Chuck norris rests againsts the tree, but wait, no... the tree rests and stands against him."

column4: "Mr. T was offered a job in the Iraq Provisional Authority, but he turned it down, because he's anti-war. ""I pity da fool thinks this sand pit worth invadin' when our schools be in such sad shape!""."
column5: "Mr. T is anti anything provisional. ""I pity da foo' who's so indecisive that he can't make nothin' permanent""."

column4: "If Mr T was white I am sure he would have been commander in chief of the USA, he just the sort of clown Americans love to vote for. (NB: I tried with the indian chief motif but kept adding feathers by mistake)."
column5: "Mr T was originally supposed to be the chief of the A-Team, but then the producers realized that America didn't want to see a Black guy as the chief of a prime-time TV show. So here, we see Mr T doing a bunch of cocaine, and then spreading it all over his face to look white, and trying out for the part of Hannibal. The directors were so impressed that they let him stunt double for Hannibal in a few episodes. OR, Mr T chiefin' on some crack cocaine. You make the call."

column4: "Mr. T says, ""Don't be like them valley girls, always speaking vulgar language and acting all vulgar! They ain't nothing but foos!""."
column5: "Mr T meets the vulgar (common) people of the valley and participates in the vulgar customs (folkways). Looking at the vulgar (common) people, Mr T says - “I pity you foo!”."

column4: "Mr. T has faith in the Word of God. (Image: Mr. T kneeling and prayering in front of a bible. ""Pity me, fool."")."
column5: Faith is believing that a person will be true to his word.

column4: "Mr T wants to go to an excellent school, so he enrolls in Harvard, an ivy-league school."
column5: "Bill and Ted are walking through medieval Europe when they see a humongous square jewel. ""Excellent!"" they both yell. But only after grabbing it do they realize it is chained to the neck of Mr. T, who grimaces angrily at them. ""Bogus!"" they cry, and totally run away."

column4: Mr T is reliant (depends on) on his garment (the gold chains).
column5: Mr. T. is so self-reliant he even makes his own garments.

column4: "Mr T shows the example to the kids, and stays in the file (at supermarket, ...). “I pity da foo who does not follow my example !”."
column5: "When Mr. T. wants to make an example out of a group of people, he lines them up all single file and knocks them all out with one punch!"

column3: individual;counter for articles and ilitary units
column4: "This keyword gave me trouble, I could write the kanji from memory but could not remember the keyword the other way around. In such case the dictionary definition can be helpful : ""Middle English, single, indivisible"". Here we have Mr. T. who is so hardened (all the body workout he's had) that he became in-dividual, that is, in-divisible. ""I pity da foo who can be divided into smaller units.""."
column5: "Mr. T insists that people be individual. He appears on television, saying, ""Being an individual is hard! But you gotta do it! Harden yourself, and be individual!""."

column4: "Mr. T in a public service announcement yells, ""I'm healthy because every day I build a food pyramid, foo!""."
column5: """Mr.T, sir, how do you stay so healthy?"" I asked. ""Simple, foo,"" he answered, ""you gotta build the body up by bodybuilding!""."

column4: Mr. T rulezzz! I am on his side!
column5: "Chuck Norris's rules are easy to live by, just be on his side."

column4: Mr. T infiltrates the secret samurai Buddhist temple as a waiter with a tray of green tea. (Careful: attend (#960)).
column5: "Remember the kanji for wait, 待. Well, now we have a waiter, and he's dropped a dish. See: 侍! 待 crash 侍."

column4: """Halt fool"" - Mr T acting as a bouncer at the pavillion."
column5: "Mister T makes a halt at the African pavilion at the World's Fair. He eats all the snacks on offer, and chats up the ladies - ""“I pity da foo who does not halt by your pavilion, it's the best !""."

column4: "Mr. T (person) tells the used car salesman to tell him the real price straight away, and when he doesn't he throws him through the windshield."
column5: "Mr. T is shopping for new chains. He knows what he wants and money isn't an issue. ""Cut the jibba-jabba, tell me the price, straightaway!""."

column4: "Mr T downloads an emulator so that he can play his favorite game, Pokemon. He plays for a different reason, though - he hates to see them poor little foos in the ball so he spends his entire time setting them free."
column5: "The black slave who was set free (#496) decides to emulate Mr. T, his role model. He uses his compass to head to Cali to start anew."

column4: "The A-Team are planning to overthrow the government. However, they can't do a damn thing until Mr T arrives."
column5: "In Return of the Jedi, after a climactic light sabre battle, Luke and Vader overthrow the emporer (literally throwing him over the balcony)."

column4: "Mr. T is a terrible spy. He walks around upright. ""Why should I hide?! I've got nothing to be ashamed of!""."
column5: "NOTE: The second primitive is upright, not eminent. There is an error in the book."

column4: "Mr. T and the artist formerly known as Prince, who by the way is a buddhist, want to form a new heavy metal band. Instead of ""Judas Priest"" they will be called ""Buddhist Priest""."
column5: "While a waiter at the Buddhist temple (see FRAME 976), Mr T increases in wisdom and becomes a Buddhist priest."

column4: Mr. T has an clear idea of what he would do if he ever got hundred million dollar. (I guess it would be a enormous gold chain !).
column5: "Mr. T's bright idea is to get a hundred million kids to vow not to use drugs. ""C'mon, foo! Sign the paper!""."

column4: Mr. T is the master of ceremonies because he is a righteous dude.
column5: "Mr. T was briefly a rapper, that is an M.C., that is a master of CEREMONIES (the origin of the phrase). But he sang only RIGHTEOUS songs, no cursing or anything like that. (all true: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7_rBidCkJxo )."

column4: "Mr. T says, ""This ain't no prize, foo! This is reparations for slavery!""."
column5: "NOTE: do not confuse with compensation (#476)賠. However, 賠 is always used in conjunction 賠償... But 償 is used in various other compounds. Mr. T sold all his jewelry to give as reparations to slave families. The governent tried to honor his charity by giving him a prize, but it was a shitty outhouse filled with clams."

column4: A HERMIT is a PERSON who lives in the MOUNTAINS.
column5: "After living as an hermit (recluse) for a while in the mountains, Mister T becomes an immortal mountain fairy (""fairy"" is another meaning of this kanji)."

column4: "And now a word from our sponsor. We see Mr. T, doing a sort of George Foreman thing, grilling Mountain Turkeys. ""I pity da foo who don't have a Mr. T grill!""."
column5: "Mister T sponsors a meeting in the mountains (he's an hermit), talking over a megaphone “I pity da foo who does not come to my event !”. The old turkey comes, and Mister T catches it and cooks it for dinner, muahaha."

column4: The beginning of humanity required at least TWO people. Mr. T and Mrs. T!
column5: Mr. T shows his humanity by giving two bucks to every homeless person he sees.

column4: Mr. T has scorn for every fool.
column5: People full of scorn tend to hate every person (including themselves).

column4: Mr. T uses the officer as a punching bag.
column5: "Of course Mr. T will tell a police officer if he catches someone using drugs, foo!"

column4: "Mr. T loves the convenience of the new konbini. Not only does it stay open even if it grows late, they have brand new toilets, and a Post Office!"
column5: "Mr. T takes a dump on the floor of a convenience store. Well, it was growing late and he couldn't wait. He pities the fool who will have to clean it up!"

column4: Mr. T keeps his double muzzled ... he wants all the glory.
column5: "Mr T, like many holywood stars, has a butt double who is used only for scenes where T's buttocks are exposed (he has issues with bearing his behind). The butt double has no speaking parts - he is muzzled. Of course T himself isn't he's rambling on about pity and foo."

column4: "The A-Team is on a mission to help Hamlet. With uncharacteristic tenderness, Mr. T consoles the melancholy Hamlet. ""No, I really DO pity the poor foo. There, there little guy...take my hanky"". (Careful: benevolence (#885)."
column5: Someone can't be melancholy for long if just one person treats them with a little tenderness.

column4: "At a fiesta, Mr. T tries to knock down a large pinata, but in his overly enthusiastic swings to get ""the sucka,"" he actually FELLS the tree the piñata is hanging from, crushing some party goers. “I pity da fools who got crushed by my FELLED tree!”."
column5: Mr T at the fiesta fell over blind drunk.

column4: The Toyoko Inn can house 100 people or 1 Mr. T.
column5: "The inn is like a big house that can addomodate a hundred persons. Only this time, there's just Mister T and he's booked all the rooms!"

column4: "Mr. T cannot believe the reclining piggy bank won't give up. He has cut off its legs one by one until it cannot stand, yet, despite being rendered almost completely useless it won't surrender. “It's just a flesh wound!” the reclining piggy bank yells."
column5: Mr. T gets wounded by reclining on his piggy bank.

column4: "Mr. T opens his mouth from the top of the tree saying ""I pitty da foo who don't protect the trees!""."
column5: Tip: Heisig later combines mouth and tree into 呆 dumbfounded (#2181). Story: Your person (Mr. T. or whoever) is dumbfounded when told to protect the bad guys rather than fight them.

column4: "Mr. T is praised for his protecting of the trees by being given a top hat and scarf which he wears over his mohawk and chains, respectively."
column5: "An old lady puts a top hat and scarf on her poodle and praises him for how cute he is. The dog thinks, ""Someone protect me from this psycho!""...　RTK2:　ホウ　過褒　かほう(excessive praise)."

column4: My wise person says greatness does not come from wearing shades (sunglasses) but from planting trees to shade everyone.
column5: "Mr T stands in front of you, his greatness radiating out from him so brightly. You need to put on your sunglasses and hide behind a tree to even talk to the guy. ""Recognise, foo!""."

column4: "賀 TO EVERYONE WHO MADE IT TO 千 kanji!! Remember, after this, you'll be 読ing japanese novels, the news, and the internet like a native. 吉 to ALL of you in your amazing japanese 往. :)."
column5: "If a PERSON ADHERES to something, they stick to it like GLUE."

column4: "I dropped my token down the drain, so I used a piece of bamboo with chewing gum on the end to retrieve it."
column5: "At the arcade, Mr. T adheres a bamboo rod to his token so that he can put it in the machine and pull it out repeatedly."

column4: "A municipality, like any type of government, adheres to having caves for offices (see government office (#591))."
column5: "Even if a municipality is in a cave, you have to adhere to its policies."

column4: It is always Mr. T's responsibility to be the porter and carry around everyone's luggage because he's so strong.
column5: "In pregnancy (#507), the woman was the porter for the first nine months. Now, as a new father, Mr.T is assuming all the RESPONSIBILITIES that comes with it. Can't you just see him here as the new porter, wearing a harness with a his little dude (who already has a little matching mohawk)?"

column4: It's your own responsibility to pay the bus fare with the correct number of shells/money.
column5: "In Japan they have automatic ticket gates so you cant easily cheat on your train fare. In England however the ticket gates are fairly open. It is a different kind of system. In England you are given the RESPONSIBILITY to put in the right amount of MONEY, but if you are caught cheating, the fines are stiff and you feel like a real CHINCHIN. ""un.CHIN""."

column4: """Mister T substitutes an arrow for a toothpick"" -- The keyword meaning is to replace something with something else, to act for another, to represent. It's best to stick to the first meaning, because the last two are very close to ""mediator"" which will come in frame 1761. The idea here is that the arrow is not a toothpick, neither it is changed into one, but it can substitute for one."
column5: Mr. T shot the substitute teacher with an arrow.

column4: A sack is an easy substitute for a garment.
column5: "A worker who was recently sacked from his job, is wearing a sack of potatoes as a substitute garment (naked otherwise), in some kind of protest. The kanji is close to frame 1547 ""bag"", and although the later really refers to a ""straw sack"", I use the image of a sack of potatoes here, and that of a ""plastic bag"" for frame 1547. The keywords would have been better swapped in my opinion, but the relevancy is not so important at this point (see notes of Lesson 31 in the book)."

column4: "In order for the bank to lend you money, you need to put up some sort of collateral as a substitute for the money."
column5: The poor substitute teacher asks the class to lend him some money for the bus fare home.

column4: "Referring to a scene in the movie ""The Matrix"" where a girl bends a spoon with the power of her mind alone, I imagine Mister T who changes a spoon into something else (maybe the waiter forgot to bring knives or forks). Note: as a primitive, it can help to use the image of ""spare change"", this can help you keep it distinct from other similar kanji such as ""shape"" or ""turn into""."
column5: Mr. T reaches into his wallet for some spare change but it has all changed into spoons.

column4: The flowers change with the seasons.
column5: "The flower is the essence of transience. So, the conceptual flower involves both the concept of flower plus change."

column4: Freight is the shells (money) paid to change the location of something big. Don't confuse with the similar 賃 fare (#1004).
column5: "This is a freight train that runs on spare change. Imagine getting on the freight train with a bunch of spare change. You put in some change and it starts up...goes for a few minutes, then starts to slow down. You look at the slot..there's actually a slot for spare change and one for regular shells. Your call, but it seems to prefer spare change over shells."

column4: Mr. T gave a girl some change to lean over and give him head.
column5: Leaning over changes the position of the head...　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ケイ　傾向　けいこう(tendency).

column4: "What can Mr T do? 'You mean: what can't MR T do, you fool'."
column5: What can't Mr. T not do?

column4: "TSA guard: What's in the baggage?! It's just flowers, I swear!"
column5: "Your girlfriend arrives at the airport. You give her flowers, but she brushes you off and says ""here, carry my BAGGAGE."" Dumbfounded at her rudeness, you say, ""what?""."

column4: "The entire town wants to get rid of legal prostitutes, but the sagacious Mr T realizes that they are a benefit to the economy and society. So he lets the sa-geishas stay."
column5: "(re: sweetneet) Since he is not very sagacious, Mr. T failed his driver's license and now needs to resort to his walking legs to get around."

column4: "In Japan, the emperor is a bystander - he stands on his crown but can't really affect the direction of the country. (thx shimouma)."
column5: "Mr. T is in the street, standing up, wearing an golden crown and a compass in his hand... he's asking the bystander if they know how to get to buckingham palace (!)."

column4: Note: this is the ひさ in ひさしぶり . Long time no see mummy! (A bound up person).
column5: "This is a picture of a person bowing ""long time no see!""."

column4: Using a TOP HAT to make FURROWS in the RICE FIELD takes a LONG TIME!
column5: A mummy tries to furrow his brow but realizes that he's got no head - just a brain with a top-hat on it. So he furrows his brain. [trigger: furrow your brain].

column4: "A person pent in is obviously captured. Imagine a man put inside a wooden box, his evil capturers waiting for ransom money."
column5: Mr. T can't be captured. This kanji is lying.

column4: "Mr. T's new belt is huge! When he's inside it, his feet no longer touch the ground!"
column5: "How is a person ever supposed to get inside that girl when she's wearing such a huge chastity belt? I guess that's kinda the point, eh?"

column4: "In this third class flight, the seatbelts are so bad that with the slightest turbulence all the persons hit the ceiling. (it's almost pictographic here!)."
column5: But third class is so small Mr. T's head hits the celing.

column4: Half Way!!!!
column5: "This is a ""design"" as in a ""pattern"", not a verb as in ""to design"". The tree grain design was too expensive for the third class airline to use for the panelling. They just painted it."

column4: Here we are looking at an x-ray of a cannibal whose insides are full on people-meat.
column5: "A person's inside - fleshy, raw, pink, meat."

column4: The rotting meat adheres to the cave walls.
column5: Smaller municipalities are well known for filling their budgets with pork (meat). Thats why they are also well known for being rotten.

column4: CONGRATULATIONS YOU'RE HALFWAY THERE!!!! =).
column5: "Coal mine (cave); tea break time; the assembly line stops and everyone sit or squat on the dirt floor, in a long line, to rest."

column4: "Ph.D graduation for assembly line of doctors(needles) with the cap and tassel(top hat). It took them 10 years (Bachelor's, Masters, PhD) to get there.... :-p."
column5: "When you graduate, you wear a hat and graduate in an assembly line while your parents sit on pins and needles because it will take ten years to pay off those loans."

column4: "There are two assembly lines at the umbrella factory. One is responsible for making the top of the umbrella, and the other for making the handle. The two lines cross at the end, where one man tries frantically to jam the sets of parts together."
column5: FOUR PERSONS can fit under this UMBRELLA if they are thin as a NEEDLE.

column4: """Dude! What happened to your arm! It's all bound up!"" ""Yeah man, it's a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!""."
column5: """Dude! What happened to your arm! It's all bound up!"" ""Yeah man, it's a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!"" ""You'll never be able to use your dagger now!"" (adapted from ergerg)."

column3: by means of;because;in view of;compared with
column4: "A man earns his living by means of the plow. I imagine a sweating man dragging a bronze-age ""ard"" behind him as he plows his field himself, too poor to afford an ox."
column5: Mr T now makes a living by means of a plow/hoe and the sweat he puts into it.

column4: Mr. T finds that living by means of dragging a plow is similar to slavery.
column5: A Mr T impersonator is becoming similarer (more like) by means of plastic surgery. The process is painful and his face is all bound up in bandages as the surgery heals.

column4: "Mr. T furiously works a puzzle in an attempt to join Mensa, the high-IQ society."
column5: """Why do I gotta join these two puzzle pieces? I ain't got time for joining no jigsaw-jabba!"" Mr. T apparently gets a severe case of crankypants when doing puzzles."

column4: "Horror scene: Hanging from the ceiling, a plough and fishhook dripping with blood down onto the tiled bathroom floor."
column5: "[true stroke order] First draw T for Tile, which then becomes I. Then draw an 'L' fish hook with a dash in the middle to make a mediocre 'e' that few can see.//ガ wa3 와 (wa)."

column4: A flower pot that has been dropped on the floor is like a puzzle of ceramic tiles to glue together.
column5: To solve this puzzle all you need is to put the flower pot on top of the proper tile. (cue secrets tune from Zelda).

column4: "This Shinto shrine is built with human spines. Have you ever seen the ossuary in Sedlec, near Kutna Hora in Czech Republic ? It is a small church entirely decorated with human bones. Do a web search for ""sedlec ossuary"", it's quite a sight."
column5: "A friend of mine made up a rhyme for this one: ""house with a spine, Shinto shrine""!"

column4: The schoolhouse is the backbone of a foundation that will allow you to find a good occupation.
column5: "During the German occupation, this Nazi officer's occupation was to manage schools that were requisitioned for training the children of the Aryan race to stand proud with an erect spine (mnemonic : ""the occupation's spine schools""). Kanji meanings : to manage, to conduct (business), and also ""barracks; camp; encapment"". This story should help avoid confusion with post (#824) and employ (#1083). The military occupation theme hints to the secondary meaning, e.g. 営倉 ""detention barracks""."

column4: "Imagine a priest's teaching: ""To achieve virtue one must first submit himself as a sheep to God's flock, rejecting the horns of Satan and resisting the mouth of Hell."
column5: "To be virtuous, a good rule to follow is to put your sheepishness (discretion) over your horns (anger) before using your mouth. In other words, ""discretion is the better part of virtue""."

column4: A horse wears a pair of sunglasses with one lens popped out after a particularly raucous celebration to ring in the New Year.
column5: "A horse wears a monocle for New Years to appear dignified for the year of the horse. ――one lens = monocle, you will encounter this again in kanji like descend (#1308)."

column4: "Actually, the lower-right primitive isn't quite ""walking legs."" It's a little more like ""evening"" with an extra stroke across it (look up the stroke order). So, it helps me to see this kanji for night as: evening plus an extra stroke representing the tuxedo tails to match the top hat which my special person is wearing out on the town..."
column5: "Here we have Mister T sleepwalking, wearing a top hat as if he was the ambassador of the night, walking, and walking and walking on his tired walking legs, until he drops (back into his bed)."

column4: A wet dream........water fluid that comes out at night....
column5: "I imagined some kind of liquid (water) that was discovered on another planet. It solidifes during the day, and becomes fluid only at night, in the absence of light. The question is, could any lifeforms thrive in there ?"

column4: There's already King of the Hill. This is Queen of the Hillock. It's Ms. Piggy sitting on top of a mound of soil in her crown.
column5: The crowned sow (we met her in overpowering) is standing atop her little mound of earth - hillock - the undisputed champeen of all the pigsty.

column3: cash;bad habit;humble prefix;gift;Shinto offerings of cloth;rope;cut paper
column4: A counterfeiter is using a shredder to shred a towel in order to print up some cash (he needs some rag paper) .
column5: "In order to create some cash, first you feed a towel through a shredder to get the raw materials. (""Paper"" money isn't plain paper; it's mostly linen.)."

column4: The Bush administration taskmasters hid their abuse of power by shredding documents as fast as they could using both hands....　　　　　RTK2: 　ヘイ　弊害　へいがい(abuse)...　　　Pure Group:　幣1041.
column5: "You’ve heard of Edward Scissor hands? Well this is Medward Shredder Hands. Instead of nicely trimming your shrubs, he uses his TWO SHREDDER equipped HANDS to ABUSE your plants by shredding them into wood chips."

column4: Think yelp when you hear yell to help dinstinguish this from shout (1508). I think of the sounds that would come from the mouths of the 4 dogs if they were bound up together. I'm imagining lots of yelping.
column5: "Yell? You mean, Old Yeller. Here, we see four St Bernard dogs all yelling for a chance to play a part in Old Yeller. They're so loud that you have to bound them, and their mouths, up."

column4: "After months of practice, you finally managed to teach a nice trick to your sled-pulling four bound up St. Bernard dogs: one snap of your fingers and they interchange their positions."
column5: "On the snap of your fingers, the four St. Bernard dogs bound up interchange places."

column4: "I have created the element ""old camera"" out of the left side of the kanji: from the subject's point of view, the light is captured by one mouth (the lens). The photographer is under a big hood, we only see his legs, and he is holding a spike in his right hand, which is the shutter release. Now, at the time the photographer takes the photo, a little insect is flying near the flash. The flash is so powerful that the insect is burnt and dissolves in the air."
column5: "I've seen this crazy thing with only one mouth that can dissolve up to 4 nails and an insect at the same time. Sweet! (It's a venus flytrap, btw)."

column4: "Under their banner, volunteers are requesting alms for scorpion sting victims."
column5: """ALMS for the poor"" cries the beggar under his tattered BANNER. An evil bastard instead drops a SCORPION into his begging bowl."

column4: "A merry-go-round with a big banner on top and below a veritable zoo of bakelite animals on poles in perpertual rotation accompanied by silly music. Giraffes, elephants, zebras, rhinos..."
column5: "Don't confuse with revolve or axis! Think of rotation as a rotation of animals in the zoo - some are on display (in rotation), some are in cages in the back (out of rotation). The ones currently in rotation (on display) are advertised with a large banner."

column4: The BANNER warns that CHILDREN PLAY on the ROAD.
column5: "There is always a stupid banner talking about children at play near the road. They mean ""drive slowly"", but it sounds like its slow(stupid) children that are at play."

column4: "The boat starts to leave on it's trip across the Atlantic. Underneath a huge banner that spans the width of the ship and says ""Bon Voyage"", the people wave their rags signalling a safe journey for all on board the Titanic."
column5: "After a long long trip, what once was a proud beautiful banner, we had nothing more than a simple rag remaining."

column4: This kanji is NOT a piglett.
column5: "The butcher is standing over the piglet. ""This is a piglet...(cuts of head)...NOT!""."

column4: "The cow's ""thing"" is tied in a knot! ouch."
column5: A cow is not a thing. Its an animal. If you study japanese you know that living beings and things are discerned from each other with the verbs iru and aru.

column4: The sun is not an easy place to get to.
column5: "Under the sun, it is easy to untie a knot. Under a pitch-dark sky, it is knot so easy."

column4: A grant is easy money.
column5: "Do you want free shells from the government? It's easy with my new book, ""How to Get a Free Grant from the Government!"" Call today!"

column4: "Animals use their urine to mark their territory. So for them, their body water works as a flag denoting their ""country"" (why bother? we all know which story you are going to pick)."
column5: "Someone is pissing on the American flag, but since the urine is clear it looks like water."

column4: "Red cross nuns sit in a tent under the red cross flag, spooning out food to the hungry."
column5: A nun sits in protests under an American flag.

column4: TV gets weirder and weirder... Now they're doing mud wrestling shows with nuns splashing around in the water. What will they think of next?
column5: "Water monks live in a den, but water nuns live in the MUD."

column4: "[fence; wall; (kokuji)] A fence separates one soil from the other. On a large scale, large pieces of soils in the world have a virtual fence called nation. Picture a world map where all countries have their soil with one color, their national flag as the legend and a fence on the borders... don't you think it looks like a giant puzzle?"
column5: "Why the Earth has to be fenced off and flags used to represent each ""country"" is a puzzle to me - we're all just monkeys on a big rock spinning round the Sun!"

column4: "NOTE: The most common use is in はく, meaning to put on footgear, rather than actual footgear itself. STORY: You are asleep in camp when you are woken up with news that the FLAG has fallen to the enemy. You quickly PUT ON YOUR FOOTGEAR and run off to RESTORE the FLAG."
column5: You should never use a flag as a shoeshine cloth to restore your footgear.

column4: Flag at the climax (highest point) of a castle roof.
column5: "A couple climaxing on the roof, draped in the American flag. The neighbors are mortified and call the landlady..."

column4: Fingers gripping the roof as your about to fall to your death. Think of an action scene in some movie.
column5: "(This is the にぎ of sushi). A sushi chef climaxes into a rice ball, wraps it in an American flag, and grips is firm with his fingers to form the ""Fuck You America Onigiri.""."

column4: "When yielding, soldiers raise the white flag before exiting from the trenches."
column5: "If you live in Japan, you are only too familiar with the helpful little man who assists you in getting out of every parking lot or parking garage, standing at the exit, waving his flag to make traffic yield to you."

column4: "If you dig with your fingers hard enough, soil eventually yields."
column5: "When you dig, you'd better hope that whatever you're digging into yields to your fingers. If not, you're bound to lose some nails."

column4: "(See dig (#1061)). When soil finally yielded thanks to your digging efforts, what you have is a ditch."
column5: "Ditch / trench. The yielding army abandons it's patch of soil, leaving behind a landscape of ditchs and trenches. Trench warfare."

column4: A humongous American flag in Florida marks the place where all the old people reside.
column5: "It is an old tradition that people plant a flag on places where decide to reside; this tradition still goes on: Antarctica, the moon: flags all over the place! cf. set (#1064)."

column4: "The man set his finger firmly on the map and said ""Here is where they reside, I am certain of it""."
column5: Cf. reside (#1063): you set the flag with your fingers on the place where you reside: an old tradition.

column4: "The strata have piled up in an ever increasing pile of dirt. As the geologists go down the rocks, they flag each stratum with the name of the corresponding era."
column5: Archaeologists at a dig site place small flags marking layers or strata of rock. Each of these layers was formerly the top layer. (This is not increase! Hseige keeps messing up).

column4: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has email scanners that flag certain phrases.
column5: They do nothing at the bureau other than repeating the stupid catchphrase they have on their flag.

column4: A sheep crossing guard waves a SLOW flag for his fellow sheep crossing the road.
column5: "Road sign (flag): ""Sheep on highway! Drive slowly.""."

column4: "WATER always LEAKED in the spot left by the FLAG planted in the roof everytime it RAINED. Not too hard to picture a hole left in the ceiling from a flag, now leaking water."
column5: Mark the holes where rain water can leak through with little flags.

column4: We printed a japanese flag on his white towel by stabbing him with a saber while he was wearing it.
column5: "The image that keeps coming to me is of the giant mechanical printing presses. The cloth-based material is coming off the roll like a flag and then, after printing, gets cut into sheets by saber-like cutting tools."

column4: "Slang for blowjob and that's priceless for stories...but also the character looks like the letter R which I think of as standing for RULER (12 inches) other meanings include: rule, measure, length."
column5: "Since this is SLANG for BLOW JOB and since it looks like an ""R"", let's have the primitive be the R in BROW JOB. :)."

column4: "A women is so exhausted by her ""shakuhachi"" that see needs to ice her jaw."
column5: That's not ice...it's my last drops and I'm exhausted! ;).

column4: "You're hiding from the enemy underwater in a swamp. To breathe, you have your shakuhachi flute poking up through the surface of the water."
column5: Sirens in the swamp play eerie music on their shakuhachi flutes to lure you in - you follow the enchanting music then its too late as you get trapped in the swamp!

column4: You cannot pretend to translate into words the melody of the shakuhachi!
column5: "You all know that 'shakuhachi' is a slang word for blowjob, right? In this kanji you got a job as a TRANSLATOR for Japanese porno movies. So you sit there all day translating dirty WORDS and watching girls perform SHAKUHACHI. This is the life!"

column4: "Hand job or ""shakuhachi"", choose."
column5: "Depending on where you choose to put your fingers, the shakuhachi will produce a different note."

column4: "Roosters in Japan are very civilised, they play the shakuhachi at nightbreak to signify the beginning of daytime."
column5: "In a Zelda game, you can warp to the daytime if you play your shakuhachi to bring about nightbreak... or your ocarina if you don't have a shakuhachi."

column4: "Traditional Japanese storefront doors have several flags, known as ""noren,"" hanging down from a curtain rod in front of them. I see this as a pseudo-pictograph, and use the horizontal line across the top to represent the curtain rod, since noren don't usually hang from the ceiling."
column5: "A Japanese door has a noren, a flag hanging from a rod. (I give this primitive the meaning of a noren-covered door)."

column4: The shoulder is the best part of the body to bash a door open with (Don't ever try this. Use your foot).
column5: "The shoulder is part of the body you use to push through the noren in a doorway. I was having trouble with positioning of the primitives until I tweaked shaydwyrm's story slightly. If you think of pushing through a noren, this makes sense as a pictograph. The noren hangs from above, and you push through it from below."

column4: Explanation here: http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?pid=14684#p14684.
column5: "When you graduate from a school, after they gave you your tassel, they shove you to the door and give you a compass saying ""Sayonara & Good Luck out there!"" (ボウ)."

column4: "It's insanely hot today! I'm standing in the doorway, fanning myself with feathers."
column5: I am a fan of the Doors but I also like the Wings. I have a fan that I take to rock concerts with the picture of each band on the sides.

column4: "This hearth is equipped with a fire-proof door. On the kanji you can see somewhat pictographically the fire-proof door keeping the fire behind, and nothing comes under the door primitive, where you would have expected to see another primitive."
column5: "-""Honey? Do we have any wood left for the hearth?"" -""Aagh, just use the frickin' door!""."

column4: The St. Bernard dog whining at the door of his master’s house in order to re-enter / re-turn inside.
column5: "Think about hachiko, the dog waiting at the door of the station, waiting for his master to re-turn."

column4: I see the story of Hachiko: the faithfull dog who still waited for his master to return long after he had died. Brings a tear to the eye.
column5: Tears are watery (water + re).

column4: Our company has no standards. We'll employ any turkey who walks in the door.
column5: "Comedy. An executive is having an argument with a cocky, but skilled, employee: ""Damn it, you might be good. But that don't account for your behavior. You keep this up and I'll fire your ass."" ""No, you won't."" ""What damn it, I'll fire you your ass so fast you won't...know...""-. ""And what will you do after you fire me, employ the next turkey that walks through that door?"" A turkey then walks through the door and hands the Exec his resume. --""The Exec employs the turkey that walked through the door""."

column4: "I was EMPLOYED to give HEAD...when I look back, maybe that was not a wise career move."
column5: The people we employ are always turning their heads to look back. They don't want to be caught playing solitare on company time.

column4: "Behind closed DOORS, the TASKMASTER tortures to get prisoners to open their MOUTHS and DISCLOSE information."
column5: You signed a non-disclosure agreement with the taskmaster but you opened your mouth as soon as you got out the door!

column4: "A boy made an altar, but he's afraid to show it to God because he thinks it's two little."
column5: """I'll SHOW you mine if you show me yours!"", she said. I did & she scoffed because it was TWO LITTLE."

column4: """Indy, my friend, you must be very careful! If you approach the altar and do not give the proper salutation a large fishhook will rip you away""."
column5: You should fish hook (bend/bow) your body before an altar as a form of salutation to God/gods.

column4: "Bringing a sheep to sacrifice on the altar was a sign of an auspicious life. The poor could only afford a pigeon, the more auspicious an expensive sheep for an offering."
column5: "On this ewe-spicious occasion, you sacrifice a sheep at the altar. —— Sorry, but I really need more than generic altar sacrifices to connect keywords to stories. Sometimes an egregious pun is the only way."

column4: "It's a Bar Mitzvah. At the altar, the teenager is singing in his awful, mid-puberty voice. We'll all celebrate when that part is over!"
column5: When Japanese people turn 20 they usually visit the altar at their local shrine and celebrate no longer being a teenager.

column4: "This recalls the selling of indulgences in the history of the Church (As an aside, Protestantism began as a protest of this practice). Basically, one gave wealth to the altar (i.e. priest) and received a blessing. If you prefer a Jewish version, think of the donation (wealth) that is expected when you're called to the ark (altar in the kanji) to give a blessing over the torah."
column5: Put all your wealth on the church altar and receive one blessing. (You stand up out of your wheelchair or something.).

column4: "And in front of every altar, she stopped to pray for the welfare of the others."
column5: Religious Republicans regularly go to the altar to pray for a stop to welfare.

column4: When you enter a Japanese company it's like you join a cult... your workdesk becomes your altar and you worship the very soil the office is built on.
column5: "Some Japanese companies, including Toyota, have a Shinto shrine on their grounds to bring luck and prosperity to the company and its employees."

column4: "The beaurocracy in Japan is such that even altars need to be inspection approved. A little man with glasses comes once a year to give the altar a ""visual once over"" as he calls it (perhaps checking for unauthorised symbology?)."
column5: [inspection; regard as; see; look at] Inspection: you 示 show (#1086) and someone else 見 see (#57).

column4: "It's beautiful place, but the dark side of Nara is that they sacrifice St. Bernards on evil altars every night after the tourists leave!"
column5: Nara is just a big show for tourists.

column4: Of course it had to be the military officer's idea to glue a national flag to the altar he's stationed at.
column5: "Perhaps you have heard about Koizumis controversial visits at the Yasukuni war memorial shrine. It is the japanese flag waving above a small stone altar. A military officer keeps watch here night and day, to honor the dead war heroes, as if he is glued to the ground."

column4: A military officer must offer consolation to the hearts of the families of his fallen men.
column5: "This Kanji appears in the word 慰安婦 いあんふ, which was what the infamous WW II ""comfort women"" were called in Japanese. The story goes something like this: As a way of providing consolation to battle-weary, heartsick military officers and soldiers, the Japanese set up comfort stations (brothels) for their servicemen. (Just to be clear: this is not an endorsement of the practice, just a way to remember the Kanji.)."

column4: "Samuari, altar, yawn The samurai is on the altar, preaching about goodwill. The audience just yawns however, they want to see the man fight!"
column5: "For better remembering the placement of the eleements: The samurai kneels before the altar at his wedding ceremony, when some of the attendants lets out a big yawn. He is a kind man and for the day his goodwill benefits everyone. No beheadings."

column4: "Similar to radical tyro's story. If you live in Japan, your main exposure to this kanji is probably ""no smoking"" signs. So I imagine the government enacting a prohibition of tobacco, and burning whole groves of tobacco plants on an altar (the altar of public health, or self-righteousness, if you will)."
column5: "Hidden in a grove was a church with a secret altar that was stocked full of prohibited alcohol during the American prohibition period of 1920-1933. A local registered himself as a mininster of this altar so he could stock prohibited alcohol ""for sacremental purposes"" and share it with his kin (きん)."

column4: "A collar is the part of your cloak that, if tightened too tight, will prohibit breathing."
column5: Collars are prohibited from wizarding cloaks. Blood purists say they're too muggle.

column4: I never really did figure out what religion my host family was - all I knew was that they kept an altar in their home.
column5: "All the RELIGIONS have their own temples, which are houses where they place their altars."

column4: "In ancient Greece, it was the religion of the time to adore the gods who live on Mount Olympus."
column5: I would adore the religious people if they just went and threw themselves off a mountain top.

column4: A ritual such as a circumcision: a small piece of flesh from the crotch is left on the altar.
column5: There are many famous penis matsuris(festivals) in Japan. The rituals of these festivals involve placing the flesh of the crotch on an altar.

column4: I have an informed guess about whose house the dark rituals are performet at.
column5: It's anyone's guess who's house she will wake up in the morning after the festival (祭-matsuri)　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　サツ　警察　けいさつ(police)…　Pure Group:　擦1104.

column4: If you mis-guess the cheese you'll grate your fingers on the cheese-grater (happens to me all the time).
column5: Ouch! Guess how many fingers I just grated in the grater? (Edit: OR: Ouch! Guess what I just grated in the grater? -- my finger!).

column4: """Wherefore art thou, Sprouteo?"" (Juliet has fallen in love with a brussel sprout) (OR: A brussel sprout has fallen from Juliet's dinner plate and rolled off)."
column5: """Cogito ergo sum."" Wherefore is a bad choice here for two reasons. For one, it's often mistranslated as ""where"" when in fact it's an urge to know a cause or reason; and two, because this kanji represents the reason, not the urge. [A thought sprouts from my brain. I think, therefore I am.]."

column4: "[When I see the word pluck, I think eyebrows, not vegetables. So, to avoid confusing with pick (#733):] Each time this singular, long, wiry black hair starts to sprout out of my chin again, I pluck it with my fingers."
column5: "If you pluck your fingers, new ones will sprout in their place. (try it ;)."

column4: The liquid oil that sprouts from an oil field.
column5: "In a rather surprising scientific breakthrough, genetically modified Brussel sprouts (which have become extremely absorbative), are thrown in the water to suck up oil spills."

column4: "Imagine some magic cloak, that when worn, has little green sprouts appearing on the sides that grow into sleeves."
column5: "The bad magician says, ""As you can see, there's nothing up my sleeves!"" Then he trips over his cloak and brussel sprouts fall everywhere."

column4: "Jack's beanstalk sprouted up, pushed at the roof and lifted the house so that it hangs in mid-air suspended on the SPROUT."
column5: "Hahaha, the image of walking into a house and finding a sea of brussel sprouts floating mid-air is enough for me to remember. Maybe there's a magician in the kitchen shouting a reassuring ""Don't mind the sprouts!""."

column4: "In the US, when the mail is delivered, a flag sprouts up on your mailbox. (We don't have that in Australia.)."
column5: "A Japanese man ordered some Brussel sprouts from Belgium. They are delivered with a little Belgian flag (as seen sometimes in shops, little flags indicating the provenance and authenticity of the food like cheese and meat)."

column4: Flute is made of bamboo sprout.
column5: "You pick up your bamboo flute, and recoil in shock as out comes not the dulcet melody you had hoped to play, but rather a Brussels sprout! You play again, and again a Brussels sprout. A bamboo flute that plays sprouts! Fabulous! Puts that golden egg laying goose in its place."

column4: The Germans manufactured so many cars during World War II that it was almost as if they were sprouting from the factories of the Axis.
column5: "An absurd image, but what the heck - worked for me. Imagine a car going across a plain at a fast speed. Suddenly a single sprout (the only one to be seen) gets stuck to the car's wheels, causing the car to fly around its axis."

column4: "Funny.. this appeared to me as a pictograph of a samurai's armor. Then I looked up images of the samurai armor and it is not even remotely similar. Then I realised it looks in fact like the belly of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which I somehow associated with the samurai armor because of the ""turtle samurai"" that appeared earlier. Fits me. The bit that pokes down is to protect the genitals, I guess."
column5: It looks like a bird's eye view of a tank (modern armor).

column4: "Push the roots down, instead of plucking the seedling."
column5: "Use your fingers to make sure the roots of your plant are deep underground by pushing them down, down, down."

column4: "A headland is a mountain that is firmly rooted despite being surrounded on 3 sides by water. (Just like your head is a mountain surrounded by air on 3 sides, a headland!)."
column5: "Headlands are natural forts; in fact, once men build castles on them, they become armoured mountains. (Gibralter, for example, is basically an armoured mountain)."

column4: "A rice farmer's delicate fingers have inserted 1,000 rooted seedlings into his field."
column5: "Imagine a crazy japanese hentai: multiple fingers and thousand of root-like tentacles are inserting themselves in... well, I think you can fill the rest."

column4: "I imagine thomeone who can not pronounth the ""s"" and speaketh like thith becauth they have a cane in their mouth."
column5: "I had persistent trouble confusing this one with 曰 sayeth (#578). The way I keep it sorted out is that this one is used in ""moshi moshi"" when answering the phone, similar to the way an American would say ""hello, this is X speaking.""."

column4: Here we see Mr. T. expanding his gang with some trained fighter monkeys.
column5: "Mr. T wants to show you the incredible expanding monkey trick. He grabs a monkey by the tail and neck, stretches him out a few times, then blows him up like a balloon. The monkey EXPANDs until it pops. Haha, sucka monkey, I pity you foo."

column4: "The Gods are gathered around debating Zeus' latest purchase for Mount Olympus. A huge and extremely kitsch gilded altar in the shape of giant ""speak no evil"" monkey. Hera decides she will never let him go shopping alone again ."
column5: "Hinduism has many gods, not just one God. One of the most famous of these gods is Hanuman the monkey. Many altars are dedicated to him."

column4: The monkey searches around with his fingers for his crotch.
column5: "If you are familiar with the Monkey legends (西遊記 Journey to the West) there is a good image for this character: While searching for the end of the universe, monkey reaches to his crotch and urinates on Buddha's fingers. (Update: new link http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RYXFppaKLL4)."

column4: If only Eve had used her brains and not taken the forbidden fruit from the tree.
column5: Eve ate fruit from the tree and knowledge filled her brain.…　　　　　　RTK2:　カ　果汁　かじゅう (fruit juice)…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　Semi-Pure Group:　菓1122　課1123　(ﾗ): 裸1124.

column4: "This candy is made in the shape of a flower, each petal with the taste of a different fruit."
column5: Candy is coloured like flowers and flavoured like fruit.

column4: "After I finish each chapter of RTK, I eat a piece of fruit to celebrate all the new words I've learned. (Thanks Misha!)."
column5: "Words signify the written words in a book. The fruit represents something whole, complete. A chapter in a book often offers a complete idea, setting, or account. It's good to disambiguate the keyword from paragraph (#82). To reinforce the kanji, imagine eating a fruit at the end of each chapter of Tolstoy's ""War and Peace"" to reward yourself. (If you ate a fruit at the end of each paragraph, you'd very quickly run out of fruit)."

column4: "Here we have Adam and Eve eating of the forbidden fruit and realizing they were naked, and so clothing themselves in a cloak."
column5: "Hey honey, I'm naked underneath this cloak. I've got some nice melons and a fresh peach waiting for you. Don't you want to taste my forbidden fruits...?"

column3: axe;1.32 lb;catty;counter for loaves of bread;axe radical (no. 69)
column4: Errata: stroke order in 4th edition is wrong. Top stroke is first.
column5: "The axe-wielding maniac nails a poor victim, right under a cliff. Blood everywhere! (thanks scottamus!)."

column4: We chop down trees with axes to analyze their rings.
column5: Wood + axe = chop? how much more simple can it get?

column4: You outsiders better learn your place! An axe stuck in the door when you get home is a pretty good indicator that this might not be the best place for you.
column5: A place for everything and everything in its place. To the right of the door is the standard place for the axe.

column4: "Religious freedom has not always been respected throughout history, and nobody knew how to force religion on an indigenous people like the Spanish missionaries. They posted conquistadors at either side of the altars at the local missions, and if anybody refused to pray, they would get the axe."
column5: "A warrior prays for victory before the battle. He kneels at the altar, his battle axe at the ready."

column4: The end is near. The axe-murderer is waiting for you on the road...
column5: "An absurd image, but working for me: two points A and B are separated by a long road. To make A and B near, take an ax, cut a big chunk of road, and the work is done."

column4: "It's the latest Japanese game show: Forudo! Contestants are given a sheet of paper and are told to fold it into a complex origami shape. If they're not done in 60 seconds, a huge axe descends from the ceiling and chops their work in half. Contestants know to recoil their hands from the falling axe, but some have been so absorbed in folding, they ignore the buzzer and get their fingers chopped off."
column5: "Fold some origami into the shape of an axe with your fingers. It's even as sharp, so watch out for paper cuts!"
