column4: "A two-hour lesson of philosophy in high school. All the students, bored to death, are folding sheets of paper into planes, love notes or whatever, while the mouth of the teacher is talking about Platon, Kierkegaard and many other notorious philosophers."
column5: "I fold my mouth, therefore I am."

column4: "One of the dearest of Japan's dearly departed is Sasaki Sadako, who developed Leukemia after the bombing of Hiroshima, and became famous for folding more than a thousand paper cranes, never giving up hope. To this day, people in Hiroshima still fold origami cranes in her memory. For this character, let us imagine a parade in her honor, the entire road lined with folded cranes."
column5: The BIG ONE hits Tokyo. You see a news report of the recently departed victims who died when the roads folded (from the earthquake).

column4: "This Japanese couple wrote the vows that they had made to each other onto a piece of paper and then folded it into an origami, and put it somewhere in their appartment. To everybody else it is an origami, but to them it is also a symbol of their vows. -- ""the folded words are vows"". Note : in this story and a few others I use the image of an origami for the primitive ""fold""."
column5: A Japanese wedding tradition is to present each other with origami cranes with their vows written on the BOTTOM.

column4: Your car has been savagely (see steadily) attacked by an ax. It will be some days before your car is fixed. So you are temporarily without car.
column5: Today is Car Axe Day. The day where you can temporarily (today only) attack cars using an axe without punishment.

column4: "I imagine firemen working steadily to rescue a man from a crashed car. First, they spray it with water; then, they use an axe to break through the window."
column5: "Water + Car + Axe: The steadily rising water was filling the car, but the firefighters took their axe and broke the window, getting me out."

column4: "[Based on fuaburisu's] A man puts some rice on a fishhook as bait, but catches a fish so strong, he needs to take out his axe and sever the line lest he be dragged into the depths."
column5: "When you get the ax at work, use your severance pay to buy fishhooks and rice. At least that way you can eat sushi."

column4: What is this substance on this clam? I've already broken 2 axes on it! (Good question...質問).
column5: "Another keyword that I do not like by Heisig. 質【しつ】 (n,n-suf) quality. Story: Your at a local ax dealer and you have TWO AXES which you are testing for QUALITY by trying to split CLAMS right down the opening. Picture yourself succeeding with one AX and then some weird SUBSTANCE comes out of the shell...eww (I don't like clams)."

column4: The kids at school used to reject me.. Made me feel really bad till I brought my axe to school. See the drop of blood on it?
column5: "The quality expectations are very high in our axe manufacturing facility. If there's one drop of rust on any axe, it gets rejected."

column4: I strongly reject the accusation implicit in your words.
column5: Words that make you feel rejected.

column4: One can use a simple word play to remember this character - the day that I saw before today was yesterday.
column5: "Yester-DAY, all my troubles seemed SAW far away..."

column4: "Pinnochio gets frustrated that every time he utters a word of a lie, his nose grows and he has to get the saw out again."
column5: "Her lies are words that cut not like a knife, no not cleanly, but savagely like a saw."

column4: "Mr T.'s favorite magazine is Make. He loves to make things. But he's a purist: he only uses saws, no power tools."
column5: "When the A-Team crash lands on a deserted island, Mr. T salvages a saw from the wreckage and says, ""I don't know about y'all foos, but I'm gonna make a raft.""."

column4: "SNOW isn't all that different from RAIN, except it can be removed with a BROOM because it only forms in freezing temperatures."
column5: Rain just soaks into the soil. Snow has to be swept away with a broom...　RTK2:　セツ　積雪　せきせつ(pilled up snow).

column4: A monk won a gold metal for breaking the current record for most swept rice in one minute.
column5: This character is about a recording for a music box. The tines of the mechanism are like a metal broom and the little pins on the cylinder are like metal grains of rice.

column4: "The policed inquired into the erotica scandal. They tried to sweep away the evidence, but some of it stuck. (Note: katakana エロ ero in the middle of this kanji is the Japanese word for erotica.)."
column5: "As a verb this means, this means ""to ask; to enquire; to search; to look for; to look into; to investigate;"". Imagine the police inquiring in an in-depth investigation. They are interrogating a suspect. But the suspect has a crafty mouth and is very sly. He/she also knows when to keep their mouth shut(glued) at the right moments to avoid self-incrimination. As a final measure, the police torture the suspect by tickling him/her with a broom while they inquire."

column4: "She was always bound to a broom, her heart pounding in a hurry to finish before she was punished for being slow."
column5: Fantasia: Bound up brooms out of control send Mickey's heart racing--he has to hurry and figure out how to stop them before the magician returns!

column4: The farmer is calm knowing that his wheat fields are protected from vultures by his strawman with a heart (all the better to do the job properly).
column5: This whole kanji is a picture of calmness. The wheat has been harvested and even the vultures sit calmly watching the humans sweep and clean-up after the harvest is over. Hearts are peaceful and calm at this time of the year. Even the days are calm without storm.

column4: "The parson ENCROACHES on the French maid; driven wild by her little broom, dainty tiara and sinfully short skirt showing her knickers (crotch)!"
column5: Mr T. hits a condom salesman (broom + crown + crotch) over the head with a broom because the dude ENCROACHed Mr. T's privates area during the sale.

column4: "The French maid draws a bath for her amorous master, but slips and falls in - getting immersed. (thanks to Nukemarine for the French maid image!)."
column5: "After being hit in the head with the broom, the condom salesman IMMERSED his head in some water."

column4: "After work, the French maid goes home and lies down with a turtle. Turtle? Well, he's sloooow and always hard... (thanks to Nukemarine and Wakela!)."
column5: "After being hit on the head encroach (#1148), the condom salesman goes back to his house to lie down. He hasn't made a single sale today, so he doesn't have enough money to buy a pillow. He lies down on his pet turtle and cries himself to sleep."

column4: "In high society, a lady is a woman who never touches a broom or an apron."
column5: The LADY of the house is nothing more than a WOMAN who's a HOUSEWIFE (BROOM and APRON anyone?).

column4: "Whether I SWEEP something away with my FINGERS or my BROOM, I should always wear my APRON."
column5: "FINGERS of the HOUSEWIFE (in itself, holding a BROOM, with an APRON) busily SWEEP the floor."

column4: Some mothers use a small broom to hit their children when they misbehave.
column5: "Here is a weird carnival game where you hold a broom like a javelin and throw it, trying to hit the center of a very small target. The target is so small, in fact, that if someone does manage to hit it, the operator turns in surprise and says, ""Whoa, really?! (本当?!)""."

column4: "This can be seen as a Retarius, a roman gladiator. The Retiarius always fought with a net to bound up his opponents, and with a trident, which was able to pierce enemies after tying them. They were terrific contenders, so they were only paired with gladiators specially equipped to fight them."
column5: A boxing ring is bound up by the ropes. The contender is cheating and using a rake.

column4: Bottled water marketers contend to make their version of tap water sound the cleanest.
column5: The water contends against the dirt in the ultimate battle for cleaninless.

column4: Just one word about this matter from your mouth and you will find this rake across it.
column5: I had to take one day off from work due to 'personal matters' after stepping on a rake and having the handle snap up and smack me across the mouth. I certainly wasn't going to tell anyone about it.

column4: "Two archeologists are in a cave looking at Chinese artifacts from various eras. One picks up a rake and says, ""What about this – T'ang, do you think?"" The second puts the rake in his mouth and answers, ""Yes, it does tang a bit""."
column5: "Screw it, this character refers to the drink. The powdery orange substance is actually found on the floor of tropical caves, where trained aboriginal peoples use wooden rakes to rake the Tang into a pile before putting a bit of it in their mouths to see if it's tasty or not."

column4: Sugar made from rice has a tangy flavour.
column5: "The T'ang are the ones who began using sugar in China--of course, the first thing they tried it on was rice."

column4: "A psychiatric hospital is located in a CAVE. To determine, which patients are sane and can be released, they are given a SIEVE and asked to empty a bathtub (the sane ones take out the plug and get the water out with ease)."
column5: "People on the cave age became more sane after they started using sieves to avoid eating harmful things with their grains. (This kanji is almost exclusively used to write 健康, health)."

column4: "Think police roadblocks. They act like road sieves, letting good people through but apprehending criminals."
column5: "In Space Balls, they were combing the desert in order to apprehend Lone Star. Picture Dark Helmet saying ""Combing the desert failed, we must now sieve the road!""."

column4: "The ""boot"" of Italy has gotten Europe all muddy. Who else could mop it up but Mr T?"
column5: "Here I have Mister T cleaning up with a mop, a real mess of spaghetti, in front of the Piza (in Italy)."

column4: "There's a tendancy in Japan to make the younger members (kouhai) clean up after the older members (senpai) of a group, which results in a lot of grumbling and whining. ""Well old boy,"" a senpai might say, ""If you did as much work with the mop as you do with your mouth, you would have been done an hour ago""."
column5: "The Beatles, english old boys, had hairs like mop and a good singing mouth."

column4: Good ol' boys are like sheep; they tend to flock together.
column5: "A little girl herder calls out, ""羊君、きて！"" to the sheeps and they flock to her at once."

column4: "[akrodha] My comb is rust-proof, water-proof, and fire-proof. But unfortunately it is not idiot-proof--and I glued it to myself."
column5: "I spent $100 recently on this excellent rust-proof, water-proof, fire-proof comb. But two days after having bought it, I left it in my back pocket and sat down, snapping this expensive comb in half! I glued it back together, but now every time I try to comb through my thick hair, it just breaks apart again. I guess my comb is also glue-proof."

column4: "Supply and demand is a simple concept: when it rains, the demand for combs goes up to deal with wet hair."
column5: "If it's raining combs, then the demand for them sure does drop."

column4: "No more Confucian jibba-jabba! I demand you tell me why it's raining combs!""."
column5: "One day, Mr. T started reading the little proverbs he found in fortune cookies, and with this newfound wisdom he became a Confucian scholar. He was suddenly in high demand as people came from all over to ask for his sage advice, immensely satisfied with suggestions such as, ""You will find happiness with a new love""."

column4: "Have you ever seen those shots in movies where the hero is standing at the edge of a sheer mountain face, hair blowing in the wind? It probably wouldn't seem so heroic if you saw him ten minutes earlier, when a crew of stylists was carefully combing his hair so it would fall perfectly."
column5: "When you stand a comb on its edge, it looks like the mountain (#768) kanji."

column4: "Primatives celing; belt; mountain as per Cumulative Errata. See volfy post for link. Both effective ways to commit suicide, hang your self from the celing with your belt or jump off a mountain."
column5: Both of Tiger Wood's initials is the logo on his belt... 　　　　　　　　RTK2:　リョウ　両親　りょうしん(one's parents).

column4: Add water THEN the flowers. With both the vase will be full.
column5: "I was thirsty so I gulped down the water. Then I realized I was also hungry. So I ate the flowers. Yes, I am responsible for both the missing water and the missing flowers. Yes, I'm afraid both. Am I still hungry or thirsty? Thank you for asking! How kind! But no, I feel quite full now."

column4: "You decide one day to paint a kanji on your ceiling. Unfortunately, you don’t have a brush, so, being innovative, you use a sprout. Knowing it could be messy, you search for a drop-cloth, but can’t find one. Instead, you put a shovel down on the floor to catch any drips resulting from the BRUSH-STROKEs."
column5: "To paint a kanji in your ceiling with only natural materials, you use a sprout as a brush and shovel some dirt to use as paint for your strokes. [modified from johnskb's]."

column4: "Stop shoveling rice into your mouth, you'll hurt a tooth! Use chopsticks instead."
column5: My dentist used his foot and a shovel to dislodge the rice stuck between my teeth.

column4: "It looks like the mouth of Bender the robot, from Matt Groening's animated series ""Futurama"". Thus, I use the character Bender the robot as a primitive."
column5: "Also means ""melody"". Think of it as a pictogram of a guitar where you have to bend the strings to make a melody."

column4: A space cadet eager to make one bend around the sun. (a dangerous maneuver).
column5: Bender lasted just one day in the space cadets.

column4: Close encounters of the third kind. The space cadet encounters aliens on the road.
column5: "Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) has an ""encounter of the third kind"" on the road. Reference to Steven Spielberg's 1977 movie ""Close Encounters of the Third Kind"". Also a reference to popular stories of people reportedly chased by UFO's while driving on the road."

column4: "Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) is rowing, during some army exercise, and he's very afraid of water (Bender is a robot)."
column5: "The space cadet is in training, rowing in the water (see it splash)."

column4: "Also as part of some army survival exercise, the cadets (including Bender see frame 1172) are sent into the woods to build a vat (for collecting water for example)."
column5: "Bender the Cadet (kudos to Fuaburisu) is found on an army training exercise, hiding behind a tree, getting drunk on the famous scotch whiskey Vat 69."

column4: "Since the meaning of ""big dipper"" is rather specific and the sense of measurement seems to be a more common usage, I concentrate on the primative meaning of measuring cup. This is a pictograph, with the first two strokes representing the measuring ticks on the side of the cup."
column5: "Is it just me, or do all of these traditional kanji pictographs look like they were drawn by a retarded bunny rabbit?"

column4: "When buying rice, the fee is calculated by the cup. Naturally we don't just use any cup; it has to be a proper measuring cup."
column5: Samurai(s) once received their fee in the form of rice that had been carefully weighed in a measuring cup beforehand.

column4: The national DEPARTMENT of WHEATS and MEASURES. Get it? This one was hard until I came up with this.
column5: Agriculture/astronomy departments...　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　カ　科学　かがく (science).

column4: "Can't see direct relation to Big Dipper (#1177) since its writing order is completely different. As raulir noted, it's written as overlapping at the last stroke of ツ and the first of メ. I take it as a pictograph or treasure map. Two dots represent big trees and the cross (marking the treasure) is placed relative to them."
column5: "A pictograph of a treasure map. Two steps east then X marks the spot. 図る はかる attempt, deceive; 地図 ちず map; 意図する いとする make a goal, intend to do."

column4: "To tenderize meat in an emergency wilderness situation, just utilize your walking stick!"
column5: "I'll confuse this with use (#990), so build a distinction right from the start. For me, ""utilize"" has an artificial, business-speak connotation; you only utilize ""utilize"" when you're trying to puff up what you're saying and sound important. So: ""BioTools Inc introduces the FG2000 screwdriver, utilizing the our latest FleshGrip(tm) technology!"" I'm seeing this as a picture of a stubby screwdriver with a handle made of flesh, a short shaft, and prongs to hold a screw in place until you drive it."

column4: "To live a comfortable life, single men need only a cave for living, a rake for cleaning and a screwdriver for fixing."
column5: "When I first moved in to my new cave, all I had was a bed (see bed (#592)). But now I've settled in, got myself a few handy things like a rake and a screwdriver, and made myself more comfortable."

column4: Mr. T wants to climb up and pick the flowers at the top of the cliff. He equips himself with screwdrivers to use as climbing spikes to reach the top of the cliff. Imagine a large AMMO belt full of philips screwdrivers instead of bullets.
column5: "An RPG where you're using Mr T as a character. Before you enter a battle, you equip the flower cliff screwdriver. This is a small screwdriver obtained at the bottom of a cliff that, when used in battle, shoots out pink flowers. When they touch the ground in front of the enemy, they create a massive cliff, and the ground under the enemy falls away into the sea. Picture being at the item select menu and EQUIPping this item just before facing a tough boss."

column4: "Once upon a time, the children were forced to eat their salad every day."
column5: "For those who don't know the expression, ""salad days"" means the time of one's youth. (originally from Shakespeare's Antony and Cleopatra - see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_days). I suspect Heisig chose ""salad"" as the name for the radical just for this phrase..."

column4: "A long time ago, people of the world got confused because there were so many kinds of Metal coins. today we only have the euro."
column5: "Once upon a time, it was thought that the ancient ""art"" of alchemy could transform anything into gold. At that time, people were obviously confused about the difference between reality and myth. (Arguably people are still as confused as ever, just about different things now.)."

column4: "Once upon a time I let Mr T borrow my salad bowl, but he won't give it back. ""This be mine now, foo!""."
column5: "Mr. T borrowed a copy of Cinderella and won't give it back. He keeps watching it over and over again, trying to figure out how the Fairy Godmother does her magic."

column4: What a pity! My state of mind when i think of the opportunities I missed from once upon a time.
column5: "Data says ""What a pity"" when he hears that once upon a time there were no robots."
column11: state of mind;once upon a time

column4: "Long ago our ancestors set aside the use of fingers and began to use cutlery. (Raichu,11-7-2006) The way I remember it's 昔 once upon a time (#1184) rather than 旧 olden times (#35) is that they began to use cutlery to eat salad. (I also think about how when you visit the Medieval Times theme park, which is set in Once upon a time, their gimmick is that you eat with your fingers.)."
column5: """Once upon a time..."" Oh hell, you're just too old for this. You close your fairy tale book and set it aside, pushing it away with your fingers."

column4: "The taskmaster is dissatisfied with the meal she's served, and scatters the salad & meat across the floor for the servants to clean up."
column5: "Perhaps you've heard of Nyotaimori or Nantaimori (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nyotaimori) in which sushi is ate from the flesh of a naked person, the story comes easily. Scatter salad over the flesh of the taskmaster in preperation for some nantaimori :)."

column4: "A generation is 30, one stroke less is twenty."
column5: Ten plus ten is twenty (see generation (#28)).

column4: "Commoners have to huddle in caverns around a campfire, while higher class people get heating and central air conditioning in a hotel."
column5: "If you are so poor that you are a commoner, you will have to live twenty commoners to a cavern, with only one fire for everyone to share."

column4: The commoners are revolting! We must intercept them on the road before they reach the castle!
column5: "If don't want your secret message to be intercepted, make sure your deliveryman is dressed as a commoner while traveling on the road."

column4: Remember those poor commoners huddled in groups of 20 in a cave? The only thing they had for a seat was some old toweling (while their lords could recline on luxurious couches).
column5: "You're tired from walking the tour at this cavern and there's no benches to sit down on, so you take a towel and sling it up into a hammock-like seat using the stalagmites. (Big no-no)."

column4: "The cavern refugees are so poor that they can't afford thermometers. So, the menfolk expose their crotches inside the cavern, and approximate the temperature in degrees from how shrivelled everything looks downstairs..."
column5: The cave is twenty degrees cooler than the outdoors. Twenty male crotches experience shrinkage.

column4: "This particular form of transit is a ferry (one of the actual meanings of this character). Naturally it can only cross the water if it's not frozen, so the temperature must be above 0 degrees."
column5: "The transit system in Tokyo is one of the best in the wrold, but why is it that when it is 35 degrees outside, it is about 2 degrees on the train? Or when it is 2 degrees outside, it is 35 degrees inside the train. This degree of difference means I am always sweating then getting the chills! I think I caught a fever!"

column4: "Hustle and bustle = a big St. Bernard dog frisking about in a haystack, knocking it down and spreading the hay about, after the field hands just stacked it up."
column5: "A bustle is also the name for the big wire-framed skirts that women used to wear. Here's a St. Bernard dog jammed ass-first into the top of a haystack, looking like some kind of proper Victorian-era lady as he struggles to get out."

column4: History of Pompei: An unexpect eruption and from the mouths of the volcano come lava that threatens the farmers collecting haystacks in the fields and the fisherman catching shells on the coast.
column5: "A bit nasty (but makes the whole thing much easier to remember) is to take the right side and call it a bearded clam. For erupt, you can make your own story about the mouth/opening on the left."

column4: After the eruption all is a tomb. The soil has covered the remains of the farmers gathering haystacks and of the fisherman collecting shells.
column5: "Using soil and hay to make bricks, the Egyptians built the pyramids to entomb the Pharaohs along with all of their money."

column4: "Note: this word in Japanese has the idea of ""indignant"". So aroused here refers to being aroused because of anger over some unjust or wrong act, unfairness etc. It doesn't seem to carry a meaning associated with arousal in the sense of sex or pleasure. So, my story: think of the angry state of mind aroused at finding all your clams buried under your haystack stolen, gone!"
column5: Data was aroused/indignant when he saw what the volcano had done to the farmers building their haystacks and the fishermen collecting their shells . The tragedy of it all aroused him so much he didn't even notice he was feeling emotion.

column4: "Ah, there's no better way to bake a pizza than an oven fueled by a burning strawman. And if you listen carefully, there are stifled strawman screams coming from the kitchen. Think of this image: http://users.mtrx.net/funnypics/content/-rdm1-ABCD1234-rdm1-/2005/2005-08-23-0002/Doughboy.jpg."
column5: Too lofty (#2095)尭 a career choice for the strawman becoming a baker. He was fired soon after starting his first shift. Literally!...　　　RTK2:　ショウ　全焼　ぜんしょう(entirely destroyed by fire).

column4: The sun rising beside a straw man in a corn field is a classic cartoon depiction of daybreak.
column5: The first person to see the sun at daybreak is of course the straw man who stands outside all day.

column4: "Imagine karate chopping the number three in half with a WALKING STICK and pausing the picture just as the first ""board"" breaks."
column5: "I think of this as a pictograph, there are three boards to cut, the first one is already in half and there are still two more to go."

column4: "The person who is your consort is most commonly ""your other half""."
column5: Mr. T wants to splits himself in half so he can be his own CONSORT.

column4: A PADDY-RIDGE divides the RICE FIELD in HALF.
column5: "Think about a large rice field as a big square. Then you draw a line down the middle, halving it into two. Then you draw a line across the middle, halving it again into four... These halvings are paddy-ridges that separate the rice field into separate sections. I dunno the reason why, but that's how it's done."

column4: "In the bible, King Solomon's JUDGMENT was admired not by saying to cut the baby in HALF with the SWORD, but that it revealed who the true mother was."
column5: It takes good judgement to cut things in exactly half with a saber.

column4: "Entering the movie, the dude asks for your ticket, so he can tear it in half. He looks at you funny when you hand him a ticket already torn in half. He quietly tears the stub into quarters after you show him your dagger with a smile."
column5: "In Japan, the JR railway ju-hachi-kippu seasonal discount ticket can be cut into quarters with a dagger and shared with your friends. (its actually sort-of true)."

column3: scroll;volume;book;part;roll up;wind up;tie;coil;counter for texts (on book scrolls)
column4: "At a mysterious bazaar, you happen to come across something interesting: a rolled-up scroll for only 25¢. You buy it up impulsively until you realize that the powerful spell contained within is cursed by a poisonous snake. If you try to cast this spell, the snake will pop out of nowhere and bite you! Hrmph. No wonder it was so cheap..."
column5: How to make snake maki: Take a snake. Roll it up in rice and nori (seaweed paper) like a scroll. Cut into quarters and serve on a wooden geta with ginger and wasabi.

column4: "I assosiate scrolls with spell casting, the efect of this spell is pent in a certain sphere of influence, outside it no damage is done."
column5: "[RPG] You're fighting a powerful enemy. Your mage uses a scroll/quartersnake of protection, and he's pent in a sphere of protection."

column4: After your VICTORY cut your enemy's FLESH into QUARTERs to show your POWER.
column5: "After England's victory over Scottish rebel William Wallace, they had his flesh drawn and quartered and then sent around Britain to demonstrate their power."

column4: "According to legend, the great Ogaki wisteria tree grew and flowered from magical rice grains that were planted under the quarter moon."
column5: "The wisteria is a type of hanging vine covered with flowers. By the light of the quarter moon, the flowers look like clusters of rice grains."

column4: Sending a facsimile to the moon can be problematic only a quarter of the words actually get there.
column5: "As a prank, a guy sits with his butt flesh on the facsimile machine, inserts a quarter, and tries to fax it to his boss. However the facsimile machine has pattern recognition technology and instead of an image of his flesh, it just transmits the word ""asshole"". Don't forget it's flesh, not words, on the left side; the flesh image gets transformed into words."

column4: Fuaburisu's pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife is a one-sided version of the story. Others say he was giving her the finger.
column5: "Taking the keyword in the sense of only one part of a whole, I see this as a pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife (I couldn't see any trees or branches in there)."

column4: "Before the advent of printers in Japan, typewriters couldn't be built as they were in the west due to how many kanji there are. Lots of small printing blocks had to be used instead. One side of the printing block would have a mirrored (anti) image of the kanji. This is true."
column5: "Nazi propaganda. Picture the printing blocks producing very one-sided (Aryan), anti-Jewish propaganda spreading posters to hang around town."

column4: "Of all the kanji, this is the only one 之orro can write."
column5: The Z of Zorro (and yes he has a hat).

column4: "Children in complete destitution have no hope of ever getting toys to play with, so when they find even a tiny drop of a building block they are overjoyed."
column5: Just one drop (of alcohol) and he starts walking in zig-zags – no wonder Zorro's living in destitution. (Note: As a primitive let 之 be Zorro or Zig-Zag: it's pictographic).

column4: "Zorro, with a flower between his teeth for the ladies, defends his turf against evildoers. ""This is my turf! And this...is for the lady.""."
column5: Artificial turf made easy: flowers stuck on top of building blocks that you can place anywhere.

column4: "[Smithsonian] Scene: Mr. T hanging from the ceiling being tortured. He is asked if he is going to talk. Spitting (a drop of saliva) in the torturer's face, he says ""Negative""."
column5: One below zero is a negative number.

column4: "To distinguish between 否 negate, and 不 negative (#1217): Note that negate contains 口, which is a kind of gate."
column5: Negative mouths negate everything.

column4: "The maple tree is very negative about it, but the farmer still collects cupfuls of maple syrup from it."
column5: A few cupfuls of sake can create a very negative situation. Like smashing into that tree...　　RTK2:　ハイ　一杯　いっぱい(one cupful).

column4: Zeus ran out of lightning bolts and has to drop darts from the heavens.
column5: Do not mistake with LOSE 失.

column4: "Angels have now been given a powerful tool to rectify human behavior instantly, without delay - they have been allowed to drop darts on those who misbehave... spare the dart and spoil the man..."
column5: "The darts of the angel Cupid are supposed to bring people joy, but usually just make things a lot worse. Here we see another angel flying around shooting people with the anti-darts (antidote), to rectify the situation."

column4: "With a banner declaring ""Keep Out!"" and blow darts to back it up, the Amazon tribe is not that friendly."
column5: "Once tribes shot darts under their war banners, now they are putting banner ads on the internet for betting on dart-games at their casinos :(."

column4: "I should know. After all, I did graduate from Dartmouth!"
column5: "[know; wisdom] [An arrow 矢 like mouth 口] If you know the answers, they will fly like darts from your mouth."

column4: Wisdom is knowing everything OVER the sun (fools assume everything UNDER).
column5: "Knowing more each day, brings wisdom."

column4: マオ Zedong always carried a halberd.
column5: "Make the halberd a heroic warrior (perhaps of scandinavian origin) who weilds this polearm - the most effective, brutal and vicious one - with great skill. He can use it to hook, pierce and chop (the three strokes)."

column4: "[tender; weakness; gentleness; softness] Love me tender, Love me perfect, Never cheat on me. Or I'll impale you on my Halberd, And hang ya atop a tree..."
column5: "Use a halberd to tenderize a tree: halberds can chop, poke, and slash, so it's all good!"

column4: It is with the halberd he holds that the taskmaster exerts his power over those actually performing the task.
column5: "So many video games have a ""boss"" stage you must pass in order to advance to the next level. Here, your task is to use your halberd to beat the taskmaster with the huge, bulging muscles."

column4: This fog is the perfect weather for us to perform our task undetected.
column5: FOG is easy to associate with the RAIN primitive. So think of FOG as a type of RAIN that is slow at the TASK of getting the place wet.

column4: "Am I the only one who took this as penis and balls? In order to be in the man-squad, naturally you need to have two balls with your ""spear"" in the middle there."
column5: Here we have two kings trying out for the cheer-leading squad. A spear on the floor separates their dancing areas.

column4: "A female warrior returns home from battle. Her husband takes away her spear to symbolize the end of fighting and gives her a broom and an apron. “Boy, this is some kind of HOMECOMING,” thinks the veteran. (Adapted from johnskb)."
column5: "Well, the boss man warrior upon his homecoming has set aside his spear. Remember the lady (#1151) (who put aside her broom and apron)? I wonder what they're doing now?"

column4: My personification for this primative is Legolas from the Lord of the Rings: a master at the bow. I suppose robin hood etc would work too.
column5: I have a BOW made from a SNAKE that I BOUND UP. He sure wasn't happy!

column4: "Put a walking stick in the bow and pull it back, ready to fire at the geezer."
column5: This is actually a bow and an arrow. (Real origin of this kanji). Pull and release to fire!

column4: "Perhaps a pictograph of a soldier's weapons--his sword and bow-placed ceremonially over his body before burial, while people offer their condolences."
column5: Send your condolences to the old geezer whom you shot the walking stick into with your bow. (see pull (#1232)).

column4: "If you pull the bow back with your elbow, you can shoot a vast distance."
column5: "The valley was so vast that if you yelled elbow! you could hear it echo bow, bow, bow."

column4: An insect who can fly vast distances is strong.
column5: Legolas is so strong that he can even shoot down vast numbers of tiny insects at vast distances with ease.

column4: "Two weak archers agree on a duel to the death. They constantly shoot at each other but never manage to hit their target. But what they lack in skill they make up in determination, and they keep shooting for hours, and days, and months, until it's wintertime and their bows are coated in ice."
column5: BOWS with ICE on them are brittle and WEAK.

column4: "Re CharleyGarrett: This liquid looks like ordinary water, but it will instantly seethe when it comes in contact with counterfeit dollar bills. The inventor must be rich (and probably has dollar signs in his eyes)."
column5: "When his daughter used a lot of water for her shower, the father could practically see the dollar signs, so he was seething with anger."

column4: "An expense is an expense, whether you put it in dollars or in local money."
column5: A dollar sign next to an amount of money denotes an expense.

column4: "The No. 1 currency in the world is the dollar. But, the Asian nations are fast catching up and may in reality have already surpassed it. So, let the bamboo represent the No. 2 currencies (the yen, etc.). The reverse order (bamboo on top and the dollar on the bottom) is really a look at the future."
column5: "Bamboo bling is the newest Asian Rapper, No. 1 on the charts right now."

column4: "Younger brothers are always more prone to mischief. Mine, you can almost see the little horns on him and the dollar signs on his eyes when he comes up with a money-making scheme."
column5: The younger brother was a horny dollar -chasing bastard.

column4: "Adroit: dextrous, deft, skillful. Snare is a little generic so I'll use BEAR TRAP, with huge teeth cartoon style that snares you around the ankle. In the crafting of a bear trap, one must be particularly adroit. Otherwise they will become the victim of their down device."
column5: To be adroit one must have mastered the crafting of snares.

column4: "My nickname is ""No Lips"". Yep, I shouldn't have put my mouth on that bear trap..."
column5: "When certain nickname snares to people's mouths, they will call you that way forever."

column4: "This snare isn't terribly effective, because it's swinging from a decaying tree. Imagine the tree as being so decayed that when an animal gets caught in the snare, its struggles cause the tree to collapse into a putrid mess."
column5: 枯 wither The decay of an animal in the TREE was from something caught in a SNARE.

column4: "The hunter's boast: I say, it was a ""big one"", but the snare broke and it got away. (credit to many others before)."
column5: "A dog owner boasts about how obedient, not how smart, his Saint Bernard dog is. ""Why, my dog will even walk right into a trap if I tell him to. Watch!"" With a single word, ""go!"", his dog obediently runs into a snare trap hanging from the ceiling. In a flash, the dog is netted tightly and swinging from the ceiling. Don't forget the ceiling!"

column4: "A hunter Washes, with WATER, his TWO SNAREs, because they are dirty."
column5: "Washing your dirty snare in water, the extra line represents the water level as you submerge the snare."

column4: "David went to battle with a slingshot and it only took him one shot to slay Goliath. Partly because of this, the prophet Nathan was later instructed to bestow upon David the throne of all Israel."
column5: "In The Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time, one of the first weapons bestowed on Link was the slingshot."

column4: "A crown was bestowed to the British royalty museum, but it was only a copy."
column5: True fact: in the UK the right to print a copy of the KJV Bible is bestowed by the crown -- there are only a few authorised bible printers. (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_James_Bible#Copyright_status).

column4: "Somebody was just looking for you. He had a longnose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face. (greenapple,16-3-2006) The way to remember that this is somebody rather than someone (#1256) is that the story is full of body descriptions."
column5: "Somebody was just looking for you. He had a long nose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face."

column4: You SHOOT SOMEBODY with a GLUE-gun.
column5: The aim of shooting is to end up with a bullet stuck in someone's body.

column4: Dick Cheney...
column5: "The famous speech by the man that Dick Cheney shot in the face: ""I'm sorry for the trouble I have caused the Vice President""."

column4: "An old man, wondering what it's like in a grave, sits in a freshly dug plot. When a gravekeeper mistakes him for dead and begins burying him with soil, the old man saves himself by flailing his walking stick in the air."
column5: "Old man sits in the dirt, having a stroke."

column4: "Before shooting an old man with a slingshot, one shold carefully consider the possible consequences."
column5: "Even though he had the old man Mr. Wilson within the sights of his slingshot, Dennis the Menace considered what he was doing and stopped."

column4: This child has taken filial piety to the next level. He is actually carrying the old man on his shoulders.
column5: +dilandau23: This child has taken filial piety to the next level. He is actually carrying the old man on his shoulders. There is a picture of a statue depicting this here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filial_piety.

column4: "In early Japan, filial piety was the cornerstone of education, and harsh taskmasters were employed to teach it."
column5: "You could say that the taskmistress is teaching you filial piety when she whips you and asks, ""Who's your daddy?!""."

column4: "In Torture 101 class they teach you to Consider the Fingers as the first part to inflict pain to. Then you can move on to other parts (like feet, groin, head, etc. etc. ; ) )."
column5: """Aaaargh, stop!"" cries the victim of torture, his fingers being squeezed by the thumb screws. ""I'll consider it,"" the torturer says coolly, ""if you tell me the names of all the agents in your organization.""."

column4: "I find the best way of memorizing this kanji is in conjunction with the Japanese compound for ninja: 忍者 -- i.e. someone who endures (see FRAME 597 for the kanji 忍). A 忍者 is not just a 身 (somebody), it's 者 who can 忍 great 拷!"
column5: "Back in the day, the old man used to be someone. His name was in the papers and all that. I use CHUCKY from the movie Child's Play as my major alternate meaning for this primitive."

column4: "I had a hard time with the next several frame numbers trying to use ""puppet."" So i thought of ""voodoo doll"" but then found ""love doll"" (which is just a special type of puppet) fit well with these 8 frames. Observe: Here I am boiling my love doll over the flames to warm her up a bit..."
column5: "There is a lesser known voodoo practice of boiling a puppet over an oven fire, to really make your victim feel the heat!"

column3: renowned;publish;write;remarkable;phenomenal;put on;don;wear;arrival;finish (race);counter for suits of clothing;literary work
column4: "Here I am, putting a wreath of flowers on my love doll's head and pretending she is someone of great renowned."
column5: This someone is so renowned they are covered with flowers every time they perform on stage.
column10: あ;ら;わ;-;す;、;い;ち;じ;る;-;し;い

column4: "Before giving your SIGNATURE to accept the LOVEDOLL, you should EYE over the LOVEDOLL for any damages, then give your SIGNATURE."
column5: The ninja's signature move was to paralyse people just by looking in their eyes.

column4: "Ahh, a fine sultry day with my love doll under the hot sun. I think she's getting a tan!"
column5: "[from decamer0n] This is the kanji for atsui (暑い) as in hot. If you've ever been in Japan in the summer no doubt you have heard hoards of people bellowing ""Atsui! Atsui!"" Here you are laying with your love doll under the hot sun. Luckily the manufacturers were smart and when the doll got to hot it would bellow ""Atsui! It's so sultry!""."

column4: "Because i get tired of saying the same old thing, I have lately been trying to use various terms of endearment to my love doll. I think she appreciates it too."
column5: "When you pull the string at the back of Chucky, he will say various things. ""Hidey-ho! Ha ha ha!"" ""Hi, I'm Chucky. Wanna play?"" ""I'm going to eat your liver, bitch!""."

column4: "My love doll is made of special pheremone impregnated vinyl. Unfortunately, a pack of wild dogs mistook her for a wild boar and tore her to pieces. Oh dear!"
column5: (Image: a pack of wild dogs chasing Pinocchio who's trying to escape by riding on the back of a boar. See him bouncing around as they race along?).

column4: I was stranded on a desert island surrounded by water for hundreds of miles on end. I wasn't upset though - I had my love doll! What a great strand of sand to be stranded on - just me and my love doll!
column5: "A lovely romantic walk on the strand, splashing in the water with my love doll."

column4: "When we gamble at the shell game, I always win against my love doll."
column5: People who gamble compulsively are like puppets controlled by money.

column4: "A gorge is where God has cut into a mountain with a pair of scissors. (synewave,6-10-2006) http://www.travelblog.org/Photos/197361.html."
column5: "A kid cuts a gorge into a paper mountain, with a pair of scissors."

column4: "In a CRAMPED space, a brave man holds off PACK OF WILD DOGS with only a pair of SCISSORS."
column5: "A pack of wild dogs, waiting in a very cramped waiting room, to get their hair cut by Edward Scissors Hands, who is very popular."

column4: "挟まる 【はさまる】 (v5r,vi) to get between; to be caught in; (P) Story: You know how in tokyo there are those really packed trains where train staff in gloves shove people in? Well imagine being sandwiched in so tight, that when the doors close, only your FINGERS are sticking out. The train staff have no choice... they must cut them off with SCISSORS =( snip snip.."
column5: Fingers sandwiched between a pair of scissors. Don't move or else!

column4: "Maestro, coattails flapping wildly, is being chased down the road by his fans."
column5: "Maestro primative = James Bond. Here he gives chase down the road to the bad guys. I'm thinking of the car chase in 'The Man with the Golden Gun' - NOT pursue (#539). I think about 'Race N Chase' (a scalextric type toy)...there were no pigs in 'Race N Chase', only cars."

column4: "A maestro in a large auditorium with high ceilings is conducting his orchestra of expert musicians at a fever-pitch, sweat pouring out of him. When the piece is over he reaches for his towel to wipe his brow."
column5: "Maestro is such as expert, he can conduct even with a towel hanging from the ceiling in front of him."

column4: The COMMANDER is a military MAESTRO who never throws in the TOWEL.
column5: "The greatest of them all; Commander James Bond, 007. Here he is the maestro of undressing women, removing the towel from some bond girl. Of course the towel symbolises her last vestige of resistance."

column4: No one likes classical music anymore. Our Maestro is here at home without his baton sighing sadly before he heads off for another day as his new job as a bureaucrat.
column5: "Bureaucrat, def: The maestro without a baton, the one who orchestrates oppressive rules, regulations and taxes on every household."

column4: "The maestro at home was sick of being a bureaucrat, so he got some wood and built himself a coffin and got in."
column5: An excellent use of wood is to make coffins for bureaucrats.

column4: Japanese bureaucrats send all their messages through an inter-office bamboo pipe system.
column5: """The Japanese internet is a series of bamboo pipes"" said one ignorant bureaucrat trying to draft Internet legislation."

column4: "Luke, I am your father. Darth Vader (really surprised nobody put this one up before: 2 laserswords)."
column5: "Not to confuse anyone, but I think if you put your mind to it, you can see the image of a father here. The first two strokes take on the form of his eye brows, and the third and fourth stroke make up the nose and mustache."

column4: "Even though your FATHER is an old man, he can't give up his party lifestyle. Once a week he still dons his cool TOP HAT (well, it was cool 40 years ago) and goes out on the town to MINGLE with the ladies. This is a pretty common thing in Japan, where old motherfuckers still think they can pick up 19 year old girls."
column5: "Darth Vader tries to mingle with his troops. He even weares one of the helmets of the stromtroopers. (one of them laughs: white helmet, black suit. Darth Vader thereby slashes him in 2)."

column4: "Mingling with the powerful can bring you success, bypassing the need for any merit."
column5: There is great merit in mingling with the powerful.

column4: "The people I had invited to the party were mingling quite well with one another, until they all suddenly started talking about the cars they own. Pretty soon the crowd divided itself into distinct, contrasting crowds: rich snobs with fancy cars, soccer moms with minivans, and hippies with bicycles."
column5: "Our world of today, cars mingling on busy streets, is in stark contrast to the one of yesteryear, where it was people who would mingle on the streets."

column4: "With the exam scores posted on a TREE, the students MINGLED around looking at the results. test. 試."
column5: Note: this Kanji does not mean exam. It means school. I find this keyword an choice odd as school by itself is not used elsewhere. Examples: 校長 is principal (lit. school chief); 中学校 is junior high school (lit. middle study/knowledge school).

column4: Captain Ahab lost his leg to the great white whale's mouth and had to mend it with a peg leg.
column5: "I'll use my mouth to mend your leg, I'll kiss it all better :)."

column4: "Mr T, ever the optimist, is trying to stimulate Capt Ahab's wooden leg by rubbing it down. Capt Ahab normally wouldn't let anyone do that, but he appreciates Mr T's stimulating conversation."
column5: You stimulate a person by giving him a kick.

column4: You can step a long-distance if you have a leg that's gigantic!
column5: You can step a long-distance if you have gigantic wooden legs (stilts).

column4: "When pirates try to hide, it's always easy to find them. Their wooden legs leave distinctive prints, showing where each is hiding and the exact path he took."
column5: "I have a wooden leg for each type of path. One with a rubber stopper at the end for absorbing shocks on paved paths, and one with a wide foot to distribute weight better on mud paths."

column4: After the rain the path was covered with dew.
column5: Dew forms on the path least weathered.

column4: "A girl with a wooden leg always wanted to play hopscotch with the other girls, but every time she tried to hop she'd lose her balance and injure another girl. That's why the other girls make fun of her and see her presence as a portent to injury."
column5: A turtle with a wooden leg needs to hop to get around.

column4: "Well, there are weekdays weekday (#576) and there are laundry days laundry (#577), and on February 29th leap day, the manufacturer recommends servicing or replacing your peg leg because they tend to wear out every 4 years."
column5: "[Story for people following katsuo in making feathers+turkey a 'futon' primitive] If you're going to leap from a high place, better hope there's a futon below -- otherwise you're going to break your leg at the very least..."

column4: "The pirate with the wooden leg chased after the parade float and was run over by the next one, leaving tread marks all over him and his leg."
column5: "Pirates must tread carefully when walking on parade floats, so as not to break through the weak plaster with their wooden legs."

column4: You have to watch your step when moving your leg on a watery day.
column5: "So, we've walked on the moon, but it's going to take a pirate with a wooden leg, with a huge supply of cooling water to land on the sun and take that ""one small step for a man""."

column4: Your body meat is attached to the bone joints of your skeleton.
column5: The top box 口 is the skull and the brain 田 has shriveled to the size of marble (but following kanji convention it is depicted as a square) and rolled into the bottom right hand corner. With all the hair and flesh gone the crown has slipped down to the shoulders like a necklace. 月 represents the rest of the body of the skeleton. [Idea for position of crown thanks to n1williams].

column4: "Don't give water to a skeleton. When he drinks it, it'll sluice right through his bones, forcing you to put one of those ""Caution - Slippery Floor"" signs up on the resultant puddle."
column5: "Slippery surfaces are very dangerous for skeletons, since their bone feet slip easily... a few drops of water, and zweep! A large mess of bones to pick up and reassemble!"

column4: "A skeleton is shuffling along the shoulder of the road, so you pull up next to him and ask where he is going. He says he's going to donate his marrow to the hospital because he got into some financial trouble and lost everything; his marrow is the only thing he still possesses."
column5: "A skeleton by the side of the road, holding a sign ""Possess marrow, will travel"". Yeah, it makes no sense but I don't foget the kanji."

column4: "Continued from auspicious (#1088). Once a year, the people pray for a sign from the gods. But if the gods are feeling particularly mischievous, they'll send down a jawbone to the altar. The people see this as a sign of calamity to come. The gods think of it as an amusing prank."
column5: Calamity Jane went to the altar to confess her sins and the priest's jawbone fell to the floor...　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　か　禍福　かふく (fortune and misfortune)...　Pure Group: 渦1292　過1293.

column4: "Grampa's flushing the toilet, when his denture (Jawbone) pops out and gets sucked down the whirlpool!"
column5: A whirlpool is water opening its jaws to swallow anything whole.

column4: "Jaws XII~! Jaws strikes the highway! Man, they're really overdoing it now."
column5: In 'American History X' Edward Norton's character overdoes it when he makes the dude that tried to steal his car lie face down with his jawbone open over the pavement of the roadway and then stamps on the back of his head. My teeth still tingle when I think of that!

column4: "If you're scared of Heights, you don't want to stay at The Pinnacle; you are anti- The Pinnacle. Primitive: The Pinnacle is a dream-like gated community at the top of a mount. This allows for innumerable stories for all the kanji with this primitive since you have a whole city to work with. Also prevents confusion with ""mountain""."
column5: "People are being displaced in 大阪 to make room for a new development, Osaka Heights, the pinnacle of modern Japanese housing. An angry mob of protestors are outside with Anti-Osaka Heights signs."

column4: Can you see Africa from The Pinnacle? I can! I can!
column5: "A kinda pictogram: 'BoT', the first 3 letters in 'Botswana' an African country."

column4: "On occasian, rituals are held at the very tip of The Pinnacle."
column5: "Many rituals are practiced every day (blessing before meals, evening prayer, etc.) Only the peak rituals (wedding, Bar Mitzvah, etc.) qualify to be called an occasion."

column4: The officer at the gate to The Pinnacle with a giant badge sewn to his chest hinders all visitors. But not the handicapped. They're hindered enough already. They're given a badge and can pass right into The Pinnacle.
column5: The pinnacle of racism was that of the Nazis. They made the Jews wear a badge on their clothes to identify them. They hindered their every movement. Moreover the peace-loving Dutch all wore the badges so that the Jews would be unidentifiable. Effectively hindering the Nazi plot.

column4: [Image: Follow the 'Yellow-Brick Road' to success] The pinnacle signifies your personal goal and destination. What you're seeking to possess lies at the end of the yellow-brick road. You must follow the road to get what you want.
column5: "I fled to The Pinnacle for safety, but the demon followed me right up the road!"

column4: "In case of emergency, The Pinnacle has auxiliary guard dogs, but they keep them muzzeled until they're needed."
column5: When you climb the pinnacle you'll need to take a muzzle of auxiliary oxygen.

column4: "A kid is perched on a pinnacle with his piggy bank. He uses the coins to catch the sunshine, and redirect it into people's eyes, far below."
column5: The Pinnacle is environmentally friendly. They collect solar power through sunshine on their piggybank shaped solar arrays.

column4: "Every morning at The Pinnacle, the residents line upon the East side for morning stretches and leisure."
column5: "Hikers line up to get to the top of that great pinnacle of the East... Mount Fuji. Seriously, they really do! ...probably the only mountain in the world with a queue at the top."

column4: A giant compass is The Pinnacle's self-defense system. It points in the direction of any invaders so the city is prepared well ahead to ward off the intruders.
column5: "To ward off enemies, the ancient Greece kept watch from the Acropolis, where they had a clear view in all directions."

column4: A sign was AFFIXED on the PINNACLE of the Acropolis so that tourists would ADHERE to the rules.
column5: The Pinnacle is firmly affixed to the top of the mount with bubble gum. (adhere (#1000)).

column4: "The Institution of The Pinnacle is perfect in every way. It is the new House of God, his chosen city."
column5: To reach the pinnacle of kanji perfect you need to attend the Heisig Inst.

column4: "Paparazzi make camp outside of The Pinnacle in their cars, waiting for the celebs to come out."
column5: "Note: This kanji is most often used in a military context. Story: Here we see an encampment of military vehicles laying siege to The Pinnacle. With other countries being envious of the perfect life they lead there that makes sense. Fortunately, the pinnacle knows how to ward off (#1302) enemies."

column4: Every regiment of The Pinnacle's army is lead by a Miss Piggy with a viking helmet on.
column5: "Every regiment of The Pinnacle's army has an animal name. This regiment is called ""Horned Pig Regiment"". They're wearing Wiking helms and are usually cowered in mud."

column4: "One of the members of our air force regiment has been shot down; he managed to safely eject, but his plane crashed into the ground."
column5: "The regiment led by horny Miss Piggy wearing a viking helmet accidently falls off The Pinnacle and crashes into the ground below. // old story with wrong meaning of regiment: Kermit is so frustrated with horny Miss Piggy's regimented sex schedule, he throws her off The Pinnacle and she crashes into the ground."

column4: """Sunglasses-missing-one-lens"" is obviously the monocle. The proper, high-class way to descend The Pinnacle is wearing a monocle with your walking legs splayed to a full gentlemanly stride."
column5: "After a cool, hip businessman angered the executives at The Pinnacle, they beat him up, popping out a lens from his sunglasses, and tossed out the window, head first, walking legs second. One executive later commented, ""It was like he was descending into Hell from Heaven!""."

column3: storey;stair;counter for storeys of a building
column4: "All buildings of The Pinnacle are multi-storey. They don't have much room, so they have to build up. It sucks when someone presses all the buttons on the elevator! You have to stop at each storey!"
column5: "Some stupid kid has pushed all the buttons in the elevator. As it stops at all storeys you reach a pinnacle of impatience. Finally you reach your storey, the last one, at the pinnacle of the building."

column4: Your highness is the pinnacle of finesse compared to all of us commoners who are but like dirt on the ground.
column5: "His Highness, the main man at the Pinnacle, often compares those who live outside the city's walls to dirt."

column4: "America thinks it is the pinnacle of the world, looking down on all neighboring countries through its mirrored, aviator sunglasses."
column5: "All the neighboring communities to the Pinnacle have a major problem. The kids at the Pinnacle have a habit of throwing down rice from the city walls in all directions, so people in neighboring communities are forced to wear sunglasses all the time in order to avoid getting rice in their eyes."

column4: "The Pinnacle, to me, is a city that makes itself out to be perfect but is filled with dirty secrets that photographers are always trying to reveal (see dissolve (#1044) The city's councilmen have isolated all professional photographers to make sure they don't photograph these ""dirty secrets"". (which are up to your imagination)."
column5: "The people of the pinnacle isolate themselves, dissolving any outside friendships."

column4: The wheat farmer's heart is calm (#1147) about the eagle not stealing his crops because of the broom scarecrow. But he still conceals all his wheat at The Pinnacle in case anyone else trys to steal it.
column5: "Move the broom with a vulture perched on top, and you'll find the concealed entrance to the heart of The Pinnacle."

column4: "Any attempt to possess the pinnacle will degenerate into a land (""ground"") war."
column5: "A degenerate doctor at The Pinnacle is doing illegal abortions. He's so sick he just throws the aborted fetuses onto the ground far below. And like a possess demon, he keeps some tied to his side on a belt as trophies."

column4: "The Pinnacle is actually bound up by supports from olden times. Eventually, they give out, and the whole thing starts to collapse."
column5: "The Pinnacle is supported by pilings which were bound up in olden times. One day when the bindings rot away, the whole thing will collapse. (tweaking dihutensoa's story to work a little better for me)."
column10: お;ち;い;-;る;、;お;と;し;い;-;れ;る

column4: "A black hole is a ""House of Infinity"". Infinity is of course represented by a sideways ""8"", but here we have a Japanese ""8"" instead."
column5: Billiards anyone? House rules here state that the first person to pot the eight ball into the hole wins the game.

column4: The craft of creating a black hole is in creating an emptiness which can attract things.
column5: "Hole-craft is the way of making empty spaces, like the sky."

column4: "With my fingers, I punch in my bank code and withdraw some money from my account. And now it's empty again, as usual!"
column5: "If you find yourself in a fight with a karate master with no weapons or martial art skills, just your empty fingers, you should withdraw because 空手 (karate=""empty hand"") is more powerful than 控 (=""empty fingers"")."

column4: When you stab something you often leave a big hole.
column5: "The police have recruited a special breed of St. Bernard that can lick the wounds of a stabbing victim. The bleeding will stop instantly, saving the victim's life. One quirky side-effect, however, is that this treatment leaves behind a rather large hole..."

column4: "Most research scientists have 9 holes.....two nostrils, two ears, a mouth, and four eyes...... :-)."
column5: "Scientiest are researching , and have already found nine black holes !"

column4: Sticking a plug up your hole will lead to stronger climaxes.
column5: "Here we have a Hole and Climax to mean PLUG UP. This is so butt-f**king easy, pun intended. If you PLUG UP her Hole, she will Climax."

column4: "This more commonly means ""steal"", like how a thief cuts a hole to steal the jewels."
column5: Stealth bombers cut holes through the enemy radar.

column4: A depression is a hole in the ground. Water naturally collects there which provides moisture for vines to grow.
column5: The depression in the ground become a trap: the hole was filled with water and covered with ivy.

column4: You have trouble squeezing your hand through the hole so you use a saw to enlarge it.
column5: "(Thanks DrJones) You squeeze the teats of the cow with your fingers but it's your first try and you don't have any milk come through the holes, so you take a saw and cut the teats to make bigger holes. Poor cow, this story squeezes my heart."

column4: "Be sure to put a hole in that ceramic sheep before you put it over the fire. Otherwise, it'll just explode in the kiln. (If you've never done ceramics before, it's important that the object have a hole in it, or this really will happen.)."
column5: You put the sheep in the hole of the kiln and turn on the flames.

column4: "Hard up = nothing but your body, living in a hole, with just a bow to hunt for your food."
column5: "Somebody so hard up for cash, the volunteered to explore a black hole with nothing but a bow."

column4: "A pictograph of a japanese schoolgirl getting groped by perverts on the train. The fingers of course, a crown (her too short skirt) and her legs below (which to be honest are pretty thick like tree trunks)."
column5: "Note: The combination ""crown +human legs"" appears seven times in Heisig. In four cases (nos. 323, 1327, 1328, 2920) the crown is above the human legs, and in the other three cases (1888, 2472, 2679) one leg passes through the crown. The naming is inconsistent, so I call the first pattern ""Miss World"" (who is wearing a crown she won due to her attractive human legs) and the second ""garter"" (one human leg passes through the crown and wears it as a garter)."

column4: "If the groper's ""tree"" goes up the girl's miniskirt too deep, he'll ejaculate fluid. (Sorry it's kinda coarse but it works.)."
column5: "Thrown in deep water, the Japanese School girl tries to reach a floating tree to save herself."

column4: Excalibur is the sword planted in a rock. Lesser known AXCAHILLBUR is the axe planted on top of a hill.
column5: At Capitol Hill proposals get axed on the floor.

column4: A point is a extra little hill at the top of a mountain. We'll call it 'Fireman's Point'.
column5: "This actually means a high mountain. So, to cater to the keyword, it's surely obvious (ahem) that if something gets such a fine title as Point, it must be more magnificent than the average mountain. It's as if there was a hill on top of an average mountain, adding to its height."

column4: "Listen up soldiers! We're going to take that hill. You are no longer men with human legs. You are voracious animals, with animal legs! Got it? Animal legs! Now take that hill!"
column5: "The hill is so steep that you almost have to have animal legs to walk on it. However, the soldiers have no problem because they've been trained to march there."

column4: "Seacoast -> Coast Guard -> ""water soldiers"" lined up on the seacoast defending our shores."
column5: Imagine Normandy after the strikes on the beach. The water of the entire seacoast dyed red with the blood of thousands of soldiers.

column4: "I also went with Spiderman. However, in the cases where this primitive appears under other primitives, as opposed to on the left (I think there are ~5 times in this chapter) I've opted to use a similar character: Venom. This helps keep the positioning clear, especially on such characters as dainty (#1363) and accumulate (#1364)."
column5: You'll be seeing this one a lot. Seriously.

column4: "Spiderman weaves his way through the skyline while listening to his theme song on his ipod. It is played, of course, by kazoos."
column5: Play the kazoo magically and the thread will weave itself.

column4: "After a day being virtuouos and keeping the city safe, Spiderman's outfit is in need of some repair. Luckily, as he can shoot out threads darning is very easy for him to do."
column5: "Darning is too obscure a word for me, I prefer to just think of it as repair. And obviously, repairing someones broken cloth things is a virtuous thing to do, and you need thread to do it."

column4: "After spending the night at an inn, spider man discovered to his dismay that his costume had shrunk in the wash, and no longer fit!"
column5: "Don't let the Inn wash your threads, they will shrink them!"

column4: "Important: Luxuriant does NOT mean luxurious, as the other stories indicate. Definition: abundant or lush in growth, as vegetation. When Venom realized he couldn't beat Spider-Man in a fair fight, he showed his cleverness by spraying venom all over Spider-Man's luxuriant garden."
column5: "Venom is covered in a luxuriant and surprisingly clever symbiotic suit, but it's also the taskmaster for his every evil act."

column4: "When Spider-man does his amazing vertical wall climbing, a throng of photographers accompanies him to get a good shot of the action."
column5: True vertical can be found by hanging a plumb line - a thread accompanied by a weight.

column4: This kanji is used for train lines. Spiderman does a hot spring tour of Japan using the train lines. You can see the Spidey costume hanging on the washing line as he enjoys the onsen.
column5: Japan's train lines are like threads that spring from Tokyo station.

column4: "(astridtops) Spiderman managed to get behind the sovereign. (pick your favourite nowadays country ruler who isn't doing a good job). Spidey has tightend a web around the sovereing's throat. As long as the sovereign says what spidey whispers, he will be fine. Sovereign yelping : ' we will draw are troops back! and we will spend more money on healthcare, schools and less on wars!' Spidey whispering: ' If you continue at this pace, you might be doing good things AND the people will like you.'."
column5: "The sovereign appears to be ruling, but in reality someone behind him (for instance his wife) has a thread around his throat, and if he dares to make a decision she doesn't like, she starts pulling the thread and tightens it around his throat."

column4: "Hey, Spidey! Eat that turkey if you want, but make sure you eat some fibers: you want spidey threads, don't ya?"
column5: "If you want to increase your fiber intake, just leave on those threads that are used to sew up the stuffed turkey and eat them too."

column4: "Lots of girls in Japan wear gauze patches over one eye made of course white fibers. They think it is cute, and I must admit, I have come to think so too."
column5: "Rocky won the match but left with a nasty eye injury, and needs some gauze for it. I use a modified version of the Rocky theme song to remember this one -- ""the eye and the fiber""."

column4: Spidey stays on the east side of the city to practice. The West Side is too dangerous.
column5: [+ skinnyneo] Spiderman visits the East to practice his swinging skills. All those Asian cities with skyscrapers and low crime rates make it easy for him to practice.

column4: "Spiderman has a secret fetish, he likes nothing better than to dress his lovedoll in a thong. Wierd, eh!"
column5: "Instead of puppet I like to think of ""someone"" as ninja (since it is the second kanji in ninja). A ninja must be able to steal a thread from a woman's thong without her noticing."

column4: "Even though Peter Parker has become Spiderman, he continues to sell pictures that he takes as a photographer."
column5: "Here's how Spiderman comics sell: At the end of the comic they leave with with a cliffhanger and say ""to be continued"". In fact, the japanese verb 続く is used in comics and tv shows to mean ""to be continued"". They have adapted the model created by Spiderman to hook the readers so that they can sell more comics."

column4: There's never a picture of Spiderman meeting Peter Parker... I wonder why?
column5: "Peter Parker's editor tells him ""Next time you have a meeting with spiderman take a goddamn picture, you're a photographer after all""."

column4: Spidey is alloted the biggest crime fighter jurisdiction in NYC because his OVERALL arrest record is the best.
column5: "According to Greek mythology, there's a thread alloted to everyone, and its length is the overall determinant of your fate."

column4: Spiderman hates going to parties and having to mingle. He wants to strangle someone after just a little small talk.
column5: "Darth Vader, who was mingling among the crowd with his hat, is spotted by Spiderman. Spiderman jumps at him to teach the villain for coming to New York. Darth Vader catches him in mid air and strangles him with the force..."

column4: "Spiderman wanted to be a salaryman, but the suit just didn't fit him."
column5: Spiderman has so little free time in his schedule that he is unable to fit in a job with a good salary.

column4: "When threads become entwined, each thread is tangled to another."
column5: Spiderman entwines each villain in a tangled mess of spidersilk.

column4: "Ok, here, you have to think of the phrase ""TIE the knot"" , which means a wedding (this kanji is used in the marriage compound 結婚 けっこん ). Now, at US weddings, it ends with the couple driving away with cans being dragged behind the car. So here, think of SPIDERMAN, who will TIE the knot with Mary Jane. At his wedding, Spider THREAD attached (or TIED) to SPRAYCANS are being drug behind the limo as they drive off."
column5: Spiderman and a fan have a competition to see who can tie up the most enemies fastest. Spidey's using his webs and the fan is using an aerosol can of silly string. So far they are tied.

column4: This winter is so cold that spiderman's web gets brittle! Could this be the end of spiderman?
column5: Spider-Man can't wait for winter to end. Going outside in spandex isn't exactly toasty.

column4: "This Kanji is the same ones used in the Japanese Language proficiency tests; i.e. ikkyuu (一級) The Kanji doesnt describe class as in a ""class of students"" or ""classroom,"" but rather a grade of quality or ability. ---------- Spiderman is taking the JLPT Level 1. In desperation he REACHES OUT to grab his friend's answer sheet next to him, who seems to be doing well. The other test takers are obviously a class above him. Looks like this test is above his class of knowledge."
column5: Spiderman with his arm stretched out showing the class how he produces webs.

column4: Worst fan fiction ever....SPIDERMAN joins the CHRONICLES of narnia to battle a big SNAKE!!
column5: In a CHRONICLE the THREAD of the story can twist and turn like a SNAKE.

column4: "After Spider-Man is whacked in the head with a I-beam, crimson blood flows from the wound."
column5: Spiderman crafted a crimson costume to fight crime in.

column4: Have you heard about patients who have surgery and the doctor mistakenly leaves a medical instrument INSIDE the patient’s body and proceeds to stitch up the patient’s incisions with stitching THREAD? Can you say “malpractice SETTLEMENT”?　.
column5: "Spider-Man was working as a surgeon's assistant. By accident, he threw his spider webs inside the patient, causing his death. Fortunately, the hospital reached an out-of-court settlement with the victim's family."

column4: Spiderman can spin his webs in any direction.
column5: """You keep me spinning right round, baby right round, like a compass baby."" Spidey is making a retro 80s music video, spinning right round on his giant compass, singing his favourite song."

column4: "Spiderman got distracted when someone yelled, ""Spiderman, wait a minute."" He turned around and flew into a building. (""part"" also means ""minute"")."
column5: "Due to the distractions of being a super-hero, spiderman can only work part-time. (variation on ayoung24's story)."

column4: Spiderman seduces all the girls he's introduced to.
column5: "Peter Parker did a terrible job of seducing MJ. Spiderman however, seduced her as soon as they were first introduced."

column4: The word ‘sutra’ literally means a rope or thread that holds things together. Here we see that it is a spool that is holding the threads together.
column5: "Spiderman is intriqued by some of the positions of the karma sutra, but reluctant to take part in an sutra orgy as he'd have to reveal his soiled underwear."

column4: "Monkeys are very adept at swinging around trees. But when they met Spiderman, who could swing around even better than they could, they all quickly addressed him as sire."
column5: Spiderman married a monkey and sired a brood of spider-monkeys.

column4: He tied a thread around the ladle as a reminder of his promise to do more house work.
column5: "Spiderman promised to get Aunt Mae's ladle back. He started to do a blood oath by spilling drops of blood but Aunt Mae stopped him and bound up the wound. ""It's only a ladle Peter""."

column4: Dainty women would always rather work with thread than in a field.
column5: "Spider-Man used to just be a dainty, brainy nerd."

column4: "When you accumulate knowledge in your brain, neural pathways are constructed. All those pathways end up like a huge ball of thread tangled together. The more knowledge you accumulate the more threads you throw into the mix!!"
column5: "(dingomick) Venom is upset because Spidey is just that much brainier than he is! He chooses to accumulate as many brains as he can, snatching them out of people's heads and storing them on top of his own, till there's just one massive brain on top of his head!"

column4: "Spiderman has been captured and given the ultimate torture: they forced a crown of needles on his head and attached it to an electrical cord, which they are about to plug into an outlet..."
column5: "(modified akrodha's great story) VENOM has been captured by scientists and is being experimented on: they forced a CROWN of NEEDLES on his head and attached it to multiple electrical cords, which are connected to a big machine."

column4: Spiderman could not achieve general acceptance by the media even after winning the public's heart.
column5: To win GENERAL approval THREAD your way into the PUBLIC's HEART.

column4: "Spiderman's polyethylene suit starts to ride up after a while, so he always looks forward to the white cotton towels he wears while lounging around his apartment."
column5: Spiderman has a dark secret - he has stolen all the white cotton towels from every hotel he has ever been in.

column4: Spider-man loves to run his mouth all over Mary Jane's silky flesh.
column5: Spiderman has little squares in the flesh of his wrists that the silk webbing comes out of.

column4: "After stopping a bank heist, Spiderman is seen winding his webbing around the stolen goods to trap them in a tree until the police arrive to take them back."
column5: "Tip: goods + wood/tree : This combination appears 4 times. I suggest calling it ""furniture"" (a common type of wooden goods). REF: parch (#215) , maneuver (#671), winding (FRAME 1369), seaweed (#2035). Story: You are winding up your new furniture using a thread to get it through the window of your high-rise apartment."

column4: Spider-Man is hooked on rice--it's all he inherited from his Uncle Ben. (thanks Nukemarine).
column5: "A poor chinese fisherman could expect to inherit: the thread for his pole, a hook for catching something to eat, and some rice to live off of. (not concentrating on stroke order, sorry if that throws anyone off). (Adapted from bigloui,12-4-2006)."

column4: Spiderman's nemesis the Green Goblin is in a slump; He's replaced his glider with a broom and is throwing grains of rice instead of bombs.
column5: "Tie green thread around the broom that you use for sweeping up grains of rice (ie the kitchen broom) to distinguish it from the other colour threaded brooms that you might use in say the toilet, or the garage etc..."

column4: "There once was a lonely little pig that constantly followed Spiderman, always nuzzling his leg and oinking tenderly. Spiderman finally caved in and decided to keep the little pig under one condition: the pig was to take a broom and sweep up all of Spiderman's leftover threads after having fought crime. The pig felt such affinity for Spiderman, he happily accepted—and did a good job too."
column5: Spiderman has no affinity for a broom hence his house is a pig sty.

column4: "Spiderman traps The Rhino under the hood of his famous netting, where even Rhino's horns can not break free, in fact if the netting did not dissappear after a few hours then Rhino might even perish in there."
column5: You use a 糸 to make a net shaped like a hood. A stray animal got caught in it by its horns and perished.

column4: "Whenever Venom is tense, he loses control of his sex drive and becomes a slave to his crotch."
column5: You'd be tense too if you were a slave and your owner removed the threads covering your crotch.

column4: "Venom starts to choke on a spoon. He's about to get it out, when you manage to stop the spoon from getting out, so he turns purple, as he chokes, and dies."
column5: "Why is your ass purple? Well, I stopped and sat for a bit on a pile of thread... (I guess it was freshly dyed)."

column4: "Spidey received good word that the acupuncturist working down the road was actually the evil Doctor Octopus! Spidey headed over to the clinic, and trussed the acupuncturist Doc Oc up using the maniac's own metal limbs!"
column5: "Because people are so afraid of the procedure, string has to be used by the acunpunturist to truss up his victims, er, patients."

column4: "The tortoise has escaped! We tied it up with a straw rope, but all that's left of the rope are some torn threads, and the unbound tortoise is nowhere to be found. (Note that the right half here is not ""eels"". This is (in my opinion) a mistake in the RTK book, as we already decided in waterfall (#537) to refer to the simplified form of dragon as ""eels"". It is much better to call the right half of this character an ""unbound tortoise"".)."
