column5: "When Spiderman fights the giant tortoise, he grabs a straw rope from the edges of the sumo ring and swings it at his head. However, the tortoise quickly tucks his head back into his shell to avoid the blow (hence no head on the tortoise)."

column4: "In its infancy, a butterfly is protected by a cocoon, as it doesn't yet have any power of its own."
column5: "During their infancy, children are often wrapped up tight like a cocoon (i.e. in those Snugli carriers) and supported by the muscle of their parents."

column4: "Column of walking legs (caterpillar) getting into a cocoon, about to leave its past self behind."
column5: "after a grub goes through the cocoon stage, it leaves its walking legs behind for a life of flight."

column4: The villagers haven't the faintest idea that giant coccoons resting in the mountain are soon to hatch.
column5: Frodo and Sam fainted in the mountains and the spider wrapped them in cacoons.

column4: "At the Mexican fiesta, there is a coccoon eating competition. How many coccoons can one person eat? No one has managed more than two before giving up..."
column5: How many went to the party? Two aliens and one person (I feel sorry for that person).

column4: An abacus is a mechanism made of wood used to calculate how many 'anythings'.
column5: "To avoid confusing with contraption (#677), focus on the ""ism"" of mechanism. For example, fetishism refers to having a fetish; mechanism here refers to having a mecha-like property, where mecha is a type of anime robot that can transform itself. Imagine a mecha that can transform itself between two forms: a huge immovable tree (as a form of defense) and a gigantic marching abacus that smashes enemies between its giant beads."

column4: What could be more mysterious than a cocoon in a top hat trying to sneak in...? (Pimitive: GANDALF).
column5: The invisible man in his top hat and cocoon of white bandages is the most mysterious man in the world.

column4: The livestock are disappearing! I've placed Gandalf over the rice field to protect them.
column5: "This mysterious rice field grows not only rice, but livestock too! Picture little pigs and chickens growing right out of the ground, among the rice plants. How bizarre!"

column4: "One sneaky farmer wanted to amass a large collection of livestock. We all know that cows like to eat flowers, so he planted lines of flowers leading to his own fields. The livestock followed the lines, eating the flowers one by one, and amassed in his field."
column5: "Kobe beef. The Japanese amass a fortune pampering livestock feeding them flowers, offering beer, playing music and giving them massages… RTK2:　チク　蓄電池　ちくでんち(battery cell)…　Pure Group:　畜1384."

column4: "A magic bow that only Gandalf can yield: there is no bowstring on it, and he uses his magic to fire arrows."
column5: A bow with a mysterious invisible bowstring.

column4: A mysterious turkey with human fingers wants to hug me... I will never go to Tokyo Disneyland again!
column5: Imagine Gandalf hugging a turkey....ouch! It bit off his finger!

column4: "Water is doubly mysterious. It's in all our nourishment...and yet, it's really not nourishing at all."
column5: "Going off the idea of the right side meaning rapid growth/increase of small objects, I've decided to make the right side be Gremlins, those little mysterious creatures that double rapidly. Gremlins find water a little too nourishing, as it makes them instantly multiply."

column4: Mercy comes from the doubly mysterious heart of God.
column5: "Here we see the DOUBLE-MYSTERIOUS Siamese twins again, at the MERCY of the machines that pump blood through their veins, since the single HEART they share won't do the job..."

column4: A magnet is a rock with two sides; one that mysteriously pushes and one that pulls; doubly mysterious. (see astridtops' story).
column5: "I found some stones on the siamese twins. Turns out the stones were magnetic, and they weren't siamese twins at all!"

column4: "(Primitive: DNA, a drop of looong spiraled thread that is the key to your lineage)."
column5: Spiderman's lineage (who his family is etc...) can be found in his DNA in a drop of blood. The villain that gets blood of Spidey will be able to find out who is family and lineage is. be carfefull spidey...

column4: "Mister T gets a DNA test, and discovers that he was meant to be the person in charge after all."
column5: The person in charge usually must come from a long standing lineage of persons in charge.

column4: Your grandchild is the child of your DNA.
column5: "Your child continues the family lineage by passing on your DNA, giving you a grandchild."

column4: The prefecture has suspended all DNA research for heart disease because of corruption. All involved will be suspended by their wrists.
column5: The prefecture has suspended all research into inheritable (lineage) heart disease.

column4: [instead; on the contrary; rather] Gone is the time for stamps - use e-mail instead.
column5: If you tried to attach money to an envelope to pay for postage it would be GONE before it arrived at the post office. That's why we use STAMPS instead.

column4: "Shins are the part of the body that one uses instead of one's eyes, for finding furniture in the dark. (Ouch!)."
column5: Shins are the part of the body that Japanese traditionally sit on instead of their asses.

column4: Selling WHOLESALE HORSES over the internet had to be STOPPED because the cost of STAMPS was too much.
column5: "If you need horseshoes (shoes that fit your horse's footprint), buy them at the wholesale shop. They lick and paste stamps in your membership card so you can get free merchandise later."

column4: An honorable man will not try to cut in front of the line at the wholesale stamp store. (Imagine just how much honor it takes facing those long lines at the post office!).
column5: "In front of the COLUMNS of the Capitol, the HONORABLE congressmen can be bought WHOLESALE."

column4: "It's customary to cover the flesh with clothing, but some designs are so outrageous they're not bigger than a stamp that just covers your crotch."
column5: Modern clothing shows a lot of flesh -- some is practically no more than a postage stamp covering your crotch!

column4: "When you're born, your fate is measured, fitted, and stamped onto your soul. Good luck defying it."
column5: Mouth meets stamp. Mail the letter to the university and wait on fate…　RTK2:　メイ　一生懸命　いっしょうけんめい(with all one's might)　　　　　　　　ミョウ　寿命　　じゅみょう　　(span of one's life).

column4: "(re: dingomick) ""These are your orders,"" declares the general while passing out documents at the meeting. As everyone started to leave, the general exclaims ""Oh wait! I need to certify these orders!"" and went around stamping each paper with his personal chop-seal."
column5: """These are your orders,"" declares the general at the meeting as he stamps them with his chop-seal. (Primitive: chop-seal imaged as a papal ring, the one's they would press into wax as their official seal. Also a cattle brand.)."

column4: The amount of people that can order the rain to rain.
column5: "Despite the rain, the zero pilot flies on. He has kamikaze orders."

column4: You know you are fast approaching a ripe old AGE when you get ORDERS from the dentist to get new TEETH.
column5: The tooth fairy has orders to stop giving money if a child is a certain age. RTK2:　レイ　高齢　こうれい(advanced age)…　　　　　　　　　　　　Semi-pure group: 　令1401　零1402　冷1404　鈴1406　(ﾘｮｳ): 領1405.

column4: "To keep your water cool, just order some ice."
column5: The Japanese boss gives an order at the meeting: eat ice to stay cool (since they won't be running the air conditioning anymore).

column4: "Two cowboys are crossing a state limit. One says to him “Did you know that in this Jurisdiction there are Orders to get your head?”, so he takes out his gun and shoots him. He claims the reward afterwards. (Thanks Fuaburisu)."
column5: Orders are given by the head person in any jurisdiction.

column4: Some restaurants have a small gold bell to call someone to take customers' orders.
column5: "In high society, people ring a small golden bell to call their servants and give their orders."

column4: "I imagined some kind of initiation rite in old China, where every young man has to show his courage. They then receive a chopseal which is a mark of their courage."
column5: "Re: fuaburisu - The initiation rite in question is actually a reverse elbow chop to the brain, and you receive the chop seal if you have the power to withstand it. This initial imagery helps me with the altered chop seal and vertical placement."

column4: "I bounce down the road on my pogo stick, easily getting through the dense traffic. (Note: New primitive: chop-seal + utilize = pogo stick. Because a chop-seal is long and thin with a rubbery bit at the end. If it were big enough, you could utilize it as a pogo stick). [Edit: pogo stick also appears in 1409, 1690, 2530]."
column5: Building on gorgon's story I now change mine to a much more silly and rememberable one. The Chinese police is using a helicopter to check and regulate the traffic. Hanging from the helicopter is a huge chopseal that they utilize to mark some of the cars that are causing trouble on the road.

column4: The winner of the long jump competition was disqualified when they found he used a pogo stick tied to his leg to jump further.
column5: "The high jumper has his wooden leg fitted with a pogo stick, and can now jump even higher. (See my note at traffic (#1408) for pogo stick). EDIT (2 years later): Keyword ""jump"" leads to confusion later on (see cjon256's post), ""Dancing"" would be better (but be sure to keep it distinct from dance (#1774)). New Story: I was no good at dancing due to my wooden leg... until I had it fitted with a pogo stick!"

column4: "(Katsuo) You come at the zoo entrance. 'Here sir, a spoon to feed the animals.' cool 'and a dart(gun) in case stuff go wrong' ....' please chop-seal (sign) here for in case of accidents the zoo is not responsible.' 'lion feeding time is. bla bla' You are having serious doubts about if you still want to go into this zoo."
column5: "A very doubtful story: At the entrance to my local zoo they issue you with a special spoon (to feed the animals) and a dart gun (to defend yourself in case of animal attack). You must then hanko (seal) a document to say you’ve received both these items, only after which will they let you enter the zoo. (Oh, and if you forget your hanko, I doubt they’ll let you in)."

column4: "Ask a MIMIC to give an impression of DOUBT, and he will no DOUBT scratch his head with his FINGER."
column5: I doubt you can mimic all these animals with just your fingers: http://www.google.com/search?q=%22Raymond+Crowe%22+Letterman (shadow puppets -- you'll love it!).

column4: "I doubt that the jello would congeal sitting on the counter, so I placed it in the icebox."
column5: Is there any doubt that ice is congealed stuff?

column4: This pattern made of bamboo is for a new model of car designed to leave as small an ecological fingerprint as possible.
column5: "How about a serial killer who's pattern is to drive by the victim and club them with a bamboo stick. Finally he makes a mistake and drops the bamboo stick, which is dusted for fingerprints."

column4: Crimes can often be solved using the tools of dogs and fingerprints.
column5: This crime gang has yet to be caught because their pack of wild dogs takes care of licking off the fingerprints from all the crime scenes.

column4: "Seeing some finger prints at the edge of a cliff, I wondered who that unlucky person was."
column5: Sherlock Holmes is very unlucky: he just fell off a cliff while he was looking around for fingerprints.

column4: "You're bound up by ropes to an unlucky person. It's dangerous, because whatever happens to him will happen to you too."
column5: "While rock climbing you are bound to the cliff by just your fingerprints, which is why it's so dangerous."

column4: Your address should be displayed on your house and mailbox.
column5: "For the primitive: This is a hi-tech Japanese mailbox, it automatically lights up in the evening, and has a biometric fingerprint scanner. --- Each house's address, even if it's hard to see in the evening, is like its own unique fingerprint."

column4: "Like in Memento, I tattoo my address on my forearm flesh so I don't forget it."
column5: "In Iraq people are having their addresses tattooed on their bodies, usually their arms, so they can be identified if they are killed. (true story)."

column4: "Japanese ""gardens"" aren't anything more than a pot of flowers on top of the mailbox."
column5: "My mailbox is actually right in the middle of my garden, which kind of sucks since the mailman has to trample all my flowers to get to it."

column4: I couldn't drop my grudge against him. So I put a severed pig's heart in his mailbox. He got the message.
column5: I had a little grudge against my ex-girlfriend and her new boyfriend...so I ripped out his heart (like in indiana jones and the temple of doom) and then I left it in her mailbox.

column4: Having decided to use SIGN OF THE HARE rather than RECEIPT and STAMP my mnemonic goes as follows: The WILLOW is the TREE that droops likes a HARE's ears.
column5: "A strange thing about the japanese willow tree is, it grows eggs... but the eggs have no yokes. weird eh?"

column4: The Easter Bunny dropped an egg on my desk and got yolk all over my receipts and stamps.
column5: The 卯sign of the hare (#2041) hides eggs in his ears for Easter...　RTK2:　ラン　卵巣　らんそう(ovary).

column4: "Got a receipt for that dagger, son? If not, we're going to detain you and send you to work in the rice fields."
column5: The use of RANSOM NOTE (think of a receipt with a dagger through it on a door) works great with DETAIN. Here the RANSOM NOTE says that the girl has been DETAINED in an undisclosed location. To get her back take the RANSOM to a empty FIELD.

column4: "There's a buyback program where you can trade in your dagger for money. But it's quite ineffective, since only registered dagger-owners with the original receipts can participate, and not criminals with illegally-purchased daggers."
column5: The new RANSOM note (a receipt stuck to a door with a dagger) from DETAIN (1423) appears again (probably after you went to the field as instructed) now gives instruction to TRADE the victim for CURRENCY you were told to bring.

column4: "Before sticky backs, they had to staple stamps to letters."
column5: "Aaaagh, this old stamp doesn't stick! Okay I'll just staple it."

column4: "To me, this looks like a pictograph of a road leading to the big city (see the buildings?) where there are plenty of places to be entertained. Unfortunately in this city, every store is the same: staples. What tools! [ayoung24]."
column5: "Photographically, this kanji simply looks like a set of two speakers (the staples primitives) between the sub-woofer (primitive for same) -- all this as a tool to entertain a group of drunks at a club."

column4: The sign of the bird on this whiskey bottle is of course the Famous Grouse blended Scotch.
column5: "Normally birds fly south, but one bird flew west. People were worried about it and kept asking ""Is there any sign of the bird – you know, the one that flew west?""."

column4: Sake is just watered down whisky.
column5: Sake is the generic term for alcohol (not just japanese rice wine). And a very popular alcoholic drink in Japan is whiskey and water.

column4: "At the local pub, their bartending practises are unusual. They serve the whiskey by pouring it from a ladle, like one would from the punch bowl."
column5: "Ever seen the anime Bartender? Bartending isn't just about bottles of whiskey, it's about ladling out advice."

column4: The secrets of fermentation are passed to the son who displays the most filial piety.
column5: "Since filial piety is all about respecting ones elders, and the older a whiskey bottle is (i.e. the time it have spent undergoing fermentation) the more respect you should give it, the meaning of this kanji becomes clear. If it doesn't, sink back some whiskey and it will."

column4: It's cruel to pour alcohol down a cow's mouth.
column5: Offering whiskey to people to encourage them to make revelations is cruel.

column4: "Imagine a different kind of tax refund - instead of money, the state repays you with whiskey."
column5: Hint: bottle deposit refund - the state will repay the recycling deposit for each alcohol bottle returned.

column4: "To stay healthy, Dr. Phil told me to have some dairy products with each bottle of whiskey I drink..."
column5: "In an attempt to increase sales of dairy products, the grocery store is giving away a free miniature whiskey bottle with each dairy product you buy."

column4: Drinking alcohol that's turned to vinegar feels like a saw going down your throat.
column5: "I spent ages sawing that whiskey bottle open, but when I got in, it had all turned to vinegar!"

column4: God you're drunk! How many whiskeys did you have? 9? 10?
column5: Whiskey with 90 percent alcohol will get you drunk. I don't care who you are.

column4: To DISTRIBUTE WHISKY during Prohibition you had to be as sneaky as a SNAKE.
column5: "In Japan, it's rude to distribute the sake to your self before anybody else."

column4: The prostitute carries an old whiskey bottle filled with acid to throw at any difficult Johns.
column5: "Dealing alcohol requires a license, dealing acid requires fast legs (to run from the police)."

column4: The waver for this kanji means to hesitate. I wavered before going into the bar with a bunch of horned wild dogs drinking whiskey straight out of the bottle.
column5: ". Have you ever had Wild Dog brand whiskey? That stuff is downright evil. So evil, the bottle has horns, and you need to sign a waver before you drink it. Because of this warning you will surely waver as you bring the shot glass to your lips."

column4: I drank the Devil Whiskey and was revered by all. Too bad I had to have my anus glued shut from the damage it did to my digestive system...
column5: "Red Bull, the chieftain (#2906) is so revered in his clan that everyone sticks to him like glue."

column4: "If I eat BEANS, after ONE MOUTHful I fart like some kind of HORNED ANIMAL."
column5: I hate using primitives that are completely unrelated. Let's call this one Mr. Bean! He's an easy character to build stories with.

column4: The head of the family sits at the head of the table.
column5: Mr Bean's head.

column4: "He's so short, he can't even throw over a table while playing darts."
column5: "Sort of like ping pong, this kanji represents a game where you throw darts over a table at your opponent. The serve is rarely returned, so the games tend to be short.------------ This character apparently refers to duration, not just to height."

column4: The bountiful feast was so bountiful that it bent the table below it under its weight! いただきま〜す！.
column5: Her bust and bum was so bountiful I couldn't resist the urge to bend her over a nearby table and...

column4: "Japanese festivals have drums so big, a samurai has to SIT (not stand) on a table to beat one with a tree branch! http://www.d2.dion.ne.jp/~hidafyh/furukawayh/gyouji/image/maturi03.jpg."
column5: "I really hate the primitive meaning of ""table"" for ""bean."" I just use ""bean."" Anyways, for the DRUM primitive, imagine a SAMURAI who beats on a DRUM with two chopsticks, and a BEAN skewered on each end of the chopstick to produce a better sound. And the obvious story is: ""DRUMing on a DRUM with a huge BRANCH""."

column4: "The samurai sitting on the drum is on a stage, and the people below him are rejoicing with their mouths in unison. It helps me to imagine the placement this way."
column5: "In the taiko (drum (#1444)) song of rejoicing, the drummers shout with open mouths."

column4: The hippies object to trees being cut down for timber. They have glued themselves to the timber-trees and are beating their drums.
column5: "Everyone likes to see big trees fall down. For this kanji imagine hundreds of spectators glued to their chairs, then a drum roll and then a cry of ""timber!!!"" as the huge tree crashes to the ground."

column4: Three dishes stacked side-by-side in a dishwasher.

column4: Vampire orders blood in one of those posh restaurants. Imagine his shock when all he gets is a giant white bowl and just a single drop of blood in the centre and a drizzling of balsamic around the edge. Disgusted he calls the manager over tells him its overpriced tosh and bites into his neck with a huge gush of blood spraying everywhere.

column4: The part of the kitchen sink in which you wash dishes in is the basin.

column4: (re: Raichu) An undercover alliance between Japan (the sun on its flag) and Turkey (the moon on its flag) detected by a surveillance satellite dish. http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20100126a3.html.
column5: "A new alliance is proclaimed at the end of a meal between officials. As a symbol of their alliance they clean up together one dish, and present it to the photographers. The clean dish under the flash lights appears very bright, and it's pretty much all you can see on the photo that appears on the next morning's newspapers, with the title ""New alliance, one bright dish!""."

column4: You are so poor you dont know where your next dish will come from all you know is that you will have to steal it.

column4: "In the old days, salt was a worth alot, so it is not surprising to find someone reclining on the ground, mouth to plate, getting every last grain of that delicious salt."

column4: "Like gold, silver is a metal."

I'm sure you can see the flash from her hair as she walks by on a sunny day. Note that the two elements (sun and hairpin) share not only a horizontal stroke, but also the left vertical one. Therefore a bit odd stroke order."

column4: The athlete's state of mind is nothing but resentment after getting the silver medal.

column5: """I hope this works,"" you say as you stuff a sheaf of stalks under your blanket but above your linens. Your real hope is that your parents don't find out that you left the house."

column4: "I've finally met my arch-rival, the evilest of all villains. Finally, I'm about to fight him. But what's this? He's suspiciously quiet. I move to attack him, and his right arm falls off at the elbow. Strange. I walk up to him and detach his left arm. Very strange. I undo his belt, and take off his top hat... BLAST! It was just a decoy turkey!"
column5: "The most ridiculous character ever dreamt up for a film. DETACHO, a top-hat wearing villian who is able to detach his body parts for use as weapons. His most powerful weapons are his elbows, which he can detach, tie together with his belt and use as nunchucks. DETACHO has a sidekick turkey which he uses as an advanced scout as well."

column4: Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the ground and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?

But unlike war , putting Ketchup on it will usually solve the problem. Wall(dingomick); Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the ground and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?"

column4: "You can try and evade them, but they'll ketchup with you on the road... Sorry, couldn't resist it."

column4: "If your firewood is too new and still has flowers on it, it's unsuitable for burning. You need drier wood."
column5: "Sometimes, new firewood still has flowers on it."

column4: "Tenacious-D is happy band led by a fat man. (It's Tenacious-D time, ya muthafucka', gwaoh!)."

column4: "There was a man in a village who had a special gift : whenever he shouted and screamed, his mouth became a cornucopia, overflowing with fruits and food of all sorts. Many of the locals thought he was a cruel man, always screaming at his wife, until they realised he was in fact very kind, and his gift brought prosperity to his family."
column5: You can hold a CORNUCOPIA up to your MOUTH (like a megaphone) to SHOUT lounder. Also notice that the shape of CORNUCOPIA implies the shouts are 4 letter words.

column4: "[twist; ask; investigate; verify] Stories full of twists are difficult to write, because of the cornucopia of threads the author has to manage."
column5: A Pepsi promotion where you twist off the cap to find pictures of your favorite heroes like Spider-Man or members of the Fantastic Four.

column4: "Prostitutes can make a veritable cornucopia of income by using their crotches -- they put the ""come"" in ""income."" (A bit lewd perhaps, but effective in keeping this character distinct from similar keywords like profit (#906) or earnings (#893))."
column5: Women love men with money. If you have a high income you can get a cornicopia of crotches.

column4: "A LOWLY single rice grain, DROPPED in an empty FIELD, can produce a CORNUCOPIA of food."
column5: Lowly people only have a drop of brains and use nothing but 4-letter words.

column4: "There is a grave of a lowly man with a tombstone made of a simple, small stone. If you bow really low you can read the very small inscription engraved on the stone, it says - “Now that you bowed so low to read this, you are as lowly as I once was”."
column5: A STONE makes a LOWLY TOMBSTONE.

column4: "My rice-seedlings have become sentient and will go on a mission. I can only apologise for the next 6 frames. In the distance, there is a pinnacle, which the newly-awakened rice-seedlings who are still stuck in the ground can see. Could it be the Promised Land?"
column5: "When sailors see land in the distance, they first see the pinnacles of the new land, but when they come close enough they'll be able to make out the rice seedlings, and finally the ground!"

column4: I keep an intimate relationship with my rice seedlings -- I never take my eye from the soil.
column5: land (#1513) Some of them begin to see eye to eye about the possibility of reaching the promised land. A group of awakened rice-seedlings stuck in the ground becomes intimate and starts to form a plan.

column4: land (#1513) The rice-seedlings still stuck in the soil gather round in a circle. Their combined power forces them out of the ground at last.
column5: What power makes rice seedlings in the ground grow into well rounded plants? The forces of nature.

column4: land (#1513) The rice-seedlings (newly freed from the ground but with soil still clinging to their roots) gather in a circle around an oven fire. They need to heat up prior to their journey (presumably plants can't walk if they're too cold?).
column5: "Heat up those RICE SEEDLINGS you pulled from the SOIL in a ROUND pan over a low FLAME. (Note: the hot pan image helps reinforce the idea that this kanji for ""atsui"" refers to something hot to the touch, as opposed to hot weather)."

column4: "land (#1513) Deciding to use the diamond-shaped water caltrop flower as cover/protection, the rice-seedlings with their walking legs (now free from soil), can start their journey."
column5: "Some girls want diamonds, but others will be satisfied with just flowers. However if you think you can win her over with rice seedlings, expect her to get up on her walking legs and walk on out!"

column4: "land (#1513) However, the pinnacle that the rice-seedlings finally reach with the use of their walking legs turns out not to be the Promised Land after all, but simply a mausoleum (containing many dead rice-seedlings exhausted from previous quests?). Oh no!"
column5: On top of The Pinnacle is a masoleum for rice seedling farmers. They make an annual walking pilgrimage there.

column4: A greedy hog in a top hat who has eaten all of the acorns. He even elbows people out of the way to get them.
column5: "Top Hat + Elbow + Person: The sign of the hog was a very recognizable tattoo - a hog with a big grin in a top hat, sticking his elbow into the person next to him."

column4: "In the nucleus of the acorn, all the DNA is stored -- the building blocks for a new tree."
column5: The nucleus of an oak TREE is an ACORN.

column4: "This famous ninja (I always use ninjas with sabres, distinct from samurai) used to engrave the kanji for his name onto acorns, and throw the acorns to distract his enemies. The legend goes that by the time his victims would pick up the acorn and read the engraved kanji, they were already dead."
column5: "While it's traditional for lovers to engrave their names on a tree in many countries, in Japan, however, it was traditional for a samurai to signify his undying love for a woman by engraving the kanji of her name on an acorn with his sabre."

column4: "I asked my teacher what this strange word meant, and she furiously replied that it was explained in the above-stated paragraph before throwing an acorn at me!"
column5: The above-stated words are the acorn from which the following statement grows.

column4: The liberal squirrel blogged that he would give all his ACORNS to congress if it would exercise its POWER to censure Bush and Cheney.
column5: Acorn Power is the people's way to CENSURE a congressman you don't agree with. Pelt your Senator with acorns today.

column4: Why are the roads leading through the woods so sticky and dirty? Hmm... I think the forest ranger mentioned something about excess resin on the roads...
column5: No-body mentioned that there was resin on the road. Now I'm stuck!

column4: "Behold the ""Boulev'Art"" : a life-size section of a boulevard cast in a huge block of resin. Some call it ... art."
column5: The definition of art is getting more and more loose these days. Why even some resin spilled onto the boulevard is now counted as art! Hmmph!

column4: "A cold lunch: in the house, celery, pre cooked animal legs (i.e. chicken drumsticks) and ice tea."
column5: "Some strange animal tried to steal a stalk of celery from my house. However, it was freezing and the floor was covered in ice, so the mysterious animal couldn't get any traction. Picture a stalk of celery and a pair of animal legs slipping and sliding clumsily around the ice, and never able to leave the house. Eventually it got so cold that the little animal froze to death."

column4: "On the troical island of JOU, they brew whiskey while wearing grass skirts (top hats and scarves too). (Image: the strangely dresses islanders stirring a pot of brew. Careful fermentation (#1430))."
column5: "Note : up to frame 1530, the kanji share the same chinese reading (JOU), so don't hesitate to group them into the same environment. Here we have the ""brew""-man, who brews some kind of whiskey using palm tree leaves. Instead of collecting them himself, he just buys the grass skirts from the people on this tropical island where he lives (which you may name the JOU island, after the chinese reading)."

column4: "(thanks chamcham) A graduate student in anthropology tells the University that he plans to defer his studies for a year, and instead conduct ""field research"" on the grass-skirt-wearing native women on the island of Jou."
column5: The islanders defer to the words of their chief Jou in his grass skirt.

column4: My dream is to buy a small lot on a tropical island and spend the rest of my days relaxing in a grass skirt.
column5: "On the island of JOU, in order to be considered a lot, a ground must be big enough to grow sufficient grass for a grass skirt."

column4: "Conversation at a party: A: ""Who is that lass?"" B: ""Which one?"" A: ""The woman wearing the grass skirt."" B: ""Alas, I don't know""."
column5: "Two Irishmen visit Hawaii and see a woman wearing a grass skirt and nothing else. ""That's some lassie,"" says one to the other. ""But alass Danny Boy, you can't be bringing her home.""."

column4: "If you grow up with a mother that drinks and smokes, you can be sure it's poison in the stuff you get from her breasts."
column5: "Note that stroke order of grow up primitive isn't obvious from Heisig's diagram: single horizontal stroke is drawn first, then vertical and two horizontals."

column4: "When he was growing up, Venom never had many friends in elementary school. Maybe it explains why he turned out how he did."
column5: "This is a pictogram of string theory. Strings are the most elementary particles of matter, which then grow up to become matter itself."

column4: "If you eat lots of barley, you'll grow up to have strong walking legs."
column5: "Barley is a very cheap grain, and it's not really worth spending time to harvest. Therefore, scientists have genetically engineered it to grow walking legs once the grain is grown up and mature, so it can harvest itself."

column4: The last time I saw a blue moon was in my youth when I was growing up.
column5: """Once in a blue moon"" refers to a rare event. But originally ""blue moon"" refers to a full moon, in other words a fully grown-up moon. Whether once a month is rare or not depends on what we're talking about, but that happens to be the origin of the expression."

column4: "Before rice is refined, it is actually blue...bet ya didn't know that!! (alternate....Condi Rice was blue when insurgents blew up the iraqi refinery where oil is refined)."
column5: Very refined people in the upper classes have skin as pale as rice and blue blood.

column4: "That door-to-door salesman can stand outside ringing my doorbell until he's blue in the face. There's a big sign on my front door, and the words clearly say ""No Soliciting""."
column5: Going through smurf blue light district - heres a smurfette saying all sorts of dirty words trying to solicit herself.

column4: "Data is feeling blue about not having any feelings ... hey, wait a minute."
column5: Feeling blue is a state of mind where you're dominated by your feelings.

column4: "Sun and blue sky! Yep, the weather's cleared up!"
column5: When we speak of clearing up we easily think of both the sun and blue skies. But in another since to clear up is the absence of weather. And therefor the reason weather has no place in its writing.

column4: Pure sea water is always a radiant blue.
column5: "Bottles of water claim to be pure. They're generally in blue containers, because blue makes you feel like its that much more pure."

column4: "When someone you know who is normally talkative goes quiet, it's usually a sign that they are contending with the blues."
column5: """And the next contender is.... a Smurf!"" As you can imagine, the crowd goes quiet with shock."

column4: "As one grows up, one typically starts to blame all of their problems on money."
column5: "This is the story of a poor fisherman and his wife. A long time ago he caught an oyster with a small but precious pearl. The intelligent wife told him to sell the pearl immediately: the greedy husband figured if he kept the oyster and fed it, it would grow up and yield an even bigger pearl. One day the oyster grew so big, it crashed through the house and escaped back to sea. The angry wife left her husband, blaming his blind greed for their poverty."

column4: Spidey's exploits are world famous but still The Daily Bugle's pages blame him for every problem out there.
column5: [Geek alert] A lot of modern software is full of exploits which can be abused by hackers. I blame multi-threading.

column4: "On many wheat cereal boxes, there is a disclaimer stating that ""This package is sold by weight, not by volume. Some settling of contents may have occurred."" well they only say that because they don't want to be blamed by people getting really disappointed after they see what a small volume of cereal the box really contains."
column5: The volume of the wheat crop is way down this year! Blame the weather!

column4: Mr. T's plot of world domination is foiled. Who is to blame? Bond. James Bond.
column5: [bond; loan; debt] Mr. T buys a lot of high risk bonds and then blames his broker when they all plummet in value.

column4: "When pickling you MUST use distilled water! When it doesn't come out right, generally it is the water that is to blame."
column5: Bad water is to blame for the process of pickling.

column4: "When I was GROWING UP, the SURFACE of my SCARF was always covered with snot from blowing my nose on it."
column5: "As girls grow up, something slowly surfaces from under their scarf."

column4: Mr. T's punching bag has one beat up surface.
column5: Do you know why every person in Japan has a Louis Vuitton bag? After the 1985 JAL air crash that killed 520 people (the world's worst). An image on tv of the crash showed Louis Vuitton bags (whose LV logo covered surface was somehow impervious) litering the crash site. From that point on they stuck in Japanese people's mind's as durable and high quality. (True story).

column4: "To ensure she remained undefiled, a young girl growing up in a rough area always kept a dagger concealed under her threads, even when she went into the water."
column5: "(rgravina) To ensure she remained undefiled, a young girl growing up in a rough area always kept a dagger concealed under her Spiderman underwear (to remember the position of thread), even when she went into the water."

column4: "Imagine a totalitarian regime where, while growing up, you have to pledge allegiance to the flag at dagger-point and with St. Bernard guard dogs watching you."
column5: "In order to pledge into her sorority, Alice had to stab a St. Bernard with a dagger. (Come on! DO it, Alice!)."

column4: "This means eat/drink/smoke. Maybe you make a pledge to stop gutsing/binging/puffing, but your own mouth is tempting you to put something in it."
column5: I make my mouth pledge to consume less.

column4: "With kids growing up in your house, you have to keep them from harm of putting anything in their mouth, paint chips, bleach, knvies, etc."
column5: "This is silly, but.. If a house suddenly grows up from your mouth, you will come to great harm."

column4: "The roads are icy, and a whole bunch of cars have spun out of control! Luckily, it was just a couple of dents; nobody was harmed."
column5: Control is very important! Especially when operating a car. Few people realize the harm they can cause just by losing control of their car for a second. Tremendous harm. Stay in control!

column4: "[proportion; comparatively; divide; cut; separate; split] Hey, don't take this out of proportion! I did you just a little harm, no need to come over here with a saber..."
column5: "As shown on this pie-chart, the proportion of people harmed by sabres is relatively a small slice compared to those harmed by guns."

column4: "The constitution is important. At least my parents thought so. In the house where I grew up, it was framed on the wall. Under the watchful (sideways) eye of my mother, we had to study it until we knew it by heart."
column5: The house of US Congress needs to grow up! Their twisted eyes have lost the heart of the constitution.

column4: "This is the first CELL of a human, the foundation of its entire LIFE, a small DROP that will GROW UP to form a complex organism."
column5: Growing Up is just a Drop of our LIFE.

column4: The sun is the nearest star to the only planet with life - Earth.
column5: Sun is a star that has given life. Can't say that of any other stars yet.

column4: "When women marry, they adopt the surname of their husband, signifiying the start of a new life together. (adapted from gorgon)."
column5: "Woman change their surname when they ""start their new life""."

column4: Sex is the only state of mind for many men through their whole life.
column5: When you're in the state of mind for creating new lives.

column4: Animal sacrifice = taking the life of a cow.
column5: "In the 21st century, animal sacrifice is no longer really necessary. We can take a single cell from a cow, with no harm to the cow. We create a viable cell line from this single cell, and feed the resulting biomatter into a furnace at the exact rate necessary to appease the gods."

column4: "If you were to stand up all the products you have accumulated over the course of your entire life on top of one another, the result would probably be as tall as a cliff."
column5: "The salesman is standing on the cliff's edge. ""Buy my products!! Buy my products! Or else I'll take my own life""! Man, that's selling on pressure."

column4: "You are struggling to the top across the humps, but you suddenly see the pinnacle and you feel new life in your walking legs."
column5: A woman takes her bra off and what happens? Nine months later the hump in her belly pops out between her legs as a new life.

column4: """Walking legs"" over ""bushes"" needs to have a primitive meaning of its own. It appears in several kanji, such as 縫 sew (#1563), 逢 tryst (#2417), 蜂 bee (#2687), and 鋒 sword's point (#2768), and it is clumsy to work bushes and walking legs into every story. ""Pointy"" works fairly well: the walking legs are stuck on top of the pointy part of the bush; and for this character: a summit is the pointy end of a mountain."
column5: Moses climbs to the summit of the mountain using his walking legs to talk to the burning bush.

column4: "Good thing I brought some thread, cause I need to sew my pants that I tore up walking through the bushes (see summit (#1562)) before we hit the road to go back down the mountain."
column5: "Spiderman while walking through bushes chasing a villain, rips his suit and stops on the road to sew it up."

column4: I put my fingers together in worship of the bush that hangs from the ceiling -- that wonderful mistletoe which has gotten me kissed by many a girl.
column5: "Because I worship her, I only finger ONE BUSH, her's, and no others!"

column4: "This old China man glued shrubs to his body. The added intake of oxygen from the shrubs was, according to him, the secret of his longevity. Sometimes he would sit all day in meditation without moving, and the locals believed the old man had actually turned into a shrub !"
column5: "To ensure longevity of her virginity, Alice applied a thick layer of glue on her bush."

column4: They made a metal casting of the Chinese man who glued shrubs to himself to increase his longevity. It's now sold around the world as it's thought that having one will increase your own longevity..
column5: You make a casting of your baby's shoes in gold to ensure the longevity of the experience.

column4: "Once upon a time, in order to enroll in a Christian school you had to answer a series of questions to ensure that you were really Christian. For example, the principal might show you a picture of a Christmas tree and a picture of some bamboo and ask you which one is most suitable for decoration at Christmas time."
column5: "Once upon a time, Santa Claus visited Asia and left presents under bamboo Christmas trees for all the children who enrolled in his Asian beta-testing..."

column4: In the springtime bonsai get plenty of sun.
column5: When it's springtime you can only leave the bonsai out when the sun has gone down. Their little leaves can't handle too much heat.

column4: "The tree of spring. Fact: Camellia are highly valued in Japan and elsewhere for their very early flowering, often among the first flowers to appear in the late winter [early spring?]."
column5: Anyone who's lived in Japan knows camellia are by far the first tree of spring to flower. And how can you miss those shockingly pink flowers!

column4: If you look into Japanese gardens they seem so peaceful - with their small bonsais and the white stones looking like rice grains.
column5: Simplistic and peaceful life: A bonsai to trim and enough rice to eat...　RTK2:　タイ　泰国　たいこく (Thailand).

column4: "When you play music to them, your bonsai will grow like they are in heaven."
column5: "In heaven you are surrounded by bonsai trees (full-sized ones fall through the clouds) while you play music on your harp. I always have trouble remembering that the bonsai tree is on top, so think of them growing on top of the clouds."

column4: "Bonsais are grown in a house, away from the harsh reality of the real world where they wouldn't survive."
column5: "On this rather boring 'big brother' type reality show, they have locked up bonsai inside a house and everyone is watching them on TV 24x7. The viewers have to vote on which bonsai shall remain in the house and which one has to leave."

column4: "To join the temple, you have to dedicate yourself to raising bonsai for enlightenment, and cornstalks for sustenance."
column5: "A Japanese farmer who was growing corn tried to dedicate himself to the god of corn (in the hope it would bring better harvests). He had a little room with prayer beads, incense, etc. One day he brought an offerand that he thought would please the god of corn : a bonsai - corn (a corn plant turned into a bonsai). The god was infuriated and yelled at him ""HOW DARE YOU TORTURE MY CORN IN SUCH WAYS!"". The End."

column4: "Mr. T gets a stipend every month if he stays dedicated to his temple training, a very hard thing for the impatient T."
column5: People who are highly dedicated to their jobs get good salaries/stipends.

column4: "Ha! If you know anything about Buddhist monks, during meditation, they're slapped with wooden rods to stay dedicated to their task."
column5: The wood from this tree is dedicated to making rods to flog naughty kids.

column4: "Muttering words of gratitude for a wonderful meal, I discreetly slipped my cabbage under the table for the dog."
column5: "Cabbage primitive: When a cabbage is growing up, you must put it in your mouth before it flowers, because that's when it becomes bitter. Seriously, it's called 'bolting' or something. When you're discreet, you try to make your words like a cabbage: well-layered, but in an unassuming way."

column4: It takes great DILIGENCE for a cabbage patch dolly to build up her muscles and win the Miss Universe contest!
column5: Growing cabbages takes muscle and diligence.

column4: "In the water between Japan and China, the Sino- side has put scarecrows in the water to try and keep the Japanese away."
column5: "Take the left to be ""kanji"" not scarecrow. Sino- (Chinese) people had to put a lot of sweat into learning the kanji. See the drops of sweat coming off."

column4: "A sigh escapes the mouth of the scarecrow, who laments: ""...if I only had a brain, I could learn kanji""."
column5: I will let out a huge sigh of relief from my mouth when I learn the last kanji.

column4: It is difficult for a scarecrow to scare a turkey or else they would've been called scareturkeys.
column5: Learning Kanji is difficult for Turkeys.

column4: "The Queen of England taking a walk round a village: 'Excuse me, I couldn't help noticing the splendour of the flowers in your garden. Simply splendid. Ten out of ten.' The villager gruffly replies: 'No it 'aint. It's all muck. An' I'm gonna cut it all down and sell it to the farmer for silage.'."
column5: Hint: Splendor in the Grass. Compare with 草. This is just a more splendid version of that kanji.

column4: "For an old man with a walking stick, even a drop of silage to carry on his back will make him droop low down to the floor."
column5: Even a drop of silage is enough to make an old man with a walking stick droop low down to the floor. (rgravina - fixed up order).

column4: Our eyes droop when we are drowsy.
column5: "Hint : the eyes of Droopy Dog (see droop (#1582)). When you are drowsy you have ""droopy eyes"". That is, you have Droopy's eyes!"

column4: Wasn't it a cursed spindle that Sleeping Beauty pricked her finger on? Therefore the spindle was the metal that caused her to droop and eventually sleep for 100 years.
column5: Spindle: the needle that drops on an LP record player. This is made of metal. It droops. Viola.

column4: It's a hay ride! You sit on piles of silage and everyone likes to imitate old-time farmers with a piece of wheat sticking out of their mouths.
column5: "[ride; power; multiplication; record; counter for vehicles; board; mount; join] In the near future, we hope to ride on biomass fueled vehicles. Good news for those who have wheat silage surplus."

column4: "If you go for a ride and find a saber beside you, perhaps you got into an Army surplus jeep."
column5: "Recall the wheat sabers we made a profit (#906) off. We made too many and now there's surplus, for sale on this hay ride."

column4: My MEETING is at 7- but that's NOW!
column5: (re: ruuku35) The meeting is not at quarter to seven but now!

column4: This clock includes a mouth that will tell you what the time is now. Hearing impaired people have this kind of watches... now imagine them as a big mouth under the clock.
column5: Batteries included with this clock. Open the mouth at the back and insert them after purchase.

column4: "A rapper is trying to versify, but sucks: Hickery dickery dock, the mouth spat out the clock. I'm gonna shoot you with my glock, if you don't suck my cock! Versify!"
column5: "To versify, words of rhythm needs to shoot out of your MOUTH with a CLOCK-like regularity."

column4: Someone wishing from the bottom of their heart that the clock would stop. A mid-life crisis perhaps.
column5: Remember in the Wizard of Oz when the tin man wished for a heart and the wizard gave him that dinky little clock instead?

column4: Two kings were fighting over a beautiful koto (harp). So they had a clock built into it that would measure how long each one played it. That way they could be sure none played it more than othe other.
column5: "Jesus is coming soon. Prepare to meet the king of kings now. Practice your harp playing skills all future angels!...　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　キン　琴線　きんせん(""heart strings"")."

column4: "The only shade at The Pinnacle is in the shadow of the giant clock tower, or from a rising cloud."
column5: "Frosty the snowman is running around the pinnacle, staying in the shade. As he looks at his clock to see how much longer he can last, small clouds rise (steam) from his body. Nooo, Frosty!"

column4: "Beforehand, this was a halberd but I cut it short so it could be for hand to hand combat."
column5: "Your halberd doesn't have a handguard? You should have thought of that beforehand (i.e., before you were missing your hand)."

column4: The preface to all human history was written beforehand in caves.
column5: "Rename the ""beforehand"" part to be glove (because you have to wear gloves beforehand if you want to wield the halberd, which is why this primitive is an incomplete halberd). The story: a winter morning. A textbook author is holed up in his tiny office, a veritable cave. He wants to start his masterpiece textbook by first writing the preface. But he can't get started. He sits and stares at empty paper until evening. It gets cold and he puts on gloves, shivering, but still unable to start his preface."

column4: Depositing money into your savings account is something you do beforehand if you use your head. If you're in Japan your passbook says 預金機（よきんき）when you make a deposit.
column5: "You bang your head on the ATM, wishing you'd deposited some money beforehand."

column4: "These days we all work in front of computers. Beforehand we all worked out in the fields, in the plains."
column5: "The plains are a challenging place to get any work done. Be sure you recharge your computer's battery beforehand, or you won't get anything done."

column4: "Our ninja hero, disguised as a gardener with a rake, is suddenly attacked from both left and right concurrently by bulls with animal horns. Our hero lets out a blood-curdling scream and tears his rake handle vertically in half, so he now has two wooden staffs (split rake handle) to fight with. He grips each staff (left side and right side) and rams it into the horns of the charging bulls. The force of each charging bull causes the tips of each staff to split again (split bottom of each rake handle)."
column5: "You decide to take the bull by the horns and do both chores concurrently, grabbing your double-handled rake before attempting to clean up both your's and your neighbours' garden. But unfortunately, it's not long until your rake splits in two."

column4: "Naturally, if you're dating more than one woman concurrently, they will certainly dislike each other!"
column5: Attempting to court two women concurrently will make them both dislike you.

column4: This is a special sickle with metal blades on both sides. It can cut many things concurrently!
column5: The gold sickle of the USSR flag represents both leaders and workers laboring concurrently.

column4: When you are self-effacing you use words to concurrently bring yourself down and make yourself look better.
column5: "Though the man's words were self-effacing, his actions concurrently made it clear that his modesty was false."

column4: "Stores don't want you to know it, but if you find the secret cave, they run bargains there concurrently to their regular prices. (Image: pulling a certain level in a store to find the ""bargain cave)."
column5: "If you have several sellers competing concurrently, one will cave in and give you a bargain…　RTK2:　レン　廉売　れんばい(bargain)…　MIXED GROUP: 鎌1599　(ｹﾝ): 兼1597　嫌1598　謙1600."

column4: The old west represented by a completely empty whiskey bottle (compare sign of the bird (#1427) whiskey bottle about one third full).
column5: Note: this kanji is also used to denote Spain.

column4: "Mr. T has a high value in the Old West because you see him in ""Wanted"" posters all over the place! (thanks fiminor)."
column5: "What might it mean for a person in the old west to be of value? Their face is on a ""Wanted!"" poster, of course. Imagine the reward..."

column4: "(ヨウ) When Clint needs a woman, he likes to be on top."
column5: "In some movie with the theme of the Old West, the population of a town finds themselve in dire need of women, after all of the town's womens became crazy and started gunshooting and participating in duels and such."

column4: "If you want to get closer to the actual meaning, then I think that 腰(こし) is more like the hips or the small of the back. After being sat down in the office too long, people often say 腰がいたい！It's the part of the body that needs massaging."
column5: "To the puritans reading this site - please stop reporting stories that have anything to do with sex! Although (as wrightak said) this kanji really refers to the hips, Heisig clearly chose the keyword 'loins' because it was anatomically close enough, and the primitives lent themselves to an easy-to-remember story. Just because you're all sexually repressed doesn't mean other people won't benefit from a story such as ""the part of the body people need more than any other are the loins""."

column4: "In the Old West there were no ballot boxes. Afraid of fraud and fighting among the gunslingers, the ballots were posted into a slot in the top of the local church altar instead. They may have been rough, but the cowboys wouldn't fight in the church."
column5: "In western political elections (US), peoples ballots will often depend on religion and at which altar the prospective president prays."

column4: "In Florida, Bush through Kerry's ballots into the water, watching them drift away and setting the whole country adrift."
column5: The political fanatic stole all the ballots and dumped them in the stream. He calmly watched them drift away as the cops came to a screech behind him.

column4: "Trees were frequenly used as signposts in those days, indicating where one had to go to cast their ballots."
column5: "Large wooden signposts are planted on peoples lawns, with the faces of their representatives all saying: ""Vote [1] Me!"" for the upcoming ballot."

column4: "Chestnut tree, west nut tree."
column5: The cowboy climbed the tree to see where they were in the woods. The poor guy chose a chestnut tree. ouch ouch.

column4: "Since the days of the Old West, traveling has transitioned from trying not to step on big snakes to driving on big roads."
column5: "The west has gone through quite a transition, gone are the days when dogs and snakes roamed the desert, it's all roads and casinos now."

column4: "The U.S.S. Old West has capsized, and all the cowboys on board are trying to restore her upright."
column5: "Remember Oregon Trail? Remember how you had to float your wagon across rivers to get to the Old West? Well, sometimes that wagon capsizes. Once that happens you'd better quickly head to the nearest town to restore."

column4: "In the Old West, they used to light fires in the ground to make smoke signals."
column5: "Should be easy. SMOKE brings to mind ""Where there's SMOKE, there's FIRE"". So, the FIRE in the OLD WEST can tell people we're you're at, so put out the FIRE with SOIL to keep the SMOKE to a minimum."

column4: South of my belt leads to happiness.
column5: "In the south (Southern Alabama, Southern Africa, picture any south, but choose one and stick with it) ""they measure happyness by the belt"". If someone has a larger belly (and a longer belt), it is believed they are well fed and thus are happy."

column4: We traveled to southern Japan just to see a camphor tree. It's what we came for.
column5: "Trivia: Cinnamomum camphora is native to Taiwan, southern Japan, southeast China and Indochina,."

column4: A South Korean street vendor is offering chihuahu snacks.
column5: "If you go to someones place and the food sucks, you lower it down south of the table as an offering to their dog."

column4: "Heisig's stroke order in the 4th edition (and earlier) is wrong, so be careful -- first is the left-most vertical stroke, then draw the rest of the ""sun"" attachment as you would normally. In fact, if you just wrote it out as two suns with elongated sides, you'll get the stroke order exactly correct."
column5: The gates to Hell. guarded by Cerebus or ... Bill Gates?

column4: "A mouth on the Gates of Hell says ""Answer me these questions three, or thru the gates ye soon will be""."
column5: """Hark! Who goes there?"" is the expected question from the mouth of the guard at the gate…　　　RTK2:　モン　質問　しつもん(question)."

column4: A little devil at the gates of hell reviews your record to see if you're evil enough to get in.
column5: "As I was reviewing for my exam at a quiet saloon, the devil popped out of nowhere and offered to make sure I pass. But I told him no way, since that's cheating. Besides, I'm just reviewing things I already know. I won't fail. But he kept insisting, so I kicked him and sent him crashing through the entrance gates."

column4: You set a guard at the gate to fell intruders not of your clique.
column5: "The felled souls of the world, cut down like trees, pass through the gates of hell and join the clique."

column4: "The interval between star systems (suns) was too large, so the stargates were created to travel between them."
column5: We open the gates at regular intervals to let a bit of sun in.

column4: The simplicity of bamboo plant is in all its joints being at equal intervals.
column5: [simplicity; brevity] The ししおどし is a bamboo device for scaring birds from the gates of your garden by clacking against a stone at regular intervals. Its design is simplicity itself. (Inspired by PepeSeco).

column4: "Sure you can squeeze through these gates by kicking them or pushing them with your body, but if you want to get them wide open, you need to do that with both your hands."
column5: "To open the gate, use your both hands."

column4: "The gates are too big to be closed by man. Only a genie can. ""Close sesame!""."
column5: "You hear lesbians moaning ""オォ~"" from behind closed gates, and you ask a genius how to get in there."

column4: "To keep this distinct from other kanji such as ""watchtower"" and ""pagoda"", I use the mnemonic ""towering tower"". -- In some old 8-bit kung-fu videogame, with a plot similar as Bruce Lee's last, unfinished movie, the hero must break through a gate at each level of the towering tower, fighting with opponents using various styles of kung-fu until he meets the finale at the topmost level of the ""towering tower""."
column5: Remember the two towers from lord of the rings... each has it's own - very difficult to master - entrance gate.

column4: "Imagine the gates the Garden of Eden, the ultimate land of leisure. You're not allowed in, but if you peek through you can see trees."
column5: Getting wood watching lesbians is my idea of leisure time.

column4: Press your ear to the gates and see if you can hear what is going on inside.
column5: "To distinguish from listen, you hear someone at the door (gate)."

column4: "Forgetting about the moat, the king stepped out of his gate and landed in the water. Needless to say he got wet."
column5: "(I had the same idea as Dingomick) I imagine some prankster who put a bucket full of water on top of the huge gates, so that it would fall on the king as he came through them. See the king now, between the gates, all wet, dripping drops of water."

column4: [column; handrail; blank; space] I think about oriental (eastern) Torii gates: they have two supporting columns made of wood.
column5: A column of text scratched on a black tree beside the gates of Hell: To the East lies The Beast.

column4: "During the saloon brawl, one guy got glued to a table and was tossed out through the saloon gates. But he really wanted to fight, so he ran back through those gates (with the table still glued to his back) only to be tossed out again. Imagine him repeatedly running in and being tossed back out."
column5: "Food fight! Look, beans are stuck to the gates like glue."

column4: "(Warning-this one is crude) Imagine a godown (dockside warehouse) where you can meet girls who will godown on you with their mouth. To keep the place a bit of a secert, they only have one gate."
column5: "Hint : the ""godown"" is like a warehouse, it's on the docks and mostly in Asia. To make an image distinct from that of ""warehouse"" or ""storehouse"", etc, I picture the goods stored there, piled up on pallets really high, and thus they have to ""godown"" before they can be taken outside. The front of this godown is a ""meeting of small gates"", i.e. a row of gates through which goods come in and out. The mouth can be an opening somewhere in the back, or the top, where cranes lift down the goods."

column4: Back in the day the people were so excited to get hold of the Sega genesis they looted the godown with sabers.
column5: I prefer to have girls Godown on my sabre to prevent unwanted GENESIS of babies............創造　そうぞう (creation).

column4: This looks like a pictogram of 3 fingers from each hand trying to open up a crack in a wall. That's an un-believable way to escape from prison OR the UN- have a prison in the Hague.
column5: "People in the jail cell are un-friendly, un-comely, and un-cooperative."

column4: I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail cell/ I pity the fool. (Credit taijuando).
column5: I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail/ I pity the fool.

column4: "When ordered to go to the jail cell, the defendant gave the judge the finger and said he repudiated all that the legal system stood for if they were going to send an innocent man like him to jail."
column5: "He reached his fingers through the bars of his jail cell, trying to touch his beloved. But she repudiated him and left."

column4: "Saddness is like having your heart captured and jailed because of some sad or terrible event, etc. Here the sad heart waits for someone to come and un-lock their jail cell and set them free again."
column5: "Stuck in a jail cell with his heart crying out to see his family again, the prisoner has never felt so sad."

column4: "Guilty under the eyes of the law, therefore sentenced to jail. [note: 'UNDER the eye of the law' works in penalty (#833) as well.]."
column5: "It is his guilt that is causing them. He is having these nightmares where the great (sideways) eye appears at the top of his jail cell, and is staring down intently at him. Guilt is a merciless tormentor."

column4: "Some man jailed in Russia, is freed by his comrade (from the Communist party perhaps), who crashes into the jail cell with a vehicle."
column5: (+fuaburisu) But it's the wrong jail cell! Your comrade is one floor above.

column4: The only way out of a jail cell is to serve your time and walk out the front door. There are no other doors.
column5: "An old man serving a very long jail sentence painted a life-like door at the back of his jail cell, hlafway open, with the blue sky, clouds, etc, as some kind of symbol of freedom. Every time the prison officers come to take him they ask him to come to the door. The old man with a grin always answers ""Which door?"", looking at his painted door with a grin. And the prison officer always answer, sighing - ""The front door !""."

column4: "Mr. T is made a marquis after he and the A-Team save the life of a duke. The duke also gives Mr. T the key to the gentleman's dart room where one can relax in luxury, smoke a cigar, and play a friendly game of darts. Mr. T eagerly accepts the key and places it on one of the gold chains that hang around his neck which acts as a key chain."
column5: (Going off various) Mr. T. is made a marquis and given the key to the city. But somebody disagrees with it and assassinates him with a dart.

column4: The marquis has absolutely no interest in issuses of climate change. He's old and near death. [Don't forget the walking stick to symbolize his old age.].
column5: The marquis moves to a warmer climate after he gets old enough to need a walking stick to get around.

column4: """Decide!"" ""Decide?! Death by drowning in polluted water or death by guillotine. How can I decide?"" I asked."
column5: To decide if someone is a witch or not first dunk them in water. If they don't drown they are a witch and can be sent to the guillotine.

column4: A large crowd in a cheerful state of mind applaude each criminal as they become victims of the guillotine.
column5: A cheerful crowd of insulted aliens applaude as Data's head is chopped off by guillotine.

column4: "Mr. T is certainly an ADMIRABLE PERSON, so much so that parents are buying lockets with his picture in it and having their children wear them like amulets."
column5: "For locket: The locket (key dangling from something, the vertical stroke) opens like a mouth, but you need a jeweler's monocle to make out the pictures within. ----- Dracula survives a staking attempt when the locket with Mina's admirable picture deflects the blow. ""It was an admirable attempt,"" he admits as he sucks his attacker's blood."

column4: "You lose your precious locket on the road to somewhere. You ask people if they've seen it, but no luck. ""Just buy another one,"" someone says. ""I mean, what's the difference?"" Then of course you say ""Well, it makes a huge difference!! Since it has sentimental value, I don't want a different one! "" Then of course they understand."
column5: "An odd version of The Road Less Traveled: ""I found a locket in the road, and that has made all the difference.""."

column4: Spiderman buys a locket for Mary Jane because he wants to get HORIZONTAL with her.
column5: "Spiderman on a boat, marking the Earth's latitudes. He first attaches a personal locket to a small piece of thread for ballast and good luck, and shoots with his right hand. After a few minutes (and lots and lots of thread), the locket and thread have flown around the world. Spiderman catches the locket with his left hand, and ties the thread's ends together. Voilà."

column4: "[defense; protection] For ""defense against the dark arts"" class, you go the magical boulevard and buy an enchanted locket."
column5: "Since it was in the middle of the boulevard, everyone could see she hit the man only in self-defense, as he was trying to steal her valuable locket."

column4: "There's a young Korean male actor, Yon-sama, famous amongst middle-aged Japanese women. Extremely famous. Read about his affect on Japan/Korean relations on Everything2.com. In any case, women just flipped over this guy, traveled to Korea to see his home, started taking Korean language classes, etc. So, imagine here the misty eyes of the Japanese women as they clutch their lockets with Yon-sama's picture inside watching his Korean romantic mini series called ""Winter Sonata""."
column5: This character represents the flag of South Korea: a locket (circular taegeuk) in the middle of the mist (white background). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_South_Korea.

column4: Dry one item in ten minutes on the clothesline.
column5: Note: the book shows the strokes for potato rather than dry...dry does not have the hook at the end.

column4: Well you all know that the liver is the part of the body that would be quite grateful if you led a dry lifestyle (i.e. no alcohol).
column5: The slaughterhouse prefers to ship dried liver to the supermarkets (can you imagine boxes soaked in blood on the truck that delivers them?). Imagine them lifting the slabs of flesh and hanging them on the clothesline to dry.

column4: The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry and then cut down with a sabre to be published.
column5: "The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry. This gives the government a chance to censor the news: they cut up unwanted stories with a sabre. Therefore, only state-approved stories are published."

column4: "The way sweat is supposed to work: it gets your skin wet, and then as it evaporates/dries, it cools you off."
column5: "When you sweat your clothes become soaked with water, prompting you to hang them to dry on a clothesline."

column4: "Flats in the city are crowded. You get a space for your car in front, and a clothesline out back. Nothing else."
column5: Small flats (garages) for cars help keeping them dry.

column4: "At the base of mountain cliffs, there is usually a beach. You often can see people lying there, drying off after a swim."
column5: Three impossibilities for a beach: There cannot be a beach at the top of a mountain. There cannot be a beach on the top of a cliff. There cannot be a beach that is completely dry.

column4: "A fine mist is falling, and so everyone gathers around near the tree-trunk, effectively using the rest of the tree as an umbrella in order to keep dry."
column5: "By astridtops - In the rainy mist, Totoro is standing in front of a tree-trunk at the bus stop, under the umbrella he just received. Look at him smiling: even when the big drops fall, he remains dry! Great story...which I get to by thinking: tree-trunk->TT ->Tonari no Totoro. I also imagine Mickey Mouse is there too as the KUNyomi for this kanji is みき."

column4: "If your potatos are growing flowers and those little hooked roots, you should either buy less or eat them faster."
column5: "If your potatoes are growing flowers, you need to store them in a more dry place, like hanging them on hooks so they don't accumulate moisture on the floor."

column4: Under the eaves of the house the poor family has potate plants.
column5: "Very good image Erik. To help those who struggleded with this, the eaves of a house is usually the bit where you hang the roof gutter along, usually made of zinc or plastic and shaped as a half-pipe. It catches rain water, so it flows to a drain pipe instead of down onto people and windows. And in this family the potato plants grow along the eaves so the water pours down on them. They are poor. so no gutter."

column4: You hang an umbrella upside-down on a hook of the scales and fill it with little potatoes. No luck: it weights too much.
column5: "This is the kanji for 「あまり Amari」, which means too little in negative sentences and too much in the rest (always with a negative sense). I take the liberty of using the symbol "">"" (more than, another meaning!!) as the umbrella component, and using two (#2) and little (#105) for the potato primitive. So, this kanji either means ""two much"" (more than 2) or ""two little"". (thanks, Virtua_leaf and Thunderball!)."

column4: "To become a member of The Pinnacle, they test you on a scale. If you weigh too much, they exclude you."
column5: You won't make it unless you exclude something. The climb to the pinacle cannot be completed if you are carrying too much. You just have to decide what you can afford to exclude.

column4: "You can't expect weight loss to happen overnight. You should limit going to the scale to weigh yourself to once a day or once a week, in order to observe the anticipated weight loss gradually."
column5: I set up a column chart next to my scales so I could record my weight gradually changing.

column4: "Amazed at the weight of his crotch, they conferred every honor upon him. (Image: guy with his junk on a scale getting a medal pinned to his chest/around his neck/being knighted, etc.)."
column5: "When you confer again 又, you confer too much 余!"

column4: "On this route, all trucks have to check in at the scales before they can get on the road."
column5: "There are too many roads, so you need to plan a route."

column4: The main bar of an old-fashioned scale(balance) will be very diagonal if you place a giant measuring cup on one side.
column5: "The constellation of libra (meaning "" scales"" in latin) is diagonal to the handle of the big dipper."

column4: If you add too much water to the paint it will drip onto the ground.
column5: A true artisan mixes his own paint from water and soils on a scale in careful proportions.

column4: "Mnemonic: Bundle of joy. Here I see the proverbial stork with a baby hanging from its mouth fly straight into a tree. Painful, but he doesn't drop the bundle."
column5: "Unlike in 杏, this big mouth isn't content to wait for apricots to fall in his mouth, so he has climbed the tree and is taking them in bundles."

column4: "We found a bundle of severed heads in your room, its difficult to trust you."

column4: You need complete trust in your water guide to attempt Class 5 rapids.
column5: "You can never trust the water in the rapids, it will do everything it can to pull you under. Imagine a line of natives with bundles upon their heads all fighting the rapids to cross the river."

column4: "This is an imperial order for pizza. To deliver the huge bundle of pizzas to the emperor, the pizza boy needs huge muscles."
column5: Imperial order carries quite a bundle of executive power.

column4: "[True story] In Osaka the homeless (the alienated) live in large numbers around the city zoo. Picture them in winter all bundled up in rags trying to keep warm, alienated from the society, living literally worst than the animals in the zoo who at least are bundled in their natural furs and have pens to live in sheltered from the elements."
column5: This kanji is so strange that it was alienated at the kanji zoo. The bundle of joy stork bundles this kanji up and takes it to a kanji foster home.

column4: "If you find a bundle of money on the road, pick it up quick before anyone notices."
column5: "Uh oh. The stork just dropped the bundle of joy in the middle of the road. Somebody save it, quick!"

column4: "Recycling in Japan, you have to make sure all your bundles are organized correctly otherwise the taskmasters won't accept them."
column5: When a bundle of taskmasters organize something chances are it won't be done correctly because they are constantly arguing.

column4: "If it helps, make the awl primitive ice pick instead. They're basically the same thing. This kanji is an easy David vs. Goliath story of the icepick vs. the saber..."
column5: "Every self-respecting ninja knows the story of ""The Awl and the Sabre"". According to the legend, a woman once defended herself by using an awl against a sabre! She used to work all day with that awl. However, the bandit using the sabre had no skill. And thus the awl beat the sabre. And from there the saying goes : ""The sabre is powerless against the awl, if one can't use the sabre.""."

column4: "The edge of The Pinnacle is precipitous, so they have a guard posted with an ice pick to poke people and keep them from the edge."
column5: Well I have someone climbing an inflatable precipitous pinnacle. Once at the top it is so precipitous that the person is afraid to climb down and instead punctures the inflatable pinnacle with an awl to get safely and slowly back to the ground.

column4: Two heavy trucks in a game of chicken collide while racing toward each other on the boulevard.

STORY:Two HEAVY trucks are playing a game of chicken on the BOULEVARD. However, they both missed the IMPORTANT POINT: that they have to turn in different directions. Naturally, they COLLIDE when they both turn in the same direction. (ty dingomick)."

column5: The heavier the flowers the stronger their fragrance when you burn them.

column4: Caveman got ill after flying third class. The cabin air and food got to him. (Primitive: these all got MUCH easier when using CAVEMAN instead. ).

column5: A sickness can only be correctly diagnosed if the symptoms are identified correctly.

Scuba divers also know that as you ascend in the water, the lucidity of the water improves, too."

column4: "Mr. T also finds himself as one of the HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. But when his wife comes up to punish him, he pleads, “It’s ME, Baby. I wasn’t behaving badly like these other foo’s.”."
column5: "Building on johnskb: Although it goes against the Heisig method, this story is a lot easier to remember when you know it's the kanji for ""boku."" Males usually use either ""boku"" or ""ore"" (instead of ""watashi"") to refer themselves. ""Boku"" is slightly boyish and soft; ""ore"" is rough & tough. Mr. T would definitely use ""ore"" -- but when he's one of the husbands hung upside down in a row about to be punished by his wife, he puts on a sweet act and switches to ""boku"" when he pleads ""come on baby, it's ME!""."

column4: This is a magic shield with ten eyes which have the power to drag the victim towards it.
column5: "From Wikipedia: ""If a Spartan hoplite were to return to Sparta alive and without his shield, it was assumed that he threw his shield at the enemy in an effort to flee; an act punishable by death or banishment."" Picture the enemy of a Spartan soldier poking his eyes out with a sewing needle and trying to steal his shield. However, the Spartan desperately clutches on, and is dragged around for a while, preferring to die than to lose his shield."

column4: "This is mostly used in the word 循環, ""circulation"" (of buses through their routes, of blood, etc). So I think of a column of little Roman soldiers with their shields marching sequentially through the veins of a person, as an anthropomorphization of the immune system."
column5: "A column of shielded soldiers advancing sequentially to avoid revealing the size of their army (Think ""Sandpeople always ride single file to hide their numbers"" from Star Wars)."

column4: "Drag + rag gave me trouble until I came up with zombie for it. The zombie population became more diverse, separating into different factions. One of them being the water Zombies."
column5: "The radical faction is almost eliminated, sir. They're living in the sewers dressed in rags and dragging their supplies."

column4: The vein is the part of the body most lusted after by the flesh hungry zombies (drag & rag - see revenantkioku frame 1855).
column5: "To get blood drawn from a vein you present the part of the body to the nurse, and they drag an alcohol swab (rag) across the vein."

column4: "Masses of zombies, splattered with blood. (any zombie movie)."
column5: "When the masses are hurt, say in a natural disaster like an earthquake, they can be seen everywhere dragging their bloody rags."

column4: (I prefer 2 towels over cornstalk and belt) - Have you ever wondered why your parcels always end up in such bad condition when you get them? Or why you never get them at all? That's because you've never looked at how they're actually delivered - each postman is given a load of parcel post and 2 towels to drag them down the road on.
