column5: "In the ancient parcel post, they just would drag the packages behind them tied to cornstalks woven into a long belt down the road. It was a wonder than anything arrived intact."

column4: This is a military-grade staple gun! It can be loaded with real missiles.
column5: "In order to get your 1st grade, or first-dan (だん) black belt, you have to learn hand to hand combat with new weapons - first the grapple involving the staple gun, and then the missile deployment technique."

column4: "As a discriminating metalsmith, I use the highest grade metals when forging such precision devices as staple guns and missiles."
column5: Metal has to be forged many times over in order to reach a high grade.

column4: "The empress is cruel. Normally she'll violently pull her servants by the ear when they've failed to follow orders. But one time she dragged this one guy around the palace by the mouth. She must have been really angry—ever since that moment, he's never been seen again."
column5: The F word often comes out of the mouth of the empress.

column4: "After the play, The Phantasm of the Opera hangs up his cape on a clothes hanger and returns to his cocoon to sleep."
column5: "You open your closet and find strange, glowing cocoons sitting on your clothes hangers... definitely a phantasm!"

column4: "The porn director has one big mouth. ""Don't bother putting your clothes on a hanger, just get started.""."
column5: The director sticks a clothes hanger in each actor's mouth and hangs them from the ceiling until he needs them.

column4: Mr. T is the director. You better pay respects to him!
column5: "If Mr. T gets a role in a film, he doesnt pay respects to the director, the director pays respects to Mr. T."

column4: "The big mouthed diretor is even picky about the parts of speech you use, shouting, ""More verbs! Less adjectives!"" and such all the time."
column5: A Grammar is basically a word director that tells us what part of speech each word is.

column4: "After a pride of hungry lions ate the director, the producer decided to tone down his documentary and film domesticated cats instead."
column5: "When you DOMESTICATE a animal, you are the DIRECTOR of it's life and what it EATS."

column4: The director's mouth dropped open as he flipped through the scrapbook of properties he was about to become heir to.
column5: "Careful with inherit (#1370). The egoistic director leaves instructions about what shall be handed down to his heir upon the director's death. First, the director's mouth should be surgically removed and preserved, to be handed down to his heir. Second, a scrapbook of the director's proudest scenes should also be handed down. The mouth reminds the heir that the director must be a loudmouth; the scrapbook reminds the heir of how to be a good director."

column4: "I see this kanji as a pictograph of a two story boat seen from the front. The glass canopy is the body of the boat. The drop on top is the chimney. The horizontal line is the ceiling/floor between the the 1st/2nd floor. Finally, the two drops in the middle are the lights on the decks."
column5: "Cinnabar (丹) colored boat, the extra drop signifying that the paint hasn't dried yet. The stick represents the oars."

column4: "The most famous LINER is the Titanic, which struck an iceberg and sunk. Just imagine that huge LINER strucking an even huger mass of white ice."
column5: "A liner is to boat as an emperor (#261) is to a king (#255), or a chief (#967) is to a person (#951): in each case we need only add white to the latter in order to get the former."

column4: "To navigate a ""boat"" through a ""whirlwind"" takes a skilled navigator."
column5: "In Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker, you can navigate your boat by summoning whirlwinds."

column4: "Carrier?! This means ""general"" (as in the general public or generally). OK.. Carriers, i.e. boats with missiles, are not available to the general public."
column5: "In general, carrier boats have missiles."

column4: "What do you call a ""CARRIER"" of DISHes? A TRAY."
column5: "Imagine a restaurant set in Disney's Fantasia or maybe in Harry Potter's university, where dishes are magically landing and taking off of a carrier tray."

column4: "When workers neglect workplace safety, their fingers get cut off and carried away by the conveyor belt, which looks like a 'finger carrier' in that case."
column5: "During WWII, morse code was the primary means of communication from sea. The morse code specialist was the conveyor of messages to and from the crew of the carrier, using his fingers to tap out the secret messages. (This works especially well for 搬送周波数 carrier frequency and 搬送波 carrier wave, being the radio waves/frequencies used in morse code)."

column4: A boy floats his toy boat in a gully and imagines it as an immense ship.
column5: "Aargh, hard to keep this separate from boat. How about this: the phrase ""shape up or ship out!"" This phrase originally meant that a soldier had better get his act together, or else face being shipped off into a combat zone. Here we see a poor WW-I soldier who has been shipped off to a combat zone. He's riding in the boat overseas to fight in the trenches (gulley)."

column4: "The warship towers over the smaller benign boats, overseeing their safe path from port to port."
column5: A warship is a boat that oversees the seas. Think of it as the patroller of the ocean.

column4: "In venice, the boat used by the courts to transport criminals is a rowboat."
column5: "Courts in olden times would often punish convicts by sentencing them to a life of being the rower crew for large rowboat ships (there were no engines or boilers back then)... Yo ho, Yo ho...."

column4: "何これ???? ok, sorry to be crude... if you claw at a girls melons, she is gonna give you the elbow."
column5: "Vegetarian vultures are fighting for a melon, each trying to elbow its way to it with claws."

column4: "When you use a bow to shoot a melon, the arc varies depending on how far away you are."
column5: "Joan of Arc (""arc"" also means ""bow"" in french) is practicing with a bow, shooting at melons in a distant field."

column4: An orphan will never know the joys on sucking on his mother's melons........
column5: "Unlike the celebrated story of Momotaro the peach boy, no one knows the story of the melon boy who was left an orphan."

column4: "This is a simple two-column manga showing the metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a cocoon. First, the caterpillar gets under a large flower (bees tend to hang around flowers, which scare away other predators). Then, in the first frame, we see the caterpillar (insect). Then, a bar separating this frame from the next frame (remember that Japanese manga run the other way!), in which we see the insect covered with thread, making a beautiful cocoon."
column5: "The magic flower is the reason why Spider-Man ended up miniaturized and confined inside a hood-like cocoon together with an insect. Now, only a walking stick separates them both."

column4: The benefit of having sharp horns and fast legs is that an animal can get to the food dish first.
column5: The benefit of being an animal with horns and fast legs is in keeping it from becoming a dish for the other animals! (shaydwyrm).

column4: "Some jackass-like people have way too much spare time. You can find video's of them all over the internet, if you like such things, you can watch it all day. You see them stapling their mouths shut, or throwing eachother upside down in boxes or kicking each other in the crotch."
column5: "Tip: The complex right side of this kanji appears twice more in Heisig. He later names it ""hobby"". REF: shrimp (#2689), haze (#2779)."

column4: Arrowheads are spread all over the field. The taskmaster profiteerer forces you to find them all using a compass.
column5: "Instead of being glued to one specialty (#46) 専, I decided to spread my attention in many directions 方, and be a taskmaster at none."

column4: "You horny bastard, don't come, at least not yet!"
column5: "Here I see, of all things, Bambi. His animal horns have not yet come out. (As we can see in the kanji, the animal horns are not at the top, not ""poking through"". ) Remember: Bambi will soon come to have a great set of animal horns but they have not yet come out."

column4: "Captain Hook, his spirit crushed, is lying on the ground cursing Wolverine who has defeated him with his far superior claws."
column5: You're reclining on the floor trying to hook a sheaf with a small hook through the cracks. That you've been doing this for seven hours without success shows your burning spirit.

column4: Water vapor almost looks like a spirit but has no soul.
column5: "Wolverine disappears into water vapor, seemingly his spirit dissipating into nothingness."

column4: Hooks with small wings attached look like hummingbirds with a long beak. Two hummingbirds are trying to fly away with our little measuring box. What do they want it for?
column5: Two hummingbirds flying into a measuring box serving as a bird feeder…　RTK2:　ヒ　飛行機　ひこうき(airplane).

column4: (thx geezer) The maimed waitress (no head and arms just her legs and trunk) is dropped into the water with a cement crown to make sure she sinks. She shouldn't have been so nosy about her yakuza-boyfriend's schemes.
column5: "This is the famous story of Archimedes and the Crown, where buoyancy was discovered. Watching the crown sink in the water, Archimedes detected the fraud and ran naked through the city (human legs distorted from running) yelling ""Eureka! Eureka!"" See http://math.nyu.edu/~crorres/Archimedes/Crown/CrownIntro.html and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eureka_%28word%29."

column4: Ten rakes woman. your wife digs her fingernails into you and it feels like 10 rakes when she finds you ontop of another woman.
column5: "(I'm really not sexist, this just helps me remember the kanji): I make my WIFE do all the yard work, and as a really mean joke, I bought her TEN RAKES for her birthday this year. ""Do the yardwork, WOMAN! You have TEN perfectly good RAKES to choose from!""."

column4: "If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven't seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, begging people to throw it for him. Note that the mouth is closed only after the stick goes in, as is only logical."
column5: "If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven't seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, allowing people to rent him and play catch with him for money!"

column4: The guy from pathetic (#401) shared his inmost feelings with a girl and she rammed a walking stick down his throat. It ruptured his inmost organs.
column5: "Besides making money from acting like a dog (see decline), the pathetic man has risked his inmost internal organs by becoming a cane swallower!"

column4: "When Jim Carrey puts on The Mask, he can make it seem like he has 100 eyes popping out of his head."
column5: "If you're wearing a mask, a hundred eyes can look at you but none of them will know who you are."

column4: You can feed twenty mouths for a year for the price of ten leather coats.
column5: "I asked the street vendor the price of the LEATHER jacket. He said TWENTY, but with my MOUTH, I talked him down to TEN. (correct stroke order)."

column4: Leather shoes are nice because they change shape to fit your foot.
column5: Leather is often changed into shoes.

column4: "In the Old West, cowboys had hegemony OVER the Indians despite their leathercraft and ability to navigate by the moon."
column5: "In the old west, animal skins were made into leather and their flesh was eaten, thus using the whole animal, which viewed from the animal side could be taken as humans asserting complete hegemony over them. All your base are belong to us."

column4: "When an enemy's flag is raised, a true samurai can split it in half with just his voice."
column5: "Having lost his voice, the samurai comunicated to his troops with a striped flag."

column4: "As a present, I gave my dentist a hand-crank tool for spreading mouths. He was so happy since it makes his job easier."
column5: "I see this as a pictograph of an old-style phonograph - a stand, record, crank and bell (the mouth). Even the primitives work out - a tool with a crank which plays music out of the bell mouth. Imaginge giving one of these old and beautiful phonographs to a classical or jazz music buff!"

column4: "A man from a less enlightened society comes for a visit, and asks the host to give him a woman for some recreation."
column5: "While at the dentist's office giving him his hand-crank tool, one of the assistant's asks me if I'd like to join her in the back for some recreation."

column4: "It is a rookie mistake to believe the words when your sweetie says ""You don't have to give me anything for my birthday."" Trust me, your sweetie wants something, something shiny, and if you disappoint, you will suffer."
column5: You must give words of apology when you make a mistake.

column4: "This kanji is used in compounds for the steaming of food and also for smoking/fumigation. Here we have the Japanese once again trying to replicate the French cuisine, only with a twist, steaming food with flowers (think of flower-smoked ham for example). Flowers must first be completely soaked in water, and then poured over a thin piece of flooring under which there is an oven fire."
column5: Note: complete + water + floor are later combined into 丞 helping hand (#2919). Story: The driver of a steam train asks you for a helping hand and explains that your job is to throw flowers on the fire to make the steam.

column4: To get someone to completely acquiesce it takes 3 dunks in the water before they give.
column5: "To get someone to acquiesce, duck them completely in aqua (=water) three times. (variation on dingomick's)."

column4: Damn racoons ill show them. I put a snare in the bin as well as a few phosphorous sparklers so as to scare the shit out of the buggers as they rummage through my bin.
column5: "(thegeezer3) Damn racoons... I'll show them. I'll put a SNARE in the BIN as well as a few SPARKLERS so as to scare the shit out of the buggers, then hit them with a SHOVEL."

column4: "Can simplify this using decay (#1243). Then: The expedition to the poles is bad for your health, and the decay that started in your mouth spreads to your crotch – at which point you fall to the floor."
column5: "(modified Katsuo) Can simplify this using decay (#1243). You travel to the poles, a frozen wasteland. In desperate need of food you try to set up a snare but the tree is decayed (see story for decay (#1243)) so you catch no prey. The brutal cold first attacks your mouth as your lips turn blue, then your crotch also gets cold as your body fails; finally you fall to the floor."

column4: "He stored the tusks into a box, along with the broken halberds."
column5: The kanji looks like an elephant with tusks. the box is the elephant's eye. The final stroke is the tusk.

column4: Zoo keepers are baffled as to why the tips of the elephant's tusks keep budding into flowers.
column5: Buds while they're still small tend to be tusk-shaped.

column4: The wicked queen builds her city walls out of menacing tusks.
column5: "As everyone knows, rhinoceroses and elephants are often killed for the value of their TUSKS. Here we see a WICKED city mayor who has had countless elephants killed just to make his CITY WALLS out of TUSKS."

column4: """Goodness gracious! Such an elegant turkey with a tusk."" This mnemonic is meant to join RtK's keyword with a better proposition. Heisig could have used ""elegant"" here, which is not confounded so easily with graceful (#721), and accurately represents the character's meaning (it is also the chosen keyword in Kodansha's Kanji Learner's Dictionary)."
column5: "To not confuse it with grace (#606) or graceful (#721), think of the phrase ""Goodness gracious."" Like: ""Goodness gracious! A turkey with tusks!""."

column4: "Mrs. Badger follows the animal tracks to the den where she finds her husband getting a blowjob from a fox. ""I have a good explanation for this. Really!""."
column5: "Animal track primitive: As expected, animal tracks were left in place of the trail of rice I'd purposely dropped the night before. EDIT - also try the footprint for a primitive meaning, the classic symbol of detective films. STORY: This shakuhachi player is so talented, he can do interpretations of animal noises too. They're so realistic he soon has animal tracks leading straight to wherever he's playing."

column4: The famers take it in turns to watch out for any animal tracks on their rice field.
column5: They take turns alternating between wheat and rice in this field…　　RTK2:　バン　電話番号　でんわばんごう(telephone number).

column4: "At your divorce hearing the judge tells you to roll dice to see who keeps the house. (""I can't believe what I'm hearing!"" you say)."
column5: In the courthouse the judge decides your hearing with a roll of the dice.

column4: "Don't play dice with birds. When you're not looking, they'll flip the dice with their feathers."
column5: "When the birds out the back are playing dice, they flip their feathers (not their finger) at their opponents."
column10: ひ;る;が;え;-;る;、;ひ;る;が;え;-;す

column4: "This character refers to feudal clans that were abolished in 1871 (Meiji 4) in favor of prefectures (廃藩置県), and thus were predecessors of the modern prefectures. As we know from 落, flowers and water drops each have their own way of falling. This character says that clans' location was decided in the way flowers, water drops and dice fall: at random. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_%28country_subdivision%29."
column5: "In the particular clan depicted by this character, each member has to take his or her turn watering the flowers."

column4: "I've heard of people having hair on the back of their hands, but this is ridiculous! That's not hair, that's fur!"
column5: Be careful not to pet a cat the wrong way - most cats don't like you rubbing your hand backwards over their fur.

column4: "The amount of ""fur"" (needles) on a Christmas tree decreases, until it doesn't look all that good."
column5: Real fur coats and real christmas trees are dereasing the last couple of years. Plasctic chrismas trees and fake fur it is nowadays.

column3: tail;end;no. of fish;lower slope of mtn
column4: A dog waves its furry tail like a flag.
column5: A FLAG of FUR is a TAIL.

column4: "This kanji is, of course, pronounced ""taku"", and it seems the owner of this home is a little bit otaku himself. He has hung up locks of hair suruptitiously obtained from various females all over his house. A veritable hair fetishist, and certainly someone whose home you wouldn't want to visit."
column5: """Home is where the hair is""."

column4: "When you consign a matter to someone, you get their word and a lock of their hair (to be used in a voodoo ritual if they don't keep their word)."
column5: "In ""The Lord of the Rings"", Galadriel consigned a lock of her hair to Gimli the dwarf, along with some wise words."

column3: do;change;make;benefit;welfare;be of use;reach to;try;practice;cost;serve as;good;advantage;as a result of
column4: "In this kanji, you can see 3 katakana characters: ソ, ユ, and then ユ again followed by TAIL FEATHERS. STORY: ""So (ソ) you (ユ) wanna DO it?"" ""Only if you (ユ) do"" says the female bird as she raises her TAIL FEATHERS."
column5: "Do me from behind, says the bird, as she shakes her tailfeathers."

column4: "Mr. T doesn’t ""DO"" FALSEHOOD. It goes against everything he stands for. “I pity da foos who revel in FALSEHOODs!”."
column5: """It depends on what your definition of do, uh, is,"" says Mr. T giving falsehood about his affair with a peacock."

column4: The Geisha with long hair uses an ornate lacquered hairpin to bundle it all up.
column5: "The top of this one reminds me of the staple primitive. So here's my story: The girl's hair was so long that she had to use staples instead of hairpins. It worked, but stapling her hair to her head was kinda painful."

column3: lengthen;counter for bows & stringed instruments;stretch;spread;put up (tent)
column4: "The longbow is follows the design of a standard bow, only it has been lengthened."
column5: "Legolas recieves spam telling him that his can lengthen his ""bow""...he smirks...he know's it's already long enough."

column4: In ancient China books were rolled-up scrolls of paper. So notebooks were nothing more than long towels.
column5: "Students, for this class, your notebook will be a towel. Make sure it's extra long though, we'll have a lot of writing."

column4: Taking Viagra let's your blood vessels dilate...resulting in a body part getting long.
column5: "Staying out in the dark moonlit sky for a long time, your pupils dilate."

column4: "Japanese teenage girls consider the style of the hair of the head very important. If a particular style is trendy, soon they all want their own hair in the same shape as that of their friends."
column5: Friends influence the length and shape of each other's hair.

column4: You use an American flag to wrap up a salad for a picnic and bind it with a hairpin. Now imagine unfolding it to open up the bounty you've fixed up for yourself.
column5: "Unfold flag, take out the salad, pin the flag down with hairpins and have a picnic."

column4: "I miss my parents dearly. Here they lay, under a big cross, their mouths side by side. I stick hairpins in their graves. CAREFUL: the stroke order/primitive order is: ten, L mouth, R mouth, hairpin. ""Soil"" is not drawn in its stroke order."
column5: "This kanji means miss as in ""miss a (dearly departed) person"", not as in ""miss a target"".　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　Here the dearly departed has been buried in the ground, with her favourite hairpin in place of a gravestone, and two mourners stand around crying with open mouths."

column4: Owls only nest in fruit trees.
column5: "The wise old OWL makes her nest out of FRUIT, carving out the middle for her chicks, because then it's less work: no running back & forth to get food!"

column4: Owls are smart...for this owl everything is simple coz his brain is ten times more powerful than mine.
column5: An owl's brain is ten times smarter than other simple minded birds…　RTK2:　タン　簡単　かんたん(simple).

column4: "George W. Bush's plans for war were so SIMPLE. To him, its all just a big FIESTA."
column5: "So there's this fiesta in downtown Compton. It's a simple party, but someone invited people from the wrong gangs and the simple fiesta turns into an all-out turf war."

column4: "Knowing ZEN’s emphasis on “nothingness,” it’s not hard to envision a ZEN ALTAR being quite clean and SIMPLE."
column5: "Simple-minded blond girl (see frame 1928) is very good at Zen, which isn't surprising since she doesn't think much. She has this bad habit of meditating perched on the main temple altar, which infuriates the Zen buddhists. When they get up to her and tell her rudely to step down the altar, she just smiles and teases them : ""Not very zen are you ?"". Who would have thought simple-minded blond girl would teach the Zen buddhists a lesson !"

column4: Hunting with a bow is too complicated. I'm switching to something simpler--using a bullet.
column5: "The bow was a weapon for simple times, but nowadays it has been replaced by bullets."

column4: "I was taking a picture of my girlfriend under the cherry tree during 花見, when an owl happened to poop on her at the exact moment the shutter snapped. It's really my favorite picture , just don't tell her that."
column5: "The tree in Japan that represents both wisdom (the owl) and femininity (the woman). This is a sakura (さくら), or cherry tree."

column4: "The owl looks for its prey in the rice field. It sees so many potential animals to eat but since it only has one mouth, it decides that the tasty looking chihuahua will be its meal for tonight. (adapted from Copycatken,1-9-2006)."
column5: "I have a strange story for this one but it works. I imagine a owl getting into a rice field which serves as a boxing ring. His opponent is a little chihuahua. The fight starts, the owl takes one punch to the mouth and is out cold. In the chihuahua's corner is that coach from Rocky saying ""Your an ANIMAL!!"". A vivid image of this story works pretty well for me."

column4: The brain is the part of the body that an owl will use to defeat the villain.
column5: The brain is the part of the body that can give you the wisdom of the owl... or the wickedness of the villain.

column4: The owl villain is the one that troubles me most of all the super-villains. He's just so smart... you never know what he'll do! Definitely enough to put you in a troubled state of mind.
column5: Data's brain quickly allerts him to the state of trouble when he see's the brainy owl villain.

column4: "This represents a stern looking owl, perched up on a cliff. This cliff is quite famous for daring individuals to cliff dive off of, but is any of them daring enough to threaten the owl?"
column5: "The daring mouse gets a stern look after he climbs onto the owl's cliff...　RTK2:　ゲン　厳禁　　げんきん　(""Strickly Prohibited!"")　　　　　　　　　　　ゴン　華厳経　けごんギョウ(Avatamsaka Sutra)."

column4: The chain on this chainsaw is made of little metal shells.
column5: A gold chain with small seashells hanging on it is in fashion these days.

column4: This is a special owl-luring tool. All you need is to raise it in your hand. Owl will come flying and perch on it right away.
column5: "The owl was asked to raise his hand if he needed anything, but he had a wing, not a hand! So he made a tool that looked like a hand which he used when he needed to raise his hand. For raiseing, owl has a tool hand."

column4: This owl's reputation skyrocketed after he created a tool in order to speak human words.
column5: "By word of mouth, owl-luring tool (raise (#1938)) gained a reputation of amazingly effective and reliable device."

column4: "[game-hunting; shooting; game; bag] According to unicode.org and wwwjdic, 鼡 and 鼠 (mouse (#2065)) are variants. So, for 鼡 (which I'll call rat) I have: an owl, flying in the wind, can easily spot a rat even if it's hiding in the cornstalks. Now 猟 is easy: wild dogs are having fun by game-hunting rats."
column5: The WILD DOGS are GAME HUNTING the OWL who flies like the WIND through the CORN STORKS.

column4: There is only one bird with such beautiful white tail feathers: the albino peakcock.
column5: The BIRD let loose a WHITE ONE from it's TAIL FEATHERS...right on my new car!

column4: A chirp is quite simply the sound that comes from the mouth of birds.
column5: "This kanji is not limited to the chirp of a bird, but stands for the sound of any kind of animal. Picture a very weird bird that can imitate with its mouth (a bird with mouth, heh) the voice of many different animals: Meeow! Woof! Mooo! Cuack!!! (Maybe the bird has Kirby powers and obtains the abilities of the animals it eats)."

column4: "The original version of the ""Ugly Duckling"" was about a crane who grew up in a turkey coop. All the other birds made fun of it for not having a wattle or a snood or fanning its tail..."
column5: "Do you know how cranes came to be? Well, they used to keep the poor bird cooped all the time. But the crane really wanted to be free, so it would always streatch its head and neck out of the coop trying to be free."

column4: "The book's story is just fine, but I found a kanji dictionary explanation also interesting: As crows are all black, it's hard to see where their eyes are (black on black), so a stroke is removed from the part in the pictograph where the eyes would be."
column5: "A crow is a bird, but not a white one. MEANING: write bird, but skip writing one in white."

column4: In the jungle there is a flowery vine called hedera rhombea that attracts humming birds by the dozens. They scoot around the flowers sucking up nectar off the vine.
column5: "Note : if you'll remember we already have a primitive for ""ivy"", but it was completely made up from the ""square jewel"" kanji. The kanji here refers to ivy, or vine, and is used in a particular compound for ""Hedera rhombea"", which is a type of ivy native to Japan. This vine here produces a lot of flowers, and attracts many small birds, which is sure to cheer up even the most depressed Japanese gardener."

column4: Feed one pigeon and nine more birds will be swarming you immediately…　RTK2:　On list of rare or no official Chinese reading.
column5: Imagine some pigeons going to see a baseball game. They would surely be the only birds there!

column4: The vulture's husband is a chicken...heck...who am I to judge their interspecies love? They're both birds so its cool.
column5: "A continuation of mountain stream (#840) (which happens to have the same chinese pronunciation) : the husband who was saved by the great eagle says to his wife that from now on, they will eat chicken ! No more fishing hardships and falling in the water.. just raising birds. Every now and then the great eagle comes to visit and the man offers one of his chicken to the great eagle who had saved his life."

column4: This island is the home of the terrible mythical bird Roc. It sits mighty atop the mountain waiting for the next hapless ship to pass by.
column5: Birds living on remote mountainous islands have few preditors. Tail feathers aren't really needed are they? Evolutionary process at work!...　RTK2:　トウ　半島　はんとう(peninsula).

column4: Ducks migrate south for the winter... they follow the warmth of the sun.
column5: "A massive group of migrating ducks is blocking the warmth of the sun as they pass over your house/barbecue/picnic. Their formation is so humongous they block the warmth for a good 10 minutes while they pass over. Mnemonic for the migrating ducks primitive : the migrating ducks stick together like the best of friends, flying together as one (fifth stroke), they are not easy prey for the great eagles / vultures."

column4: "As I saw the most beautiful woman on Earth, a flock of migrating ducks passed by and let their poop fly. That just ruined the moment..."
column5: "You want to know about a beautiful woman? There's a woman that's so beautiful, the birds migrate to her instead of the sun!"

column4: You abet the escape of migrating ducks by pointing them the way.
column5: """Aiding and abetting:"" You are accuse of abetting a drug dealer, by smuggling drugs in migrating ducks. Of course, this means you have to stick your fingers in their mouths."

column4: "Oh no Spiderman has some migrating ducks stuck in his web, he has to slacken it so they can get out."
column5: Spiderman is a slacken off. He lays around all day in the park watching migrating ducks...　RTK2:　カン　緩和　かんわ(mitigation).

column4: "These bugs BELONG TO an extremist group promoting insect independence. They are parading the FLAG of their group, the Nationalist GNATS, and wearing explosives BELTS for their planned terrorist war."
column5: "[WARNING: violent story] Two teams of insects are playing “capture the flag” (ala Unreal Tournament). All of them wear ammunition belts. Here you try to take the flag of the opponent team, when you are faced by an insect: “You’ll get our flag over my dead body!”. You reply: “All your base are BELONG to us!”, shoot him on the head, take the flag and run away. See the drop of blood flowing from his head?"

column4: "The commando gnats entrusted their mouths to the translators and what came out was ""All your base are belong to us!""."
column5: "If you entrust me with something, my mouth belongs to you."

column4: "Mr. T accidentially stepped on Jiminy Cricket (a brainy insect, with a belt sort of sash to hold his ""conscience"" badge)."
column5: "Mr. T accidentally steps on Jiminy Cricket. // Primitive: right side: Talking cricket = Jiminy Cricket, a brainy insect with a belt to whip little kids who misbehave."

column4: "I was finally able to score an interview with the wisest being around: Jiminy Cricket. However, his schedule is really packed, so they had to squeeze me in while his tour bus rode between gigs. In fact, it was really short---after a few miles I was kicked out of the bus and stranded in the middle of the interstate. But man, it was worth it!"
column5: On the road to my interview I accidentally bump into Jiminy Cricket who gives me some good advice.

column4: """Don't be foolish!"" says Jiminy Cricket as he lashes you with his belt. Follow logic, like me, not your heart."
column5: "I simply imagine Jiminy Cricket jumping all over the place, like a mad man, yelling ""yeeeeehaaaaa!"". Maybe he just fell in love? Mnemonic - ""Jiminy Cricket has a foolish heart""."

column4: Jiminy Cricket has a favorite corner he likes to slip into at The Pinnacle for a long drink.
column5: Oh how the pious fall from their lofty pinnacles! Jiminy Cricket now deals drugs on the street corner.

column4: There's a road that's been inverted- it's gone from horizontal to directly vertical! The only beast that could possibly climb it is a mountain goat of course.
column5: "This reminds me of a cartoon I saw once, perhaps it was with Donald Duck. he is startled and furious when he chases this mountain billygoat further and further up the mountain road, untill the angle is so steep that he finds himself inverted. And falls down, while the goat stands solidly placed inverted and laughs a goaty laughter as Donald plumments and makes that typical Donald shaped cartoon crater at the bottom."

column4: "A legend says that if you model a mountain goat (with tail and everything) from dirt and leave to the light of the moon on the first day of the month (#2846), the dirt will became flesh. (blackstockc)."
column5: "If you model a mountain goat from ""soil"" and leave it under the full ""moon,"" it will come to life."

column4: "White mount , Fuji mount , olympus mount whatever ....The choice is yours but wherever you go they sell those snowglobe souvenir : under a GLASS HOOD you can see the mount with a MOUTAIN GOAT standing on top of it .... So kitsch you just can't forget it ."
column5: "This has the same meaning as 丘, so my ""Mount"" is a hill with mountain goats on it under a glass canopy. It's obviously an effort by the locals to add some Mount atmosphere to their hill. As a primitive, it has the meaning ""sturdy"" (really), which Heisig has not used for some reason, but I will. The glass canopy must be pretty sturdy to keep the goats inside (bulletproof glass, I'm sure)."

column4: Mount Fuji is completely made up of a metal known as steel.
column5: Ancient shamans predicted a time when there would be Mounts made of metal. The steel skyscrapers of today…　　　　　　　　RTK2: 　コウ　鋼鉄　こうてつ(steel)…　Semi-Pure Group:　綱1963　(ｺﾞｳ): 剛1964.

column4: Spiderman saves Japan from floating away by tying Mt. Fuji to mainland Asia using a hawser made of web.
column5: A sturdy thread is equally obviously hawser (heavy rope). (see previous frame).

column4: "Mount everest is very sturdy, you can hit it all day with a saber and it wont even wobble."
column5: "Anything sturdy in Japan is associated with Mount Fuji. Perhaps this is because it's symmetry is believed to make it rather sturdy itself, unlike all those crooked mountains that are around and tend to fall apart (think rock slides, avalanches, etc.). Here we see Sturdy-brand sabers with Mount Fuji engraved on the blade."

column4: "Horses kept in the mountains have a unique savory taste. At least so the text on this tin can would have us believe, which contains 100% authentic mountain horse."
column5: "The starving horse, stranded on the mountain, is forced to eat a tasty tin can."

column4: "At The Pinnacle, traditional pottery is done by binding up a bunch of tin cans into whatever pot shape desired."
column5: "In order the get clay up to the Acropolis for the pottery class, clay is packed into tin cans, bound in huge loads, and lugged up there by some unfortunate soul."

column4: I keep swinging gleefuly on the talons of the soaring condor until he slices off my fingers and sends me plummeting.
column5: "For the condor primitive: A condor is like a vulture, but twice as big and it lives near mountains (a suitable place for such a majestic bird). For swing: I'm sitting on a swing when a condor comes by and picks up the whole swing set with its big finger-like claws and now I'm swinging in mid-air. Weeeeeeeee!!!!!"

column4: "Noh chanting?!? I meant ""NO CHANTING!"" Now all you, just shut up! Not another word! Don't you know that chanting can provoke attacks from the local condor? So, no chanting, and especially no Noh chanting."
column5: Picture guy dressed in a condor mask up on stage during Noh performance chanting some words nobody understands.

column4: In the capital they have been having hearings concerning bioethics and bioengineering they call as their first witness a chihuahua with one human leg.
column5: "Ahem...CONCERNING your recent science fair project, it was a CAPITAL idea, but the CHIHUAHUA with a HUMAN LEG is freaking out the other contestants!"

column4: "The skunk here is Pepe LePew of Looney Tunes fame. He's a very sociable skunk, as far as skunks go, but instead of having a ""heart of gold"" he has a heart of silver (since he always finishes second in the game of love)."
column5: "The skunk here is Pepe LePew of Looney Tunes fame. He's a very sociable skunk, as far as skunks go, but instead of having a ""heart of gold"" he has a heart of silver."

column4: "It was the groundbreaking of the new farm, but there was an uninvited guest to the ceremony. It was a famous skunk, the one with the familiar silver stripe. The feet of the crowd rushing from the ceremony site churned up the soil very nicely. The ceremony was ruined but the groundbreaking was a great success."
column5: "I got sprayed by a skunk, so no one is helping me with the groundbreaking of my farm. On a positive note, I found silver laying all over the soil. Mine all mine!"

column4: "Obviously this is the rabbit from Alice, excusing himself and rushing away on his legs, as he has a binding day schedule. This is at the same time an image, with bound=ears, day=head and legs are just legs. The image is used in rabbit (#2093)."
column5: What is the rabbit's excuse for being such a jerk? Well he was bound up for a whole day while being stepped on by peoples human legs in some make-up labratory. Yeah I think I can excuse him after knowing that.

column4: "Tip : as a primitive rabbit becomes Bugs Bunny of Looney Tunes fame. Here Bugs Bunny eludes Elmer Fudd the hunter, once again."
column5: Bugs Bunny eludes Elmer Fudd by pretending to be roadkill.

column4: At nightfall the sun excuses itself and goes to sleep.
column5: "Imagine Bugs Bunny halfway sticking out of a rabbit hole, somewhere in Japan, taking in the sun, when all of a sudden, night falls. Our ""sun-loving rabbit"" burrows his way into the earth and pops out on the other side of the planet (say somewhere in America) and there it is, the sun high and bright in the sky! Thus, whenever it is nightfall you can be sure our ""sun-loving rabbit"" is taking in the sun somewhere else accross the globe."

column4: Notice how BUGS BUNNY's legs (hint about stroke extension) are starting to get big MUSCLES? It must be because he's always EXERTING himself on the run from Elmer Fudd (or from kicking the shit out of Elmer Fudd when he catches up!!).
column5: Hint: Energizer bunny.

column4: "An elephant has huge ears, like a rabbit, and a big, fat body, like a sow."
column5: "An animal with huge ears like a rabbit, and a body fat like a pig... ¡An ELEPHANT! For the ""phenomenon"" connotation you could use Dumbo, or Joseph Merrick (the ""elephant man"") ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Merrick )."

column4: The statue of liberty is being replaced by a statue of Mr. T riding an elephant.
column5: "In India, you see a lot of statues of the Hindu god Ganesha. Easy to recognize: he's the person with the elephant head."

column4: "Turkey with the drops at the top removed and tail feathers added (this matches stroke order and there are the tail feathers already, why not have the whole bird). If you take the two drops of 隹 as wings, then horses are like turkeys, but have no wings and have more prominent tail ""feathers"". Both are actually supposed to be pictographs, though."
column5: "The top part is half a comb (see frame 1920) with an extra vertical stroke to account for a sturdier version used to comb a horse mane. As a primitive I used the theme of the Trojan Horse. Not the modern computer viruses, but the large wooden horse which led to the demise of Troy and of the Trojans. Either its size (much greater than a live horse), or the fact that it conceals things into its belly, will set it appart from the horse primitive that came in frame 568 (""noon"")."

column4: "The cute little innocent-looking plastic pony on the desk of a student is in fact a trojan horse, hiding phrases in its belly which are used for cheating during an exam. No pony will be permitted on desks during tests!"
column5: "A particular My Little Pony has a string that when you pull it, it repeats the same dumb phrase like ""I love you""."

column4: We just verification that there are indeed no soldiers in the belly of this trojan horse. We're just gonna stab it in the belly with this awl to check.
column5: The verification proves the horse is real by poking it with an ice pick.

column4: "If the equestrian team used trojan horses, it would be really strange."
column5: Equestrian events are where you get horses to do strange things.

column4: "Parking in the dark may be difficult...specially if you're parking a trojan horse. To lend you a tiny bit of help, take this candlestick with you, and at least you'll have some light."
column5: "In the olden days parking lots used to have reserved spaces for where the lord (of the set of houses, shops, whatever) could park his team of horses. nowadays it's pretty much the same...reserved parking in front for the big bosses' cars...."

column4: You have to be craaazzzzyy to drive a buggy led by a team of horses through a ward of Tokyo!
column5: Wolverine drives his box by having a horse drag him around. He seems to really be losing it after coming to the homeless ward...

column4: "This reminds me of those infamous Mexican porn movies in which shakuhachi is performed on a horse. Here the deed is being done at a train station. As the passengers get off, so does the horse."
column5: "Anyone living in Japan knows that train stations play little melodies when the train is about to arrive. In Ye Olden Days, when horses and carriages were used for transport, the carriage driver would play a little melody on his shakuhachi to let the passengers know the carriage was arriving at the next station."

column4: "The hidden Greeks inside the Trojan Horse are getting boisterous as one of them is bitten in the crotch by a nasty insect. If they don't shut up, the Trojans will hear them..."
column5: "Or more precisely: the team of horses are getting boisterous because one of them got bitten in the crotch by a horse fly. The kanji also means to roar, make up noise, to kick up a fuss and to make merry. Perhaps it is exactly the etymology behind this kanji."

column4: "The Greek warriors inside the Trojan Horse are complaining about this burdensome plump warrior who is not helping at all (say, just eating candies and watching). - ""You know you're such a burden!"". Note : be sure to keep ""plump"" distinct from the primitive meaning of ""round"" (""fat man"")."
column5: "If a passenger is too plump and heavy, its too burdensome for the horse."

column4: "You stand in AWE at the 8th WONDER of the world, a huge TROJAN HORSE."
column5: "This is another word for surprise. 驚く＝おどろく= surprise. The Trojans stood in awe of the magnificent Trojan Horse that they thought was a gift. But imagine their surprise (wonder) when a bunch of Greeks came rushing out of it! (To further cement the connection between the primitives, if needed: It's a wonder that the Trojans managed to speak keigo 敬語 even then, saying ""わたくしたちを殺さないでください!!お願い致します!!"")."

column4: "A fervent horse doesnt need to be whipped with a bamboo stick during a race, it will go fast by itself."
column5: "A fervent history otaku rebuild the the Trojan Horse. But since he was Japanese, he used bamboo instead of normal wood."

column4: "Every quarter moon, the cost of a trojan horse rises one quarter by inflation."
column5: "Flesh+quarter=McDonald's quarter pounder. Due to inflation, McDonald's has had to start making quarter pounders out of horse meat."

column4: "Magic wand + first two strokes of pelt (皮) + diced + human legs. A wizard who turns people he doesn't like into newts with his magic wand goes for variety - he has always wanted a tiger pelt - but things go awry when the tiger promptly dices and eats him, leaving only a pair of legs. (a fitting end for a wicked wizard)."
column5: "Tigger, the tiger, (from Pooh stories) is happy to have found a magic wand. Using it he can bounce up to a the top of a cliff, seven times as high as some human legs could bounce. Tigger thinks ""Its great to be a tiger!"

column4: Captive men are thrown to the tigers. I think you can imagine something else is done to captive women...
column5: "Tip: To avoid confusing keyword captive with captured (#1018) note that captive contains ""ti"" for tiger."

column4: "Ending up in a tiger's stomach is not good for your skin, as it's full of stomach acids."
column5: TIGGER only has visible SKIN on his STOMACH. The rest of his body is covered in orange fur.

column4: "In Japanese folklore there is no hell, but there is the void. There, a row of tigers waits in the blackness to devour those souls who have failed in their spiritual life."
column5: Warning to Sigfreid and Roy: Your entertainment contract will be null and void unless you can make all the tigers stand in a row.

column4: This is a story about the end of the universe. The universe is turning into a featureless void. There's nothing we can do about it except for throw a fiesta and frolic a little bit before it's all over.
column5: "Sigfreid and Roy's contract having been voided, the tiger is free to frolic about at the fiesta."

column4: The dentist couldn't help but feel uneasiness as he used his hand crank mouth tool on the tiger in his chair.
column5: "My dear friend, a Bengali merchant, gave me a tiger as a birthday present. I felt uneasiness, knowing that I'll have to reject it. Or was it horror?"

column4: "Real meaning: ""to ponder"". You have to think with prudence (ponder carefully) about approaching a tiger, as is evident from 虎."
column5: "You have to think with prudence about approaching a tiger. If not, it will eat your brains and heart. Thanks raulir."

column4: A great Indian drama acted out every year is how a poor Bengali boy fended off the tigers from his pigs using only a sabre.
column5: "If you thought ""The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe"" was full of drama then you'll love ""The Tiger the Sow and the Sword""."

column4: "Here we see the evil tyrannizing tiger. What is on his chest? A giant E, for EVIL, of course."
column5: "The ""E"" shape actually means claws here, and the real etymology is a tiger tyrannizing other animals with its claws (the etymologies actually make sense once in a blue moon!). I think of the claws here as two hooks, representing the front paws. (stroke order of that part: 二＋last of 直)."

column4: Bambi wanders into a cave and sees a side order of salad and 2 spoons...but what's the main course?
column5: "Santa's reindeer, Rudolf, opens a nightclub in a cave. It's popular with all the deer and reindeer in the world. The cave speciality is a salad w/ dressing on the side. There is no other deer club that can compare. How many other deer nightclubs are there?"

column4: "Picture an ad in which Uncle Jimbo (of ""South Park"" fame) recommends the latest craze in deer hunting : a high tech slingshot! The ad begins with Bambi prancing around, smelling the flowers. Then, all of a sudden, Bambi is brutally murdered with the slingshot, put on the cooking fire, and the camera pans to Uncle Jimbo happily munching on crispy cooked Bambi! Note: the slingshot is strokes 11-12."
column5: "It is recommended that deers stick to eating flowers. If they try to eat birds, they may end up choking on them, like this one here. Note that the head (白) is gone and the visible part of the body which is normally written with a stroke of the head must by necessity be drawn with a stroke of the tail."

column4: "In this kanji, ""deer"" replaces the ""head"" primitive from the ""melancholy"" kanji. Poor Ned is feeling melancholy so Uncle Jimbo (of South Park animated series) suggests a good deer huntin' trip to fix that and turn that melancholy into jubilation."
column5: "Bambi was melancholy at the death of his mother, but is now in jubilation as he's made friends with thumper."

column4: "The anthropologist made an exact deer painting from the cave ceiling on the ceiling of his house. Too bad they're both mediocre. All his wife could say was, ""How...lovely.""."
column5: Lovely bambi.... pictographe : just take a look at those innocent open eyes (part 1 it's not more far fetched than seeing mediocre in it) with thin eyebrows what a lovely deer ...(part 2).

column4: "Most don't know it, but bears have the ability to walk on fire. They're invincible creatures!"
column5: "Note : I don't know why James Heisig put ""bear"" ahead of ""ability"" (next frame), but I sugget to skip this, learn the next kanji (""ability"") then go back here and use ability as a primitive."

column4: "The amputee has no hands but only stumps of flesh beneath his elbows. To give him the ability to eat he has two spoons implanted in his arm stumps, one in each side."
column5: "Kid from the Oracle's place in the Matrix (whose head is shining like the moon) is holding a a spoon and making it bend using his special ability. When Neo asks to learn this ability the child replies, "" Remember the truth Neo, there is no spoon."" Neo Proceeds to the kitchen pondering these words of wisdom. The Child smiles mischeviously and pulls a second spoon hidden up his sleeve in the crook of his elbow. ""That's right Neo,"" the child laughs, ""there is no spoon...there are two spoons!""."

column4: "This guy has an attitude problem – lots of ability, but his heart's not in it."
column5: "Having a good attitude means believing in your heart that you have the ability to do anything - like memorizing more than 2000 kanji, for example."

column3: sign of the tiger;3-5AM;3rd zodiac sign
column4: "If you draw the sign of the tiger on the ceiling of your house, you will sprout tiger's legs (animal legs) and be able to run and pounce like the big cats yourself."
column5: The sign of the tiger is that he's eaten all of the yellow (#1750) salad in the house.

column4: That was some great performance! He caused the water to shoot up into the air and form the sign of the tiger in airborne droplets. You sure missed a great performance!
column5: "I remember seeing advertisements growing up with the sign of the tiger saying to ""Put a tiger in your tank"", meaning that it would increase the performance of the drops of gasoline you put in."

column3: sign of the dragon;7-9AM;5th zodiac sign
column4: Bruce Lee is such a badass he climbed a sheer vertical cliff using only 2 hairpins.
column5: "The kid said ""I don't believe you! Dragons don't exist!"" so we made a little surprise for him: we pinned a huge dragon (it was just a sign really) on a nearby cliff. ""Whoaaa! Dragon!"" the kid said. ""But why won't it move?"" ""I tell you why, cause it's pinned there with two hairpins"" I thought to myself."

column4: "During the shooting of one of his first movies in China, Bruce Lee fell through the cheaply built movie set, and into a barrel of glue. As you can imagine, to put Bruce Lee in that position must have caused great embarass to the chinese producer. Note the hints in the story for the position of the primitives."
column5: Bruce Lee is embarrassed when he does a high kick and splits his pants. He has to glue them back together.

column4: Bruce Lee has magical abilities in his newest movie. He can conjure rain and earthquakes.
column5: "A la Kung Fu Hustle, Bruce Lee descends from the storm and causes an earthquake by smashing the ground."

column4: "Bruce Lee shakes the confidence of his opponents by simply waving his fingers in front of them, they know that each of them is a deadly weapon in their own right. Hwwaaaa..."
column5: Your fingers will be crushed if you shake hands with Bruce Lee.

column4: Any woman spending a night with the virile Bruce Lee is bound to end up with child.
column5: BRUCE LEE'S WOMAN was WITH CHILD and it really upset her stomach because little Brandon Lee was kicking ass from the inside.

column4: "I love Bruce Lee dubbing. His lips move, but sometimes words don't come out of his mouth."
column5: "Bruce Lee says ""Read my lips..."", but when I try to, his mouth isn't moving with the dialogue."

column4: "The most unlikely persons in the world to take up agriculture must be Bender and Bruce Lee. An awkwared moment as they stare on the various farming utensils, hoe, plow. Both with straw hats on and blue overalls, and drawn in Groenigs irrevent style."
column5: "Bruce Lee is tough. But so is agricultural work. If Bruce took it up, even he would hurt his back from all the bending."

column4: "The agriculture of Florida is concentrated on making concentrated orange juice. Just add water! Imagine a can of FCOJ, dumping it into a pitcher and adding water."
column5: Concentrated water is going to revolutionize the agriculture! Just add water... oh wait...

column4: "After worshipping the golden calf, God sent the Jews on a long road through the wilderness."
column5: "The problem with the ""gold calf"" primitive is that the first vertical stroke of ""heavenly"" is shorter than the second stroke. But as we know, ""heavenly"" clearly has the FIRST stroke longer, not the second. The primitives we really have here are ""animal horns (first 3 strokes)"" and ""big/dog (last 3 strokes)."" What are the BIGGEST ANIMAL HORNS that you can think of? For me its a MASTODON. STORY: In caveman times, you SENT OFF packages with the MASTODON express."

column4: The golden calf is sent to the gates of Hell for it's connection to false idols.
column5: There's a weird connection between worshipping the golden calf and visiting the gates of Hell.

column4: Evil blossoms from the mouths of those who worship the golden calf. (Playing it safe and avoiding the image of a flower completely).
column5: Blossom is an elegant euphemism for the precise part of the golden maiko that commands such a price in gold when she is 'deflowered'. (Along the lines of 'jade pillar' and 'lotus flower' in certain Asian texts.) [See my 2016-2018 for this sad tale.].

column4: "A ghost, or oni, wandering slowly on its human legs, searching for brains to eat. What looks like an elbow here is actually a pictoral representation of the forked tail protruding out of its rear."
column5: Ghosts aren't very intelligent - they have but a drop of brains - so can't tell the difference between an elbow and a pair of human legs.

column4: The ugly oni can't get a date so he drinks sake by himself at the bar.
column5: Drinking too much whisky can make you as ugly as an oni.

column4: "When we die, our soul rises up in a ghostlike rising cloud of mist up to heaven (we hope) (Adapted from darg_sama,28-10-2005)."
column5: "When you die, your SOUL either goes to the RISING CLOUDS (heaven) or to the ONI (hell, the devil)."

column4: The witch sold me some hemp that made me see ghosts don't do drugs.
column5: "This modern version of the witch lives in some hippie community. She smokes a lot of hemp, and spends the day talking to ghosts, which not surprisingly appears only to her."

column4: "Ghosts have not yet left the world, they must still have a deep fascination with their past life on Earth."
column5: "Here the ""Ghostbusters"" founder talks about his fascination for ghosts (picture Dan Arkroyd in the movie if that helps). He says he has a fascination for ghosts ever since he saw one as a teenager. Since then he's been scouring all of the world, trying to capture them on tape, on video... A journalist asks ""When will it end ? Aren't you tired of chasing ghosts ?"" ""Oh no, not yet ! Not until I become a ghost myself anyway !""."

column4: "Without any weapons, our only defense was to throw clods of dirt at the advancing zombie horde."
column5: "Easy: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golem (or if you prefer, http://schwicky.net/xfiles/episodes/4/kaddish/)."

column4: "The top 16 strokes are the chinese radical for ""dragon"". Joining up both meanings of the radical we can name the top part of this kanji ""imperial dragon"". Two-headed snakes do exist as biological curiosities, and they look a bit like a slingshot (with the heads splitting at a junction). Our imperial dragon here, the pet of a Chinese emperor, is a rare ""three-headed slingshot-snake"" kept in a vase and fed with meat. When the emperor attacked neighbours, his army wore the imperial dragon garment."
column5: You attack an old dragon 龍 and take his clothes. REF: dragon [old] (#2981).

column4: "To upbraid someone, you criticize them in a menacing way. In other words, you jaw at them with your MOUTH until both sides of their face turn RED (hence the double-red)."
column5: "Tip: Heisig later names 赫 ""red + red"" as incandescent (#2908). Story: ""So the boss upbraided you, huh?"". ""Yep, his mouth was incandescent."

column4: "The king says ""Only We are allowed to partake of the flesh of the golden calf.""."
column5: "The golden calf is about the difference between monotheism (one king) and paganism (majestic plural). By giving a flesh offering to the golden calf, the rebellious Israelites showed they still believed in the majestic plural."

column4: "(This is atmosphere as in ambiance, mood). Rain is only part of the atmosphere for a romantic porch date. Food, music, and candles are the rest."
column5: The part of the sky that is responsible for weather and rain is known as the atmosphere. It only occupies part of the sky though.

column4: "You've entered in a chinese shop where apparently the only item in sale is old, dusty, hardened bamboo (for construction for example). It looks like these items have been there forever. Asking the clerk if anything else is available, he doesn't understand and instead asks - ""Two items? Three items?"" (the kanji is a counter for items) - thinking you want to buy something."
column5: "Dragon Quest - You find a hardened bamboo stick, perfect for a weapon, but you can't pick it up because your items are full."

column4: "Tempering should be done with the metal facing east. (If not, the metal may pick up the earth's magnetic field)."
column5: "In the East, especially Japan ...there are masters of tempering metal to great strength....on the Spring of Trivia show in Japan I saw how a Japanese sword ...actually split flying bullets...all because of special Eastern tempering techniques."

column4: You must abide by the revered rules of the road! No devil's brew and stay glued to your lane in the road!
column5: Even the most revered person must still abide by the rules of the road -- no exceptions are granted to anyone.

column4: My eye doesn't seem to have the ability to quit staring at her...　　　　　RTK2:　ヒ　罷業　ひぎょう(a walkout).
column5: "Hey, screw you! Don't you look down on me! I have the ability to quit anytime I want!"

column4: The game characters from Worms sleep in their barracks at night.
column5: Earthworm jim sleeps in a barracks because he is a soldier... apparently.

column4: "Moreover is a literary term to shelve what you had just been talking about, to come back to it later."
column5: "Same as darg_sama. Play on words. I imagine visiting someone who has an impressive collection of medals and trophies (chess champion, for example). After spending an hour showing you all the trophies in the glass shelf, you think ""Whew! It's over."" ... but the person says ""... and wait, there's ""moreover"" !"", pointing at more trophies lined atop the glass shelf."

column4: "Let wooden goods = furniture. Then: Walking along the sea shore you see some washed-up furniture with water (waves) splashing against it. From a distance it looks like flowers are growing out the top, but as you get closer you see it is in fact seaweed."
column5: Take seaweed (water + flower) and hang it to dry in a tree to produce nori goods.

column4: The samurai sits on the altar and watches the slave rake rice all day.
column5: The samurai from goodwill (#1097) maintains his good mood on his wedding day. He tells his slave that he can keep all rice (used for confetti) that he rakes up after the ceremony. Generous Man!!

column4: "At the butcher's meeting, all the butcher's who have a heart disease attend the faith healing workshop."
column5: "Note: meeting of butchers + heart are later combined into 愈 in the nick of time (#2433). Story: For healing to take place, you must catch the sickness in the nick of time."

column4: "How about a rusty cinnabar colored dilapidated boat, found abandoned somewhere. The smoke-stack and the keel have fallen off..."
column5: Rusty old boat with the bottom and top missing.

column4: "Right part: mortar bound up over oven fire, comprising boiling cauldron. Lagoon is a shallow pond, thus easily warmed by sun, large-scale equivalent of a boiling cauldron."
column5: I stapled both sides of some tail feathers to a waterfall towering over the lagoon to give it a more tropical feel…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　On list of rare or no official Chinese reading.

column4: "Pictograph of a stanchion, which includes two vertical posts to restrain cows so they can be milked, with a horizontal stroke showing the number of cows per stanchion: one. A stanchion is a great symbol for the SIGN OF THE COW, since modern, domesticated cows are often stanchioned in barns."
column5: 77 cows behind a fence.

column3: sign of the hare;5-7AM;4th zodiac sign;rabbit;east
column4: "You know how missing childrens' pictures often appear on milk cartons? Well here we have a missing hare. His concerned family is having his picture printed on the backs of receipts and even on stamps. So far, however, there has been no SIGN OF THE HARE."
column5: rabbit ears.

column3: sign of the snake;9-11AM;6th zodiac sign;serpent
column4: "Haha! If you are reading this then I beat you. You went too slow, browsed the forum too long, or stayed out too late with your Japanese girl/boyfriend, whilst I, Kanji Master (you may call me 'sir'), sat alone in my room with a leaky pen and a clawed grip. All your kanji are belong to me, Heisig. And just remember; I beat you."
column5: "The snake likes stealing pieces from mosaics, so if you notice your mosaic has a piece missing, that’s a sign of the snake."

column4: "I'm not going to use 'this here' as a primitive because it's too vague. But 'stop and sit down', usually tied to a tour guide explaining scenery works for me.//Stop and sit down to have a look at this here."
column5: "A wildlife explorer, let's call him Steve Irwin, the sadly passed away wildlife expert, is tracking down an animal in a forest. He finds a footprint, and gets out a spoon to taste it. He scrapes the spoon over the floor and tries it. ""Now, this here is a crocodile footprint"" he announces."

column4: "(From mantixen's) I'll stop and sit down on this here tree, which happens to be brushwood. Now I have to brush wood off my butt."
column5: "I'll stop and sit down on this here tree, which happens to be brushwood."

column4: "Stop and sit down to listen to the tour guide's story. ""These stones down there used to be a fort, but the enemy came and tore the place down. It has never been rebuild""."
column5: "(Grammar and story adjustment from astridtops story) You STOP AND SIT DOWN to listen to the tour guides story. ""These STONES are remnants of what used to be a fort long ago, but the enemy came and tore the place down. It has never been rebuilt""."

column4: Those two tourists from my tour group don't have a whit of common sense. They never stop and sit down when the tour guide tells them to!
column5: I am at my whit's end with these two. They never just stop and sit down. Kids are nerve racking.

column4: """Please stop and sit down to look to the painting up there"", the tour guide says. ""We don't know exactly who is on the painting, but from the shape of the hair and the distinctive beard, we think they meant to depict President Lincoln.""."
column5: "A beard is hair that, instead of wanting it SHAPED like your friends, you grow it LONG so that you can STOP, SIT DOWN and scratch it thoughtful while considering this here and that there."

column4: "Michael Jackson is the king of pop, wearing his crystal rhinestone glove (see detach (#1492)."
column5: "In my story for detatch detach (#1492), the left side primitive was junkie. The top-hatted villian of society with a belt around their elbow. Here, the junkie is getting a fix of crystal meth: the jewel in the crown of today's drugs."

column4: "Being a Terrorist on the FBI most wanted list, Bin Laden must constantly move from place to place and is never quite certain where is going to sleep. Sometimes he can count on a loyal supporter to let him stay in a spare room, but when traveling to more remote parts of Arabia, he is sometimes forced to sleep under an umbrella with the fowl. (which consequently, makes him smell rather foul)."
column5: Michael Jackson stands under an umbrella feeding some fowl on his ranch.

column4: "A flying fowl smashes into a tree and all the apples drop off. ""Eureka!"" shouts Newton, who happens to be watching."
column5: Michael Jackson stands under an umbrella in case an apple falls way off the tree like he did.

column4: Tom Cruise - American with sunglasses (thanks synewave). I can't sympathize with Tom Cruise's state of mind regarding scientology.
column5: "After the Bush years, you can sympathize with the state of mind of Americans for wearing sunglasses when traveling abroad. Heck, I tell people I'm Canadian."

column4: "Tom Cruise's shoes caught on fire, because he was using phosphorous to shine them."
column5: "The shoeshiner always starts by cleaning the shoes first with phosphorus. This is a bit risky, though, and he sets himself on fire (picture him running around in flames)."

column4: "As a scientologist, A DEER to TOM CRUISE, is not just a deer. It is actually a descendent of a camelopard that was sent by extraterrestrials."
column5: "You saw a camelopard!? Bullshit! Next your going to tell me that you saw a deer getting a shoeshine. (Actually I saw a camelopard getting a shoeshine, but now that you mention it, his body did look like a deer...)."

column4: "Little known fact: Tom Cruise turns into a merman at night, scaled like a fish and everything. Weird."
column5: "A scaled fish goes to a shoeshine place to get his scales shined up to impress the lady fish. (Shoeshines will shine up any type of scaled creature, including but not limited to fish and dragons)."

column4: "The DACHSHUND is so long he can stretch himself around the circumference of the earth, encompassing the whole globe. (It might help to think of the dachshund as the slinky dog from Toy Story.)."
column5: "Can't work with the Heisig primitive of Dachshund, as the all encompassing big eel is obviously the mythical Norse Midgard Snake."

column4: "The hermit's home, his hermitage, is a simple CAVE where he lives with his pet DACHSHUND."
column5: "At the famous Hermitage museum in St. Petersburg, they have a cave below the museum with a big sculpture of the Midgard Snake."

column4: "When your fingers completely encompass something, it is shrouded from view."
column5: "Apparently there is a cult worshipping the Midgard Snake, which is shrouded in mystery. Members have to cut off one of their fingers to join up."

column4: """I did it all by myself!"" Mr T stands there proud as holding a moray eel in his hand. He's brought down terrorist organisations, drug syndicates, but gets all worked up when catching a fish... what a guy."
column5: "As astridtops mentions, this is ""Ore"". In Japanese r = l, so could write it ""Ole"". So picture a bullfight with person as the matador and a dachshund replacing the bull. The crowd keep shouting ""Ole! (Ore)""."

column4: "Data accidentally bumps into a legal prostitute, causing her to fall on her ass. To make amends, he invites her to a romantic dinner."
column5: "I used to beat up random licenced walkers of the street, but I've had some nagging guilt at the back of my state of mind for months now. So I've decided to make amends by throwing small change at them while driving down the road."

column4: "This should be obvious, owners of prize race horse (STEEDS) are paid to have their STEED mate with another (hopefully to produce a prize winning foal). Yep, the STEEDS are glorified HORSE HOOKERS."
column5: "Trojan horse, legal prostitute: The guy told the legal prostitute that he is like a steed in the bed and that she should do it for free. However, afterward - being severely disappointed- she considered him more like a Trojan horse."

column4: Steep prices for streetwalkers up a mountain.
column5: "There are legal prostitutes waiting on top of a steep mountain. Not only is the mountain steep, but so are the cost of the legal prostitutes."

column4: "I like mantixen's thinking. As long as its still standing up, the streetwalker still needs to complete her job!"
column5: The streetwalker has to make something stand up in order to complete a job.

column4: I removed all the back to back staples and grinded them in a mortar to create metal dust.
column5: "The mortar bomb exploded, ripping the sun in half."

column4: "My father-in-law is more fun than my blood father. My father-in-law is a hillbilly with an arsenal of army gear. He gave me the mortar launcher and said: ""Be a man! Blow up a chunk of Planet Earth!"" And so I did..."
column5: "(from astridtops) ""Real men don't use mortars"", said my father-in-law, as he began to grind some stones down using only his fists."

column4: "You are chasing the famous three blind mice and try to catch them by slamming a mortar on top of them. Success! You can see their three tails sticking out from under the mortar. In fact the impact has broken the first two tails, as you can see from the sharp angle they bend at, and the two drops (blood) on each. The third tail still curves nicely though, and hence has no drops of blood on it."
column5: "A pictograph of an elaborate mouse-catching device. A hook on the front to grab them, a couple of alternating ploughs to slice them (spattered with drops of blood) and a mortar on top for the big jobs."

column4: "This is pretty much only used in the word 鑿(のみ), chisel. Missile + metal is obviously a hammer being swung. The needle is the chisel and the mortar represents the impressions left (bored) by the chisel. For some reason the chisel is used to make a row of such impressions here, and the work is done in such a difficult place that it has to be done upside down. Perhaps this is some sort of sabotage, done in a place that is not readily visible to the outside."
column5: Hanging upside down in a row are ten mortars. You must shoot chisel tipped missiles into all of them and successfully bore holes through them in order to get the prize of gold. Talk about a messed up county fair game!

column4: "To ""break the soil"" is to make a symbolic gesture that indicates the beginning of construction. Like when a politician in a hardhat gets a shovel and lifts a piece of dirt. This particular project is behind schedule, so to speed things up, they blow it up with mortar and an air-to-ground missile."
column5: "Wow, that baker must really be mad! He's trying to BREAK his MORTAR by throwing it to the SOIL. Whoa! Now he's aiming a MISSILE at it!"

column4: "In a small craft, the boat is so small that you hit yourself in the crotch when trying to use a mortar and walking stick (as a pestle)."
column5: "In military terms, a small craft is a boat that only has enough room for a mortar that fires walking sticks - which is pretty useless unless you hit the enemy in the crotch."

column4: "Mr. Rhinoceros doesn't see well, so to prevent an unwanted attack, I don't surprise him. I always approach waving a flag attached to my walking stick. I've drawn a picture of the I-ching and an attractive cow on the flag, so Mr. Rhinoceros will stay calm when he sees it."
column5: I hang a flag imprinted with the picture of a rhinoceros on the grill of my car to scare cows.

column4: "For 二十二 days of the lunar month, a girl is fine. The other six days she wears a white pad."
column5: To keep track of time on a desert island Tom Hanks puts a needle into the white part of his yin yang symbol every time a lunar month passes.

column4: """Look"", says the teacher in biology class. ""The spinal column holds your flesh together, just like the metal rod of this umbrella (he demonstrates this with an umbrella covered in I-Ching symbols) holds the umbrella together""."
column5: "A pictograph of a spinal column. The umbrella representing the shoulder blades, the I Ching as the shoulder muscles and the part of the body as the spine itself."

column4: In the rice-field footpath I found a condom (used to protect you from the one in four crotches that shouldn't be done ヌde) of someone who couldn't afford a hotel.
column5: "Rope ladder, like as found on the side of a large ship. The rice-field footpath depicted here is actually a rope ladder suspended a metre above the rice field. Don't let your limbs slip through!"

column4: "SPIDEY has to mend his own costume, so he used the CROSS-STITCHING his aunt showed him."
column5: "After a long fight with his enemies, Spider-Man uses THREAD to mend the EMBROIDERY on his torn outfit."

column4: "Story by katsuo (but not yet posted) - At a small concert for the Beatles I was hanging eight towels from the celing. I asked Paul if he wanted me to stitch them together but he said ""Let It Be""."
column5: "There's a new cabaret show in town called ""It's Raining X-Men"" where eight Chippendales dress up in superhero costumes for the ladies. I would say something negative, but I just shake my head and let it be."

column4: "This aquatic mammal belongs to the emperor, so it's an imperial seal. Nobody is allowed to mess with it. They have to let it be wherever it wants to go. You can spot it from the other seals by the jewel studded collar around the neck of the imperial seal, but above all, remember to let it be."
column5: "If you find a jewel with the imperial seal on it, just let it be. You wouldn't want to be accused of stealing the royal family jewels."

column4: """Without the right metal, that there suit of armor won't mount to more than a hill 'o beans!"" said the dwarven smith as I embarked on my quest - with my aluminum-foil hat and shield."
column5: A suit of armor crafted from metal so strong that it could withstand the weight of a mountain of beans.

column4: "After eating a mountain of beans, I was able to triumph in the wind contest."
column5: "With the wind blowing, it was a triumph for Jack to climb the giant beanstalk."

column4: "If you don't want to get bewitched (and who would?), then avoid any woman you see carrying what might appear to be a sapling. It's really a wand in disguise, and if you're not aware you might get bewitched."
column5: "I was bewitched by the woman fairy (like an angel, but not as tall)."

column4: You use water to irrigate your saplings.
column5: "A fairy needs a lot of water to irrigate those beating wings, so you have make sure they drink a lot to be well irrigated (see bewitched (#2078)."

column4: "After planting the saplings, the villagers open their mouth and quaff large quantities of sake!"
column5: The fairy spreads her legs over my mouth to let me quaff her moisture.

column4: You can tell green onions from leeks because leeks are the ones that flower.
column5: "For the green onion primitive, I use a pun: Green UN ONE. Leeks are milder than green onions, they're more like the flowers of the scallion family."

column4: "I never play the lottery. I'd rather be whacked by bamboo staffs as I pass down an assembly line than do that. Of course, when a buddy wins, I'll go to the fiesta and enjoy the special salsa packed with green onions, but I will never play the lottery myself."
column5: "(based on mantixen's) If I won the lottery, I wouldn't even need to go speed dating (a fiesta to form couples) to find a woman, even if I had onionbreath they'd be flocking in my direction. On second thoughts.. I'd better buy a bamboo cane to keep the ugly ones away."

column4: Someone stole the bamboo from the previous lottery--but I'm sure their state of mind is very penitential.
column5: "Indiana Jones: ""The penitent man shall pass. The penitent man shall pass."" Indy's state of mind is screaming at him that something is wrong. This assembly line of death is giving all kinds of hints that something is wrong. ""Oh hey, green onions!"" Indy ducks down to grab them and the trap misses him completely... fiestas ensue..."

column4: The 2 mountain goats have to bind up all the hay then the farmer might give them their horns back.
column5: "This one is easy if you know the old form of grass (艸); To make hay, get the old grass, bind up the clumps individually, and then stack them vertically."

column4: "A young chick milling about in the hay looks up and sees a huge turkey looking down on it. Turkey leans down and says: ""Boy, you got no hope of leavin this place alive...""."
column5: The chick got lost in the hay. Now mama turkey is throwing the stuff all over looking for her chick.

column4: "If you suddenly open the barn doors, the rats will scurry away, RUNNING quickly over the HAY scattered across the floor."
column5: "Imagine a cartoon character hiding in a haystack, and then trying to run - the result is a haystack scurrying across the field."

column4: A chihuahua with one human leg is understandably not as fast as other chihuahuas.
column5: That one-human-legged chihuahua that appeared before the capital in concerning (#1969) is understandably traumatized by the abuse he suffered at the hands of the scientists.

column4: "After a hard day of training, wheat is understandably delicious."
column5: "After training hard and eating Wheaties for months, you are understandably thrilled to sink your spoon into a delicious hot fudge sundae."

column4: "Subject to even more cruel experiments in the name of biological science, the one-human-legged chihuahua is injected with chemicals that alters his shape grotesquely, and makes him as immense as a cliff (see how he's tall enough, standing right beneath it, to reach the top?)."
column5: This pup is immense! It's head is almost level with the edge of this tall cliff. Who ever heard of a chihuahua with a human leg with a shape so immense?

column4: "You ever wondered why this appeared as a primitive in so many RTK1 kanji? Well, you should know that once a vulture grabs hold of a tree, he can never let go. Even Heisig couldn't shake him loose."
column5: "A common meaning for this kanji is 'DICE'. --- Ever wonder what vultures do up in the trees? They play DICE. But of course, being vultures, they are always grabbing the dice away from each other."
