Unknowing of her fate, there is a party in her honor that evening. Near the end, the lights suddenly darken and a lot of noise can be heared. When the lights go on again, the sow has been slaughtered and is ready to be baked for Christmas dinner."
column5: "Miss Piggy has entered the Miss Universe pageant. Only one sow will get the crown, when the lights darken, Miss Piggy accepts the flowers as she is announced the winner!"

column4: "There are two methods for swimming up on your enemy unnoticed. A ninja using a grassy reed, making sure the flower is first removed, will approach stealthily. A warriors scabbard, once the halberd is removed, can also substitute for a breathing tube in a pinch."
column5: "To prevent the weed from spreading, you must cut the grassy reed with a halberd before it flowers.　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　http://www.flickr.com/photos/wasatyu/168795205/."

column4: "A plantain is a flowering fruit that looks kind of like a banana, and of course bananas look sort of like a comma, so you might even say that they have a sort of comma-design."
column5: Southern cities in Europe often have plantains for street decoration. The light filtering through these plants makes for a nice light mosaic on the streets.

column4: You reap what flowers you mow. (thanks synewave).
column5: "Before you mow the lawn, first quickly reap any flowers growing it, otherwise they'll just go to waste."

column4: The lid of this dish is gone! Now the whole room smells of the flowers that were used in the cooking.
column5: The magic lid trick: you put flowers in the dish and cover them up with the lid. Then you lift and the flowers are gone!

column4: "The onion is a plant that has such spicy fumes, that you have to cry as if your heart is in a double knot."
column5: The ONION is a type of FLOWER (bulb) that makes you INSTANTANEOUSLY cry a DROP of tear. Just remember the DROP goes on the KNOT.

column4: "They gays were reviled by society, so they put flowers above their eyes and marched around."
column5: "In Northern Ireland, bitter religious groups revile their opponents by marching defiantly under their very eye, holding flowers that symbolize their beliefs."

column4: Hollyhock loved to suck cock. With a flower in her hair she would lead you into a teepee and let you experience heaven.
column5: The hollyhock is a flower that can grow as large as a teepee. It almost reaches to heaven.

column4: "When shingling with flowers, they can often block up your mouth and ears unless you wear the proper safety gear."
column5: "Flower, deaf: The deaf guy was shingling the roof of his house with flowers (ecohouse). Being deaf was an advantage since he didn't hear the comment of his neighbours."

column4: A male flower attracts many hearts with its stamen.
column5: This flower's stamen is so manly that it has three hearts.

column4: "My mother used to joke that if I didn't wash my ears properly, mushroom plants would be growing out of them."
column5: "How could Mushroom be flower/ear??? It makes no freakin' sense! 　http://www.flickr.com/photos/fotofilo/2202580888/　　　　　　　Oh, O.K.. Well, then maybe it could be."

column4: All it takes is time to get flowers after sowing seeds.
column5: After sowing seeds it will take TIME before FLOWERS grow.

column4: "The axe murderer glares at his flower garden victims ""First Parsley, Sage, Rosemary, and Thyme!""."
column5: Cooking for Cannibals: Sprinkling a freshly chopped parsley flower onto your axe before cutting up those helpless victims is a great way to add a little zest to your dishes.

column4: The thatching of the old thatched roofs in rural Japan often has FLOWERS growing out of it when it's gotten weathered. So you can pluck them and use them like tea leaves to tell your FORTUNE.
column5: The fortuneteller wants the thatching of his roof done with flowers instead of reeds.

column4: "Flower, siesta: The muchacho was not careful. He passed the warning signs and decided to hold a siesta in the kudzu field. The kudzu grew so fast, he was completely covered by it in a few hours and not able to escape. Now, the kudzu flowers mark his grave."
column5: The muchacho takes a siesta under the flowers of the kudzu.

column4: "The godown was filled with pale blue flowers, probably some drug..."
column5: "If you give her pale blue flowers, she'll godown on you every time."

column4: "When a giant drinks a cocktail, he needs a straw of large proportions. He hollows out a tall tree for the straw, and sticks a giant flower on the rim of his drink."
column5: "Story of three little pigs. First one built a house out of straw but it got blown down. Second one built a house out of flowers but it got blown down. Third one built a tall house out of wood. It was so tall, when the wolf blew it it fell back on the wolf, killing him instantly. The end."

column4: "Turnip flowers? Gross, but at least it's better than nothing to eat."
column5: Turnips just taste like nothing to me.

column4: The sweet potato is a plant that can be used in various dishes quite well.
column5: "The sweet potato is a plant that has various names. (So don't get it confused with ""yam"")."

column4: The idiot savant was thought to be a quack because he couldn't help but count the number of flowers he saw.
column5: "I don't even know where Heisig got this keyword from. Using ""thicket"" instead: Picture a thicket with a large number of flowers."

column4: "In the temple were two altars. One of them had the usual array of fl0wers, but the other was adorned with garlic, so that the locals could pray to keep the vampires out."
column5: The Vampire approaches - You take out a clove of garlic 2 show him you mean business.

column4: Bracken is a flower that grows on cliffs and resembles a fish spine lacking stability.
column5: "After eating all the BRACKEN FLOWERS on the CLIFF, the MOUNTAIN GOAT belts out a huge YAWN and takes a nap. Unfortunately he never wakes up as the BRACKEN is highly carcinogenic to mountain goats...."

column4: "This reminds me of the old Peter, Paul and Mary anti-war song, ""Where have all the flowers gone?"" The final verse talks about the graveyards of military officers being the place where flowers grow plentiful."
column5: Military officers make for good fertilizer. So after a war the flowers in the military officer's graveyard grow plentiful.

column4: Madder red is an extract from a flower which was used as fake blood in western films.
column5: Madder red is a colouring agent that is acquired out of the roots of plants that grow in the west.

column4: "The candle rush doesn't bloom often, but when it does, the flowers must be perfect."
column5: "On valentines day (a.k.a. the candle rush), people are rushing to buy candles and the perfect flowers for their lover. Of course they do this all with a smile 莞爾【かんじ】として."

column4: Debt collectors will even hustle ghosts for the flowers on their bodies' graves.
column5: "This demon is a bit of an oddball, he's a collector of rare flowers, most of the time you can seem him trawling the graveyards looking for species that he doesn't yet have."

column4: "Sedge is a flower (plant) that looks like grass, much like bureaucrats look a lot like real humans."
column5: The bureaucrats wanted all the sedge plants in the district counted. Whatever will they think of next...

column4: As soon as Iris decided to ditch reed she took off the locket he gave her and tossed it along with the corsage into the nearest ditch. Iris is quite a bitch to ditch reed on the night of the prom!
column5: The lost locket was found between the flowers of the ditch reed.

column4: "Imagine a trail of brussel sprouts along a road. You follow it, picking up each sprout and eating it as you go along. Eventually, after the last sprout, you find your reward – a milky Way."
column5: A road magically sprouts up to show the chosen ones onto the Way.

column4: "When you're following someone along a road high atop a mountain, it is easy to track them down, since all tracks lead down."
column5: "Despite travelling all the mountain roads and paths, no one could track down the Yeti."

column4: Some of those amateur marathon runners at the end seem merely to crawl on the road instead of running. They truly need words of encouragement.
column5: "There are words written on the road, but you have to crawl along to read them: 'If...you...can...read...this...you...look...silly...'."

column4: "Due to potatoes in the road, there was a detour."
column5: "A truck had spilt its load of potatoes on the road, forcing us to make a detour."

column4: "It really eludes me why we have two kanji with the same keyword... this one and deviate/elude (#1973). But lets intertwine their stories: The rabbit, who eluded capture (deviate/elude (#1973)) on the road, was finally caught when someone threw a shield over it."
column5: "The Spartan had to block the road to stop the advancing enemy army, but he tried to shirk his duty and threw away his shield. That's suicide."

column4: "Going out on the road to use a pointy (see my comments in 峰 summit (#1562)) part of my anatomy, is called a tryst."
column5: "While I was having a tryst with my secret lover on the road, I had to quickly run towards the bushes with my walking legs, because my husband suddenly appeared."

column4: "On the long long road through the desert, far off you can see a condor flying..."
column5: "The condor might seem like its far off in the distance now, but if you don't start running down the road you could be dinner."

column4: "(From astridtops) Faraway (2nd edition keyword) from civilisation, there are no camping sites, so you can see people in a pup tent near the road doing some wild camping instead."
column5: "[+Katsuo] In remote areas you can pitch your pup tent in the road, as there is no traffic. To disambiguate 悠 permanence/remote (#958) & 遼 remote (#2419), recall that 悠久 [ゆうきゅう] distinctly implies permanence, while a pup tent is by definition and design a temporary structure, particularly if it's pitched on a road."

column4: "When the wealthy go on the road, they always pretend to be pursuing pressing matters, so they speed along in their big BMW's."
column5: Those with wealth speed down the road as if they have some pressing matter to attend.

column4: Beg in the road until you get what you want.
column5: """I'm going to sit here by the side of the road, in front of the government building and beg until they give me a pension"", the war veteran said."

column4: "My parents aren't at all modest about their grandchildren, at every opportunity they take them on the road showing them off to their friends!"
column5: "He wasn't at all modest when telling us about his grandchildren - ""They're all on the road to success"" he said."

column4: The negotiations had reached a complete standstill. To try and get things moving again the meeting table was placed in the middle of a busy road! That should do the trick!
column5: "I ripped a huge bean fart, bringing our road trip to a standstill."

column4: The most important sign of a cultured area in ancient times was the possession of city walls. Anyone who has ever played Civilization knows that...
column5: This cultured gentleman possesses a part of the city walls of old Rome.

column4: A St. Bernard balances a bottle of horned whiskey on his nose to get it over the city walls as a courtesy to his exiled master.
column5: "The 酋 chieftain (#2906) and his St. Bernard practice common courtesy at the city walls: Every newcomer is kissed ardently. The women by the chieftain, the men by the dog."

column4: "There was only one chink in his plan. Even standing atop the highest pinnacle, standing above even the sun, the little man was still just as little as when he was under the sun."
column5: "Man those little chinks can do anything! They were the first to build rockets, and by launching one off the top of the highest pinnacle in China, one little chink was the first to ride above the sun, and see all the little chinks below!"

column4: Those apprehensive when they reach the pinnacle often find a nook to hide in.
column5: "On the pinnacle of the secret government organisation, every nook and cranny of the pinnacle is under government control, even the ricefields. You can't even drop a hairpin there without being noticed."

column4: "I entered the stable and felt an icy chill. Yes, that horse is possessed and the only way to deal with it is a stake in the heart!"
column5: "The frozen horse still had a heart beat, it must be possessed!"

column4: You have to be young at heart to attract the opposite sex.
column5: Take just one look at the junior idol video industry (or don't!) in Japan to understand how the young attract the hearts of the Japanese. ;-).

column4: "Without exception, the heart of every hunter starts beating like crazy as he comes upon the tracks of an animal."
column5: If you get addicted to playing dice (番）without exception you will end up losing your rice fields (田） so take my warning to heart.

column4: His heart got tied in a knot and he died instantaneously.
column5: "Instead of Blood Clot, think of Blood KNOT, where if you get a Blood KNOT that goes to your HEART, you will die INSTANTANEOUSLY."

column4: "The caveman, introducing his firstborn son: ""And this is thing with heart. Come yesterday from woman's stomach.""."
column5: "The firstborn son gets everything his heart desires. Historically, the firstborn son inherited the family fortune and title if any."

column4: Nick XXX needs a heart transplant quick. He goes to a meeting of butchers where one of them is about to chop up an ideal heart. Nick snatches away the heart from under the butcher’s knife – just in the nick of time. (note: replace XXX with a Nick you know).
column5: The guy who had a heart attack at the butcher's meeting was saved in the nick of time.

column4: "He's very sensitive about that sculpture, as it captures the likeness of the woman of his heart."
column5: "To tell if someone is sensitive, first make a likeness of their heart. Then observe them while you poke the heart, stick needles in it, etc. If the person reacts, then that means they are sensitive."

column4: "In this astrological tempel, a sun is depicted, overarching the Sign of the Hare."
column5: When the sun shines during the sign of the hare the hares go mad and have an overarching desire to jump over arches.

column4: "The churches teach that if we eliminate horniness as a universal trait, we can make progress as a society."
column5: "Thinking of “The Pilgrim’s Progress”, imagine the pilgrim is stuck outside the universe 普, trying to get in. But the universe is surrounded by horns which block his path. Once he removes the horns from the universe, then he can make progress."

column4: The sun's love is equivocal: it warms yet burns us.
column5: "曖昧。 On a sunny day, a guy professes his love to a girl he admires. But she gives him the common equivocal response, ""Let's just be friends.""."

column4: "When the sun comes up and sets the sky aglow, night turns into day."
column5: The SUN TURNS the sky aglow.

column4: "My halo is as bright as the sun, and is actually made from a wheel I pulled off a chariot."
column5: "The sun, high above us, was according to ancient Greeks the chariot of a god, and the halo of this chariot are the rays of the sun."

column4: "Every day, the chariot of the god glitters as it moves from from east to west."
column5: "Garry Glitter (British 70's glam rock star) is starring in a remake of ""Ben Hur"" and they are now filming the famous chariot race scene. Somehow, a reporter from the Sun (British tabloid) newspaper has got on the set and is running alongside Glitter’s glittering chariot, trying to interview him."

column4: "Dry weather is of course good drying weather, so everyone puts their clotheslines out under the sun."
column5: Excessive SUN has caused DRY weather.

column4: "Under the sun and the clear skies, you can really relax."
column5: "When there are clear skies above you, you can relax under the sun."

column4: "The ancient villain in the Bruce Lee movies said to Bruce: ""In the morrow, when the sun is high in the sky, I will feed you to my pet crocodiles""."
column5: Bruce Lee waits for the sun of the morrow to begin a showdown.

column4: "In the Old West, the sun was the only method for bleaching hair."
column5: "Sun, west: The Japanese like to bleach their hairs until these shine in the sun. It has to do with their obsession for the West."

column4: Something that is obscure has not yet been brought before the light of day.
column5: "'Can't you go outside and get some sun?' 'Not yet, I have to learn all these obscure RTK3 kanji!'."

column4: The sun's rays passed through to the very bottom of the limpid pond.
column5: The sun's rays can be seen in a limpid liquid.

column4: An outburst of sun is a good time to air out your things.
column5: If you don't air out your grievances. One day they will be released in an outburst of anger.

column4: "I go out at the crack of dawn to buy a newspaper (The Sun), and bump into ex-sumo wrestler Akebono (曙) who is doing the same. Of course I ask for his signature on my copy of The Sun, which he signs ""Dawn (Akebono)""."
column5: "At DAWN, the SUN starts it's DAY of work, yes? So doesn't it need to SIGN IN with with SIGNATURE? Just picture that silly image for this kanji."

column4: A sunny day to a depressed person is just like a box of stamps to a stamp otaku: both have the ability to elevate spirits!
column5: Sending mail to the sun. It would take a whole box of stamps to elevate it that high.

column4: The Sun King (Louis XIV) was known for his effulgent reign.
column5: "[+katsuo] This is the Sun King. Sayeth Wikipedia: ""The Sun King (in French le Roi Soleil) because of the idea that, just as the planets revolve around the Sun, so too should France and the court revolve around [the king] (""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France). And just like the sun, he was quite effulgent and actually emitted sunlight."

column4: At dusk every day I go out in one of those airplanes that leaves a vapour trail and write my family name just above the setting sun. (I have to wait until dusk so that the sun is low enough in the sky).
column5: The woman leaves her marriage at dusk after all the guests have gone home.

column4: "Every month, there is one day that is the last day of the month."
column5: "If only every day could be the last day of the month, I'd be filing for paychecks all the time."

column4: "When the sex slave misbehaves, threaten to sell his body parts starting with his kidney."
column5: "If you have a weak KIDNEY, you'll become a SLAVE to your CROTCH's need to pee. Oh well, it's just a weakness of the FLESH."

column4: "Where's my flesh missile? Between my thighs, naturally..."
column5: My thigh is the part of the body that my missile smacks against.

column4: "If your flesh gets stung by the thorns of certain plants while doing agriculture work, your wound may infect and show pus."
column5: "Forget Manure, the best thing for agriculture is pus, freshly squeezed from some rancid flesh."

column4: "That municipality is so unsafe, thugs will attack you and cut the viscera out of your flesh to sell them on the black organs market."
column5: Your viscera are like a municipality of body parts working together with different roles.

column4: "It starts in the bladder, passes through a certain body part and then appears like a ray of golden light!"
column5: The part of the body that golden rays of light seem to pour out from.

column4: "When she took the pregnancy test because she thought she was carrying the flesh of an embryo, the test was negative and she dropped it on the floor."
column5: "When a baby is born, he or she is considered ""age zero"". After a year of life, he or she is only then considered one year old. Since an embryo is found within a woman, it is effectively part of the body of that person. However, it is not yet zero years old - in fact, its age is negative one (i.e. -1 years old)! 胚性幹細胞　－　はいせいかんさいぼう　＝　embryonic stem cell."

column4: The anus is the part of the body where crafty smugglers often hide small valuables.
column5: "The body part I was always told a new one would be crafted for me (albeit in the less friendly ""I'll tear you a new one!"") is the anus."

column4: Cowardice is the situation where you get the thought that maybe running away and saving your flesh is a good idea.
column5: Cowardice is when you are not willing to sacrifice your flesh for your ideas.

column4: "Before lacquer (#932) was made with water, it was made by draining this body part of fluid: the knee!"
column5: "Back in ancient Japan, people didn't have knee pads for things like rollerblading and such (what, come on. Ninjas on rollerblades. Ultimate 90s flashback). Instead, they would simply dip their knees in laquer, and wait until it dried (hence the flesh, and the abscence of any drops of water). Unfortunately, this meant that you would have to wait about 30 minutes after deciding to go rollerblade until you could actually do it (took some time to dry) - and removing it was a serious pain."

column4: "If you're a fragile person, lots of things are dangerous and will hurt your flesh."
column5: Doing dangerous things reminds us that our flesh is fragile.

column4: "Without ribs, our flesh wouldn't have the power to stay upright."
column5: "Flesh, power: According to the bible, the part of the body that gave power to womankind was the mans' rib. Without it, they wouldn't exist."

column4: Sometimes I get carried away and do elbow curls until the point where my forearm snaps off! When that happens I simply pull out the glue and re-attach the elbow to my flesh.
column5: Picture two Siamese twins glued together at the elbow.

column4: A body cavity is an empty space within your flesh.
column5: "During a body cavity search, the police check certain parts of your body to make sure they're empty of things like cocaine, etc.."

column4: A body part that acts like a spring for hormones is a gland.
column5: "When adrenaline glands release hormones, the body springs into action."

column4: A tumor is a useless body part that is nothing but heavy.
column5: "When flesh clumps together and gets heavy, it forms a tumor."

column4: Some people insist that the serving maids who bring in the dining trays are especially virtuous and never let any man touch their flesh.
column5: The virtuous vegan will not touch this dining tray because it has had a piece of meat on it.

column4: An armrest is something that lets you rest the flesh of your arm by keeping your elbow by your side.
column5: "You are sitting in a nice easy chair and all of a sudden there's a loud fart sound. Everyone looks at you, but you shrug your shoulders. They go back to what they're doing...""pyuuuun!"" They look back at you. ""It's not me,"" you say, ""it's just this armrest rubbing against my flesh."" They seem satisfied, and go back to their work. Little do they know that you're making armpit farts (my primitive for the right side) and really putting all of your flesh into it!"

column4: Only uncivilized people eat old flesh.
column5: "Tip: uncivilized appears as part of four other kanji in Heisig, but is not named as such in the text. REF: lake (#148), coral reef (#2562), paste (#2650), ghee (#2749). (P.S. As a primitive I call this ""zombie"", because when the moon shines on the gravestones the zombies arise. And, zombies do tend to be uncivilized.)."

column4: "How do you know if a tree is a maple tree? Easy: Just stand next to the tree on a windy day, and if you get covered in maple syrup, it's a maple tree."
column5: Maple tree helicopter seeds twirling in the wind:　　　　　　　　　 http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnewton/441336070/.

column4: "The guy who was thrown into the river to sink was given one last request. ""If I'm gonna be sleeping with the fishes,"" he said, ""can I at least have a pillow? I'm real sensitive."" The mafia bosses laughed. ""Look, my doctor said I can only use wooden pillows, I have a real serious condition. Can I at least die comfortable-like?"" The mafia dudes said fine, and let him have his pillow. They tossed him the river and drove off...and after a minute, he bobbed to the top, thanks to his floating wood pillow."
column5: WOODEN PILLOWS do not sink (#1888) in water.

column4: "Because it's easy to spot, a purple willow is the tree that marks where my piggy bank is."
column5: "Normally, I can resist the cries of a weeping willow, but this one, she was a purple willow! I just couldn't let the poor tree sit there, so I gave her my piggy bank."

column4: "The Oriental elm is, of course, a tree fairly representative of the Orient and thus it is common in the capital in order to show ambassadors what the Orient is all about."
column5: "In the Japanese remake ""A Nightmare on Oriental Elm Street"", an anthropomorphic tree wreaks havoc on Kyoto. They should never have sold the film rights."

column4: Tip: bonsai and wheat are later combined into Manchu dynasty (#2877). Story: I come across lots of trees all planted in the Manchu dynasty. Then I notice every single one is a hazel tree. I wonder why? In the Manchu dynasty people must have been hazel nuts.
column5: "I love hazelnuts so much that I had a hazel tree installed in my backyard. Mostly it's just for decoration, like a bonsai plant, but I harvest it like wheat every so often: there's just nothing better than homemade Nutella."

column4: This magic comb will comb the nodes out of wood/trees (and make the grain straight).
column5: A comb used to be a wooden tool with many nodes.

column4: "Sick of being chased, the maestro grabs a wooden hammer to fight back with."
column5: "When the trees rebel, they will chase us with wooden hammers."

column4: Mallet seems to be a poor word choice for this A lumberjack won't cut down a charred tree as they're not useful for anything.
column5: A charred tree can be toppled with a mallet.

column4: "The tree was a little too high, but, hey, no problem, I'll just use my younger brother as a ladder!"
column5: The only one who really needs the LADDER to climb onto our TREE house is my LITTLE BROTHER. The rest of us can just scramble up.

column4: "To the Japanese, the first time they saw a chair, it looked like a strange use of wood! Probably why they still like to sit on the floor..."
column5: A strange kind of tree grows in the shape of a chair.

column4: "Nobody buys persimmons at the market, because there's a tree in the middle where you can pick them for free."
column5: The guy at the market says: I'll give you one persimmon tree per every Simon you bring me!

column4: Behold! The sweetrus tree!
column5: The fruits from the citrus tree taste sweet.

column4: Girders are support beams that are nowadays mostly made out of steel. But in the ancient houses that are placed at the boulevard the girders will be made out of wood.
column5: "When the wooden girders start to snap, the workmen shout ""Run! Let's go!""."

column4: Use pickets to hold down the tree in times of whirlwind.
column5: "After the whirlwind hit, the wooden pickets from his fence were scattered all over his yard."

column4: "The holly tree has leaves which are always green. This is very practical in winter, when so much isn't, so that's why it became very popular as christmas decoration."
column5: "All the best holly-days are during the winters, x-mas, new years...emperor's birthday?"

column4: "The citron is relatively unknown overseas, but citron trees are beginning to sprout up everwhere in Japan."
column5: In keeping with the move to greener autos Citroën has introduced its new line which instead of 油 oil (#1107) runs on an extract from citron trees.

column4: Wooden bowls made of wood have the address of the maker on the on the side.
column5: "This is a specially hand-crafted wooden bowl. If you turn is over, you can see the address of the craftsman on the bottom."

column4: The tree your mother warned you about is the hemlock.
column5: Mother called me out to the tree in order to partake of some delicious hemlock tea.

column4: "Give the spindle tree a spin, if you can guess where it lands correctly, you'll get a prize!"
column5: I am not sure if tree is the correct term. It looks more like a plastic hedge. Spindle little more and get a real tree.　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　http://www.flickr.com/photos/koichiwb/2433102011/.

column4: The sacred Shinto tree is a tree of the gods.
column5: The sacred Shinto tree is of course a tree that is dedicated to the gods.

column4: "The evergreen oak is a tree most strict with its leaves: they must be evergreen, or else!"
column5: "A very strict master dictates that the slaves must ensure that the evergreen oaks are ever green. One day a slave notices, to his terror, that one of them has turned brown! Not wanting to get buried up to his crotch in soil, he quickly pulls out a can of green spray paint and paints the entire tree. Even if that tree wasn't ever green before, it certainly is now!"

column4: "Truth is that all Chinese secretly pine for black ""trees"" if you get what I mean!"
column5: The tree of white lies is the Chinese white pine. The tree of truth is the Chinese black pine.

column4: The special brand Horned Whiskey is riped in special oak caskets made of the Japanese oak tree.
column5: Wood from the Japanese oak is very valuable. That's why the chieftain (#2906) demands that his house be made from the Japanese oak.

column4: "The tachibana, or mandarin orange, is a type of tree which sometimes yields poor quality fruit. In such times, instead of simply standing up and inviting customers to make a deal, you must force the sale of your mandarin oranges by brandishing a halberd and forcing the customer to make a deal with you by purchasing your substandard fruit. [Note: along with 柚 citrus tree (#2482), this is used to describe all citrus plants - 柑橘類 かんきつるい means 'citrus fruit'.]."
column5: "To get MANDARIN ORANGES off the tree use your HALBERD, then MAKE A DEAL to sell them."

column4: "The Japanese cypress is a good tree to meet at: the Japanese covers the atmosphere and the cypress presses on any spies. Hey, I tried."
column5: "According to the Wikipedia article, Japanese cypress (hinoki) is grown for its high-quality wood, which is used in the building of ""temples, shrines, traditional noh theatres, baths"" etc. So, this tree is vital to the construction of many of the major meeting places in Japanese society. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamaecyparis_obtusa."

column4: "His wife wanted the chickens in the hen house to be housed properly, so she chopped up a tree and made wooden roosts for them to sit on."
column5: "My wife wanted a special place to roost, so I built her one - on the top of that tree."

column4: "For nestling, the west side of the tree is best – otherwise you get woken up by the sun in the morning. Remember: West is best for your nest."
column5: Its a secret that Nestlé chocolate syrup is drawn from chocolate trees that are found in the west.

column4: "I learned this one from the movie Evil Dead, but when it grows late, trees change shape and become spiny creatures! Lesson: don't go out at night."
column5: "With the safety of darkness as it grows late, spiny little insects start crawling out of the trees."

column4: "When you see bellflowers next to a tree, ring them for good luck."
column5: "When you see bellflowers growing under a tree, it means good luck."

column4: "A normal grove is 林, so in a temple grove half the trees have been removed and replaced by soil (presumably for graves)."
column5: A simple Zen temple grove: A single tree with soil.

column4: "All the grain that was spilled under the tree looked like a mosaic, but someone took a grain rake and disposed of it."
column5: "Dad gave me a grain rake and told me to go and rake the grain, but since this is the most boring task in the whole world, I climbed a tree and played with my Rubik's cube instead."

column4: "An otter's tail like an oar, which he uses to help move trees into his dam."
column5: An oar looks a little like a wooden tail.

column4: "Tree, horse: At cooking school, I learned that there's always a relation between the item you will pestle and the size of the pestle itself. When I read in a cooking book that I had to mash up a horse with a wooden pestle, naturally a tried to obtain a tree to do the job."
column5: "Ah, nothing like using a wooden pestle to mash up some horse meat on a Sunday afternoon."

column4: Wood of a certain length can be used as a cane.
column5: "A length of wood will be suitable as a cane, a walking stick or even a weapon (a jo).This is じょう from the martial art Joudou 杖道. Ten 尺 make up a 杖. Also, walking stick, つえ."

column4: "Why is the sweet oak so sweet? Not sure, but to me it tastes just like turkey (with gravy and cranberry sauce!) Now that is sweet."
column5: Sweeter than Shiit~ake? Turkeys gobble Shiitake mushrooms椎茸 off the sweet oak tree. 　http://www.flickr.com/photos/tinyhare/13963627/.

column4: The revered horned whiskey is riped in special barrels made out of Japanese Oak trees.
column5: The most revered tree is one that can be used as a wine barrel.

column4: "A palisade is a ""fence of stakes especially for defense,"" usually the stakes are very strong, set closely together, and pointed on top. Tome can be seen as a pictograph of several close-set wooden stakes, braced by one horizontal bar."
column5: An army of scholars build a wooden palisade to protect their precious tome of literature.

column4: The village that made its living out of catching fish above all was prone to be raided by pirates. So they made a watch turret out of trees and would look every day if the pirates were coming.
column5: "They were stuck in that wooden turret for ages, with nothing but sundried fish to eat."

column4: "A sturdy oak was the tree I tried to build with my stack of pancakes and waffles, but it didn't turn out to be so sturdy."
column5: How does an oak tree become sturdy? By eating pancake stacks for breakfast every morning. That's a sturdy oak.

column4: A wooden ladle is of course a ladle made out of wood.
column5: A wooden ladle is a wooden ladle is a wooden ladle.

column4: "A kid falls out a tree and the father exclaims, ""Damn, son! Watch where you're going when you go plum-pickin'!""."
column5: Children like to stand under the damson tree and hope the plum fruits will fall into their mouths.

column4: "Before cotton (#1367) is made into thread for Spider-Man's white towels, it simply grows on a tree as raw cotton."
column5: "The raw cotton that is ultimately made into white towels does not grow on trees, but on a kind of bush instead."

column4: Escutcheons are noble shields that depict the coat of arms of a family. They are usually made out of wood.
column5: "Escutcheons are heraldic displays, often found on shields and made of wood."

column4: A Japanese hackberry tree is a type of tree that only has full foliage in the summer. It loses its foliage in the winter.
column5: "If you hack into the hackberry tree with ur PC, you can program it to grow berries even in summer. What a cool hack!"

column4: A birch tree can have a great aura of splendor with it's shiny white coated trunk.
column5: "The headmaster walks past and notices a teacher beating a student with a wooden birch stick. ""Splendid work old chap! As you were!""."

column4: When Sir Lancelot wants a new lance he goes down to the godown (they have a nice selection for sale) and tries some out by thrusting them into a nearby tree.
column5: Sir Lancelot gets wood when she godowns. -or- Lance Bass gets wood thinking about Sir Lancelot godowning on him.

column4: "The mulberry (#698) may be nice and let you dance around it, but if it were a wild mulberry tree it would try to protectiself by throwing rocks at you."
column5: "If you smoke the leaves of the wild mulberry tree, you'll get stoned fo sho coz that tree is wild, brother."

column4: You would be in a quandary if you had to bale trees.
column5: "How do make a bale? Simple. You take a tree, like the one on the left, and you pent it up like the one on the right. Just like that."

column4: "A loquat is a tropical fruit tree, that compared to other trees has an odd seasonal pattern: it's fruit is ripe in late winter or early spring."
column5: "The loquat tree is very rare. To loquate it, you need to compare it to the trees next to it."

column4: "A downspout is made by hollowing out a tree and placing it to carry water ""traffic"" from your rooftop down to the ground."
column5: My downspout empties into a bucket (#2530) 桶 beside the road.

column4: Santa needs to wear 3 fur coats when he rides his wooden sled.
column5: A dog sled is made of wood and has to be pulled by at least 3 ultra furry dogs whose fur can withstand the arctic cold.

column4: "To the enjoyment of humans, many trees are carriers of delicious fruits."
column5: "Just for some fun and enjoyment, the crew put their carrier on top of a tree as an April Fool's prank."

column4: "Two birds high up in a tree drying out after flying through a storm. ""How will we get back on track? We lost our bearings!"" number one cries. ""Don't worry,"" the other one says, as he flips out his mobile. ""I have it bookmarked.""."
column5: "He was reading his book up a tree, and used clotheslines for a bookmark."

column4: "(Note: ear + city walls = exclamation (#2680)). I see a tree with an exclamation mark painted on it. ""Why is that?"" I think, ""An exclamation mark indicates danger, but it's only a tree"". Then a coconut drops on my head. Ah, it's a coconut tree."
column5: "A coconut tree drops a coconut on your head, causing you to make an obscene exclamation (#2680)."

column4: Sandalwood is the ideal wood for a podium: it's easy on your sandals!
column5: "The gunslinger raises the smooth sandalwood grip of his revolver just as the corrupt ""Big Boss"" politician ascends his podium for a victory speech."

column4: "We were seeking shelter for the rain under the plotosid tree, but someone had put a double snare there. As if that foul smelling tree wasn't enough trouble already."
column5: ~~ Keyword should be sumac ~~ Sumacs are worthless trees. They don't protect from rain so you shouldn't use them for a ceiling - and they stink so you can't use them to make snares.

column4: "The zelkova is a sort of elm tree that is very good for making bonsais, setting a standard for other trees, so to speak."
column5: The zelkova is like the standard tree people think of when they think of Japan.

column4: "Due its tendency to encrypt all its messages, the cryptomeria has been a fairly prosperous tree whereas all the other trees have already fallen prey to espionage."
column5: The cryptomeria [すぎ - also written (encrypted) as 杉 cedar (#1713)] is a valuable timber tree so growing them would naturally lead to prosperity.

column4: Cedar trees are so copious they only come in groves.
column5: "How to make a grove: Take a sheet of carton, fold it, cut out one tree in the shape of a cedar, unfold. You'll get copious amounts of trees in no time."

column4: "One of my favourite pastimes is that I like to jump out of a tree on my pogo stick and try to land in a bucket. When successful it makes a very satisfying ""clang"". (Note: new primitive pogo stick = chop seal + utilize, for explanation see my entry at traffic (#1408).)."
column5: "As if in a cartoon, my pogo stick got stuck in a wooden bucket, causing me to fall over."

column4: The 惰 lazy (#629) way to draw an ellipse requires two wooden pegs and some string (http://tinyurl.com/252zgx).
column5: "When tasked with planting the trees to form a circle, the somewhat lazy gardener just winged it (instead of measuring) and the result was an ellipse of trees."

column4: The star-anise is an evergreen tree kept in secrecy for it's aromatic oil.
column5: "Before Anise was a star she lived openly in town, but now that she is star-Anise she lives in secrecy in the woods."

column4: I requested that the cat do something and he spit up a furball.
column5: "For her birthday, your pampered girlfriend's request is, ""Something made of fur"". So you get the cat to cough her up a furball."

column4: "New primitive; let futon = feathers + turkey (i.e. my futon is made with turkey feathers). Then: Twinkle, twinkle little star, oops my futon is on fire."
column5: "With a twinkle in my eye, I set my turkey feather futon on fire for no apparent reason."

column4: The fires outside the puptent of the sentinel are watchfires.
column5: "Watchfire is what you must do if you light a fire outside your pup tent, in case it sets it alight."

column4: A gigantic fire was started by the Olympic torch.
column5: The olympic torch is a fire carried on a gigantic journey from olympus to wherever the games are.

column4: "A fire was kindled by the insane arsonist under a grove of trees. Unable to escape the ensuing inferno, he was burned alive."
column5: "I'm really bad at making fires, I needed kindling from a whole grove of trees before I managed to kindle the fire."

column4: A mummy is running around the room on fire after his moxa treatment goes wrong.
column5: Moxa is a therapy involving burning a plant with fire together with acupuncture or shiatsu. It simply burns for a long time.

column4: "Fire, voiced - water: After the incident where the insect made a pitiful voiced sound, you decide to free it. Immediately it is attracted to the candlelight and flies into the fire. Bugger!"
column5: "蜀:　ショク　(Green caterpillar)　If you are trying to view a green caterpillar late in the evening, use the fire of a candlelight. They are tough to spot:　http://www.flickr.com/photos/moozkat/1606476712/."

column4: Fanning the flames with a fan.
column5: With a fan you can be fanning the fire into a bigger fire. Just make sure it doesn't get out of hand...

column4: The so-and-so from Mary Poppins was covered in soot because he was a fire chimney sweep.
column5: "Teacher: ""How is soot formed?"" Student: ""Well, there is a fire, so-and-so, and then there is soot!""."

column4: The East are the best at tempering (#2030) because their fires are the best at firing.
column5: "The process of firing, that is, glaze bricks or refine metals, is well known in the east, and of course fire is used for it."

column4: "After the evening rice, the guest set out to entertain the children of the house with a dazzling show. He pulled a wand seemingly from out of his crotch and suddenly it appeared to be on fire! Ohs and ahs ensued."
column5: Tip: The wand + evening + crotch combination appears again in repast (#2798).

column4: "The cook just got a new set of pots and pans from the master of the house. Putting them on the fire, they shined so much the refulgent shine blinded him until he blocked it from his view by holding up his ladel."
column5: He used a ladle to protect his eyes from the refulgent light of the fire.

column4: "With an iron that has been in the fire, each beast is subjected to branding."
column5: Branding with FIRE - EACH animal.

column4: "When The Pinnacle collapses, there'll be plenty of flames for sure."
column5: She's a witch!!! Bind her up and set her on fire like they did in olden days so she can feel the flames of hell.

column4: "The fire was contained in the valley (they put a roof over it to keep it from spreading) but it grew hot enough in there to fuse metal... when it was over, the valley looked like a giant mirror!"
column5: "If you contain a fire, you can fuse metal with it."

column4: "In many asian restaurants, meat is roasted right in front of you over flames."
column5: "At the roast, they make the roastee sit in front of everyone else, over the flames to speak, as the comedians roast him a new one!"

column4: If a fire goes smoothly you will have stew in no time.
column5: Tip: tall and complete can be combined into go smoothly (#3001).

column4: I tugged at the the cow's udder but mysteriously no milk came out. I then noticed the crown of his head. It was a bull!
column5: "Mysterious, crown, cow: In Kazad-dum, Gandalf had found a mysterious crown. It really helped his magic, but when they came back to Rivendell, he had become unresistable to the cows (small side-effect). He tried to tug the crown off, but did not succeed..."

column4: "The cow in this frame 牝 is filling a spoon with milk from its udders, so it must be a female animal. (The cow in the next frame 牡 is rolling around in the soil and is, not surprisingly, a male animal.)."
column5: "While the bull wants rough sex, the cow would rather spoon, I guess all female animals are the same."

column4: "Male animals are dirty pigs in English, but in Japanese they are dirty cows ボ ボウ おす お- おん-."
column5: That cow is staring at me and kicking up soil... hold on that's a male... animal... Oh shit! Run!

column4: "That condor is a hoarding creature, it will pick up any precious stone and hoard it with the rest of its jewels as if it were a dragon!"
column5: The king entrusts his most precious stone to his pet condor. It quickly flies off to the mountains if anyone else tries to take it.

column4: The mechanism in my old grandfather clock suddenly broke with an almighty chime and one of the jewels was thrown out through the window into a nearby grove of trees. I'm now searching for the jewel in the grove while the clock continues to chime incessantly.
column5: The king knew playtime in the grove was over when he heard the clock tower chime.

column4: “The king has been detained by some marines!” “How do you know they were marines?” “Because they were wearing marine blue.”.
column5: "The king was detained, by men in marine blue; Must be the marines, planning a coup. (thx Katsuo/gavmck)."

column4: Wolverine was easily able to join the squad (#1229) when he was seen wearing a top hat speckled with jewels on the sides. (thanks mantixen).
column5: Tenacious D (the two kings) speckled the death row inmate from both sides with their pearl juice.

column4: "The king was given two choices by the abductor: either the king gives him the lapis lazuli jewels, or he throws the king's infant son into the stream."
column5: "This kanji should be ""Ryukyu Islands"" or something similar and 瑠 should be Lapis Lazuli."

column4: The king used both hands to tinker with himself in his spare time.
column5: "Picture the king holding a large pan in his two hands and tinkering with it, wishing he could lead the itinerant life of a tinker. As a rhyme: The king, he uses his two hands, To tinker with his pots and pans . . ."

column4: The king appreciated the distinction of burnished jewels.
column5: Most can not tell the distinction between a precious jewel and an ordinary rock until it has been burnished.

column4: I hone my skills by skillfully separating real jewels from the fake junk worn by fat sows!
column5: King Henry VIII was keen on hunting wild boar. Here we see him first honing his skills on a sow.

column4: "The coral is not found in this tome of jewels since it's really not a mineral, but the remains of small animals."
column5: The greet coral reef (珊瑚礁) forms a palisade (#2507) encrusted with the finest jewels the ocean ca offer.

column4: Coral reefs are a like a jewel of the ocean. Though our uncivilized behavior is causing them to die off.
column5: The king had a coral reef installed in his lake.

column4: "The king wished he was as handsome as Fabio standing on the edge (#1167) of a mountain combing his hair, but he realized he was fortunate in other ways."
column5: "How most fortunate! After gambling his life on the edge (#1167), Indiana Jones discovers that the comb is studded with countless jewels."

column4: "In Silicon Valley, people live like kings in ivy-clad mansions."
column5: Ivy from Soul Calibur has big balls of silicon in her chest.

column4: "Mummies are adorned with jet jewels to connote death, or something. Oh, yeah, 'cause King Tut was a big fan of jet planes."
column5: Public airlines fly slow and take a long time to arrive so the king has a private jet.

column4: He who possesses the crystal stone is the rightful king of England.
column5: King Arthur of England pulls the sword from a crystal stone and embarks on his destiny.

column4: The ball was the only thing that people at the beginning of time had to use as a toy. Poor cavemen.
column5: "And so it was, the ball marked the beginning of all the toys that were to come."

column4: "The king orders his penis, ""Start tinkling!""."
column5: "When the king barks out his orders, all the chandeliers and other ornaments in the palace start tinkling."

column4: The man being tortured was apprehensive as he saw his tormentor approaching with a hairpin poised to pierce his brain!
column5: I’m feeling apprehensive because I’m wading barefoot in a paddyfield and I've just dropped my hairpin.

column4: "First, we sow the rice field, then we plant the flowers, and lastly we plant the corn. (Stroke order and story in one)."
column5: "Lastly, let me mention that my ricefield and silage stack are amongst the top ten in the country..."

column4: Ivy grows on the paddy-field ridge encircling the rice field as opposed to the intra-field paddy ridge that divides it in half.
column5: "[+mantixen] The ordinary 畔 paddy-ridge (#1204) dissects the field by dividing it in half, but the paddy-field ridge runs around the outside & is covered in ivy. Disambiguate by noting that the hyphen in 'paddy-ridge' divides the word itself in half (five letters each side) but 'paddy-field ridge' has five extra letters on the right, the ridge itself, in fact, the part covered in ivy."

column4: Scrapie is a disease sheep sometimes catch. It causes them to itch so unbearably that they scrape themselves to death.
column5: "If you think wearing a wool sweater is itchy, just think of how sheep must feel! They must be so sick of wearing that itchy wool all the time!"

column4: "When your sickness involves inflammation, you will produce phlegm (perhaps inphlegmation?)."
column5: "If I'm sick, and have an inflammation of my lungs, I cough up a lot of phlegm."

column4: He had a curious form of measles : the red marks on his skin were all in the shape of an umbrella. The doctors of course couldn't explain it...
column5: "I'm sick with the measles. Whenever I go out, I carry my parasol to try and cover up the rash."

column4: """Hemorrhoids 痔 are the sickness suffered by people who sit in meditative poses for long periods at Buddhist temples 寺."" ( Joseph De Roo's ""2001 Kanji"")."
column5: "Hemorrhoids is a sickness. Mnemonic 'holy hemorrhoids' and picture a monk at a Buddhist temple. This is a word that kids find funny, pronounced ジ。."

column4: "The SICKNESS called cancer works by self-replication, so that its bad GOODS grow more & more until a vertiable MOUNTAIN of them forms on you-- that's the tumor, the awful sign of cancer."
column5: "You may have a mountain of goods, but cancer is a sickness that strikes the rich and poor with equal contempt."

column4: The sickness that only allows you to eat monkey crotch will surely make you lose weight.
column5: "The poor monkey obviously had a sickness. He was scratching his crotch the whole time and when he started to lose weight heavily, the caretakers knew they couldn't save him anymore."

column4: "I suffer from silver-sickness, that is, if anything made of silver even touches my skin it leaves a scar."
column5: "I got sick and needed surgery, but the silver lining is that now I have these awesome scars I can show off!"

column4: "This sickness seems to prey upon the lowly of society mostly, and causes paralysis in its final stages."
column5: "Caveman, lowly: Caveman was just a lowly Neanderthaler, trying to survive. But he had healing hands and people were brought in from far to have him cure their paralysis."

column4: "Here you have a picture of him with his apple of the eye: you see him keeping an eye upon his favourite cow, while leaning on it with his elbow."
column5: "Barnyard romance: The big bull winked with his EYE and let out a MOO (牟 2961) toward the cow and said, ""Your the APPLE OF my EYE baby!""."

column4: If you see mysterious things in front of your eyes you're definitely dizzy.
column5: "When you see mysterious stars from your eyes, it's a sign that you're dizzy - 眩暈（めまい）。 Maybe becuase you're fighting off a face hugger who has its tail round your neck!"

column4: I paint a huge eye on the side of my pup tent. Why? – It’s obvious: when I’m at the camping site it makes it obvious which tent is mine so I can quickly locate it.
column5: It's obvious that the pup tent with a huge eye on the side belongs to the dark lord Sauron.

column4: The eyebrows hover over the eyes like a divided flag.
column5: Pictograph: opera glasses over eyes ビ ミ まゆ.

column4: "I threw my dart at a pheasant during the hunt, but hit a turkey instead."
column5: A pheasant is like a small wild TURKEY except you can kill it with a DART.

column4: "That carpenter can never remember where his tools are, so there is a gigantic arrow pointing to his carpenter's square."
column5: My carpenter's square is hanging on that gigantic dart.

column4: "Last time I was on crag's list, I found someone selling an aircraft carrier they carved out of stone! A crazy lawn ornament I suppose."
column5: "If you want to take all the stones out of this crag, you'll need a large carrier."

column4: "A grapnel is a small anchor with several hooks, used for anchoring small boats, or to pull up sunken objects (it looks very much like a grappling hook). The position of stones underwater determines where the grapnel will catch."
column5: "He was determined to climb this rock, so he used a grapnel."

column4: "Notes: 珀 (not in Heisig) means ""amber"". Story for both: A bus is stopped at some traffic lights in Japan. Inside, King Henry VIII and Barry White are arguing over whether the lights are yellow or amber. The lights change to ""Go"", and Mick Jagger (stone) then joins a new argument over whether the lights are blue or green. They compromise on blue-green."
column5: The king gets stoned on white powder and sees little blue-green men.

column4: "This is not an ordinary rock, if you look carefully you will see that it is an ancient inkstone."
column5: A rock that you often see (in writing) is an inkstone.

column4: "My calling card is made of rock, which is a bit inconvenient because it is so big & heavy. So I’m using a grindstone to grind it down in size."
column5: "In Bedrock, people had business cards made of rock and engraved using a grindstone. (Big ups to Katsuo)."

column4: Teacups at the Japanese restaurant are usually made of stone and have the name and address of the restaurant written on them.
column5: Teacup = 茶碗（ちゃわん）. Pieces of stone(?) that everyone has at their address.

column4: Those gremlins! At night break they insist on coming out and gluing stones all over the place. These obstacles make it nearly impossible for me to get to work!
column5: Getting stoned until night break glued to your couch is a major obstacle to success.

column4: Mount Rushmore is a place in the US where the heads of illustrious presidents are carved into the stone of a cliff.
column5: The stone heads at Mt. Rushmore are of illustrious historical figures.

column4: "To qualify as a rocky beach (as opposed to a sandy beach), how many stones does the beach need?"
column5: """How many stones can you find at a rocky beach?"" the Zen Master asked his baffled pupil."

column4: A whetstone so notorious that it had destroyed ten thousand cliffs.
column5: Whatstone would make the best whetstone? I wandered ten thousand cliffs in search of an answer.

column4: "Some mills use an animal, typically an ox or donkey, to rotate the stone. But in this mill the stone is being pulled round by a turkey."
column5: "I can tell you, it was a big mess when a turkey accidentally came between the stones of the wind mill. We had to clean the blood and feathers away for ages."

column4: "The beautiful woman has to fend off honorable admirers every day, who want to drag her to the altar and marry her."
column5: An honorable Catholic girl will fend off sexual advances until she exchanges vows at the altar.

column4: "If you want longevity, go to an altar and beseech the gods."
column5: "Altar, longevity: Having seen all his friends and family die so long ago, the ancient sage visited the altar and beseeched the gods to put an end to his longevity."

column4: "Picture a Japanese altar that contains ancestral tablets, placed on the right (on the left would be the incense)."
column5: "On the lower right of each altar, there is a small ancestral tablet. Its purpose is to record all of the past converts to Buddhism - they are the ones who chose the right path before you and should be respected."

column4: "From http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shinto: Whenever a child is born in Japan, a local Shinto shrine adds the child's name to a list kept at the shrine and declares him or her a ""family child"" (氏子 ujiko?). After death an ujiko becomes a ""family spirit"", or ""family kami"" (氏神 ujigami?). Therefore, if your family name is inscribed in the altar, then you will become a local god."
column5: "The altar dedicated to this local god has the family names of all the villagers inscribed in it, so that the god knows whom he should favour."

column4: The ancestral shrine has an altar that shows little reclining figurines of ancestors.
column5: "In countries where ancestors are worshiped, small children are taught to lie down (prostrate themselves) at the altar that is their ancestral shrine."

column4: "Ancient Japanese officials collected their salarium in the shrines. A priest would collect their rice grains with a broom, and sweep it unto the altar, where the officials could collect their rice."
column5: "Rather than cold hard cash, the rice that the altar boys could sweep up became their salarium."

column4: "When the wheelchair-bound Felicity was healed at the altar (by one of those healer priests), she was finally able to stand upright and was overcome by felicitation."
column5: "On the special festival day, the altar of the local shrine contains the felicitations of local upright citizens, thanking their local gods for doing such a good job."

column4: I use balancing scales to make sure everyone gets an even amount of Wheaties.
column5: "He didn't have a balancing scales to figure out how much his wheat weighed, but he came up with a solution: he loaded a vessel with wheat and let it float in his lily pond, and then he measured how deep the vessel would be in the water."

column4: "Millet is a small grain whose importance was greater in prehistoric times. Nowadays, it has been supplanted in the West by wheat, and in the East (""under the bamboo umbrella""), by rice."
column5: Millet is grown primarily in African countries where there is little rain. As opposed to wheat and rice grains which are grown in areas one would need an umbrella.

column4: The dude was so upset about going bald that he covered himself with a wheat sack so that only his legs were showing.
column5: "Because the poor guy went bald, he made a big, big hat out of wheat stalks. But it was so big, that it covered his whole torso, so that basically only his walking legs were visible under it."

column4: "Every day, the farmer works in his wheat field, making a wish that his hard labor will bear fruit."
column5: I wish Wheaties would bear fruit... Then I wouldn't have to add any myself!

column4: "Crabgrass is lowly wild grass, quickly spreading with nasty roots, and difficult to remove out of your wheat field."
column5: A lowly wheat field only grows crap grass.

column4: "A bumper crop is a very full crop. In this particular case, the bumper crop is a wheat crop, grown by this excentric guy in a grass skirt, who has gone completely native, but knows the secrets of how to get a good crop!"
column5: "On the tropical island of JOU, lots of crops are grown - coconuts, bananas, pineapples, etc - but these are really just for show to get lots of tourists. The real bumper crop that feeds the islanders is wheat."

column4: "Wheat, rice seedling, walking legs: The next hurdle for mission of the rice seedlings with walking legs was the imperial authority. They had to cross through a wheat field, but the imperial authority didn't give permission for rice seedlings and wheat to mix. How to solve this...?"
column5: "The greatest threat to a imperial authority is famine. If those seedlings do not become wheat crops, walking legs will storm the Imperial Palace."

column4: "This region only has sparse agriculture. The few farmers hope their wheat crops will do well, but the soil isn't really good."
column5: "Scarce is a better keyword since this really means rare. Here, the farmer hopes he gets some wheat during the harvest since food is scarce."

column4: I'm being obeisant to Doctor's orders -- trying to get into shape by eating only wheat and drinking only from that spring.
column5: The wheat farmers are obeisant towards the shape of the white little goddess.

column4: "Ladies, I apologize for peeping through the hole, but, you know, it's just standard protocol."
column5: "A husband is peeping at his wife undressing through the key hole. ""What the heck are you doing? You can see me naked anytime!""."

column4: That hole is still too tight. Bring the saw to enlarge it!
column5: Use a saw to enlarge a hole that's too tight.

column4: "After Osama blew a hole in NY, the counterreaction forced him to yield and retreat into caverns."
column5: "In ""The Empire Strikes Back"", the Milennium Falcon flies into a large hole, of what they think is a cavern, because they don't want to yield to the forces of the Empire. Turns out it's not a cavern at all, actually..."

column4: "There's a knock on my door, and it's the local dentist accompanied by an elephant. The latter is a patient, and the dentist explains that he wants to drill a hole in its tusk, but his normal dentist's drill is too small, so could he borrow my big DIY drill. Anyway, I drill the hole in the tusk for him."
column5: "No drill? Pfft, just use this here tusk as a drill and make all the holes you can!"

column4: "The original Japanese kitchen stoves were powered by electric eels (hey, Edison never made it to the far east!), so a small hole had to be placed in the dirt under the stove (for the eels to swim around in)."
column5: "We finally found the tortoise that escaped (straw rope (#1377)), it has somehow crawled into a hole just above the kitchen stove and had become quite dirty."

column4: In the slave's crotch there something standing with a vase-like longness. What could it be?
column5: "Sitting cross-legged or standing, the longness of a slaves workday doesn't change."

column4: When I hear rustling in the night I stand up and go to check out what it is but it's always just wind.
column5: "Vase, wind (with gnats): He heard a rustling outside and when he checked, saw a host of killer gnats riding the wind in the direction of his house. He quickly jumped into the large standing vase and put the stopper in, to ride it out..."

column4: "Stand up, fortune telling: Something scary happened at the Mars outpost near the alien ruins. Suddenly, one of the soldiers stood up and started to tell fortunes. (Which weren't all that positive for mankind). Then he fell down and never spoke again."
column5: A characteristic of an outpost is the lack of usual facilities. Here we see a fortune teller with no crystal ball having to make do with a vase.

column4: Many repose peacefully in a blue vase after being cremated.
column5: "Standing in the blue ocean with sand between my toes, dolphins swimming and palm trees rustling in the breeze. I Soak in this repose dreamscape."

column4: It's a concubine: feel free to touch (#672) her all you want.
column5: "A concubine is a woman you can stand on and walk all over. She does not have the same status as a wife. The contrast can be seen in the compound: 妻妾 (one's wife and mistresses). Both are women; however, the wife gets a brush for her hair; whereas the concubine is stood upon and trampled."

column4: "Cloak, clock: The cloaks of Muslims have a tiny clock on their lapel, so that they can keep track on when to pray..."
column5: The lapel of a cloak sometimes has a clock pinned on it for meditation sessions.

column4: Something is residing in the hem of your cloak. Maybe you should consider cleaning it? キョ コ すそ cuff; hem; foot of mountain.
column5: "If you reside in the slums, you start off as a small child with a very large cloak. As you grow it gets hemmed. The rich kids just get new cloaks."

column4: "Cloak, fit: The lined kimono was lined in such a way that it made people appear to be slimmer than they really were. Even people who didn't fit in the accompanying cloak still bought the lined kimono..."
column5: Girls all lined up in front of the cloakroom in the department store to be fitted with lined kimonos for their coming of age ceremony.

column4: "You can 誇 boast (#1244) with words, or you can instead show off your expensive cloak and hakama."
column5: I wear a cloak with a pleated skirt so that my girlfriend can easily put her jaws around my big one.

column4: "The safety violations at Japanese nuclear power plants are egregious! Not only are they built inside ancient Japanese castles, there are no considerations for contamination. I was visiting last month when I opened a sliding door to reveal the cloak room. All the scientists had haphazardly piled their cloaks on the CORE itself!"
column5: "Before you open the sliding door to the core of the nuclear reactor, you'd better put on your anti-radioactivity cloak."

column4: "The Chinese panpipe is an old musical instrument made of bamboo. People practiced the Chinese panpipe their whole life just so that they could play for the emperor, often a bad performance would have the emperor take their life away from them."
column5: The Chinese panpipe is made by using different sized cells of bamboo.

column4: The bamboo was felled to make a raft.
column5: "Bamboo, fell: To escape the forestfire, the pandas felled some of the bamboo to make a raft and escape."

column4: I see a load of bamboo for sale at a bargain price and decide it’s so cheap that I’ll buy it and make my own bamboo blinds.
column5: Buy bargain bamboo blinds at Panda Palace.

column4: "If you are making a rattan box, then the best advice I can give you is to use bamboo and keep it simple."
column5: The bamboo rice basket is a simple basket made of bamboo.

column4: In Japan they use bamboo poles to dry their clothes on.
column5: bamboo cane (#2642) + bamboo pole = bamboo clothlines.

column4: "Compared to before when Japanese mothers used to throw a hood over their naughty kids and beat them bloody with bamboo, the modern ""kitchen-discipline by spatula"" seems much more civilized."
column5: "Compare the effectiveness of beating a person with bamboo, a belt, and a spatula."

column4: If I have any bamboo shoots left over from my stirfry I wrap them up in foil to keep them moist overnight. Then I can use them the next day.
column5: I always roll up my foil and hide it in sticks of bamboo overnight. This is to foil any attempt to steal it.

column4: "The film director is making a new low budget version of ""The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe"". As we watch him, he appears to be constructing something out of bamboo. Finally the director says, ""Well, no lion or witch yet, but thanks to this bamboo at least the wardrobe is finished""."
column5: A director of a samurai war film has his actors fitted in a bamboo armor wardrobe.

column4: "Bamboo, in front: Martial arts movie. The hero walks through a bamboo forest, and suddenly an arrow shaft stands quivering in the bamboo tree just in front of him. Time for some action scenes."
column5: Bamboo forms the arrow shaft you shoot in front of you.

column4: I can't play this ancient harp! It's craftsmanship is so mediocre! The bamboo is hard and stiff! Give me a new koto any day of the week.
column5: Musical instruments are so mediocre these days. I call for a return to the ancient harps crafted from genuine bamboo.

column4: The only cage that can keep a dragon is made of bamboo.
column5: A bamboo cage won't hold a dragon!

column4: Mr T uses a stick of slender bamboo to beat his taskmaster that he chased up into the tree.
column5: "The wise sensei instructs Mr. T while they perch atop a tree: Oh, you must be supple and thin like the slender bamboo!"

column4: "Bamboo, lovedoll: At dinner, my lovedoll decided to eat her meal the Japanese way using chopsticks. But well, what a problems she had getting those bamboo shoots into her mouth (which should not be that difficult, I would say!)."
column5: "I've always wanted to use bamboo chopsticks to eat sushi off a naked woman. Unfortunately, there is no woman in my life, so this love doll will have to do."

column4: "During post-production of a movie, redaction is required for ""red action"", or action that results in a bloody accident, like when they miscalculated how large an object Spider-Man could hold up with both hands."
column5: "Calculate, st bernard, venom: Venom had made an insidious plan to strike at the redaction office of the Daily Bugle, to scare the free press. He plans to leave corpses of dead St.Bernards on every desk of the news office. Now, he still needs to calculate how many St. Bernards are required..."

column4: My bamboo cane is collapsible. It can fold into two separate bamboo sticks.
column5: This bamboo cane is too short for me; it's made of only two feet of bamboo.

column4: A winnowing fan made of bamboo is used to cool off the basketball player.
column5: "The hard working peasants get a little annoyed watching the aristocrats sitting around playing chess, so they start a revolt and whack the chess board and pieces away with their bamboo winnowing baskets.."

column4: "I see a panda wearing a backpack, and every so often something inside the backpack reaches out and grabs bamboo. (it’s acutally a baby panda reaching out to grab bamboo to eat)."
column5: "When I encountered an ravenous panda, I just reached back to my backpack and pulled out two bamboo katanas."

column4: "Each livraison (installment) of the scrapbook is delivered by post, and sits resting on your doorstep for when you get home. Of course, it might blow away so the postman has put heavy bamboo blocks on top of it."
column5: A limited livraison (edition) of manga made of bamboo.

column4: "Should you put bamboo through your tongue? If you don't already know the answer yourself, you shouldn't even ask."
column5: "In some tribes, it is fully expected that you should put bamboo through your tongue."

column4: To winnow you need two things: a winnowing fan (no. 2643 箕) and a pelt (to use as a bag to collect the grain you winnowed).
column5: "After Bobby Fischer's 箕 winnowing fan (#2643) winnowed Spassky's bamboo pawn from the other pieces in the famous game three, the rest was history: Spassky returned to Moscow in disgrace & was pelted by fruits & vegetables."

column4: Settlings at the bottom of sake are white and made of rice.
column5: "Scrap, waste, settlings. Think of scrap or waste paper - like the confetti or rice thrown at a wedding - it is white."

column4: The other cadets are really cruel: giving this cadet only the lees of the sake to drink….
column5: "New cadets aren't allowed to drink with the seniors, so they have to settle for the rice lees at the bottom of the empty sake bottles."

column4: The uncivilized used rice as paste.
column5: "It would be uncivilized to eat rice without natto, that delicious bean paste! (I think I just vomitted a little in my mouth)."

column4: Unhulled rice still needs a blade taken to it.
column5: What's all this unhulled rice still doing here? You were supposed to hull this yesterday! Pick up that blade and get to work immediately!

column4: Rice bran is for old people: its benefits to sanity in additional to being delicious rice make it an instant sell.
column5: Rice bran keeps you sane. But only if it's made from real rice. None of that fake stuff.

column4: "Rice is easy to digest, so if you poke through your excrement, finding bits of rice is uncommon."
column5: "It is uncommon to find rice in your excrement. Corn, on the other hand..."

column4: "Maybe the Japanese ought to rethink their nickname for America. Seriously, the only ""rice"" I have seen in the wild west is foxtail millet."
column5: "West, rice: In the old west there was a special type of plant (it's now extinct): the foxtail millet. It behaved like regular millet, but when somebody wanted to reap it, it ran away as quick as a fox, leaving a small trail of rice."

column4: This should do the trick: http://tinyurl.com/dzhu4g.
column5: "In one of those ridiculous sentai TV programs, after the ""car rangers"" fire their missiles at the enemy monster, you can clearly see the thread that pulls them together when they link up to form CAR-RANGER-MON."

column4: Spidey assists the older ladies at the twine convention by providing them with a continuous line of twine to knit with. They thank him for the twine with some wine.
column5: "Spiderman + methodical: If you want to be like Spiderman, you'll have to be methodical and start from the beginning by learning how to make webs with twine. Note: 侖 is an extremely rare kanji meaning ""methodical"", I remember this with: ""A meeting of scrapbookers who are very methodical""."

column4: "Spiderman, burgler - money (burglar (#357)): When the old lady returned from visiting the fiesta, she found a burglar in her home tied up with carpet yarn. A note said: Regards from you friendly neighborhood Spiderman. Well, she was not amused when she saw the remains of her carpet."
column5: "The burglar isn't getting Spider-Man's money, but he can get tied up with carpet yarn if he wants."

column4: "Spiderman, half: Since only half of his family was left (aunt May, uncle died), Spiderman kept strong ties with her."
column5: "I must buy some more ties – half of mine are in threads. (Edit: All the kanji dictionaries I have checked classify this character as thread + half. Depending on the font, though, the right side often appears as a variant of 半 with the top two strokes sloping outwards)."

column4: "Spiderman is put in a jail cell by the fashion police for wearing scarlet. (His fellow inmates include Scarlet O'Hara, Scarlett Johansson, Captain Scarlet, The Scarlet Pimpernel, etc)."
column5: "Frankly Scarlet, I don't give a damn. Here we see Scarlet O'Hara going to visit Rhett in his jail cell (damn those yankees!) wearing her new (green, and velvet incidentally) threads, created from Tara's (the manor) drapes."

column4: "Spiderman, religion: Spiderman discovered that the Scientology religion (which just opened a chapterhouse in his city) was a synthesis of idiotic believes and a little mystery. Everything to obtain large sums of money from its 'believers'."
column5: Spider-Man's religion is a synthesis of spirituality and scientific proof.

column4: "A vegetarian replaces all his leather bootlaces with string, saying “There’s no sign of the cow in this thread!”."
column5: "Spider-Man suspects there's a cow walking through his room while he's asleep, but when he wakes up he sees no sign of the cow. He decides to tie string around everything in the room, which will create a boobytrap for the cow."

column4: "Spiderman tries out for a football team. He fastens his chinstrap and tackles runners with webs from his forearm. 　　　　　　　　　　　　　厷　コウ　(Forearm)　""ムarm""."
column5: Spider-Man poses with his hands on his hips to convey being larger than life.

column4: "Spiderman, cave, computer, human legs, soil: To summarize the newest Spiderman comic: Spidy needs to turn off a computer in a cave (countdown clock for nuclear bomb). However, his human legs get stuck in the soil (some kind of quicksand). The situation seems hopeless... but somehow at the end of the comic, Spiderman has saved the day."
column5: "To summarize the story of Spiderman, he was a computer geek who lived in a cave. Then he got super powers and his human legs rarely touch the ground anymore."

column4: "Spider-Man is quite the womanizer. When he sees a hot babe, he whistles and calls, 'Hey, gorgeous, how'd you like to be bound up with Spidey for a decameron?' Unfortunately most of the women he whistles at don't know what a decameron is; some of them think it's a hot car."
column5: "According to society’s twisted ideals, if Black Widow went without eating for a decameron, she would be gorgeous."

column4: "Spiderman solemnly swears that he hates embroidery, but everyone knows he loves it, he's always got the sewing machine out when nobody else is around."
column5: "Because of the special thread Spiderman uses for embroidery, and the special location from which it is produced, he is always solemn when he does embroidery, because it makes him hemorroidery."

column4: "Spiderman, sprout: Pongee is a soft thin woven cloth. Spiderman - a textile buff in his own right- found out that the mold growing on rotting Brussel sprouts may also be used to make pongee. And it's much cheaper than silk!"
column5: Spiderman decides to try a new diet of sprouts to see how it affects the consistency of his web. To his surprise (150m above ground) a lovely line of pongee comes out instead. Time to think quickly.

column4: "Spiderman's a strange guy, wearing such ornate outfits to make himself look 綺麗【きれい】."
column5: "SPIDERMAN wears such STRANGE outfits, that they seem almost ORNATE compared to the thugs he captures."

column4: The rice seedlings notice that Spiderman's blocking their path to the promised land. So they put on da mask which was made of a figured cloth and managed to outsmart spidey.
column5: Those rice-seedlings on walking legs had to carry this thread all the way from the middle east to introduce the beautiful damask to the Japanese.

column4: The thread with a mysterious origin... hint: its not from a plant!
column5: "Spiderman tries the mysterious meat threaded into a pasta form at the Korean market... ""You prepared this dish purrrrrfectly!""."

column4: "Even though his costume is coming apart at the seams as he chases the bad guys, Spiderman is still determined to catch them."
column5: "Spiderman's costume has come apart at the seams and here he is, mending it in his house, determined to make it stronger than before."

column4: "If you wear clothes with vertical stripes, those threads will make you look taller."
column5: "Spiderman, tall: Spiderman seemed taller than he really was, due to the stripes in his uniform. As is to be expected from our textile expert..."

column4: No one can accept the fact that Spiderman is a gimp.
column5: I cannot accept that Spiderman will star in the remake of Forrest Gimp.

column4: "If there are very few threads, then the light will come through and the fabric be considered to be a gossamer."
column5: "Because it has too few threads, Spider-Man decided not to use gossamer to make his skin-tight costume."

column4: A household spoon is used for the rudder of your model boat.
column5: "Tip: house + spoon : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig. REF: snake (#519), rudder (FRAME 2674), prevarication (#2718), Shakyamuni Buddha (#2955)."

column4: The gunwale is perhaps the most mysterious part of a boat for it is neither a gun nor a whale.
