column5: "Gunwale (rhymes with ""tunnel"") is the top edge of the side of a boat, for example the widened lip on the sides of a canoe. The mysterious origin of this part of a boat comes from the strengthened sides of warships that used artillery (it means ""gun ridge"")."

column4: My friend's new dangly earrings are interesting--cacti strung together with butterfly cocoons.
column5: "While practicing slicing a cactus in half, you accidentally cut Venom from ear to ear, but he's strung together by his tar-like symbiote."

column4: Policymakers' ears have to be attentive to the heart of the public.
column5: "If you open your ears (耳をすませば), you can be attentive to the public's heart. -------------- OR -------------- It only takes one ear that is attentive to the public heart to win them over."

column4: "Ear, sprout, snare: When the summons reached his ears, he sprang up and started running. However, he suddenly noticed a delicious cooked meal of Brussel sprouts. He started to eat it, but it was snared! Appearantly, his loyalty had been tested and it was clear which was more important to him..."
column5: "When my parents asked me to eat my sprouts, I threw a snare at their ears. The next day I received a summons to appear in court."

column4: "Fearful that I was addicted to ear piercings, my dad put a crown around one of my legs so that I couldn’t go to the piercing dude."
column5: "Ear, crown/human legs (also in sink (#1888)): After they had recovered the body that had been sunk by the mafia, the autopsy revealed that the victim had been addicted to drugs. This, they could see from the form of her ear! I love CSI!"

column4: Quiet!!!! The city walls have ears he exclaimed.
column5: The city walls have ears!? Did you say that with an exclamation or question mark?

column4: "Fleas jump onto your crotch, take two drops of blood, and then go on their merry way: what vile insects!"
column5: "Right side of boisterous (#1985) (but without the drops there). A flea is an insect that is depicted here as jumping from (or to) a crotch (the two drops). Note: this is indeed flea, not louse, which has its own character (虱). I'm not sure of the stroke order, but by the rule of drawing from top to bottom, the crotch drop should come first. The louse (虱) then is of course a drop-like insect that attaches itself to body hairs by little hooks."

column4: "The crab isn’t truly an insect, but certainly looks like one. They’re real tasty, too, but you have to unravel it if you want to eat it."
column5: "You unravel a crab leg, but insects fall out of it. It's probably too old to be edible."

column4: "At the zoo, most animals think of insects as just good sources of protein."
column5: Insects are fed to the critters at the zoo for protein.

column4: "Rather than die, tenacious insects go down into hibernation."
column5: Many animals go into hibernation over the winter due to lack of food. The most tenacious remain and dig in the icy ground for insects.

column4: I unbind my tortoise to let him catch that pesky insect the housefly.
column5: The housefly was bugging the tortoise so it tucked its head inside.

column4: "The ant is an insect of righteousness, putting the group before its individual concerns."
column5: "In Aesop's stories, the ant is often considered righteous."

column4: A bee is an insect with a pointy (see summit (#1562)) stinger.
column5: The insect that interrupted our tryst (#2417) was a bee!

column4: "While I’m game-hunting, I cover my dogs with wax so that they won’t be bother by insects."
column5: I like to go game-hunting (#1940) for exotic insects and then store them in wax.

column4: Shrimp are the only “insects” that I can eat in my spare time: anything else requires way too much willpower.
column5: "Tip: Many different Kanji for shrimp: 蝦,海老, 鰕､蛯. This particular Kanji is likely to be seen as the old name for the Ainu: Ezo 蝦夷, and the land associated with them Ezochi 蝦夷地 (now called Hokkaido). A kanji you are likely to see for Shrimp on menus and such is 海老(えび). Those kanji are also used for Tiger Prawns 車海老(くるまえび) Co."

column4: The octopus holds up two of his legs so that they look like antennas and then walks on the other six. He bears a strong resemblance to an insect when he does that.
column5: "Insect, candle: As insects are drawn to candles, so, also are deep sea divers drawn to the legend of the huge octopus living in the deep waters of the sea. (They also don't come back)."

column4: "螺　(にし) is a fresh water mollusk with a shell like a screw. When the mollusk has died the shell is used by insects like a house. Thus, insects accumulate in the screw shell."
column5: Insects accumulate if a screw is missing.

column4: "Cicadas are simple insects: they just pop out of the ground, mate, and die, albeit only every ten years or so."
column5: "The cicada is a simple insect, making noise, mating, and dying."

column4: "There he sits, eating insects with his long tongue and blending in with the green ivy. It may no be easy being green, but it is easy being a frog."
column5: A frog hides in the ivy to catch insects.

column4: The moth is an insect that affects your ego by eating holes in your clothes.
column5: The moth is an insect with an ego -- always looking for the (lime)light.

column4: An insect fits right into the clam's mouth before it clamps shut.
column5: "For contraband purposes, I tried to fit insects into a clam, but that didn’t work out too well."

column4: "The leech is an insect that sucks on you, but good luck reaching climax with all that blood being lost."
column5: The climax of this little insect's life is sucking your blood. Leeches suck.

column4: "An insect crosses ten thousand cliffs to make it to sea, only to be eaten by an oyster."
column5: "Slogan at The Cliffs Piano Oyster Bar: ""Because it is ten thousand times better to have oysters on your piano than crabs on your organ""."

column4: "Keeping my eye fixed directly over the paper, I hold down the ivy and melt the strands with my magic wand. Viola, ruled lines are created! I bet most people think a machine does it."
column5: "The cyclops couldn't make ruled lines with his wooden wand because it wasn't smooth, so he had to use a square jewel."

column4: "In ancient Japan, the most grievous insult was to poke a rival's horse in the eye (consider how rare an expensive a steed was in those days). It was the final step in preparation for a duel to the death."
column5: Giving the evil eye while calling them a horse's ass.

column4: "In Japanese RPGs, you are well advised to add a stole to your clothing as a ""freebie"" way to add defensive points without swapping out some other garment. But since you can't find them in the shops, you have to ""stole"" that stole from a glamorous NPC who is ostensibly there to aid your quest."
column5: That Buddhist priest stole that stole: it was like he subtracted some clothes from me and added some clothes to him.

column4: A monk's sash is a garment that has grains of sand in it from beachside meditations.
column5: The monk stashes grains of sand in his sash and hides it under his garment. Probably emptied the hourglass to hasten dinner time.

column4: "At Thanksgiving, it’s uncommon for people to accept humbly the food: most people just dig in."
column5: "You're invited to a Thanksgiving party in Japan! Awesome! You're so happy that your Japanese friends are trying to make you feel at home (you've been homesick recently). You sit down to the table, and they bring out some..uh...uncommon food. Really uncommon. Like just imagine the most uncommon Thanksgiving food ever, and that's what you're given (i don't know, a frisbee or something?). Of course, you have to be Japanese and accept humbly their food."

column4: "I’ll do the honors! So, I grabbed the knife and made an incision into the Thanksgiving turkey."
column5: The surgeon scrubs up & puts on plastic gloves before making his first incision in the Thanksgiving turkey. 9th of 14 RtK3 turkeys lost to other primitives.

column4: "At Thanksgiving, there’s a pretty common bet: I wonder how much you can stuff into your mouth!"
column5: "In rikaichan this means ""how! what! alas!"" . Alas! How did my mouth end up unfed at this thanksgiving feast? I wonder."

column4: "In order to provide superior counsel, I spoke to him for ten days."
column5: I was counselled for ten days about my bad language. It was f**king horrible.

column4: "When receiving a gift, you should say something polite."
column5: How about 'tedious' instead. Think of all those tedious things you have to say when you receive something.

column4: "In many Sicilian villages, when words are spoken which can never be taken back, a vendetta exists until this retribution - ""a turkey for a turkey"" - can be extracted."
column5: Two turkeys (one from Foster Farms and the other from Butterball) exchange words that cause a vendetta.

column4: Words in the East remonstrate those who stand out.
column5: "While talking to an eastern man: ""I will remonstrate to you how to draw this kanji."" ""Don't you mean 'demonstrate'?"" ""No, I mean REMONSTRATE!"" remonstrated the man."

column4: Words meant to lead you astray are those of a riddle.
column5: I led Socrates astray with my riddle. He quit philosophizing and thought only about the riddle.

column4: "When a Japanese person says they'll meet you at the capital, it's best to verify whether they mean Tokyo or Kyoto."
column5: "You sure that the capital said that? Sorry, but I'll have to go verify that."

column4: Compliments are words of approval.
column5: "The words spoken between the two husbands who approve of how each spends their wife's hard earned money are nothing but compliments. ""Good job old chap!"" ""A fine car you purchased on her credit!"" ""What nice designer pants, won't she be miffed!""."

column4: "Do you remember that song where they say ""Who let the turkeys out!? Gobble.. gobble.. gobble""?"
column5: "[who; someone; somebody] You're alone when, suddenly, you think you hear someone speaking. ""Who's there?"", you say, but there is no answer. Then you find out it was only a turkey gobbling. You feel relieved (and ashamed to tell this story). (Based on raulir)."

column4: "Word, needle, fishhook: The prisoner didn't speak a word in response to our query, so we got out our needles and fishhooks to get things going."
column5: "I needed to query as to how much ten fishhooks costs so I said to the shopkeeper ""How much for ten fishhooks?""."

column4: "When you split up from your partner, you say words that cut things off for good, like a guillotine."
column5: "Words, guillotine: The prisoner was given the opportunity to speak a final word, before the guillotine would do its' work. He made a morbid joke, saying to his chest: ""Here's head speaking. Let's split up.""."

column4: "To fat, effete Japanophiles (cheerily munching on 肉まん in the back of the tour bus) hearing the words of the tour guide ""Now we will visit a shrine"" elicits squeals of joy. ""Oooooh, how absolutely delicious!""."
column5: You visit a shrine to say your wishes and offer delicious offering to the gods.

column4: The words of the sovereign king inspire the people: never give up! Never surrender! Okay...maybe it wasn't a king.
column5: "Anytime I think to give up Japanese, I remember giving my word that I would become sovereign of Japanese! And I watch あきら to get pumped about it. Note: to give up - 諦める is read あきらめる)."

column4: Words that tell you the results of the whole story really elucidate.
column5: "Elucidate me. Tell me, in your own words, the whole story."

column4: "In my house, when I prevaricate (say false words) my mother smacks me with a nasty big cooking spoon."
column5: "Your girlfriend texts you and asks what you're doing. You're out with another girl on a date, but you can't tell her that! So you go with a prevarication. ""n/much just stng @ hm. u?"". ""o ok"", she replies. Looks like your prevarication worked! You go home later, only to find her sitting there, waiting for you - maybe you shouldn't have brought the girl back home this time..."

column4: "After someone moves into the house next door, and after you give them a best regards gift (something they can fill their shelves with) the words you can now speak are those of familiarity. No more ""始めまして"" ect."
column5: "When you tell your buddy, ""Best regards to the wife"", you don't care about his wife. Unless, you know, you had some ""familiarity"" with her."

column4: "Check-up (check-up (#1724)), feathers: When, during the check-up, I noticed that the doctor had feathers sticking out of different bodyparts, I decided that his diagnosis would be fallible, since he obviously was a nut."
column5: "At my check-up, the doctor tickled me with feathers and I laughed. Doc says it means I'm fallible."

column4: """I'm going out with an otaku"" ""I beg your pardon! What did you just say?!""."
column5: "A strange person suddenly emerges from the shower in your house, naked and bald, saying how you need to help him because his only lock of hair got washed down the drain. ""Beg your pardon?""."

column4: You should take the words of someone who advises you with a grain of salt.
column5: "Words, take: The gnarled old man gave some advise to the newlywed couple: ""Just take my words of advise: try to keep your relationship interesting.""."

column4: Proverbs are profound words of wisdom so simply put even a lad can understand their meanings.
column5: "Words, lad: The lad keeping watch at the cliff came running to town and began pouring out words. Leader: ""What? I don't understand a word you're saying. Oh yeah, now I remember... you're the lad who speaks in proverbs.""."

column4: "If you slander someone with your words, you could end up in jail - Jeffrey Archer."
column5: SLANDER is WORDS that can UNdo one's good reputation.

column4: "That so-called specialist's exact words were ""don't worry, its just an upset stomach!"" When it turned out to be cancer, his words dried up quick."
column5: The so called flattering WORDS made me sick to my STOMACH.

column4: "Words, generation, tree: You see that guy over there having words with that tree? That's a secret agent. And you see that tree there? That's a secret agent too: the new generation of secret agents is not limited to the human race anymore."
column5: Secret agents are taught never to chatter (#2158) 喋. When their 'mouths' open only carefully chosen words emerge.

column4: A study Bible has many footnotes under the words of the Lord.
column5: The footnote's words were buried so far below the page that I had to pull out a candlestick in order to read it.

column4: A parable is like putting ketchup on words to make them easier to swallow.
column5: "Ketchup, words: Do you know the parable of ""The Ketchup and the Holy Word""? No? Well, it's about a boy who spilled ketchup on the Holy Word and then got punished by a priest. Lesson: don't use ketchup above the scripture."

column4: Many cars rumble through the streets as the bousouzoku ride through.
column5: "When you get three cars going at once at a monster truck rally, you can feel the ground rumble."

column4: "Car, dog tag: A car hung with hundreds of military dog tags passed by the police station. The officer on duty immediately called in for reinforcements: the notorious veteran soldier killer had just passed by."
column5: "Two kinds of reinforcement the army needs: military cars (tanks) and, of course, offspring (#2097): more soldiers."

column4: "Wealthy people tend to have cars with solid gold spokes, sometimes they even spin with the car's not in motion, kinda cool."
column5: "Wealthy people can afford vintage cars, which have wheels with spokes in them. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:1926_Bentley.jpg."

column4: "When they offered a really cheap Porsche, my mouth dropped open and I bought that car immediately, but if I had had my ears open, I would have heard, ""Some assembly may be required.""."
column5: You must interpret the assembley instructions carefully in order to build your own car [or you could end up losing a finger]. interpretation (#2263).

column4: "He counters, ""Your legs are so white, all I would have to do is apply some black and they would be the perfect countenance of a skunk!""."
column5: "Skunk, white, human legs: You should have seen the shocked countenance on the girls' face when she saw the skunk nibbling away at the white human legs of the corpse she found in the woods. (Because of that, and the smell of course)."

column4: Imagine that in the cartoon series the pink panther is in a dispute with a skunk. Picture the skunk filling a ladle with its stink liquid and then emptying it onto a snoozing pink panther.
column5: "Someone drew a white line down the female black panther's back by pouring white paint from a ladle, and then Pepe mistook the panther for a skunk and started chasing her."

column4: "When they toss metal, that's all fine and dandy, but when those float people toss down shellfish, ugh!, that's just despicable!"
column5: "Money, float: It's despicable. They throw down money off the carnaval float, while there are so many people in this world living in poverty. Just give it to them. Despicable!"

column4: Fortune teller writes your fortune on a piece of paper and tells you to affix it to a shell and throw into the ocean for it to come true. Picture licking the back of the shell like a stamp and affixing it to the fortune.
column5: "I gots a fix for your current bad luck: just pass some extra clams over to the fortune teller, and they will make sure you have a very bright fate instore."

column4: You get money from the generation above you.
column5: "You get the generation above you to give you money. (note: I've modified the keyword a bit after having just read ""Making Sense of Japanese"" because it's important to me to integrate into もらう the idea that getting in this sense is to get someone else to give it to you."

column4: "It might sound simple to bribe someone, but then you have to graft the guy above him and the guy below him, and soon you're just giving shells to each and everyone!"
column5: "When I was caught by the police doing some graft (graffiti), I gave each cop some clams and told them to be on their way. 賄賂【わいろ】 bribe."

column4: Bruce Lee has money because he is always bustling about.
column5: Bruce Lee made his clams in the bustling city of Hong Kong.

column4: "At the border crossing, a man was trying to smuggle a controlled substance in his wooden leg. He would have made it too had he not stumbled and spilled the contents."
column5: "Wooden leg, substance: The pirate was in port to visit the red light district. It was a difficult going in there with his wooden leg: he stumbled over passed-out people and slippery substances were smearing the streets."

column4: "After He lost a leg in combat, our sovereign king got a wooden leg as a replacement. Since He thought it was a little boring, he added a hoof for kicks. (Wow, that was totally unintentional, I like)."
column5: Our sovereign is horse-crazy and even had her own wooden leg fitted with a hoof.

column4: The soccer player was concerned that his peg leg would affect his ability to kick.
column5: "I kick with my FEET in the CAPITAL of all the ONE LEGGED CHIHUAHUAS. It is such a great fun, since they cannot kick me back! lol."

column4: The man who lost his leg in a accident now has to attach a wooden leg to the vestiges of his old leg. He only has himself to blame for drinking and driving.
column5: "Upon finding the vestiges of your peg leg, you blame it on poor craftsmanship."

column4: The amputee boasts about how the ladies just love to straddle his wooden leg.
column5: Same right side as boast (#1244). The big one that got away (so big you couldn't straddle it) took your leg with it. コ カ また.がる またが.る また.ぐ be; sit or stand astride; extend over; straddle.

column4: It's dangerous to kneel with a wooden leg. It might fall off.
column5: It's dangerous to kneel before a pirate with a peg leg: They might take offense.

column4: The leader's whiskey bottle is filled with soy sauce since he doesn't drink alcohol but likes to pretend he's one of the boys by making a strained face when he takes a swig.
column5: The leaders of Japan use to trade soy sauce for whiskey when foreigners first entered Japan.

column4: "When filling a whiskey bottle with a whey mixture, you've got to get the proportions just so or it will just taste like curdled milk."
column5: "If you hold the whiskey bottle just so, it scoops up the 'isk' out of the 'whiskey' and you're left with 'whey'. 'No way!' 'Whey!'."

column4: "While the keyword is ""hooch"", this usually means 焼酎. It has similar effect as whiskey and sniffing glue has: you get intoxicated."
column5: "This thick, illicitly-made beverage is actually just whiskey mixed with glue!"

column4: Drinking ghee out of a whiskey bottle is rather uncivilized (#2470).
column5: GHEE (clarified butter) if stored in a WHISKEY BOTTLE or some other air tight container will not get OLD and has a shelf life of many MONTHS at room temperature. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghee.

column4: On awakening the first thing I notice is a (nearly empty) whiskey bottle by my bed. Then I see the stars are still shining. “I think I’ll go back to sleep and try awakening again later.”.
column5: You'll need an awakening after the whiskey bottle makes you see stars.

column4: "Whiskey bottle, receive: When you receive a bottle of whiskey from a Japanese person, large chance it is strong saké. It seems that giving 'sissy' saké is considered impolite."
column5: "Now we know why the tall child is so 諄 polite (#2706) & 惇 considerate (#2279): the effect of the the strong saké. He receives it at cost in the 廓 licensed quarters (#2235) he set up in the cave, of course."

column4: There is a certain restaurant in West-Shinjuku that serves its noodles made of BARLEY in a MASK instead of a plate. I love these theme-restaurants!
column5: Don't be fooled! That's just barley masquerading as noodles.

column4: Malt made from barley is often bound up with rice for brewing.
column5: "This means kouji mould, so I think malt is a poor keyword. Sake, shochu and other East Asian spirits use this mould in place of yeast, which is used to make most other alcoholic spirits in the world. Mould and yeast are two different types of fungus. Yeast might have been a better keyword, as it is the organism doing the fermenting. Story: Kouji mould is grown on rice specially bound up to form a starter culture. To make mugishochu, the starter culture is added to a barley mash."

column4: A button is metal that requires an opening in order to function.
column5: "Once you can get the metal button through the mouth, it's fastened."

column4: A big metal keg portends a good party.
column5: The most expensive keg ever made: solid gold with tortoise-shell inlay.

column4: "Tilling a field by hand is very tough. A handy piece of metal to help get the job done, is the plow."
column5: "15 strokes, not 14!"

column4: A gruesome kind of cauldron that Snape might have used is a metal pot in the shape of a skull.
column5: A metall pot with non-thermoconductive jawbones as handholds.

column4: Metal arrowheads are considered antiques.
column5: I have an antique arrowhead made of solid gold.

column4: A handsaw is a piece of metal that helps you fix up the place you reside in.
column5: "Metal, reside: In that mansion resides a creepy man. In the last year, a few people have gone missing, so at one night we decided to sneak into his toolshed. There we found a metal handsaw and other equipment, all covered with bloodstains..."

column4: I used a metal awl to drill right through this here turkey: it was so much easier than using a knife to cut it open!
column5: The only way to hobble the gobble of the metal turkey is to run him through with a golden awl.

column4: The metal thing you need in order to enter things you build is a key.
column5: "鍵盤key (#2761) ケン, かぎ ... Parts: 金, 建 ... Story: The most important Metal in any building is the lock on the front door, and without a key you ain't getting in. This kanji means both lock and key to most Japanese people. 錠前 is technically the word for lock but it's not used in daily conversation. ... 熟語: ... cf: 錠前."

column4: A metal object often used in autumn is the hoe.
column5: The hoe is a metal tool used in preparation for the autumn harvest.

column4: Metal soldiers (toy ones) make good rivets.
column5: "In medieval times, soldiers used metal rivets to build their suits of armor."

column4: "Tin is soft, bends easily, and melts at a low temperature. Hence tin is written as the metal that is easy to work with."
column5: Metal tin cans are sometimes far from easy to open.

column4: An anchor is metal planted like a seedling.
column5: """The golden city of Ankor Wat"" was misunderstood as ""The golden seedling of anchor cat (#244)""."

column4: A nail is a metal spike.
column5: "A nail is a metal, well, nail."

column4: A javelin is a piece of metal used for dispatching enemies – or athletics judges if they’re not careful.
column5: A javelin is a metal object you dispatch.

column4: A pointy (see my explanation in 峰 summit (#1562)) bit of metal is a sword's point.
column5: A metal sword's point is pointed at the lovers having a tryst. Looks like someone got caught!

column4: The maestro grabs a metal hammer to get back at those chasing him down the road.
column5: "The hammer is the same as the wooden hammer (#2477), except it's made out of metal."

column4: The church carillion was composed of metal bells that informed when it was the correct time to go to church.
column5: "Wtf is a carillion? How about ""gong"" instead. Picture a game show where they bang on the gong every time you get the correct answer. Or, if you want to go with the book explanation, carillion is the ""western"" bell which is struck from the inside rather than outside. Story: just like everything else in the East (writing, utensils, etc) bells are harder to work than necessary, being hit from the outside and all. The correct way is to put the gong on the inside, makes it so much easier."

column4: "The easiest place to spot rust is when it grows on blue metal. All of my cars have been blue, and as soon as the first red rust appears, its off to the scrapheap."
column5: The blue oxidation that forms on metals like copper is a form of rust.

column4: The heavy metal band explode cluster bombs as part of their act.
column5: 1) Metal seems more heavy when it's balled up in a cluster.2) Fans cluster around the stage at the heavy metal concert.

column4: "On the St. Bernard assembly line, the dogs pass by and the workers clip their fur with metal scissors."
column5: "At the grand opening, they had metal scissors so big that it required two people to cut the ribbon and let the first batch of customers in."

column4: "The lesbians flash a person with their ""gates""."
column5: "The flasher hung out by the gates. Whenever someone emerged, the flasher opened his cloak, flashed the unsuspecting person, and ran off in a flash!"

column4: "The gates suddenly slam shut, squashing your heart. Needless to say, this is agony."
column5: "Because her child is out several hours past his curfew, the mother waits in agony at the gates, her heart pounding as she imagines the worst."

column4: "If you can't fit through the gates due to your size, try the side gate."
column5: "Apart from the big gates of hell, there are many side gates leading out of hell. But they're designed to always be too little for the person trying to escape to fit through. Invented by the devil to drive the humans to despair."

column4: "In the pitch dark, I can hear the sound of the lesbians rubbing their gates together."
column5: "Through the gates of hell there is no sound, no light, its all pitch dark."

column4: "Is it raining? Hmm...I can see some clouds up there, but I can't feel much down here: must be just a trickle."
column5: Rain trickles downwards.

column4: Jimi Hendrix works as a weather forcaster in his spare time. Today he predicts a (purple) haze.
column5: What a coincidence that work should give me time off only days that have rain or haze but no sun.

column4: "How to obtain quills for free: Wait for a misty day, then under cover of the mist creep up on an unsuspecting bird and quickly cover it with your umbrella. The bird will flap around wildly trying to escape and while doing so will shed a number of feathers. You can use these as quills."
column5: The latest quills are feathers with an umbrella-like point that sprays mist you can write with.

column4: "Under the auspices of the local observatory, we looked at the Big Dipper on a misty night, huddled under an umbrella."
column5: "Under the auspices of NASA, we explored the Big Dipper -- it was misty but NASA placed a giant umbrella over the Big Dipper to keep us dry."

column4: A saddle is leather that helps you relax on horseback.
column5: "Save a horse, ride your woman inside your house in a leather saddle instead. (Just to pick up competition with mantixen's story ^_^)."

column4: There's a leather section in the convenience store now – that's where I got this whip.
column5: A whip is leather that makes others do things at your convenience.

column4: "Originally, the leather saddle straps were for holding candles, but now they're more commonly used for holding swords, like scabbards."
column5: A scabbard is a leather sheath that should to resemble the blade it's going to hold.

column4: The first briefcase was a piece of leather used to wrap documents.
column5: The businessman likes to make out he's important but the only thing his leather briefcase keeps wrapped up his the lunch his wife made.

column4: "A leather blade would make for a poor sword, because it's too pliable."
column5: A leather blade is liable to be too pliable to be viable in a fight.

column4: "Wtf terminate? This is ""ball"". Use ""leather ball"" for keyword, imagine a leather american football packed with bound up rice."
column5: Rice bound up with leather makes a good hacky sack. The game terminates when the ball touches the ground. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kemari.

column4: Ever chopped the head off an earthworm? Notice how it will grow back immediately! Beware the killer earthworms...
column5: "When someone in the barracks tells you to come immediately, you'll lose your head for sure トン トツ にわか.に とん.と つまず.く とみ.に ぬかずく suddenly; immediately; in a hurry."

column4: The DNA evidence reveals the truth about the crime but its too late to overturn the sentence now - they already chopped off the innocent prisoners head.
column5: "If you come to learn the truth, you can overturn any unjust verdict on its head."

column4: A cheap brush tip is just wheat attached to the head of a spoon.
column5: Attach a head of wheat to the handle of a spoon and voila! A brush tip that can draw a へのへのもへじhead--if little else.

column4: "An alarm clock with a unique design: You set it for, say, 7:00 am, and at about that time the clock reaches out with a spoon and hits you on the head."
column5: After spooning for hours it's about that time he got some head. Dayum woman.

column4: "Your cheeks contain your jawbones, which are known as the ""scissors of the head.""."
column5: The Joker from Batman had his cheeks cut with scissors to give him that eternal smile. Now the Joker isn't right in the head.

column4: "Donald Trump is exceedingly wealthy, but wears a really bad toupee -- he has an exceedingly large collection of pelts to place on his head."
column5: "Pelt, head: The guy had an exceedingly quick hairgrowth. That's why it always seemed like he was carrying a pelt around his head."

column4: Accolades are bestowed on your head in public.
column5: You gotta wear your public head when you receive accolades -- inside you're proud as can be but you gotta keep the cool with your public head.

column4: Your chin is the part of your head under your nostrils that forms the double snare that is your jaw.
column5: Left side is crocodile primative. crocodile's head's most prominent feature is his jaw.

column4: I soiled my ヌde crotch when I got head and stuck it all the way down her neck and throat.
column5: Your neck and throat gag as the smell of soiled crotch hits your head.

column4: Food made of ears is animal feed.
column5: Do you know Mike Tayson favorite feed? Ears! He eats ears!

column4: Remember that dazzling evening where you found the magic wand and used it on your crotch to make it bigger? Well this time you use the wand to disguise your little guy as food so that she thinks it's a repast. dazzling (#2543).
column5: What dazzling food! This shall be the most splendid repast yet!

column4: "After journeying the world wide, I returned to my hometown and was met with an incredible feast."
column5: Hometown food.

column4: "To enjoy watching the eclipse, you go on a picnic with your friends. But due to the dim light, you accidentally pick up and eat an insect."
column5: You eat an insect by accident while watching the jaw-dropping eclipse.

column4: The only food at the pedestal is sweets to keep the lecturer's energy up.
column5: "Of all the foods, sweets are definitely the ones kids put on a pedestal."

column4: "Call your friend and he answers the phone ""Mochi, mochi!"" whatever he is eating sure is making it hard to understand. I will puzzle over the content of our conversation for some time to come."
column5: "Mochi ice cream is a puzzling food, I still have no idea how they get that ice cream in there, but it sure tastes good."

column4: "This man is too heavy! We can't move the stretcher! Quick, add a team of horses to the ambulance!"
column5: "The final addition to the Trojan Horse was a stretcher (laid across the top). Hey, if the plan doesn't work, better be safe than sorry!"

column4: "Yep, old Piebald was the simplest horse in the book, just sitting there, eating bald pies."
column5: "Being just black and white, the piebald is a simple horse."

column4: Use a scorpion to make a horse rush.
column5: "The soldiers in the Trojan Horse were supposed to wait several hours before coming out, but when they spotted a scorpion in the horse with them, they all rushed out at once."

column4: "This character is だます, which means to trick or fool someone. The Greeks tricked (cheated) the Trojans by hiding in the Trojan Horse, which actually had a secret door from which the hidden soldiers would emerge. It was a brilliant tactic that would be recorded in the tomes of history."
column5: "I got caught by my ex- with a pack of Trojans and a Hentai mag... of course she broke up with me, how the hell could I have convinced her I was not a cheat?!?"

column4: "The guy who said that you can take a horse to a river, but you can't make it drink obviously has never encountered a tame horse."
column5: "The process to getting a tame horse is a bit like getting a tame Christian - baptizization! you take it into the river at a young age (just after it's born is best) and dunk it in until it is almost drowned. Then at the last possible moment, when its life is flashing before its eyes (good baptizers know when this is), you pull it back above water. The first thing it sees is its ""rescuer"" and ""savior"", and it will be tame and follow you for the rest of its life."

column4: "Wolverine's had charges placed on him for murdering a horse, but he make's a rebuttal stating that he couldn't have been in two different places at the same time (i.e. There cannot exist two Wolverines). He was having dinner with his Aunt Margaret at the time, it's impossible."
column5: "Trojan horse, 2 sheafs: Proponents of taking the Trojan Horse into the city employed convincing arguments in their rebuttal. They put 2 sheafs next to the Trojan Horse and put them on fire. 'You see, if it were a trap, and enemies were inside, they would surely come out right now.' However, during the rebuttal, nobody noticed the caughing coming from inside the Trojan Horse...."

column4: The team of horses slowed to a gallop as they started up the hill.
column5: "Trojan Horse, hill: The anchoring of the Trojan Horse had broken, and now it was accelerating down the hill. To save the men inside, riders were galloping down the hill to get them out in time."

column4: "The team of horses is nervously asking a tiger not to eat them. ""Don't worry"", says the tiger, ""over in that paddyfield I can see my favourite dish – donkey!""."
column5: The team of horses ran when they saw the tiger. But the stubborn donkey continued drinking from his dish in the open field. Talk about easy prey.

column4: The only fish that Nelson Manadala got to eat in prison was うなぎ eel...sounds like punishment to me!
column5: Manga fish: picture a manga version of an eel and you're done.

column4: The sea bream （たい） is a fish that often goes around the circumference of a 回転寿司（かいてんずし） a number of たいmes.
column5: Sea Bream (fish) found on the circumference of Australia and New Zealand waters.

column4: "This is a weak fish -- you just open a can of sardines and there they are, weak and defenseless, ready to be eaten."
column5: "Due to its small size, the sardine is a weak fish."

column4: "Fish, revered: The fish tribe revered a fat trout, living in an aquarium in the temple. One morning, they woke up, smelling a funny smell. It appeared as if a jungle explorer had found the trout's temple...."
column5: Trout are a fish often revered for their beauty (especially rainbow trout).

column4: "Salmon are fish that go over ivy trying to get back to their breeding grounds, killing bears along the way."
column5: "さけ, salmon are fish that go to higher ground (ground on ground) to spawn."

column4: "Tuna is the fish that posesses the most toxins (heavy metals, pesticides, mercury)."
column5: Maguro tuna is a must-have (possess) fish.

column4: "A fish arrives at the fortune-teller's who, without looking, says ""Welcome, Sweet Smelt"". ""That's amazing"", says the fish, ""how did you know I was a sweet smelt?"" ""Well, most fish smell bad, but you smelt sweet.""."
column5: "The fortune teller turned to me smiling, ""Ah you (アユ) will do well. I can sense the sweet smell of success. And what better way to celebrate than with that sweetest of fish the sweet smelt!""."

column4: "Fish, visit: Mother to daughter: ""I bought you a hors..."". The girls started a joyous screaming. ""Let's visit it"", the girl says. Daughter follows mother to.. the kitchen, showing her the fish she bought. Mother: ""I wanted to tell you that I bought a horse mackerel for dinner!""."
column5: The horse mackerel is the fish that is nonplussed – it isn't sure whether it's a horse or a mackerel.

column4: Cod is a fish that is packed in snow to reach the inland parts of Japan.
column5: "たら, cod is a beautiful fish whose flesh is the colour and texture of snow."

column4: Holy mackarel! That fish just turned blue!
column5: "Fish, blue: After the young girl found that disappointing mackerel fish (see story horse mackerel (#2818)), she felt a bit blue."

column4: Ever noticed how tiny fish will often mingle around a shark for protection?
column5: A shark tries to mingle with other fish to get close enough to eat them.

column4: The bonito is a fish with strict preparation procedures for making 出汁（だし） and 鰹節（かつおぶし）.
column5: "Fish, strict: La Isla Bonito. Madonna is very strict on the type of fish imported to the island. Only the best is good enough..."

column4: "Fish, autumn: Old man to his son: ""You are bullheaded if you think you can catch a bullhead fish in the middle of autumn. It's out of season!""."
column5: "Perhaps a bit of a misnomer. Bullhead is a river fish (カジカ). This kanji is most likely to refer to young Japanese yellowtail or amberjack. It is a fish of many names depending on age: fry (もじゃこ), young (鰍・いなだ or 魬・はまち), mature (鰤・ぶり). I suppose these kanji might crop up on a fish menu. STORY: Young Amberjack is not at its best in summer. Eat from autumn onwards (when it becomes more fatty). Also its tail is amber - the colour of autumn leaves."

column4: """Dude! What happened to your chin?"" ""Well, I was out fishing...""."
column5: Saltwater crocs swim in the sea like fish. Right side = crocodile primative. Pictograph - 2 big eyes and one massive snare for a mouth.

column4: "Due to its oxygenating properties, it is crucial that you adhere to a crucian fish if you plan on spending a long time underwater."
column5: The crucian fish adheres strongly to Crucianism principles.

column4: Japanese consider fish to be most delicious when eaten as sushi.
column5: SUSHI is FISH that is DELICIOUS.

column4: "Fish, old man, sun: An ominous fish fin approaches the old man, who went for a swim as the sun was going down. Soon, he'll sleep with the fishes."
column5: The old man thinks fish fin sushi is delicious.

column4: A bird that goes to the inland wards for food is the seagull.
column5: "Wolverine had enough of this ward and hence went to the seaside with his cardboard box. Now he always kills a bird, a seagull, when he wakes up and eats it for breakfast, while listening to the sound of the sea."

column4: "Companion, bird: Roc, the mythical bird, was searching for a companion for as long as he existed. Little did he know that he was the only one of his kind."
column5: "The roc is a large and intimidating bird. Because of this, the roc has a hard time finding a companion."

column4: The parakeet is a bird that acts like a suckling infant when it drinks from the water dropper.
column5: "Ariel, that little mermaid with the shells over her ""ha-ha"" 's is good friends with a parakeet voiced by Gilbert Godfried... or wait, is that some other Disney film?"

column4: "A parrot is a bird of the warrior, for example pirates."
column5: "A parrot makes a terrible bird for any warrior. As soon as the warrior tries to sneak up on its enemy, Polly wants a freaking cracker."

column4: "[+brose] The cormorant was historically used in Japan and China to catch fish. The fisher would use some rope or something to tie its throat so that it could only swallow small fish. If it caught something too big to swallow, it would take it back to the fisher's boat and the fisher would take it out. This particular cormorant is going after bigger and bigger prey - but one day it goes too far, and tries to swallow your little brother! Imagine trying to yank your brother out of its throat."
column5: The cormorant is a bird you use like your younger brother to fetch things for you.

column4: "As I was walking I noticed hair-on the path! When I bent to see what was up, I realized that they were in fact fine feathers poking through - someone had paved over a large bird!"
column5: The heron is a bird large enough to walk on both paths.

column4: "Concerning, bird: The US senate had a meeting concerning the eagle. Although symbol of the US, this bird is close to extinction."
column5: Matters concerning a bird in the capital are usually about the eagle.

column4: "Due to its waterproof armor, the wild duck is a bird that resurfaces even if you push it underwater."
column5: "かも, or wild duck, is a Japanese term that means an easy mark or a sucker because wild ducks are considered to be easy to catch. This kanji shows a duck that is wearing some armor to avoid being an easy mark."

column4: The kite falcon is a majestic bird that flies in the sky as fast as an arrow. So much so that its feathers are often used to make arrows.
column5: "Arrow, bird: The black kite is a bird of prey (like the raptor). You can see it approaching its target, like an arrow speeding through the air."

column4: "The owl, being wise, is hiding its tail feathers in a tree so that its prey can't tell what kind of bird it is."
column5: "The owl is a very snooty bird, one could say that it has a tree stuck up it's ass. キョウ."

column4: A deer stomps on the soil and dust rises from the ground. (big ups mantixen).
column5: "On the ground, we found the whole body of a deer covered in dust."

column4: Many deer can be found in the grove at the foot of a mountain.
column5: "Deer are well known for frolicking in groves of trees. However, they are not well known for actually watching where the heck they are bounding about. Here we have a bunch of dead deer bodies that you find at the foot of a mountain. You are trying to figure why there are so many dead deer in one spot, and then you trace a line up the mountain - leaves and such are scattered all the way up...to a grove. Looks like they hopped through some leaves to their doom."

column4: A deer standing on a bushel basket still isn't tall enough to be mistaken for a giraffe.
column5: A giraffe is like a deer except that when it plays chess it has a better overview of the board.

column4: "The beast of hades one day will wear a crown, and the number of the beast is 666."
column5: "In Hades you have to work six days a week before crowning it with something vaguely resembling a weekend. Oh wait, that's Japan."

column4: When you close the eyes of someone who just died...
column5: It's as dark as Hades when you close your eyes.

column4: "Hades is normally very dark, and even when the sun shines in it is still murky."
column5: The Sunshine looks Murky in Hades.

column4: "The cave was too dark for my tastes, so I went out to sit in mediation."
column5: The cave of ignorance was lifted for these two monks sitting in meditation on the ground.

column4: I sprained my fingers when I sat in meditation (by sitting in a strange position).
column5: I sprained in my finger doing a complicated mudra while sitting in meditation.

column4: "On the first day of the month a mountain goat lets out a ""Baah"" as it jumps over the moon."
column5: The female mountain goat can only give milk on one day of the month: on the first day of the month. Her milk cycles are controlled by the moon.

column4: "On the first day of the month, all the salmon go upstream, up the road, to the mating grounds."
column5: On the first day of the month the road to go upstream is opened for salmon fisherman.

column4: The day seems to drag when it keeps you from having a fiesta.
column5: "Bored with the sun always going the same way (“it’s such a drag”), I tuck the sun under my arm and try to drag it in the opposite direction to usual. EDIT: Notes (1): tucked under the arm is reversed here, i.e. a mirror image of the usual primitive. Note (2): Tow might be a better keyword: see my note at dribble out (#2849)."

column4: "Tip: Heisig has duplicated a primitive name here by calling the right side drag. We already have a two-stroke primitive called drag (see numbers 1853-1861 盾,派,脈,逓,后). I suggest calling 曳 ""tow"" instead."
column5: "Good water flows and thus keeps on moving, but here, the water has too much drag and thus can dribble out of its tube."

column4: "A comet flew by and knocked down two bushes, so I went out there and swept up the mess, cursing astrological bodies along the way."
column5: Broom is ヨ. The lower primitive here resembles a rake 肀 without a handle (vertical stroke). STORY: Comets actually have 2 bushy tails (http://apod.nasa.gov/apod/image/9703/halebopp4_aac.jpg). Imagine a NASA probe with an attachment like a rake head designed to catch (rake up) the fine particles streaming from the tails for later analysis.

column4: "Comet, heart: Heisig: ""The astute reader will notice that the second stroke in the broom element of comet doesn't pass through. The astute reader will take this observation to heart""."
column5: "The astute astral observer Edmond Halley put his heart into his work. And in return, we named a comet for him."

column4: Add a drum when you really want to applaud.
column5: The drummer wasn't very good so he had a speaker built into the bottom of the drum which automatically added applause.

column4: Think of Mike Myers' Dr. Evil standing in an identity parade of intergalactic criminals. Evil is the only villain with human legs.
column5: The evil villain's favorite hobby is breaking human legs.

column4: "The overly-cautious white geek protects his entire upper body with a special helmet he constructed out of two cardboard boxes, unfortunately his human legs could still be easy targets for bullies."
column5: "To protect my very white skull from the sun while standing on my legs, I fashioned a helmet by placing boxes all around my head."

column4: The St Bernard is bracing itself for an operation requiring four stitches.
column5: "That old St. Bernard was just barely limping around, but me, I stitched up the ol' chap and I dare say that the operation was quite bracing."

column4: "The baron crashed his plane across enemy lines. Pulling himself out of the wreck, he looked up to see a nearby grove of trees. However he turned depressed as he realized the two flashes of light were actually reflections from the steel as Wolverine deployed both of his razors for action. Out of the frying pan..."
column5: "The baron is depressed because he lost his pet vulture. He wandered around a grove, where he rummaged through two sheaves, but still he couldn't find his darling vulture."

column4: "kalpa is a Sanskrit word for a long period of time, sort of like ""aeon."" Once a kalpa has gone (passed), there will be no more fossil fuels for power."
column5: "When a kalpa passes, all forms of power we see today will be gone."

column4: An erection can shoot like a needle from its crown and has the power to make a child.
column5: The erection is the crowned needle that's got the power to make children.

column4: "Audrey II yawns, bemoaning being stuck in the flower shop with nothing to eat."
column5: A scarecrow bemoans that it lacks legs.

column4: "I hop into my palanquin, my car of sorts, such that I may be transported to my next location of entertainment."
column5: A palanquin is a car used for the entertainment of royalty when they want to take a joyride.

column4: "Two snakes are strung together. One is trying to head south, the other to go east. But as they are strung together they have to compromise, ""Let's go Sssssssouth-East.""."
column5: The two snakes Noah elected (1804) for his Ark came from the southeast.

column4: "In the debate, your political opponent's has such a warped sense of perspective, that he believes the negative is actually correct."
column5: On standardized tests they use negative questions that are so warped you don't know which answer is correct.

column4: "You're so jaded by the time you graduate that when you finally spread your wings, your feathers are all jade green."
column5: "This what the valedictorian wears in Chinese high school graduations. It's a beautiful cap with jade green feathers covering it. No tassel, just those pretty feathers."

column4: "A good substitute for black is blue-black, like the color women try to substitute for their black eyebrows with a pencil."
column5: "Substitute + black= blue-black or blackened-eyebrows. A close substitute for the color black is the color blue-black. Also, women in Japan sometimes have blackened-eyebrows, since their color is naturally a faint blue-black."

column4: "Here we have two people sitting on chairs, trying to set up their camera on a tripod and periodically checking the viewfinder with their eyes."
column5: "(NB: I use THREE-LEGGED KETTLE for 鼎, and reserve TRIPOD for 鬲 Unicode-0x9b32 (#39730).) This THREE-LEGGED KETTLE is used for sacrificial incense-burning. 鼎 shows a watchful EYE carefully putting the offering material in the opening of the KETTLE, which is shown as being squarely supported ON EACH SIDE."

column4: "The fortune-teller tells Wolverine that in a past life, she sees him covered in rocksalt from working in a salt mine."
column5: You see a block of rocksalt containing a pent-in ladybird (US = ladybug). Touch it with your magic wand and the ladybird is set free. (Note: Let ladybird = sheaf + four drops. It's pictographic: the sheaf showing the curved back and the four drops the spots on the ladybird).

column4: Lye is white like rocksalt and sharp like an awl.
column5: Lye is white like rocksalt and can be broken up with an ice pick.

column4: """That tiger at the zoo was so reserved. He didn't say so much as one sentence."" ""Um, you know tigers can't talk, right?""."
column5: The death row inmate acts reserved when staying at the magic house of seven tigers!

column4: "Twenty birds (swallows) are perched at the north exit (北口) of the station. I light a fire underneath them, and as they wilt and fall in the heat, passing commuters swallow them whole. Well, they are swallows."
column5: Twenty swallows are perched atop the station's 北口 raining droppings all over everyone. Keep your mouth closed so you don't swallow any. (Thanks Katsuo).

column4: "There are things in the outhouse that may appear delicious, and you may even want to lick them, but I assure you: they ain't delicious."
column5: "Those big white ""mints"" in the outhouse urinals may look delicious, but it's best not to lick them."

column4: A pedestal in an Indiana Jones movie is littered with the bones of people who almost seized the treasure.
column5: I see a some bones near the pedestal of immortality: someone almost got there!

column4: "This is how things looked at the start, before the 猛 fierce (#1456) wild dogs showed up."
column5: "You are choosing a start(er) at the cannibal restaurant: ""I think I'll start with that child dish""."

column4: "Mahjong tiles, to the best of my understanding have only one side and are considered a lowly use of time."
column5: "Mahjong tiles are one-sided, and only lowly people who don't play mahjong don't know this."

column4: The remains consisted of a skeleton which had the remains of some acorns in its stomach area. Whether it died from eating the acorns remains to be seen.
column5: Hint: The remains of a chipmunk.

column4: Sneak preview - peek - director lets you see his new movie - 店を覗く（のぞく） - have a quick noze/look in a shop (nozoku).
column5: "If a director lets anyone see his film before it's finished, it's only a sneak peek."

column4: "It's fun to look at the tiger's mottled leg and pick out shapes, sort of like looking at clouds."
column5: The T-1000 has a hard time shape shifting into a tiger. The stripes always come out mottled.

column4: "What did man chew in the Manchu dynasty? Well, first man chew bonsai, but he find that rather tough, so next man chew wheat. EDIT: I think the keyword should really be Qin dynasty. So how a about new story based on Bob Dylan's song ""Mighty Quinn"": ""Bonsai without, wheat plants within, you'll not grow nothing like the mighty Qin. (dynasty).""."
column5: (thx Katsuo) The so-called 'mighty' Qin dynasty died a nasty death from starvation because they focused on growing bonsai instead of wheat.

column4: There are relatively few turkeys compared to the widely familiar sparrow.
column5: "There are few turkeys available this Christmas/Thanksgiving, so we're having to make do with sparrow."

column4: "My peregrine falcon recently has been having confidence issues - recently it dives out of the sky and misses the target completely. To boost its confidence, I got a nice, fat turkey, killed it, and then set it up on a big needle so it looked like it was still alive - just loafing about. Then I went to my peregrine falcon - ""hey buddy, look! A nice fat turkey. I bet you can get it!"" It goes for it, but it spears itself on the needle!!"
column5: The peregrine falcon is the fastest animal in the world. It can reach speeds of over 322 km/h in a dive - over ten times as fast as a turkey!

column4: "Rays of light hit the futon, making it shimmer. Think maybe somebody wet the futon last night.."
column5: "Once it had been in a state of twinkle (#2534) for awhile, the turkey's feathers began to a-shimmering with some strange light."

column4: When passing through Ebisu in Tokyo (one stop south of Shibuya) you see a St. Bernard that has swallowed a bow (you can see the shape of the bow sticking through its skin).
column5: "征夷大将軍 (せいいたいしょうぐん) This is the 'i' part of the full name of the ancient shoguns. Sei i tai shougun (Great general who subdues the eastern barbarians). This Kanji is the ""eastern barbarian"" part. Being the shogun, the most powerful military leader in all of Japan, it is only fitting that he also have a very large bow to go along with his office. So large in fact, that it was given to him by the god of good luck, Ebisu."

column4: "Your half-uncle is leading a parade of your relatives. (Note: 上 + 小 makes up part of ""uncle"" 叔, so I've called it ""half-uncle"".)."
column5: "Your uncle organizes a parade of all your relatives, which he himself is only half in because he's busy taking pictures of it."

column4: "Grass skirt, middle, crown: The girl wearing the grass skirt had a cyst growing in the middle of her head, seeming like a crown. A sign she will be the new village elder, I heard later."
column5: "The hula girl got a cyst on her lips after she placed her mouth on my ""crown"" ten times."

column4: "A little one is eating a domburi while standing over, looking down into, a WELL. He drops it, and it falls down & down until it looks like nothing more than a DROP, landing at the bottom of the well!"
column5: I drop a domburi down into the well for the goblin living there.

column4: "The monkey is carefree with his piggy bank, tossing it at whatever financial opportunity he stumbles upon."
column5: "As a carefree person, I'm always using my piggy bank to monkey around."

column4: "A dishonest taxi driver is circling to increase the fare -- trying to stretch out the ride, going around the block many times."
column5: A taxi driver stretches out the time it takes to get to Times Square by circling around it (thanks mcfate).

column4: "People aside, I wonder how many rice fields there are in the capital suburbs."
column5: How many brains does it take to run the capital suburbs?

column4: "I was bored, yawning and such, so I picked up my axe and was suddenly filled with much elation."
column5: I feel elation when I realize the axe murderer is lacking his axe.

column4: A stalwart sow stands up against a missile.
column5: "Stand up, sow, missile: See our stalwart hunter standing upon the sow he just shot, his missile launcher still smoking. (Nothing much left of the sow by the way)."

column4: "Tip: Learn ""this"" 斯 and ""that"" 其 at the same time. (""that"", 其 , is not in Heisig, but is probably more common than 斯). Stories: This bushel basket comes with an axe to open it, but that one doesn't."
column5: (Thx Kats) THIS AXE can beat any CHESS peice... except for maybe THAT ROOK.

column4: "After you get the wooden spoon in the ""egg & spoon"" race another competitor explains that you need to hold the spoon ""just so""."
column5: A spoon used to measure ingredients just so is a measuring spoon.

column4: "After the revolution, the king was put into a box so that the government could be set straight."
column5: "Walking through the park, I see many large boxes where homeless people live. But there's one guy dressed as a king, who seems to be arranging them all, i.e. he's setting the boxes straight. ""Surely you're not a real king?"" I ask. He replies, ""Let me set you straight, I'm king of the boxes""."

column4: Founding of a nation is usually done by the taskmasters in charge behind closed doors. They sign some papers with their writing brushes and voila..
column5: "After the founding of Post Secret, people started to disclose things with a brush instead of their mouths."

column4: Bending over constantly to cut all those woodblocks has given Utamaro a bad back. Now he smokes hemp while he works to ease the pain in in his spine.
column5: A soft Mashimaro doll made with a hemp spine for some semblance of posture.

column4: "I have a huge conglomerate (collection) of old books I'm looking to get rid of. They're not in any particular order... some are upside down in a row, some are soiled... just look through them and take whatever you want."
column5: "This is similar to 業 business/profession (#1792), with ""not yet"" replaced by ""take."" A giant company that takes up many companies with different professions, is called a conglomerate."

column4: "Tip: ""snack"" or ""appetizer"" would be better keywords for this kanji."
column5: Wolverine posesses the most treats at the party because he's entreated for being famous.

column4: The murderer who carved symmetrical patterns into all his victims was sentenced life in a jailcell. (thanks tomusan).
column5: Chun-Li gave the death row inmate a symmetrically patterned footprint on the top of his head with a foot stomp cross-up.

column4: British magistrates wear wigs made of silver hair. But picture an eccentric magistrate who instead wears a silver hare on his head.
column5: Slight modification of katsuo (kiddo): british magistrate wear wigs made of silver hair . But just because they re compelled to do so doesn t mean they re necessarly comfortable with . If you saw the wig of mozart in Amadeus it s not very hard to picture a judge who wears his wig so badly that it looks like two huge hare/Bunny ears.

column4: In the beginning you learn by fiddling with things.
column5: "Emperor Nero fiddled with his fiddle while Rome burned. When he was later asked to explain himself he said, “Well, I was learning how to play this piece and had to keep going back to the beginning”."

column4: "Image: An Arctic explorer frozen within ice, within his hands are an umbrella and a compass."
column5: Within minutes the weather changed and ice blew in from all directions making my umbrella useless…　　RTK2:　お　於ける　おれる(in).

column4: "The hackneyed hangover cure is to have ""some hair of the dog that bit you.""."
column5: "You may think you're being original by sporting an afro, but it's hackneyed to have big poofy long hair."

column4: The half that was anti- started a rebellion.
column5: The rebellion was unpopular and HALF the population was AGAINST it.

column4: A small tip on something large creates a sharp point.
column5: "Little, St Bernard: In primary school, I had a pencil sharpener shaped as a little St. Bernard. I put in my blunt pencil, and it came out with a sharp point."

column4: "The samurai's crock was so old it was a crowned a heritage item of Asia, and he wouldn't sell it."
column5: "The E-mail read: ""Hello, my name is Ubuntu Nonga, crowned samurai of a small Asian country. I have $5 million that I need to move to a safe place ..."" But I knew that advance-fee scams are a crock."

column4: "The magic wand in a guy's crotch is crowned with one eye, and contains a certain sapience... but they should try not to ""think with the little head.""."
column5: "Magic wand, crown, 1-eyed valley, crotch: The archeologist was searching for the birthplace of the homo sapience. Wearing his magic wand and his divining crown, he was able to located it in the 1-eyed valley, somewhere in Bolivia. His crotch got all excited, thinking on all the publicity of finding the birthplace of homo sapience."

column4: Only the chieftain could drink horned whiskey since he was the one responsible for procreation.
column5: "I have used Red Bull as a primitive since furthermore/waver (#1438), so now it is easy to remember the chieftain's name: Chief Red Bull!"

column4: The nightingale is a bird that goes to a schoolhouse at night to learn to sing.
column5: "This character is actually a 俗字 (unofficial simplification) of the character 鶯. As such, it is actually far less common than the traditional character according to a google search. Story for the correct character: The nightingale is bird with a crown (mane) as bright as a deep fire (two fires)."

column4: "Incandescent red is naturally twice as bright as ordinary red (赤). Alternatively, this is a picture of spreading (already doubled), incandescent red fire. Note: This is used by far most commonly to write 赫(あか)い, although dictionaries do not recognize such a reading (except for kanji dictionaries)."
column5: "Rosy cheeks are incandescent, glowing red with heat."

column4: "If a person has retainers, then he can spend his life supinate (i.e. lying on his back doing nothing). (note: for the writing order think: SuPinate = Slave-Person)."
column5: Mr. Garrison gets Mr. Slave to supinate while he watches. (notice if you look at 臣 sideways it looks like a person bending over with a cock and balls.).

column4: A nephew is someone you can watch grow into a man over his lifetime.
column5: "Life, male: During a visit to your family, you meet your nephew. You find out that in his short life, your nephew already has collected a great many male things in his room, such as 'dirty' magazines, etc."

column4: "I enter a ballot to try to win a melon, but end up with a gourd."
column5: "With its protective hard rind, a gourd is a melon used to deposit ballots in during elections."

column4: "The two kings play their biwa, comparing each other's skill."
column5: "When choosing new instruments, Tenacious D compared the biwa to the harp (#1591)."

column4: When she's playing the lute between your two balls Japanese censors mosaic it out.
column5: "The lute is a good name for the thing between your TWO JEWELS, which is often behind a pixel MOSAIC on film."

column4: "Think of this as ""tuning fork"" (音叉). Then, touching a vibrating tuning fork against a crotch causes it to drip drops."
column5: "You are looking for a bathroom, but the path in front is forked and you don't know which way to go. Suddenly a drop begins to appear on your crotch over your pants..."

column4: Elton john takes off his birdhouse sunglasses as he winks and gives a rose to sharon.
column5: "You can't 瞬 wink (#817) if you're minus an eye, but you can still hand out a rose of Sharon to get attention from the ladies."

column4: "You see a white dove about to land in a paddyfield, and, believing that field to be under water, expect to hear a ""plop"". But the plop doesn't come, so you think to yourself, ""Ah, that must be a dry field""."
column5: A rice field turns white as shit (literally) it is such a dry field.

column4: 1) I hold a roll of quarters in my hand when I make a fist. 2) I hold a quarter in my hand as I prepare to play the Iron Fist Tournament: 鉄拳 （てっけん） at the arcade.
column5: "Quarter, hand: If you have a roll of quarters in your hand, your fist will deliver a much more effective punch."

column4: "Think of a vegetable patch owned by a perfectionist, where every group of crops is pent in and separated accordingly, and every single crop is dogtagged and earmarked."
column5: "My offspring is supposed to be weeding my vegetable patch, but he keeps running off to play. So I put an electric fence around the veggie patch to pent him in. Now he's hard at work in there!"

column4: "If water completely covers the floor, you will need a helping hand to clean it up."
column5: "Water is completely covering your floor, and no matter how fast you mop it up it makes no difference. In desperation you cry, ""Can someone give me a helping hand?""."

column4: Let crown + human legs = Miss World. Then the very tall Miss World won the title due to her translucent dress.
column5: A tall girl in a translucent mini skirt... Hell yes.

column4: The body part between Venom's legs can produce blood relatives.
column5: "I think Halpern's keyword ""progeny"" is a better fit for this kanji. Then: Progeny – a cocoon-like piece of flesh that drops out between two human legs."

column4: The zoo needed a transcription of the accident report involving the infant caught in the flood.
column5: "Imagine spending your whole summer learning two ancient arts - first, the art of speaking to animals at the zoo (this is a bunch of different languages - no small feat), and the art of writing your name in urine (you go see the Mannequin de Pis for this - just sitting there and observing for hours on end). Anyway, you decide to put these two together, and go to a zoo cage, and ask the animal to tell its story. You then open your fly and proceed to do a full transcription of what it is saying."

column4: Your body parts will become tall if you apply a special ointment.
column5: The tall Heisig swapped his hood for a crown before applying ointment on his body parts to make them smooth as silk (#1368).

column4: The ghost who went to the Big Dipper was a pioneer.
column5: "The Ghostbusters were pioneers, being the first people ever to capture a ghost in a measuring cup."

column4: "Voice, missile, incense: Before they were going to launch the missile, they were having a service to beg favor of the Gods. Then, when they lit the incense, a booming voice came out of nowhere: ""Hmmm... this smell is great, no, ambrosial. Really worthy of the Gods...""."
column5: "[+abaddon] An ambrosial voice, like a missile from the Gods, said: 'That incense is positively ambrosial'."

column4: "Tip: New primitive: Let Tarzan = generation + tree -- because Tarzan lives with several generations of his family at the top of a tree. (This combination appears five times: leaf (#228), butterfly (#521), chatter (#2158), secret agent (#2726), label (FRAME 2926)). Story: You notice Tarzan is wearing his shirt inside-out and explain to him that clothes are one-sided and that he can tell by looking at the label."
column5: "It is with mindless chatter (#2158) that one-sided labels are attached to good, honourable people."

column4: My sharp eye caught a glimpse of the confidential information before it went through the shredder.
column5: "As the taskmaster makes me get down on my knees to clean the floor with rags, my eye catches a glimpse of her panties."

column4: The maestro lives on top of a large hill so that he can play music at over ten decibels without anyone giving a damn.
column5: "Note to those who have not got this far in the book: This is the full kanji for the Pinnacle primitive (i.e. only the left-hand version of the primitive). The full kanji for the City Walls primitive is city walls (#2180). Beyonce went for an invigorating walk up a large hill on a summer's afternoon. Since the grass was so lush and cool, she took off her sandals and immediately stepped on a used hypodermic needle. 岐阜県　ぎふけん Gifu Prefecture."

column4: Tip: primitives given in the book are: blood + happiness. But should be: drop + eye (/net) + happiness. Story: As you squeeze the last drop out of your testicles you go cross-eyed with happiness.
column5: "Sometimes I teabag my friend, dropping my testicles on his eyes, because it brings me happiness."

column4: "Craft, assembly line: The sorceress was very good at her craft. She magicked an assembly line to produce all kinds of sorceress' merchandise. Shrewed businesswoman, I'd say."
column5: "When assembly lines first became popular, they were so quick at their craft that some swore they had to be the work of a sorceress."

column4: A taskmaster can be empathetic if she receives something.
column5: "The taskmaster was very empathetic when the tall kid explained how his dog had eaten his homework. Yeah, right. And if you believe that one ..."

column4: "(From Greek mythology). When Perseus goes to rescue Andromeda, he finds he's made a mistake. What looked from a distance like a beautiful maiden chained to a rock turns out to be a St. Bernard tangled up in some ivy. (Andromeda was chained up a bit further down on another beach)."
column5: Andromeda is a large constellation that represents the god of literature thought to inhabit Ivy League schools.

column4: "If a sheep had feathers, it could soar."
column5: Icarus' wings made him soar across the ocean (#549) without becoming wet.

column4: The revelation brought back by the dove left Noah beaming -- the flood waters were receding.
column5: The holy white dove surrounded by beaming light came down from the sky with a revelation to tell us.

column4: """tenebrous"" = ""dark"" or ""obscure."" In tenebrous nights, millet is found tied in slipknots, in crop circles."
column5: The tenebrous Slipknot forces their way into the millet of Iowa.

column4: "Run, cornucopia: The thief was bold, but stupid. He was running away with the cornucopia he just stole from the feudal lord. However, he was leaving an easy track to follow as the cornucopia was pouring out its riches. So, bold, but stupid."
column5: A marathon runner bold enough to race the Fantastic Four.

column4: This character would be the sign of the snake if the last stroke didn't stop short.
column5: Igor (イ)'s move to steal a snake's girl was to stop short. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lxGRE2wpjsY.

column4: The belt of thorns around a tree is doubled in a thornbush.
column5: "A thornbush so thorny, even its thorns have thorns. Note: A good example is gorse http://www.weeds.asn.au/gifs/line_art/gorse.gif."

column4: "Zombies love a good crowd, as they can take as many ears and crotches as they want."
column5: The crowd of zombies goes for the ears and crotches first. mmmmm.

column4: "Grow late, life: It had nearly grown too late to resucitate the half-drowned man, but a passer-by was able to breath life back into him, thus resucitating him."
column5: To breathe life into someone after it might have grown (too) late is to resuscitate them.

column4: Lazy guide to pruning: Grab a dagger and slash everything in front.
column5: "In front (drops), dagger: The gardener is pruning his roses. He closes up to the one in front of him until he can see the dewdrops on the petals. Then he gets out his dagger and prunes."

column4: "With the right upbringing, you might become somebody beautiful."
column5: "Guys don't care about what kind of upbringing the woman had, they just want somebody with a beautiful body."

column4: There are many fruits when they're plentiful.
column5: "When fruit is plentiful, it feeds many mouths. This could mean anything that is vast or abundant."

column4: "If you snore, your nose becomes dry. I try to remember the slightly different bottom part by wanting to hit the snoring nose with two hands but can't quite reach. KUN yomi reading いびき."
column5: Stay dry (from alcohol) and wear a nose plug if you tend to snore.

column4: Beings exit the spirit world through the altar when you cast a spell.
column5: "SPOILER: The trophy in the Triwizard Tournament was just for show, in reality Barty Crouch Jr. had cast a spell on the trophy so it would be a Portkey that would make anyone who touched it exit the school grounds and teleport to the graveyard where Voldemort was waiting."

column4: "If you mark each meter with a grain of rice, after 1,000 grains of rice you have measured out a kilometre."
column5: A kilometer is made of one thousand meters.

column4: A rin of a meter is a centimeter.
column5: "Centimeter is spelt the American way. As mantixen says, it is a rin of a meter."

column4: The portion of a meter the width of fur is a millimeter.
column5: RICE and cheap FUR are about 1 MILLIMETER thick.

column4: "Unsuccessful dieter's excuse: ""If I put anything in my mouth, I immediately put on a ton.""."
column5: A mouth that says things immediately without thinking gets into a ton of trouble.

column4: "Mouth, computer: The mouth on my navigation computer tells me it's only a mile left to my destination."
column5: A computer with a mouth could talk a mile a minute.

column4: "Water, computer: Some water leaked into my navigation computer and now it expresses all distances in nautical miles. Very annoying!!"
column5: A ri on water is about a nautical mile.

column4: "If you GLUE your MOUTH shut, you can't open it one INCH."
column5: To glue your mouth shut it only takes an inch of it.

column4: "Mouth, shakuhachi: The hookers mouth was huge and also she was very skilled in 'shakuhachi': she could hold up to one foot."
column5: Whenever my girlfriend puts a footlong in her mouth I want her to give me a shakuhachi.

column4: "This is a Brahman, a fully enlightened one. He's sitting in front of a grove of trees, legs open (looks like wind), just meditating. You run up to him asking him all sorts of crazy questions, and he looks at you and smiles. ""Brah, man, just chill, man. Braaaaah#."" Apparently he's a surfer brahman. You ask him the meaning of life, and he smiles, and waits...waits...waits...until a bit of wind blows by. He lets out a small fart in the wind, and nods knowingly at you."
column5: "Brahman who are mediocre don't get the sweet meditation spots on the beach. Instead, they have to settle for a grove of trees."

column4: "At the pinnacle of enlightenment, Shakyamuni Buddha had the ability to bend common household spoons."
column5: Shakyamuni Buddha sits in his house at the pinnacle.

column4: "[+megaqwerty] This is the Bodhisattva, who wants to help release the wicked from the painful cycle of life. Of course, the most vain and wicked are the pathetic lamers in the Pinnacle. He goes to register to stand at the station and hand out products. The registrar - ""Okay, buddy, what are you selling?"" ""Nothing,"" he says. ""I am giving out physical products to entice true enlightment."" ""Whatever, dude..."" He gets his license, and hands out flowers to anyone who will take them."
column5: "Flower, pinnacle, product: I didn't understand the terrorist: bodhisattva... body fatwa? Hmm.. just to be sure, I gave him the booby trap flower (a product of the Pinnacle). Later, I learned that bodhisattva is someone who postpones his or her own enlightenment to help others. Oops..."

column4: The flower shop has put a muzzle on Bo Derek and is selling her as a bo tree.
column5: "A wannabe buddhist buys a tree and tries to give it to Buddha as a gift, ""Yo Bo, 'sup, I got yo a tree!"" Buddha gracefully accepts the gift and gives him a flower in return to shut him up (muzzle him)."

column4: Babble is what comes out of Asian people's mouths until you learn their language.
column5: "The kanji has the meanings of ""mute"" (聾唖) and ""speechless"" (唖然), like ""dumb"" used to (""struck dumb"" etc). Asian mouth is mute in a way, because they don't babble so much as they do in some parts of the world."

column4: You wanna drive a Sanskrit ka? Just add it to the road.
column5: "Ford didn't know what to call their next car, and it was ready to be released. A quick-witted Indian employee thought to himself, ""why don't they just call it the 'car', so they can get this show on the road?"" He raised his hand at the meeting and said, ""I propose we call it the Ford Ka. No, not like 'car', the Sanskrit ka invokes a sense of reliability, safety, performance and beauty. Add to that the fact that nobody will forget its name, because it's homophonous with the actual product!"

column4: "If you arrive with two swords at the city walls, expect some interrogatives before they'll let you in."
column5: "Interrogation at the city walls: ""Any weapons, question mark."" ""Just a blade."" ""Why the two scratches on the blade, question mark."" ""To remind me that I cut off my other ear too, exclamation mark (exclamation (#2680)).""."

column4: "If you elbow a cow it's will moo. (or alternatively, a cow mooing, the sound being somewhat like ム)."
column5: "Turns out that raulir is correct, According to RTK2[2nd ed. Frame 41] this is the root of the katakana ム."

column4: "To cut down on カロries, the king adds a jeweled hairpin to his coffee rather than sugar."
column5: When the Jewish king added jewels to his jeweled hairpin he was lauded. When the Palestinian king put beads on his 琲 beaded hairpin (#2963) he was jailed.

column4: The king is in the jail cell and is trying to escape by picking the lock with his beaded hairpin.
