column5: "Every king wants to add a jewelled hairpin to their collection of crown jewels. No kings want beaded hairpins though, because they're uncool."

column4: It used to be that for a meeting [old] you'd meet for a day to get the small details pent in. Even then such meetings were still held under the Japanese cypress [old].
column5: "You wait as days pass, pent in a little wooden cage, until you are summoned for a meeting with the old Japanese Cypress in which she sets you free."

column4: "This is a picture of a horse cart (車) from which the reins (糸) go to the mouth (口) of the horse, in which is the bit."
column5: A bridle's bit was put in the mouth of the horse and connected by two threads back to the horse-drawn car.

column4: "The abyss [old] used to be the water you were pushed into if you lost in the arm wrestling match. (the primitive to the right screams two guys arm wrestling on a table, any one else see it?)."
column5: Be careful on the suspension bridge lest you fall into the water of the abyss [old].

column4: Mr T knows that the Roman Numeral for five is V.
column5: Yoda figured out what the V in V for Vendetta meant within the first 5 minutes. He ain't no fool.

column4: Mr T also knows that the Roman Numeral for ten is X.
column5: "Mr. T gives ten reasons he looks up to Malcolm X, then wonders out loud what happened to the other IX Malcolms."

column4: This is actually the old ten thousand yen bill in Japan - Jiminy Cricket surrounded by a wreath of flowers. It's pretty uncommon to see nowadays since it was only in print for a few days immediately after the war (MacArthur wanted a way to make sure that even the rich kept their atrocities in their consciences).
column5: Your flowers will not be safe if ten thousand [old] Jiminy Crickets come to town.

column4: "I see lots of 10,000 yen notes just lying on the road and think, ""Should I stop and pick them up?"" But then I realise they are old 10,000's (i.e. worthless) and decide I’ll just pass through."
column5: "I wonder if I can pass through this old road, it looks 10000 years old."

column4: Tough guys like to display there force on the road.
column5: An especially TOUGH form of discipline was used in old Japan. Criminals would be tied up or crucified on posts and put on DISPLAY and their blood would DROP onto the ROAD.

column4: "In old style street lamps, to light the fire you had to ascend them."
column5: Fire can ascend from the ground and hang in a lamp [old].

column4: "In the old days, instead of having a micro-computer sewn into the suit of the master spy, a whole computer was carried in the back of his cloak, although it was clearly obvious that he was a spy. ""What's that um.. enormous computer doing in the back your cloak?""."
column5: "Prior to donning a hat and cloak to protect his back, the evil cyborg simply kept a cloak to the side to protect his back [old]."

column4: "Parks in Japan are designed around water, rocks and trees. A park with flowers is considered to be an alternate park."
column5: In the old days parks had more flowers.

column4: "At an alternative shop you can buy strange items like metal dogtags from wars, active grenades, torture sets, etc."
column5: Understandable that the alternate shop is more successful than the regular 舗 shop (#1839): trendy metal motif instead of that dingy cottage look.

column4: "Mountain, bird: On the alternative island, birds could just breed beside the mountains instead of upon one. The hippies didn't do any harm."
column5: "The bird got tired of the mountain he lived on, so now he's flying away searching for an alternative island."

column4: The alternative summit is so steep that the mountain is above you rather than beside you. People usually just go with the regular summit.
column5: "Mountain, walking through the bushes: The hippies didn't want to climb the entire mountain and decided to go to the 'alternative summit' which involved walking through the bushes below the mountain."

column4: "Mountain, stern: Below the mountain, a stern owl was sitting on an old boulder. 'Don't go up there', it said. 'There's danger of old boulders rolling down'."
column5: A stern mountain ready to send [old] boulders down at climbers.

column4: A grove now grows on the soil of [old] plains.
column5: The old plains natives continue to inhabit the groves & work the soil. The lucky ones are helped by their daughters & sons who work the new 野 plains (#1596) on computers & know already beforehand to whom & what they owe their joy.

column4: "When the bureaucrat first moved to his [old] Bldg., people walking by under umbrellas would secretly stick their tongue out at him, wishing he hadn't retired from being a musical maestro."
column5: "In the old building there used to be no water fountains, so the bureaucrats would lick water off their umbrellas with their tongues. Thankfully, water fountains are now installed."

column4: "An ancient Japanese dragon, beautiful and terrifying. Here it is depicted standing on a piece of meat (its prey) and a description is written on the right margin. It is said to be like a snake that has three toes on its feet and can sometimes use its head as a flamethrower (kind of like a sling, but with fire instead of stones). (Note: The Japanese dragon has three toes, unlike other Asian dragons. Asian dragons generally don't breath fire, but Godzilla does, and it is supposed to be a dragon!)."
column5: "(insp by raulir) The ancient Japanese Dragon, now extinct, is depicted in a book of lore STANDING on a pile of freshly slaughtered MEAT. The column describes how the last Japanese Dragon was killed by a party of adventurers, who struck its SNAKE body simultaneously with a SLINGSHOT and THREE swords."

column4: "House, dragon [old]: The house of the old dragon was filled with art pieces: he was very active in patronage, i.e. supporting artists. (He had to do something with his hoard)."
column5: A Chinese dragon's house enjoys a lot of patronage from would-be disciples.

column4: A Chinese dragon flying overhead can cause deafness to your ears.
column5: When the old dragon roared into my ears I suffered from a little deafness.

column4: The old longing is a 欲 longing (#792) of the heart.
column5: "As you get old, you develop a longing for a new heart."

column4: "I drop two five cent pieces on the ground, and a span of old homeless men coming diving in my direction."
column5: "In olden times, the span of a day seemed different when it looked like it was going to rain."

column4: "I may have an old body, but I am somebody in this ward (in this ward I am somebody)."
column5: "An old body of somebody was found in Minato ku, killed by a 枢 hinge (#1697) gun in a 駆 drive (#1983)-by shooting. Note that this took place on the West side (i.e., left side, for placement of the non-ward primitive). It is on the East side that the 鴎 seagull (#2828) lives, plotting her 殴 assault (#1698) on 欧 Europe (#1699)."

column4: A long time ago the Monkey King was kept in prison under a mountain Point.
column5: "It's an old point to say that land developers don't always provide full disclosure. Brochures touting the 'New Point', an artificial hill atop the mountain, fail to mention the notorious prison on the Old Point just below."

column4: "Russia, an old country, has everyone pent-in and drinking vodka saying ""aaaaaaaaa"". See mantixen's story, a (#2091)."
column5: It used to be you were pent in by a certain country. Now we have global travel and dual citizenships.

column4: "[+brian44] is right - so I'll try using the right primitive as sewers. I've been using Ninja Turtles and stuff though, so I'll have to use this as a series of narrow, long, lead pipes that bring floods of water to the city. Here, someone has taken a lead sewer pipe and hit you in the part of your flesh that is most vulnerable to impact: your shin (after years of soccer/football, I can't think of the word shin without thinking of pain)."
column5: The body part that gets wet when you wade through the sewers (a crafted flood underneath the ground) is your shin (thanks brian44).

column4: The powerful stench coming from the sewers is formidable.
column5: The legendary barge (see 脛 shin (#2989)) owned by Cleopatra was a symbol of her formidable power.

column4: "Note: the spelling should be stationery (= paper, office supplies), not stationary (= not moving). The error is in the original book."
column5: The two fiestas communicated to each other on their respective floats by using bamboo stationery.

column4: "Old evil altar, sign of snake: In the ancient temple, they found and old evil altar with the sign of the snake imprinted on it. What evil could be enshrined within it???"
column5: An altar with the sign of the snake etched into it enshrines a serpent god.

column4: "Old evil altar, chihuahua with extra leg: They opened up the old evil altar in the ancient temple. Nothing inside. But suddenly, their chihuahua grew an extra leg, and started speaking in a strange language. Time for an exorcism, one would say."
column5: When grandma's chihuahua developed the extra leg we thought an exorcism in order. We did it on a very old altar. It was not successful.

column4: People with wooden legs are renowned for dithering over whether to decorate them with a drop of paint or not.
column5: "Make the story as you need, but 躊hesitate (#2996) and this kanji 躇dither (#2994) mean the same thing and are used as a unit exclusively..... 躊躇(ちゅうちょ)する= 躊躇う(ためらう)= hesitate, falter, waver. (Heisig RTK2 error: 躊躇 does not mean 'warning') My stupid suggestion for a story: Give flowers to your Peg-Legged love doll. If you diddle (I mean dither) her, maybe she will get a little wet, at least a drop worth."

column4: "A samurai wearing a broken crown crafted an inch-thick floor under which to hide with his mouth glued, giving him longevity as his enemies failed to find him."
column5: "This is an old samurai who's seen a lot of longevity. He has been sitting in the same spot, on his torn Burger King Crown, for ages. He's something of a local landmark, so when a construction site is set up around him, they simply put a ceiling over his head and build around him. A gum company puts him in their CM for Longevity Gum. In the CM, he eats a stick of gum and rambles something foreign (he's actually saying - why are you putting this glue in my mouth?)."

column4: I hesitate to have a wooden leg fitted as I'm not sure how it will affect my longevity.
column5: "The man suffering from gangrene hesitated a bit, but knew he'd have to choose the peg leg if he wanted longevity."

column4: People who read the glossary are mutually exclusive (exclude the top line of mutually (#757) ) from those who eat crowned fruit イ はりねずみ same kind 語彙.
column5: "I was having mutual difficulties in my relationship. She was always the one wearing the crown and I was the one picking the fruit. In order to fix the problem I checked the glossary for ""mutual difficulties"" but found nothing. I guess we're going to have to mutually end our relationship."

column4: "A bit of old food is stuck on one of my mandalas. What could it be? I scrape it off and taste it . . . Hmm, bean jam, I reckon."
column5: Steamed bean jam dumplings were invented as a form of Chinese take-out that could be eaten while meditating on a mandala (thanks dihutenosa).

column4: The mouth on the left eats a whole box full of goods and then starts to retch them out again.
column5: "In my grandmother's attic, I found a box of goods from WWII. I put some in my mouth and started to retch."

column4: "The snapping turtle is ordering lunch at a restaurant, ""I'll have the shredded old eel -- and make it snappy!"". (Picture the waiter putting old eels through the shredder before serving them)."
column5: (Note: Bottom 黽 means Green frog /industry. Check your Japanese dictionary.) Story - The Snapping turtle eats through green frogs like a shredder eats through paper.

column4: "It's a tall order, but we can complete it if things go smoothly."
column5: "Remember the Tall & Wide Receiver from receive (#308)? Things have gone pretty smoothly in his life. He's grown up, graduated, and now is a COMPLETE man, TALL and respected as his life and career go smoothly on to great things."

column4: Person-possession (i.e. slavery) cannot be condoned.
column5: Mr T doesn't condone possession of drugs.

column4: "If I could be a tree, I'd be a parasol tree to give others shade."
column5: "A parasol tree can be closed like a parasol. It is then shaped like the letter ""I"", i.e. an ""I-tree"" = 梧."

column4: "The Golden Rule: ""He who has the gold, makes the rules."" Those who lack gold must remain circumspect."
column5: "If you show a lot of gold when you yawn, then you need to be more circumspect because a criminal might yank your teeth out."

column4: "The slave, despite being thrown over a fire and getting horribly deformed, and getting bit by a full-grown snake so badly it left a permanent slit, managed to survive and tell the tale. You can't help but cheer for him."
column5: "Picture a deformed retainer with a sign of the snake tattoo working at a barbecue (fire) behind the bar in tv series ""Cheer(s)""."

column4: "If you lose your comb, there is no point just hoping it will turn up. You must carefully comb the whole house looking for it, and then you will find it."
column5: "First it was a mask, and then it became a comb."

column4: Congratulations. Now get into that AJATT!
column5: "Mandates are often decided by a show of hands, but in this case is finger-determined."
